webTitle: Blair's memo: We cannot avoid debate on Europe

fields.headline: Blair's memo: We cannot avoid debate on Europe
fields.standfirst:
The latest No 10 leak PM and Labour's polling pundit spell out their tactics and fears on selling the single currency to British voters

Special report: Labour in power
fields.trailText: This the full text of Tony Blair's memo, Standing up for Britain, written in December:
fields.body:
This the full text of Tony Blair's memo, Standing up for Britain, written in December:

a) We cannot avoid this debate on Europe. Either we expose the Tories' posturing for what it is: a defeat of our national interest in the name of our national interest; or we just look weak.

On the euro, we need to be firmer, more certain, clearer. The truth is the politics is overwhelmingly in favour: but the economics has to be right; and at present it is not. It would be far better to be open and up front about this.

b) Defence. We really cannot think we have any prospect of winning the "Standing up for Britain" argument if we appear to be anti-defence.

This is uncomfortable; for perfectly obvious reasons, in a clash of spending priorities, there are many other claims.

But again, there is no point in shying away from the truth. "Weak on defence" in the eighties was the reason why we were seen as unpatriotic.

c) Asylum and crime. These may appear unlinked to patriotism but they are: partly because they are toughness issues; partly because they reach deep into British instincts.

We don't need to be irresponsibly populist; but we do need to be seen to care; and to act.

d) I think that debt and development issues would be seen as advancing Britain. They bring us a huge international dividend and give us advantages with a whole range of countries with which otherwise we could have no real point of contact.

So "Standing up for Britain" is simple: it is about British power and influence. Everything we do in Europe should be about increasing it. Everything the Tories propose should be seen as weakening it. The idea of Britishness is a vital accompanying argument but it can't take the place of a brute argument about power and influence.

webTitle: Investor nervousness cuts iTouch value by half

fields.headline: Investor nervousness cuts iTouch value by half
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Tony O'Reilly's Independent News & Media was yesterday forced to cut the offer price of shares in its iTouch wireless internet business virtually by half.
fields.body:
Tony O'Reilly's Independent News & Media was yesterday forced to cut the offer price of shares in its iTouch wireless internet business virtually by half.

The company said it had encountered nervousness among potential investors after a series of disappointing flotations of hi-tech companies.

The shares, which had been priced at 100p to 130p valuing the business at up to £370m, have been set at 70p giving a capitalisation of £200m. Trading begins on Wednesday.

Ivan Fallon, iTouch chairman, said the company had suffered from the lack of any business on the market to compare itself against. The company is an internet portal offering content and services via mobile phones.

"In the end we had quite a robust institutional interest and we got a pretty realistic valuation," he said. The amount raised has been clawed back from £70m to about £49m as a result of the repricing, but this would not alter the business plan and would keep iTouch going for a couple of years. It operates in South Africa, Ireland, Britain, Australia, New Zealand and Israel.

fields.headline: UBS plans web share market
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: UBS Warburg has become the first global investment bank to sign up to a new service which aims to become a one stop on-line shop for private investors to buy into companies as they float on the stock market.
fields.body:
UBS Warburg has become the first global investment bank to sign up to a new service which aims to become a one stop on-line shop for private investors to buy into companies as they float on the stock market.

EO, the electronic share distribution platform, said users of its EO.net site would be able to take part in equity offerings being co-ordinated by UBS Warburg. The Swiss bank is also taking a 3% stake in EO.

Users will be able to buy shares in flotations such as that of EasyJet, the budget airline which plans an autumn listing. EO users were able to log on and buy shares in Carphone Warehouse before its recent flotation.

Chief executive John St John said EO aimed to strike more deals with global and local investment banks to build a "hypermarket" for private investors. "We will aggregate products to give investors a single port of call when they are looking to take part in new issues."

EO has a pan-European distribution agreement with GlobalNetFinancial, the US-owned financial information portal. Mr St John said investment banks were attracted by the prospect of being able to tap a broad base of private investors.

fields.headline: Factories on the brink
fields.standfirst:
CBI pleads for help as recession nears
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The premier employers' body yesterday urged the Bank of England to signal that cuts in interest rates are on the way after reporting that weaker orders, lower output and falling business confidence had pushed manufacturing to the brink of recession.
fields.body:
The premier employers' body yesterday urged the Bank of England to signal that cuts in interest rates are on the way after reporting that weaker orders, lower output and falling business confidence had pushed manufacturing to the brink of recession.

The Confederation of British Industry said that the continued strength of the pound was putting an intense squeeze on industry's profitability, forcing firms to cut investment and lay off staff.

Nick Reilly, chairman and managing director of Vauxhall motors and head of the CBI's economic affairs committee, said: "Manufacturing is faltering and risks slipping back into a downturn. UK companies have had no real respite from the strength of sterling against the euro, which has made it more difficult to compete abroad and at home."

With order books at their weakest for 18 months and cheap imports flooding the domestic market, Mr Reilly said manufacturers on the economic affairs committee had wanted the CBI to call for more aggressive rate-cutting action from the Bank. However, warnings from CBI members operating in the service sector that there was a potential inflationary threat from the tight labour market and from the government's boost to public spending had resulted in a more cautious approach being adopted.

"We urge the monetary policy committee to leave interest rates on hold next month and to give a signal that the next rates movement will be down", Mr Reilly said. "If the trends indicated by this survey continue to weaken, a quarter point cut would be the right medicine sooner rather than later." It was not only manufacturing that was suffering from the high pound, but tourism and agriculture also.

However, Ian Plenderleith, an executive director of the Bank and a member of the nine-strong MPC said yesterday that any weakening of sterling on the foreign ex changes might lead to an increase in the cost of borrowing. Speaking to the Aberdeen chamber of commerce, he said that the Bank was expecting the pound to fall and that while this would be "enormously helpful" to exporters, it might threaten the government's 2.5% inflation target.

"We also have to take into account the possibility further ahead that, if the exchange rate moves back to more realistic levels, as we expect, the boost that could bring to external demand could only be accommodated, without strain on the supply capacity of the economy as a whole, if domestic demand has moderated."

According to the CBI's quarterly industrial trends survey of almost 1,000 manufacturers, output from Britain's factories is falling at its fastest rate for a year as more and more firms source production more cheaply overseas.

Despite the pick-up in the world economy in recent months, industry has become markedly gloomier about its prospects. Higher prices for oil and other commodities has pushed up costs at a time when strong competition is putting pressure on companies to cut prices.

Mr Reilly said that the squeeze on margins was so tight that firms were discouraged from investing. "If firms continue to rein in their spending plans the future for manufacturng industry is rather bleak."

fields.headline: 14,000 HSBC staff benefit from windfalls
fields.standfirst:
Five years of saving could add up to £85,000
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: More than 14,000 HSBC staff, from branch staff to top management, stand to receive payouts of as much as £85,000 each next week when a save-as- you-earn scheme matures.
fields.body:
More than 14,000 HSBC staff, from branch staff to top management, stand to receive payouts of as much as £85,000 each next week when a save-as- you-earn scheme matures.

Employees in branches throughout the country will begin to receive letters on Tuesday detailing the gains they stand to make from a plan that they began contributing to five years ago.

Expiry of the share ownership scheme comes as HSBC's shares reached record highs after the bank finalised acquisition of CCF in France and several leading brokers rated the stock a buy ahead of its interim profit figures next week.

The biggest gains - £84,986 - stand to be made by those who were able to save the maximum £250 each month for the past five years.

But, the windfalls will still be sizable for employees who put £50 away each month, the average amount paid in by the 14,000 of HSBC's 40,000 British employees who participated. They stand to make £16,981.

The scheme began on August 1, 1995 and was struck at an HSBC share price of £5.41, the equivalent of £1.86 after last year's three-for-one split. HSBC's shares were trading at around £8.90 yesterday.

The scheme is one of many which the bank has run, and continues to run, in various guises since 1979.

The letters to be sent out next week will give employees the opportunity to take up the right to buy the shares at the £1.86 option price.

Participants will realise their profit by buying the shares and then selling them. Employees will be advised by the bank about how to complete the transactions without incurring capital gains tax.

An HSBC spokesman said: "Lots of commentators suggest that the rewards only ever go to senior executives. This scheme was available to every member of staff and designed to allow them to share in the success of the business."

Other companies which have run share schemes for staff and prompted feelings equivalent to a mini-lottery win include Asda which last year gave check-out assistants pay-outs worth an average of £900.

The scheme run by Asda, which is now part of the US supermarket chain Wal-Mart, has been described as the biggest employee share ownership plan of its kind in Britain and is typical of the workplace investments which Gordon Brown says companies should adopt.

HSBC, which also gave away free shares to 28,000 of its 140,000 workforce worldwide this year, is aiming to put 5% of its shares in the hands of its employees.

fields.headline: Traders trounce Eidos
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Eidos, the company behind cyber heroine Lara Croft, managed to catch the attention of a few traders yesterday.
fields.body:
Eidos, the company behind cyber heroine Lara Croft, managed to catch the attention of a few traders yesterday.

The computer games developer which is run by Charles Cornwall is in takeover discussions. It is widely believed the French company Infogrames is the suitor.

But there are worries in the City that the talks might have hit a snag, with followers gossiping about apparent problems at one of Eidos' many US associate companies.

The upshot of all this speculation is that no one is dreaming of the 700p-a-share offer that was being mooted a month ago. Yesterday the stock stood at 448.5p, up 12.75p on the day.

The fact that the Eidos tale was being taken so seriously was probably a reflection of the malaise affecting the wider market. Traders had to endure another soporific session that saw the FTSE 100 end down 3.6 points at 6,387.1, as a bunch of corporate results failed to provide any direction.

That said, there were some some interesting sideshows. The cable operator Telewest fell sharply for a fourth consecutive session - closing down 17p at 193p after a massive 63m shares changed hands. The shares have been in trouble since HSBC Securities downgraded the stock to "sell" as it emerged that Telewest had been forced to suspend marketing of its digital television service.

But clearly there is something more sinister going on. Yesterday saw the re-emergence of speculation that Telewest and rival NTL are facing hefty bills because of alleged shoddy laying of television cable. Whatever the merits of the tale, it was clear that broker Morgan Stanley was handling the sell orders.

Morgan Stanley was also involved in the decline of mortgage bank Alliance & Leicester. Its shares ended the day down 18.5p at 445.5p after the broker was said to have placed a line of 14m shares at a level well below Tuesday's closing price. Market players took the view that the placing meant the sector was still looking expensive and vulnerable to earnings downgrades. As a result the shares of Abbey National, off 28p at740p and Halifax, 31p easier at 53p, were marked down.

Marks & Spencer, up 3.5p to 224p, attracted some support in the wake of an analyst's presentation on Tuesday night. Dresdner Kleinwort Benson repeated its "buy" stance in the wake of the briefing, at which marketing director Alan McWalter gave a presentation on the customer insight unit. The ominous sounding unit is responsible for the new Marks & Spencer store formats.

Lower down, engineering stocks were back in focus. Weir Group advanced 8.5p to 187p amid speculation that the group has received a bid approach. Weir recently ousted its chief executive, Duncan Whyte, in a move that was widely interpreted as placing the for-sale sign over the company.

Turbo Genset motored up 110p to £21.40 as heavyweight broker Merrill Lynch gave it a seal of approval. The company, which has developed a unique alternator for the power generation industry, is - according to Merrill Lynch - poised to grow rapidly. It has set a target price of £27 for the stock, which came to the market earlier this month at £13.

Osmetech, a company that develops gas and odour sensors, attracted some interesting buying. The shares ended 1.75p higher at 24.25p on turnover of 4.7m. The trigger for the move was a positive note from broker Bell Lawrie White.

Now that the company has undertaken direct pre-submission dialogue with the FDA for two products, the broker reckons the stock is undervalued and it has set a short-term price target of 87p.

Rich clickings

Shares in Just2Clicks.com, the business-to-business marketplace creator, could be poised for a significant re-rating. Yesterday they closed at 68.5p, up 11p, after a disenchanted institution completed a sizeable sell order, but they are still some way below February's placing price.

The company has suffered as investors shunned internet-related stocks. But fans point out that Just2Clicks has about £45m in cash on its books (about 50p a share) and plans to spin off Tradezone, which develops and supplies e-commerce technology. A similar business was recently floated in the US for $1.3bn.

Just2Clicks B2B cement exchange is also proving a success. Last week one of Italy's largest cement companies bought a 37.5% stake in e-cement.com for £3m, leaving Just2Clicks with a 25% stake.

With downside limited by the healthy cash position, the stock looks an interesting short-term punt.

fields.headline: Bewitched by puppets
fields.trailText:
Faust Gate, London
***
fields.body:
Faust Gate, London
***

There is witchery in Notting Hill, where Georgia's Basement Theatre has taken up residence as part of the Gate's East Goes West season. This is a new take on Goethe's story: Faust's pact with the devil takes the form of a morphine-induced hallucination.

In a mental hospital an elderly man is deluded into thinking he is Faust. His doctors, whom he believes are the archangels Gabriel, Michael and Raphael, administer an injection and withdraw to watch the results. What follows is a version of Faust's pact with Mephisto, his love for and betrayal of Gretchen and the final suffering, that is played entirely by puppets. As the programme succinctly points out, this is not a puppet show but a show with puppets.

Doing things in miniature doesn't always ensure a magnification of Goethe's original, and undoubtedly something is lost because the script is not translated. But for all its inconsistencies, this is an enjoyable and occasionally breathtaking piece of theatre.

Superb manipulation combines with some devilishly imaginative puppets (Mephisto's ally, Marta, has the most startling embonpoint), and there is a really witty musical soundtrack that can be ironic, smoochily seductive in 50s crooning style or romantically soulful. Gretchen's final rejection of Faust and her acceptance of death is sufficiently stirring to make one wonder whether it is you or the puppets that are being manipulated.

What this show successfully highlights is the way the combined presence of manipulators (there are always several to each puppet here) with puppets can sometimes heighten theatrical emotion and distil it to a degree that would be impossible for a single human actor, however talented. The effect is intensified in this show by having the actors who play the doctors also providing the voices for the puppets. They do this through microphones but in full view of the audience, so that everything that happens on stage has a kind of double impact. It is like witnessing something both at a distance and in close-up simultaneously.

Until July 29. Box office: 020-7229 0706.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Oftel calls for media and telecoms super-regulator

fields.headline: Oftel calls for media and telecoms super-regulator
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Oftel, the telecoms watchdog, will today call for itself and the Independent Television Commission to be scrapped to make way for a single regulator covering the converging telecoms and media sectors.
fields.body:
Oftel, the telecoms watchdog, will today call for itself and the Independent Television Commission to be scrapped to make way for a single regulator covering the converging telecoms and media sectors.

David Edmonds, Oftel director general will also call for the BBC to be brought under the ambit of the proposed super regulator which has been dubbed Ofcom.

In his submission to the consultation on the forthcoming white paper for the communications industry, Mr Edmonds will propose that the government start anew rather than weld existing regulatory bodies together.

"This is very important for the future of Britain plc and we should start from scratch," he said yesterday. "The government needs to decide what it wants from regulation of the communications industry and then build an agency from there.

"But there is a very strong case to have economic and content regulation sitting side by side within the same organisation."

The white paper is being jointly prepared by the Department of Trade and industry and the Department of Culture, Media and Sport.

The aim is to address the collision of broadcasting and telecommunications being forced by digital technology. New legislation is expected to be passed by the next government.

The white paper will also address a broad range of issues such as cross media ownership rules and the role of public service broadcasters.

Mr Edmonds said he believed the BBC should be brought under the new regulator's auspices, replacing the existing structure which sees the corporation answerable only to its board of governors.

"I don't think you can have a coherent regulatory framework and exclude the BBC," he said. "That doesn't necessarily diminish the role of the gover nors who would be more like the board of a public company - it would even take some of the hassle out of the job because they would be subject to the same rules as everyone else."

There has been intense speculation about which of the clutch of current regulatory bodies would emerge as top watchdog in a combined Ofcom.

The Independent Television Commission was viewed as making a play for control with the recent appointment of Patrica Hodgson as chief executive. Ms Hodgson negotiated the inflation busting increase in the licence fee and clearly has the requisite contacts in government.

Mr Edmonds said his submission to the white paper was not about self protection. "I am not arguing our case - I am arguing what will be best for the industry," he said. Mr Edmonds also echoed the views of Ms Hodgson in advocating a "light touch" regulatory approach.

fields.headline: Darkness visible
fields.trailText: Michael J Sheehy Borderline, London ****
fields.body:
Michael J Sheehy Borderline, London ****

If Elvis, Nick Cave and Michael Stipe sired a composite offspring, Michael J Sheehy would be the result. He may not be pretty - his Stipean tendency toward male pattern baldness is too assertive - but he certainly is striking.

Working the same area of Southern gothic as Presley and Cave, he hints at weird and unpleasant things in an airless whisper that repels as much as it attracts. Like his antecedents, Sheehy has returned to the original source - the blues - and uses the old melancholy structures as a starting point for a trawl through guilt and regret.

Formerly singer with Dream City Film Club, London rockers better known for their high living than their punk banging, Sheehy has done an abrupt about-face since launching his solo career 10 months ago. Where his old band grabbed you by the lapels, he diffidently tugs at your sleeve; where they employed volume as a weapon, Sheehy achieves the same effect with long silences mid-song, during which he collects his evidently dark thoughts.

Discreetly backed by drums, violin and harmonica (the last played by a teenage boy awed by his elevation to the big time, even though the room is half full), he sang most of his debut album, Sweet Blue Gene. You could have drowned in his chocolatey voice, which was accompanied only by guitar in the opening Love Me, but by New Year's Eve, three songs in, he was all coiled aggression under that Anglo-Elvis drawl.

The most unsettling thing wasn't the pacing of the show, which insidiously unfolded from delicate beginnings until you were enclosed in a swamp of sound where violin and harmonica tried to break free of their moorings. It was the calm way Sheehy sang of disturbing things. Daddy is a Good Man, directed at the underaged subject of a custody battle, was a case in point. "Daddy is a good man, pay no mind to what Mummy said, or soon you'll be just like her, bitter and sick in the head," he crooned with disconcerting tranquillity, recalling those people who end up in newspapers above the caption, "Neighbours said he kept himself to himself".

By the time he gently announced: "This one's called The Black Hole's Waiting, Baby," you didn't know whether to worry about his emotional health or wallow in the darkness along with him, a willing accomplice. Parental guidance suggested.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Corner shops to aid online purchasers

fields.headline: Corner shops to aid online purchasers
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Special report: Are money men killing net?
fields.trailText: Local convenience stores are to be repositioned at the heart of the online shopping revolution if a nationwide pilot scheme proves successful.
fields.body:
Local convenience stores are to be repositioned at the heart of the online shopping revolution if a nationwide pilot scheme proves successful.

Internet shopping fulfilment specialist M-box said yesterday that convenience store chains including Spar, Londis, Costcutter and Bells Stores had agreed to act as pick-up points from where internet shoppers can receive parcels.

The trial service aims to solve the problem faced by customers who shop online but are at work when the goods can be delivered to their homes. M-box hopes the initiative will enable customers to pick up the goods from their local convenience shop on their way to or from work.

The firm already has a delivery agreement for smaller packages with Express Dairies. Domino's Pizza, with 205 stores in Britain and Ireland, has previously delivered computer games to peoples' homes on behalf of Gameplay.

Around 1,000 local shops will take part in the M-box trial. If the service is a success it will be rolled out to around 10,000 stores.

Geoff Web, chief executive of M-box, said stores would know in advance what was coming in and when it was arriving.

M-box sells its services to online retailers, allowing customers to receive their goods by parcel delivery, milkmen, convenience stores or motorbike express couriers.

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.standfirst:
Sainsbury

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: It has been a long time since J Sainsbury found itself at the top of the market leaderboard. But yesterday the country's second largest supermarket performed better than any other FTSE 100 company. Its shares finished the day up 29.75p at 315.25p.
fields.body:
It has been a long time since J Sainsbury found itself at the top of the market leaderboard. But yesterday the country's second largest supermarket performed better than any other FTSE 100 company. Its shares finished the day up 29.75p at 315.25p.

The reason for the euphoria was a 3.1% increase in like-for-like first-quarter sales from the core supermarket business. Not fantastic figures but considerably better than expected and certainly a marked improvement on the 0.6% growth produced in the same period of 1999.

Peter Davis, the big man from the Pru who was appointed chief executive at Sainsbury in May, is not yet dancing in the aisles.

When he arrived he predicted it would take three years to fully recover. But yesterday he told shareholders: "We are confident we can put Sainsbury up front again."

The City is beginning to believe him. Sara Carter, retail analyst at Merrill Lynch, said she was very encouraged and was keeping her "accumulate" rating on Sainsury shares. Her counterpart, Nick Seaward at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, said the performance was "significantly better than expected".

No one is is upgrading their £550m or so pre-tax profit forecasts yet. They say evidence of a sustained turnaround must be provided first.

Sainsbury shares have under-performed the supermarket sector by 25% in the past six months and competitive pressures in the shops show little sign of decreasing as Wal-Mart drives Asda forward through price cutting.

But the sales figures at Sainsbury are now in line with the rest of the sector instead of dragging behind. Total Sainsbury sales rose 9.2% and sales at the Homebase DIY chain were up 12.3%.

Is now the time to buy the Sainsbury share story along with the weekly shopping? Only if you are the kind of customer who likes taking a chance on a new product just because it's cheap.

fields.headline: Late-night elegance
fields.trailText:
Europa Galante/Biondi; BBC National Orchestra of Wales/OtakaRoyal Albert Hall, London
****/***
fields.body:
Europa Galante/Biondi; BBC National Orchestra of Wales/OtakaRoyal Albert Hall, London
****/***

Founded in 1989 by the nattily elegant violinist Fabio Biondi, Europa Galante has become one of the finest of period bands, best known for their exploration of the lesser known Italian byways of the 18th-century repertoire. They unearthed some glorious rarities for their prom.

Biondi himself was the soloist in Vivaldi's G Minor Violin Concerto, a disconcertingly austere work far removed in tone from the sensuousness that we usually associate with Vivaldi. Another surprise was Locatelli's Sinfonia Funèbre. Written on the death of his wife, it's a brooding expression of grief, filled with palpitating, snagging rhythms and chromatic sobs. Their playing throughout has a drive and a warmth of colour that knock spots off many of their rivals.

Bach is a recent addition to Europa Galante's repertoire and on this occasion they were joined by Ian Bostridge for two of his cantatas. Number 55, Ich armer Mensch, ich Sundenknecht, the only cantata written specifically for a tenor, is a vocally treacherous meditation on the nature of sin.

Bostridge's approach is inherently reflective rather than dramatic. You are occasionally aware of a lack of fullness in his tone, notably when the vocal line suddenly dips into the lower registers, though his singing in the stratospheres is glorious. He also opts for the rarely heard version for high voice of Cantata 82, Ich habe genug, pouring out a luxurious stream of steady, silvery tone and phrasing it exquisitely.

This was one of those late night proms which was infinitely more enjoyable than the evening's main event, a hit-and-miss affair from the BBC National Orchestra of Wales under Tadaaki Otaka. The high point was Shostakovich's Second Piano Concerto, played with delicate finesse by Boris Berezovsky. The low point was an extremely sluggish rendition of Mussorgsky's Pictures at an Exhibition.

In between came the world premiere of Tirluniau, an evocation of Celtic landscapes by the Welsh composer Rhian Samuel. Sustained chords broken by fragmentary phrases hint at expansive vistas. Whiffs of Scottish rhythms and an overlong, plangent melody depict a rocky outcrop on the coast of Skye.

The work culminates in an extensive scherzo, which owes slightly too much to the Sea Interludes from Britten's Peter Grimes, and depicts lights twinkling in Cardigan Bay. The sonorities, all low woodwind and strings, are predominantly dark, lit up by sudden brass flares and piccolo flashes. The audience response was enthusiastic - many, I suspect, enjoyed it much more than I did.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: German bank deal collapses
fields.standfirst:
Second failure for Dresdner
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Dresdner and Commerzbank yesterday called off merger talks - the second setback this year for attempts to restructure the German banking sector.
fields.body:
Dresdner and Commerzbank yesterday called off merger talks - the second setback this year for attempts to restructure the German banking sector.

The failure of Germany's third and fourth largest banks to line up a deal is particularly embarrassing for Dresdner Bank, following the collapse of its planned merger with Deutsche Bank in the spring.

Dresdner and Commerzbank each insisted yesterday that they had the strategies and resources to survive independently, but some ana -lysts believe that both could become the targets of takeover interest from banks outside Germany.

Both sides said the talks had been friendly and constructive but each bank acknowledged that it could not agree a deal which suited both.

Dresdner chief executive Bernd Fahrholz said that "there remained significant differences in valuation between the two sides".

A Commerzbank spokesman said that despite progress on a number of issues "we could not find a convincing perspective for the future for both of us."

The Dresdner team is understood to have pressed for ownership of a merged entity to be split around 60/40 between its own and Commerzbank shareholders, while Commerzbank wanted a deal based on an ownership division closer to 50/50.

However it is understood that a number of other factors stood in the way of a deal, including a wish by German insurer Allianz, which owns 22% of Dresdner, to play a leading role in the merged asset management business.

Allianz and CoBRa, an investment company which owns 17% of Commerzbank are likely to play important roles in determining the future of the two banks.

Yesterday CoBRa, which has clashed with Commerzbank management over the bank's strategy, said the failure of the talks put both banks in play. "People now have a unique opportunity to look at two major banks, both of which are not in a position to play a major European role on their own. This is a unique opportunity for a cross-border move."

Both banks disagreed. Commerzbank said that it would seek to strengthen its relations - short of a merger - with its European partners in Spain, Italy, France and Austria. Dresdner said it was unlikely his bank would reopen talks with Deutsche but, in principle, it remained open to talks with other banks.

webTitle: The best facetious boss scene: Mission Impossible 2

fields.headline: The best facetious boss scene: Mission Impossible 2
fields.trailText: Called back from his rock-climbing holiday, special agent Ethan Hunt (Tom Cruise) is briefed by his commanding officer Swanbeck (Anthony Hopkins). Explaining that the Russian scientist Nekhorovich is dead, and that rogue agent Ambrose is attempting to secure the deadly Chimera virus, Swanbeck turns the conversation around to professional thief Nyah Nordoff-Hall (Thandie Newton).
fields.body:
Called back from his rock-climbing holiday, special agent Ethan Hunt (Tom Cruise) is briefed by his commanding officer Swanbeck (Anthony Hopkins). Explaining that the Russian scientist Nekhorovich is dead, and that rogue agent Ambrose is attempting to secure the deadly Chimera virus, Swanbeck turns the conversation around to professional thief Nyah Nordoff-Hall (Thandie Newton).

"Miss Hall and Ambrose had a relationship, which he took very seriously," Swanbeck explains. "She walked away and he has wanted her back ever since. I believe that she is the surest and quickest way of finding him."

"And then what?"

"Make sure she gets him to confide in her, and report to you."

Hunt eyes Swanbeck suspiciously.

"You made it sound as if I was recruiting her for her skills as a thief."

"Well, then I misled you, or you made a wrong assumption. Either way, we are asking her to resume her prior relationship, not do anything she hasn't already done. Voluntarily, I might add."

Hunt scowls.

"No. She's got no training for this kind of thing."

"To be with a man and lie to him? She's a woman. She's got all the training she needs."

"I don't think I can get her to do it."

"You mean it will be difficult?"

"Very."

Swanbeck pauses, a mischievous smile playing around his lips.

"Well, this isn't Mission Difficult, Mr Hunt, it's Mission Impossible."

See also: The Hudsucker Proxy, Swimming With Sharks, Office Space

Don't see also: Working Girl

Pointless trivia: M:I2 director John Woo has also worked under the names Yusen Wu, Wu Hsiang-Fei and Yu-Sam Ng.

webTitle: Knight comes out of the dark

fields.headline: Knight comes out of the dark
fields.standfirst:
Dumped England opener leads from the front as Welshmen wobble out
Warwickshire 273-7
Glamorgan 192
Warwickshire win by 81 runs
fields.trailText:
Warwickshire 273-7
Glamorgan 192
Warwickshire win by 81 runs
fields.body:
If Nick Knight had not broken his finger in England's second Test victory at Lord's, Marcus Trescothick would still be a relatively unknown county cricketer. So the relish with which Knight celebrated a match-winning century for Warwickshire yesterday, 24 hours after losing his Test place to Mike Atherton's new left-handed opening partner, was understandable.

Knight was the least hapless of the England batsmen in the first Test against West Indies here little more than a month ago, top-scoring in each innings with 26 and 34. But he failed twice at Lord's and twice before that in the second Test against Zimbabwe, leaving the door ajar for Trescothick to barge through when he was called up to replace Knight in the one-day series.

Now Knight faces a prolonged period in county cricket - just as he did at the start of the summer before he was given an unexpected chance against Zimbabwe by Michael Vaughan's finger fracture. What goes around comes around.

If Knight continues to cope with his disappointment in this manner it will be good news for Warwickshire. He enjoyed a treble portion of early luck yesterday, with miscued hooks and sweeps falling safe and a difficult leg-side chance dropped by the Glamorgan wicketkeeper Adrian Shaw, but that was necessary after Warwickshire had been inserted in morning Midlands murk and slipped to 25 for two.

Knight also benefited from being allowed to play the anchor role, thanks to the positive batting of Dominic Ostler and Trevor Penney in partnerships of 123 in 25 overs for the third wicket and 71 in 11 for the fifth. He took 84 balls over his 50 but Ostler's came from only 71, the right-hander hurrying to 63 from 78 deliveries with seven boundaries - the latter feat especially impressive on yet another Edgbaston pudding. Along the way he became the fifth Warwickshire batsman to pass 1,000 runs in this competition, again showing that the members knew best when they protested at the club's reluctance to offer him a new contract last season.

Ostler and David Hemp were caught from consecutive Robert Croft deliveries - Hemp later following his golden duck by dropping Keith Newell on the first ball of Glamorgan's reply - to leave Warwickshire with work still to do at 148 for four.

Knight did it in the company of Penney, who ran brilliantly between the wickets for 42 from 36 balls before reaching his 11th one-day century from 134 balls with eight boundaries. He then added three fours in a single Darren Thomas over, ensuring that Glamorgan's target would be formidable rather than merely tough.

They made a bright start. After the early loss of Matthew Elliott, Newell and Steve James took the score to 76 for one at the first drinks break, having plundered 27 from Ed Giddins' first four overs and dealt comfortably with Allan Donald's opening burst.

But in the first over after the break James responded slowly to Newell's call and was neatly run out by Michael Powell. Two balls later Neil Smith turned one through the gate of Newell's ambitious drive, and four overs after that Adrian Dale was beaten by another big off-break and Keith Piper's smart leg-side stumping.

Glamorgan still had a chance while Matthew Maynard was gliding, but when he was bowled for 36 their noisy travelling supporters were left to concentrate on some beery hymns and arias; the players on the higher priority of bringing First Division championship cricket back to Wales.
fields.bodyText: If Nick Knight had not broken his finger in England's second Test victory at Lord's, Marcus Trescothick would still be a relatively unknown county cricketer. So the relish with which Knight celebrated a match-winning century for Warwickshire yesterday, 24 hours after losing his Test place to Mike Atherton's new left-handed opening partner, was understandable. Knight was the least hapless of the England batsmen in the first Test against West Indies here little more than a month ago, top-scoring in each innings with 26 and 34. But he failed twice at Lord's and twice before that in the second Test against Zimbabwe, leaving the door ajar for Trescothick to barge through when he was called up to replace Knight in the one-day series. Now Knight faces a prolonged period in county cricket - just as he did at the start of the summer before he was given an unexpected chance against Zimbabwe by Michael Vaughan's finger fracture. What goes around comes around. If Knight continues to cope with his disappointment in this manner it will be good news for Warwickshire. He enjoyed a treble portion of early luck yesterday, with miscued hooks and sweeps falling safe and a difficult leg-side chance dropped by the Glamorgan wicketkeeper Adrian Shaw, but that was necessary after Warwickshire had been inserted in morning Midlands murk and slipped to 25 for two. Knight also benefited from being allowed to play the anchor role, thanks to the positive batting of Dominic Ostler and Trevor Penney in partnerships of 123 in 25 overs for the third wicket and 71 in 11 for the fifth. He took 84 balls over his 50 but Ostler's came from only 71, the right-hander hurrying to 63 from 78 deliveries with seven boundaries - the latter feat especially impressive on yet another Edgbaston pudding. Along the way he became the fifth Warwickshire batsman to pass 1,000 runs in this competition, again showing that the members knew best when they protested at the club's reluctance to offer him a new contract last season. Ostler and David Hemp were caught from consecutive Robert Croft deliveries - Hemp later following his golden duck by dropping Keith Newell on the first ball of Glamorgan's reply - to leave Warwickshire with work still to do at 148 for four. Knight did it in the company of Penney, who ran brilliantly between the wickets for 42 from 36 balls before reaching his 11th one-day century from 134 balls with eight boundaries. He then added three fours in a single Darren Thomas over, ensuring that Glamorgan's target would be formidable rather than merely tough. They made a bright start. After the early loss of Matthew Elliott, Newell and Steve James took the score to 76 for one at the first drinks break, having plundered 27 from Ed Giddins' first four overs and dealt comfortably with Allan Donald's opening burst. But in the first over after the break James responded slowly to Newell's call and was neatly run out by Michael Powell. Two balls later Neil Smith turned one through the gate of Newell's ambitious drive, and four overs after that Adrian Dale was beaten by another big off-break and Keith Piper's smart leg-side stumping. fields.headline: West Indians thrash Yorkshire
fields.trailText: West Indies flexed their muscles for the third Test match at Old Trafford next week, completing a 10-wicket win over Yorkshire in a mere two days at Headingley.
fields.body:
West Indies flexed their muscles for the third Test match at Old Trafford next week, completing a 10-wicket win over Yorkshire in a mere two days at Headingley.

Although limited to a first-innings lead of 83, their bowlers, led by Nixon McLean, were in superb form on a responsive pitch. They bowled out the home side for 94 in 37 overs, leaving the tourists to make only 12 runs for victory.

They achieved this comfortably with Chris Gayle driving James Middlebrook over long-off for six before the winning run came.

The West Indians resumed on 83 for four and reached 209 all out thanks to contributions by Mahendra Nagamootoo, who top-scored with 40 from 74 balls, and Wayne Phillip.

Missed by David Byas in the slips before he had scored, Phillip went on to pull Leroy Weekes for six on his way to 38 from 103 balls, which also included five fours.

After an opening burst by Courtney Walsh that included the wicket of Simon Widdup caught in the slips from a lifter, McLean finished with five for 49 to take the man-of-the-match award.

Yorkshire slumped to 16 for four and at tea were facing a humiliating innings defeat on 30 for five.

But Byas held firm again, hitting four boundaries in an 83-minute stay before edging McLean to third slip with Yorkshire still 12 runs adrift.

Weekes, who had bowled superbly for Yorkshire to take six for 56, joined forces with Ian Fisher to put them ahead but Weekes was stumped off the leg-spinner Nagamootoo and Fisher lost his off stump to McLean.

 England have withdrawn their leading strike bowlers Andrew Caddick and Darren Gough from this week's round of championship matches ahead of the third Test. The pair are the only members of the 14 centrally contracted players to miss out.

 England face Bangladesh in the opening round of the International Cricket Council Knock-out 2000 tournament in Nairobi in October. The ICC used a seeding system based on performances in last year's World Cup. This meant England had to qualify for the right to meet South Africa in the quarter-finals. This year's tournament will feature the ICC's 10 full-member countries as well as the host nation Kenya, who have one-day international status.

webTitle: Mascarenhas hits pay dirt for Hampshire

fields.headline: Mascarenhas hits pay dirt for Hampshire
fields.standfirst:
Middlesex 127
Hampshire 128-3
Hampshire win by seven wickets
fields.trailText:
Middlesex 127
Hampshire 128-3
Hampshire win by seven wickets.
fields.body:
Rod Bransgrove enjoyed his best day of the season yesterday. The Hampshire businessman, whose money smoothed the way for the arrival of Shane Warne and Alan Mullally, finally saw some reward for his investment. One more win and Hampshire will be back in late August for their first one-day final since 1992.

This match may serve as sound preparation because it resembled the unappetising fare often served up by the final of this competition. The side winning the toss chose to field, the batting side were dismissed cheaply and the game was over by 4.35pm.

There were two glaring differences, however. The pitch did not start damp nor was the bowling unplayable. Middlesex, with a little persuasion from their opponents, simply rolled over.

Indeed, fielding first was not necessarily the obvious choice on a wicket expected to play slower and lower as the day progressed. It was just as well, then, that Hampshire's captain Robin Smith was swayed by the cloud cover.

But even he could not have expected Middlesex to bat so limply. Excuses for their performance are hard to find. The ball swung, but not prodigiously, and the pitch gave some assistance to the spinners. Yet Warne did not bowl until the 24th over, by which time Middlesex were 61 for six.

Instead they were undone by Dimitri Mascarenhas, the 22-year-old all-rounder, who claimed career-best one-day figures of four for 25. There was nothing sensational about his bowling but he stuck to the sound theory that bowling straight will bring its rewards.

He began by knocking out Mike Roseberry's leg stump in his third over and having David Alleyne caught at mid-off in his next. Seeing no reason to take him off his captain kept him going, and he was rewarded with the wickets of Mark Ramprakash and Justin Langer later in his spell.

Ramprakash has discovered some form since the last Test but here he was back to his tortured worst. He edged one boundary off Mascarenhas through the vacant first-slip area and survived two confident shouts for lbw, before the umpire Vanburn Holder ended it all when he was palpably struck in front. Holder took an age over his decision, as though analysing every possible argument in favour of helping out a man in distress, but the raised finger was as inevitable as the batsman's omission from the latest England squad.

Once Langer had played on in Mascarenhas's final over Middlesex scrambled to reach three figures, Keith Dutch making a resolute 26 and Richard Johnson thumping Warne for four boundaries in his 21.

Hampshire are one of the few sides for whom a target of 128 can seem daunting. But Giles White and John Stephen son dispelled any thoughts of embarrassment with a confident opening stand of 50, before Warne's promotion to No3 added some lustre to a match that had long lost its edge. Two boundaries through the off side off Angus Fraser were worthy of his Australian team-mate Mark Waugh.

In a season of struggle Warne has been one of Hampshire's few reliable performers, but he will miss next month's semi-final because he is required for a one-day series against South Africa. It is bad timing for Hampshire, just when their season is showing some unexpected promise.

webTitle: Bicknell ripe as the Surrey attack bears fruit

fields.headline: Bicknell ripe as the Surrey attack bears fruit
fields.standfirst: Not that fast but no slouch at taking wickets
fields.trailText: The current Surrey XI a match for Stuart Surridge's 1950s combo who won seven championships in a row? Martin Bicknell is not in the least deterred.
fields.body:
For sheer hubris it might rank with John Lennon's assertion that The Beatles were "bigger" than Jesus. The current Surrey XI a match for Stuart Surridge's 1950s combo - May, Barrington, Bedser, Laker, Lock et al - who won seven championships in a row? Martin Bicknell is not in the least deterred.

"Our attack compares very favourably," he says. "As spinners, Saqi [Saqlain Mushtaq] and Sals [Ian Salisbury] are the equal of Lock and Laker. The pace attacks are equal: Tudes [Alex Tudor] and I are on a par with Loader and Bedser. The batting is open to debate; ours may not always score enough runs."

To many, of course, further success for the county champions, with their perceived penchant for strut and swagger, is anathema. Yet since losing at Derby in early June, Adam Hollioake and his side have won 11 matches off the reel and top both the championship and the National League Second Division.

Victory beneath the gas holders today, moreover, will put them in the NatWest semi-finals, in line for a championship-trophy double hitherto achieved only by Middlesex (1977 and 1980), Nottinghamshire (1987) and Warwickshire (1995).

Fittingly Lancashire, their closest four-day pursuers and the unchallenged kings of the knockout, are their opponents. With Tudor expected to return after a side strain, the outcome will probably hinge on the scrap between Surrey's new-ball pair and Lancashire's openers, Mike Atherton and Sourav Ganguly. Of the quartet, Bicknell is in much the ripest form, fresh from last week's 16 for 119 against Leicestershire in Guild ford, the best return on English soil since Jim Laker nabbed his n-n-nineteen.

"I was very aware of the need to take wickets there," he reflects, pride mingling uneasily with self-effacement. "Tudes wasn't fit, Sals had a shoulder injury and so we were left with only four bowlers. There's a saying we have here: a team's only as strong as its weakest link. Our talent is well spread out, there's always someone coming off."

Which Bicknell, with more than 800 first-class victims under his belt, has done more often than anyone. Not that this totally compensates for that meagre ration of two Test caps, the worst such oversight for the best part of 70 years. Charlie Parker (3,278 victims, one Test) declined to bow and scrape; Bicknell's failing, as he sees it, lies in mph.

"To be honest, I'm a bit sick of talking about it. But it does disappoint me a bit. Of course it does. My stats stand above everyone else. I get good players out all the time. I've suffered because I was perceived as not being quick enough, and more recently because of my age. Somebody wrote the other day that it was a pity I was 31. But that puts me in the same age bracket as Caddick, Gough and Mullally."

Tudor makes no bones about it: "Bickers is the best new-ball bowler in the country." Not that Tudor lacks an axe worth grinding, having been overlooked for a board contract despite his five-wicket Test debut against Australia and his unbeaten 99 in last July's Edgbaston win over New Zealand. In South Africa, it seems, he got up noses: how keen was he to defy the pain barrier? More damagingly, he is seen as insufficiently nasty. Or, as Australians put it, not having enough "dog".

"He's got everything a fast bowler needs," counters Bicknell. "Pace, bounce, swing; sky's the limit. He's bowled as well this season as I've ever seen him and he's also got one of the best ranges of shots I've seen, which should give him an edge over his competitors."

webTitle: Ban for captain who blew up at racist sledging

fields.headline: Ban for captain who blew up at racist sledging
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel Cricket clubs throughout the country have just received a little brochure from Lord's, entitled Clean Bowl Racism. But in one league, "institutionalised racism" appears to be alive and kicking.
fields.body:
Cricket clubs throughout the country have just received a little brochure from Lord's, entitled Clean Bowl Racism. It contains 17 policies and 28 action plans which the England and Wales Cricket Board wants introduced to further racial equality in cricket.

Most of these suggestions are pious, unobjectionable and cheap (Policy 3 (iv): Season and match-day tickets to bear an anti-racism statement). Unfortunately, the one significant move the ECB could have made to encourage new spectators into cricket grounds - holding back a few tickets for sale on the day, Wimbledon-style - was rejected. As the brochure explains with unusual frankness, "commercial considerations" were considered more important.

None the less, the board has made its views clear (Policy 6: ECB to introduce and implement regulations to eliminate racist comments and actions, with appropriate penalties) - but not clear, apparently, to everyone.

The Bradford League is at the very heart of English cricket. Its geography also places it in one of cricket's most racially sensitive areas. But first and foremost it is the most traditional, the toughest and arguably the best league in Yorkshire.

Even in the second-team second division, the cricket is rarely of the jolly-good-show-and-let's-have-a- cucumber-sandwich variety. This goes particularly for matches between Idle II and Lightcliffe II. It was against this background that one of the Idle players last month allegedly called a Lightcliffe batsman both "a black bastard" and "a black cunt".

The batsman, Tony Bowry, originally from St Kitts, had been given not out after an appeal for caught behind. The Idle captain, Paul Wiseman, did not hear the remarks but admits that one of his team-mates has told him these words were used. The square-leg umpire, Tom Priestley, also apparently heard them, but chose to take no action. He said later he had dealt with the situation on the field.

All this incensed the Lightcliffe captain, Bob Furness, who afterwards told Priestley what he thought of him. "The red mist came down, I admit it," said Furness. "I might have said he was fucking useless, but I'm sticking my hand up to that, and I told him to get out of our dressing room."

Priestley reported Furness to the league, and he is now banned for a month for verbally abusing an official. Nothing else from this match was reported, and no one else has been punished. It is germane at this point to mention Furness's profession: he is a constable in the West Yorkshire police, a body which more than most has had to confront allegations of racism.

Furness is still incensed, and wrote to Wisden. The case is interesting because the Bradford League's attitudes have come under scrutiny before. No one suggests the league is inherently racist, and many of the teams are increasingly integrated. But there is a strong smack of that unthinking set of attitudes known as "institutionalised racism". Asian players have complained before that they find clubs unwelcoming, and there remains considerable mutual suspicion.

I have had the strong impression over the years that league officials are simply bored by the subject, and they appear not to have changed. Normally, the league puts out press releases announcing disciplinary findings; this time it did not. "We didn't consider it of much interest," said Graham Reid, the chairman.

"We do not condone any sledging or verbal abuse irrespective of racism," he said. "What was said on the field was not reported, so we can't take any action. The umpire said he never considered it a racial matter. Whatever was said doesn't justify what Mr Furness did."

Reid says the Bradford League has not yet formulated a policy on racial abuse as such; it has not received the ECB document, which has apparently gone to clubs and not leagues. However, incidents such as this go beyond cricketing policy and touch the borders of what might, under the last Criminal Justice Act, now be construed as a criminal offence.

Furness says the disciplinary panel asked: "Don't you think you're going over the top with this racism thing?"

"There's sledging and there's personal," he says, "and there's a line you don't go over. I'm 43 and I came up before a lot of white males, most of them old enough to be my father, all mates together. Do they want us to go on to the field and start arresting people, or is the league going to deal with it?"

Throughout Yorkshire cricket there are people working like crazy to build racial harmony, with considerable success. But I sense that there are still people in authority who have not yet got the message.

The Headingley Test, with its history of racial unpleasantness, is coming up next month. After that, they will be getting rid of the awful Western Terrace; perhaps they could also demolish the last of the attitudes it represents.

webTitle: Why plcs should give a Figo

fields.headline: Why plcs should give a Figo
fields.trailText: When it comes to the real business of buying players, Premiership plcs cannot compete with the likes of Real Madrid, Barcelona, Lazio, Internazionale and Parma. These are proper football clubs.
fields.body:
Transfer fees have been spiralling ever since Middlesbrough scandalised the nation by paying Sunderland £1,000 for Alf Common in 1905, so you may not give a Figo how many pesetas Real Madrid have just paid Barcelona in football's latest exotic transfer. But you should.

Tomorrow, after Luis Figo's world-record £37m move to Real, a delegation from Barcelona is expected to arrive in London to open negotiations for Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars. But it is not only Arsenal who will feel the backlash of the Figo deal.

British clubs, not even Manchester United, can dare to compete with the sort of money now being sloshed around on the continent. United's manager Alex Ferguson's idea of a big-money deal, it seems, is selling another squalid little chapter of his over-hyped book to reveal why he dropped David Beckham for the match against Leeds last February. United fans should have been told at the time, free of charge.

When it comes to the real business of buying players, however, United cannot compete with the likes of Real Madrid, Barcelona, Lazio, Internazionale and Parma. These, dare it be uttered, are proper football clubs.

They don't mind diving into hock for a special player, in the same way that most of us can be seduced beyond our means by the blandishments of a High Street shop window. British clubs, though, are run like businesses. They are not responsible to their supporters but, grimly, they are answerable to their bank managers and shareholders.

It is only two weeks ago that Argentine forward Hernan Crespo moved from Parma to Lazio for £36m, which beat the £31m that Internazionale paid Lazio for Christian Vieri last year. Twice in the past year Nicolas Anelka has been sold for fees surpassing £21m. In fact there have been more big-money moves in recent years than you could shake an offside flag at. Alan Shearer's switch from Blackburn to Newcastle for a British-record £15m four years ago is now only 15th in the table.

The football consultant Alex Fynn, who once worked for the Football Association and was a catalyst in setting up the Premiership, told me yesterday: "Clubs like Real and Barcelona are run something like the way cricket clubs are run here.

"The president is elected by the membership and his mandate is to bring in the best players, the best youth policy, the best coach and the best everything else. The sport, not the business, comes first. Lazio, just like Manchester United, have gone public. But the owner calls the shots and all the money goes on transfers.

"English clubs can attract top players at the moment not because they pay more but because of the good exchange rate and the tax situation. But the long-term view is not healthy. The leading clubs in other countries have a better infrastructure and the gap between the top two divisions is not so big. Here, everything is concentrated at the top."

Jason Zillwood, a senior manager with the financial advisers Deloitte & Touche, says: "To say Manchester United and one or two other clubs in Britain cannot compete is wrong, because they can. But generally they choose not to, because they have more responsibilities. They are plcs with stock-market valuations to consider. A lot more business acumen is involved but it is not the good old fans' game it once was."

Meanwhile, don't get too excited by the new Football Foundation to aid the game's grass roots, launched by the Premier League - which has pledged £90m over four years - the FA, Sport England and the Government.

The grass roots of British football appear to have been tended by some surly, overworked and underpaid gardener for generations. Other countries, meanwhile, have been utterly committed to the game's development. They're playing football; we're just playing catch-up.

fields.headline: Advocaat not taking Lithuanians lightly
fields.trailText: It is a mark of the strides that Rangers have made under their coach Dick Advocaat these past two years that the Dutchman was warning against complacency before tonight's Champions League qualifying tie against the Lithuanian champions Kaunas in Glasgow.
fields.body:
It is a mark of the strides that Rangers have made under their coach Dick Advocaat these past two years that the Dutchman was warning against complacency before tonight's Champions League qualifying tie against the Lithuanian champions Kaunas in Glasgow.

Advocaat, recalling Rangers' struggles in home cup ties against Stenhousemuir and Morton, warned his team to be on their mettle: "These games showed that it is possible for anything to happen if you don't produce your normal game.

"They [Kaunas] are a very physical team and they will try to intimidate us." Kaunas, who won their first championship last year, have both football and basketball sections, and the bulky appearance of most of their team suggests they would be equally at home shooting hoops as shooting at goal. They currently lie second to Zalgiris Vilnius in their summer championship.

"Normally we would win but you never know. If we can play our own game, keep possession and put the passes, I know that football-wise we are the best team, and Kaunas do seem to allow opponents to create chances."

With six summer signings, Advocaat has a squad of 31 but the Dutchmen Giovanni van Bronckhorst, Arthur Numan and Bert Konterman, along with the club captain Lorenzo Amoruso and Turkish midfielder Tugay are unavailable, as is the striker Michael Mols, sidelined since December.

fields.headline: Brazil coach faces D-day
fields.standfirst: Luxemburgo needs a World Cup win against Argentina tonight
fields.trailText: Brazil face Argentina tonight for the first time in a World Cup qualifier, in a match billed as a fight for survival for Brazil's embattled coach Wanderley Luxemburgo.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Brazil face Argentina tonight for the first time in a World Cup qualifier, in a match billed as a fight for survival for Brazil's embattled coach Wanderley Luxemburgo.

A run of poor results - culminating in an embarrassing 2-1 defeat in Paraguay last week - has left the four-times champions in fifth place in the single South American qualifying group behind Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay and Colombia with five games played by each.

If they finish in this position Brazil will be forced into an unappetising long-haul flight to meet the champions of Oceania in a two-leg play-off.

The pressure on Luxemburgo is all the more acute since Argentina have won all their group games, scoring twice as many as anyone else, and are favourites to defeat the hosts tonight in Sao Paulo. Mario Zagallo, Luxemburgo's predecessor, has led nationwide criticism of the team, saying they are "on a road to nowhere".

Echoing common sentiments that Luxemburgo has failed in two years to decide which players out of Brazil's vast pool he prefers, he said: "No one knows who is in the team. Only about four players are regulars. When you don't define anything you don't get a good team."

Last week's defeat was only the second time Brazil have lost in a World Cup qualifier, and came after a lacklustre 1-1 draw at home to Uruguay.

"Football can change a lot from one week to the next, but it will be very difficult for us to win tonight," added Zagallo, who won winners' medals as a player in 1958 and 1962, as a coach in 1970 and as assistant coach in 1994. He also coached the team that lost to France in the 1998 final.

"Anything can happen, and Brazilian football has to be respected even during its worst moments. But the way we are playing doesn't inspire confidence."

In the five qualifying games Luxemburgo has used 12 strikers, and none has yet scored. In total he has called up 38 players.

To resolve the crisis in attack it is thought he will push Rivaldo into the front line to partner Ronaldinho. Alex will take Rivaldo's place in central midfield.

Luxemburgo has also won few friends with his overly formal style - he wears suits and black leather gloves, making him look like more like a gangster than a Brazilian coach, most of whom prefer laidback sportswear - and by his perceived arrogance. He has clashed with almost all the team's stars.

Last week it was the turn of Cafu, the team captain and veteran of two World Cups. Cafu - who was sent off against Paraguay and is therefore suspended from the Argentina game - left the team hotel and was publicly reprimanded by Luxemburgo for deserting his team-mates.

In the slanging match that ensued Cafu contradicted Luxemburgo's account, and the spat threatens the right-wing-back's international future. In Cafu's absence his Roma team-mate Antonio Carlos will take the captain's armband.

As Brazil coach, Zagallo also went through periods when the team played badly, especially in the months leading up to the 1998 World Cup. "Everyone has to start some day in being the target of criticisms. But I was better prepared than Luxemburgo because I had a history of playing in World Cups.

"Luxemburgo has never really had harsh criticisms because he won championships with [his club sides]. He has to start learning now, and the only person who can pull himself out of the rut is himself."

The first time Brazil lost a World Cup qualifier was against Bolivia in 1993. Brazil went on to qualify and win the 1994 World Cup under the stewardship of Carlos Alberto Parreira. He said: "I've been through this pressure, and I know it's not easy. But the difference with me is that after we lost to Bolivia we beat Venezuela comprehensively. Luxemburgo has got the bad luck to be facing Argentina." He added: "The team hasn't found itself yet. They lack a chemistry, a unity. But it's a difficult job."

Tonight's match will have possibly the most expensive array of footballing talent on show in history. The combined value of the 22 players has been calculated at £280m - and it would be even more if Ronaldo and Batistuta were not ruled out with injuries.

Argentina - who had the world's most expensive player, Hernan Crespo, until his £36m fee was superseded by Luis Figo's move this week to Real Madrid - are worth £8m more on paper than Brazil.

Although Argentina and Brazil have never before met in the World Cup qualifying competition, they have South America's most hotly disputed rivalry. They have played each other 104 times and are level pegging with 37 wins each.

Brazil (probable): Dida; Evanilson, Antonio Carlos, Roque Junior, Roberto Carlos, Emerson, Vampeta, Ze Roberto, Alex, Ronaldinho, Rivaldo.

Argentina (probable): Bonano; Ayala, Sensini, Samuel, Zanetti, Simeone, Veron, Kily Gonzalez, Ortega, Claudio Lopez, Crespo.

South America

P-W-D-L-F-A Pts

Argentina 5 5 0 0 14 2 15

Uruguay 5 3 1 1 7 4 10

Paraguay 5 3 0 2 7 7 9

Colombia 5 2 2 1 6 4 8

Brazil 5 2 2 1 6 5 8

Ecuador 5 2 0 3 7 9 6

Peru 5 1 1 3 4 5 4

Chile 5 1 1 3 6 9 4

Bolivia 5 1 1 3 4 7 4

Venezuela 5 1 0 4 5 14 3

Brazil's results: Colombia 0 Brazil 0 / Brazil 3 Ecuador 2 / Peru 0 Brazil 1 / Brazil 1 Uruguay 1 / Paraguay 2 Brazil 1.

Tonight: Brazil v Argentina.

webTitle: Liverpool in £20m deal to pioneer internet coverage

fields.headline: Liverpool in £20m deal to pioneer internet coverage
fields.trailText: Liverpool yesterday became the first club to cash in on new technology when they signed a £20m deal with Granada for the right to show their matches on the internet.
fields.body:
Liverpool yesterday became the first club to cash in on new technology when they signed a £20m deal with Granada for the right to show their matches on the internet.

The money will be used by their manager Gérard Houllier to increase his summer spending spree and represents football's first internet coverage deal after Premier League clubs were given rights to show their matches via new technology this year.

Under the deal, Liverpool will allow delayed coverage of their matches on the internet as well as on Wap (wireless application protocol) mobile phones and through digitial television. In some cases matches will be screened on the internet less than 24 hours after they have taken place.

The internet deal will include full coverage, edited highlights and live audio commentary as well as an online betting service, online shopping for Liverpool merchandise and live auctions of memorabilia.

Although the service will be available in Britain within 18 months it is particularly aimed at Reds fans around the world.

A club spokesman said: "The deal means we have £20m in the bank account to fund the summer's transfer spending."

Houllier has spent £9m this summer on Nick Barmby and Bernard Diomède. Part of the new money from the deal with Granada, which owns 9.9% of Liverpool, will be used to improve facilities at the club's Melwood training ground.

Steve Morrison, Granada Media's chief executive, said: "I would not preclude trying to do something with other football clubs, but they would have to have the same range that Liverpool have."

The existing Liverpool website will be overhauled in the autumn. The club's chief executive Rick Parry said the new version, which will eventually use broadband technology offering sharp television images, would take four to five years to develop fully and that fans would pay either by subscription or pay-per-view. Those in the Far East will be able to hear match commentary in Mandarin and other Asian languages.

Parry said: "If we get this right, Liverpool FC Broadband could become more valuable than the club itself. It's a proper dot.com business that we could float on the stock market in years to come."

He added: "At Liverpool our supporters come first and that means keeping them up to date with the latest news about the club. This pioneering project will enable us to provide an innovative, entertaining and informative service for our supporters."

fields.headline: Casiraghi lashes out
fields.trailText: Pierluigi Casiraghi has launched an astonishing attack on Chelsea after a 10th operation on the knee he injured in November 1998.
fields.body:
Pierluigi Casiraghi has launched an astonishing attack on Chelsea after a 10th operation on the knee he injured in November 1998.

"I have had no help from England, either from club officials or medical staff," he said.

The former Italy striker, who had his latest operation in Bologna last week, continued: "Lots of my team-mates have phoned, as has Gianluca Vialli, but he is the manager and not an official of the club. Anything I have done since my injury, I have had to do alone.

"Sergio Cragnotti [Lazio's president] has sent me a lot of telegrams. He is a man of great class, unlike others I could mention."

But Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson hit back yesterday. "Our physios have been in Italy regularly monitoring his progress. He is still being paid his full wages.

"Our liaison officer, who deals with the affairs with our Italian players, has been in touch with him sometimes up to four times a week, to pass on our best wishes and concerns. I don't know what else we can do."

Casiraghi suffered knee-ligament damage in a clash with West Ham's goalkeeper Shaka Hislop and has not played since. But he remains confident he will recover. "I hope to make a return as soon as possible," said the 31-year-old.

"I've never given up. I have been battling with all my strength to leave this nightmare behind.

"I'm doing all I can to get better. I can already detect some improvements and, contrary to what some people have said, I have been walking normally for a year and a half."

Chelsea recently set a £4m insurance claim process rolling on the striker, who cost £5.4m from Lazio two years ago.

webTitle: Boro launch £10m bid for Barca's Dani

fields.headline: Boro launch £10m bid for Barca's Dani
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough are confident of concluding a club-record £10m move for the Barcelona striker Dani after opening talks with the Catalan club.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough are confident of concluding a club-record £10m move for the Barcelona striker Dani after opening talks with the Catalan club.

The Boro manager Bryan Robson returned to England yesterday after holding preliminary negotiations with the Barcelona hierarchy and is waiting to hear whether the 26-year-old will opt to remain at the Nou Camp as understudy to Patrick Kluivert or move to the Riverside.

Neil Lennon will almost certainly be a Celtic player by the weekend despite Leicester City making a final attempt today to keep him at Filbert Street.

The midfielder and his advisers will meet the Leicester chairman John Elsom and the club's new manager Peter Taylor this afternoon to reiterate his position after making it clear he wants the chance to be reunited with Martin O'Neill.

O'Neill has tabled a £6m bid for the Northern Ireland international and Lennon has gone on record as saying he would relish the opportunity to move north of the border.

Aston Villa have offered to match any bid from Celtic but Lennon will not entertain the possibility of moving across the midlands.

Taylor took his spending to more than £10m since succeeding O'Neill last month by completing the club-record £5m transfer of Ade Akinbiyi from Wolverhampton Wanderers yesterday.

Sunderland have agreed a deal worth about £3.5m to bring the Argentine defender Julio Arca to Wearside. The 19-year-old left-back, who has dual nationality, will sign a five-year contract once he has been issued with an Italian passport.

Arca, currently with Argentinos Juniors, has represented his country at Under-17 and Under-21 levels. "I am very happy to be coming to Sunderland," he said. "I am looking forward to training with the team and I hope that I can win a place in the side and that we can win some trophies."

The Sunderland manager Peter Reid said: "I spotted Arca playing for Argentina Under-21s against England last season. He's an exceptional player."

The Aston Villa manager John Gregory yesterday confirmed he is "finished" with Benito Carbone. Speaking before Villa's Intertoto Cup semi-final first leg against Celta Vigo in Spain tonight, he revealed that Monday's ultimatum for the Italian striker to return had been met with silence. "We've not heard from him so as far as I'm concerned the matter is finished," he said.

Uefa said yesterday it is investigating claims that a Romanian club tried to offer prostitutes to officials in charge of an Intertoto Cup match between Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt and Austria Vienna in Romania on July 15.
