fields.headline: Slow progress
fields.standfirst: Nicola Hill on belated guidelines for local partnerships
fields.trailText: Nicola Hill on belated guidelines for local partnerships
fields.body:
Tomorrow the government will launch guidelines to improve relations between local statutory bodies and voluntary agencies. The framework will set out how to establish a local "compact", or agreed way of working, and it represents a development of the national compact between government and the voluntary sector, launched in 1998.

Adam Gaines, director of public affairs at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO), says that as 70% of voluntary activity takes place at a local level, the guidelines will be a way of putting local partnerships on a formal footing. Hilary Armstrong, local government minister, asserts: "Local compacts will help create the conditions for healthy partnerships between local government and the voluntary and community sectors, based on shared values and mutual respect."

But critics say the guidelines are absurdly late, as many local voluntary agencies have already developed compacts. Carole Howells, director of Newcastle-upon-Tyne Council for Voluntary Services (CVS) says: "Any CVS worth its salt has done this already; the guidelines would have been helpful a year ago."

The guidelines could well have proved useful in Newcastle's case, as they will stress the importance of involving local councillors throughout the compact process. Newcastle CVS wrote its compact in consultation only with the voluntary and community sector, and then passed it to the local authority. It is still waiting for the authority to sign up to it.

Howells claims it is not easy to reach agreement within the voluntary and community sector and argues: "It is best to get your side to agree before going to the other side." Paul Barasi, compact development officer at the NCVO, says compacts are all about building relationships. "We know how much time one-to-one relationships take to establish, so those between a number of organisations are bound to be more complicated."

Barasi explains that it has taken a year for the guidelines to be published because of extensive consultation. "This is the first time we have had a joint steering group of this nature to produce something which enables local people to take things forward," he says.

In keeping with the theme of relationships, the guidelines are being published jointly by the voluntary and community sector's working group on government relations and the Local Government Association. Carol Clinton, policy officer at the association, says the document was circulated to local authorities for comment and has been refined as a result. It should now be a useful tool to review compacts that are already in train. "Having a compact is not about having a document which sits on a shelf; it is about an ongoing and developing relationship."

Barasi is particularly encouraged by the participation of local government in drawing up the detail of the guidelines. He refers to section 3.22 which says that when making funding decisions, government departments may take into account whether there is an effective local compact. "This could result in a colossal shift in goodies to the sector," he claims.

Appendix 1 of the document sets out the basic elements of a compact, including a government undertaking to give three months' notice of funding decisions and allowing 12 weeks for consultation. And under a section entitled "partnerships and joint working", the document states: "The voluntary and community sector is now seen as local government's key partner in an era where partnership is increasingly becoming the working pattern for public authorities."

However the section goes on to acknowledge: "Within local government, it is now generally felt that a real shift in culture is needed for local authorities to understand and accept the voluntary and community sector's role."

Lis Pritchard, director of the National Association of Councils for Voluntary Service, says the next year will be a telling time for compacts. "Compacts may say the right things, but what will happen if one side doesn't comply?" She claims this is an issue at both national and local level. "So far the experience has been mixed, there is varied awareness of compacts and in some areas they haven't heard of them."

Hilary Russell, deputy director of the European Institute for Urban Affairs at Liverpool's John Moores University, was on the Deakin commission into the future of the voluntary sector in 1996, which first floated the concept of compacts. She says the idea reflects the shifting ground in society in the past 20 years. "There has been a redrawing of boundaries between the state, market place and third sector. Hopefully local compacts will boost awareness of the contribution of the voluntary sector to the economy."

However, there are dilemmas. Russell says: "As opportunities for funding and contracting with the public sector are growing, we don't want to see the voluntary sector becoming so colonised that it loses its cutting edge and capacity to criticise."

 The Local Compact Guidelines will be launched tomorrow by the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions. Single copies can be obtained free from NCVO's helpdesk: 0800 279 8798

webTitle: When the talking has to stop

fields.headline: When the talking has to stop
fields.standfirst: William Wells on how to implement the NHS plan successfully
fields.trailText: William Wells on how to implement the NHS plan successfully.
fields.body:
Production of the national plan has spawned record air time and column inches on the problems of the NHS. This is to be applauded - provided something happens on the ground when the talking stops.

Nobody should underestimate the huge pressure under which the NHS has been operating over the past few years, but - rightly - the government is in a hurry to see positive progress on the changes it is introducing. However, there are already worrying signs of initiative fatigue in management and the professions.

To respond to this, and achieve early progress, ministers should challenge the NHS to implement the proposals to an agreed timetable, with vigorous monitoring arrangements, but must resist the temptation of further initiatives. Apart from anything else, even more changes would give management the perfect excuse not to meet the prescribed timetable.

Commitment on the part of the medical profession is also vital. Its image has been seriously tarnished by the large number of high-profile negligence cases coming to the surface and by concerns over self-regulation by the General Medical Council. However, it must be emphasised that these are cases from the past and that considerable change has taken place over recent years.

It is true that there has been a conspiracy of silence among doctors, and that GMC regulation has been slow, cumbersome and not as effective as many would like. But it is important that the profession is given time to demonstrate that it can put its own house in order. The GMC has changed out of all recognition over the last few years and is out to consultation on wholesale changes to the regulatory system.

Both the profession and the GMC must be held to account for timely delivery of a modern system of regulation which includes appraisal, revalidation and a rapid way of determining concerns over a doctor's performance. However, its implementation by the profession is inextricably bound into the NHS's ability to enable clinical teams in both primary and secondary care to practise in accordance with the principles of quality assurance and management. For them to do this, clinicians' contracts of employment have to be overhauled and, among other things, tied into the process of appraisal, revalidation and registration.

One of the many exciting and encouraging aspects of preparation of the national plan has been the involvement of so many stakeholders. Following its publication, the government must find a way of continuing to tap into this huge resource of knowledge and innovation so that, during implementation, it can be used to test and adapt the plan as it evolves - perhaps through regional modernisation boards and local staff councils.

The public has been more involved in preparation of the plan than ever before and, despite inevitable criticisms of some of the process, the approach has been a success. It is important that, during the course of the plan's implementation, the public's involvement is maintained and the government introduces methods by which views can be obtained at regular intervals. Widespread introduction of "patient panels" would be one way of achieving this aim.

Finally, people's view of the NHS, and the success of the national plan, will be coloured by the way they are treated as individuals during any particular episode of care. Far too often, the attitude of NHS staff at all levels has been patronising and paternalistic - borne out of the fact that the NHS is in practice a state monopoly. The government needs to set aside significant resources to provide intensive training of staff so they understand that for the NHS to survive, patients must be treated as valued customers during the whole of their treatment.

 Sir William Wells chairs the south-east region of the NHS.

webTitle: Happy hols, and give us all a break

fields.headline: Happy hols, and give us all a break
fields.standfirst: Summer recess lasts until October. But don't grumble
fields.trailText: Summer recess lasts until October. But don't grumble
fields.body:
The current parliamentary term ends this Friday. MPs will be allowed to bring in games for the last day, and will be dropped off at the gate with all sorts of cards and presents for Mrs Speaker. Then they'll fly off for a few weeks lying in the sun to get away from all those months of lying in the Sun. Gordon Brown has been down to WH Smiths to choose his summer reads. There's nothing better than stretching out on the beach with a copy of Whither Global Economics? Tony Blair is constantly setting himself tougher targets, so this summer he'll be fathering triplets and rescuing an entire team of drowning synchronised swimmers. John Prescott will make do with a week at Blackpool but will be the only person at the funfair to insist on two Dodgem cars. William Hague and Ffion will spend the summer on their own and far away from the crowds as they undertake another Meet the People Tour of Britain. And for Conservative shadow ministers such as Gary Streeter and Edward Garnier, it will be a relief just to enjoy a few weeks out of the limelight. But then it's straight back to work as MPs return to Westminster at the end of the summer on er, October 23.

It has been suggested that when the rest of us take a fortnight off, 14 weeks might be considered a little excessive. Obviously our politicians won't spend all their holidays staying in luxury hotels and drinking too much there are the party conferences to fit in as well. But it's hard to sympathise with successive governments complaining that they cannot bring in all the measures they would like due to a lack of parliamentary time, when one quarter of the year is used up with the summer holidays alone. The government remind me of those students who used to get up at two o'clock in the afternoon and say: "When am I supposed to fit in writing this essay?"

The length of the summer recess is just one of the ridiculous anachronisms that alienates ordinary voters and increases cynicism and antipathy towards those who govern over us. Like the anti-social hours and the myriad obscure parliamentary conventions, it gives the impression that our politicians are from a different planet to the rest of us, which is unfair on the MPs, John Redwood excepted.

Many of these traditions go back hundreds of years their origins lost in the mists of time, like Edward Heath's grudges. But that doesn't make them sacrosanct and so when this government was elected it established a " modernisation committee " to try to examine ways of bringing things forward a couple of centuries to somewhere in the mid-1800s. Sadly parliamentary convention dictated that the modernisation committee was only allowed to meet once a year on Michaelmas Eve, and then only if the member for Old Sarum was wearing a hat. But they have managed to put an end to late-night sitting despite fierce Tory opposition for some reason MPs like Ann Widdecombe and Michael Howard prefer to come out at night. And experimental morning sittings have now been tried and deemed a great success the chamber was just as empty before lunch as it usually is the rest to the time.

Another improvement has been Prime Minister's Questions. For no better reason than tradition members could only put the PM on the spot with a supplementary question, so they always had to precede their interrogation with an enquiry about his engagements that day. This convention was done away with to prevent Tony Blair finally losing patience in the way that any ordinary member of the pubic would. "Are you completely deaf or what? You are the sixth bloody person in a row to ask me my engagements for the day why don't you try listening for a change, you stupid, cloth-eared bastard?"

But the problem is that the modernisation of parliament has only been nibbling at the edges. Instead of coming back in late October, the MPs should never come back at all. In place of a parliament in Westminster, the MPs should meet in cyberspace we should have a virtual House of Commons to represent our virtual democracy. Like a video conference call, debates could be carried out without MPs ever having to leave their constituencies. It would be the internet equivalent of a late-night radio phone in, though the quality of debates would probably not be quite that liberal and sophisticated.

The day that we understand everything that is being said will be the day that we realise that the policies don't make any sense either. So nod and smile when politicians say that parliament has to close for three months. The truth is we allow our politicians to have such long holidays for the same reason that we put our senile old relatives into homes. It's not for their benefit, it's just to give the rest of us a break.

fields.headline: Keep a clear head
fields.standfirst: If you have any doubt about your A-level grades, writes Donald MacLeod, it's worth planning now to ensure clearing doesn't take you by surprise
fields.trailText: Clearing is not is not an experience anyone actually wants to go through - but it isnt as bad as some would have you believe.
fields.body:
Clearing is not is not an experience anyone actually wants to go through - but it isnt as bad as some would have you believe.

As the stories from clearing survivors make clear, it is possible to emerge at the end with a place on a suitable and enjoyable degree course - even if your nerves and those of your nearest and dearest have been frayed in the process. Every bit of planning and research helps, so if you are at all doubtful about your A-level grades, it is worth considering some alternatives and doing your homework on other types of courses or other universities and colleges.

There is a higher drop-out rate among students who enter university or college via clearing than among those who get their first or second choice. The Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (Ucas) is convinced that this is because students do not find out enough about the course before they embark on it, or discover they hate the place when they get there. A visit is probably essential. If you have already decided you want to study in a big city, there is no point in plumping for a remore rural campus just because they are prepared to offer you a place.

For the past three years, the number of applicants going through clearing has been falling steadily - from 54,401 in 1997 to 50,650 in 1998 and 48,239 last year - although you wouldnt guess it from the amount of attention it gets in the press and television. Last year this was partly accounted for by an increase in late registrations in the wake of controversy over tuition fees; mature students in particular seem to have waited to see what their financial position would be before applying. A rising number of people apply very late and direct to one college or university, rather than going through the year-long applications process.

This year neither Ucas nor anyone else knows how many will be involved. But it is a fair bet that the pace will be more frenetic than ever, with more students hitting the phones on the first morning (August 17). As clearing survivor Aftab Aslam says: The biggest hurdle everybody faces is the engaged tone."

Last year the Ucas website recorded hundreds of hits from midnight onwards on results day. Some universities claim the main business of clearing is over in a couple of days. Does this mean that all the best courses will be snapped up by the first weekend after the A-level results, and that if you havent secured a place straight away you might as well give up? Emphatically, no: a lot of informal offers are made at this stage.

Take this example. Student rings university A.

Would you take me to study X with my grades?

Yes, says the admissions tutor. Student rings university B, college C - possibly 10 or a dozen institutions to find the best offer. The upshot is that days and weeks pass before the true situation becomes clear.

If you have missed your grades and find yourself in clearing, Ucas says you should start with your first or alternative choice: they may well take you anyway. After that, start ringing round - and if you already have a shortlist, that is going to make life easier.

Official advice from Ucas

webTitle: Hillsborough: The verdict they waited 11 years to hear

fields.headline: The verdict they waited 11 years to hear
fields.standfirst:
The years of inquiries, inquests and trials are at an end for the families of the Hillsborough victims and the men accused of being responsible for two of their deaths. David Ward and Martin Wainwright report
More about the Hillsborough disaster
fields.trailText: The years of inquiries, inquests and trials are at an end for the families of the Hillsborough victims and the men accused of being responsible for two of their deaths. David Ward and Martin Wainwright report
fields.body:
Every day for six weeks, families of the 96 victims of the Hillsborough disaster packed the public gallery of court number five at Leeds crown court.

Some came by bus from Liverpool; some stayed in Leeds; all of them wanted verdicts which, 11 years after that horrific afternoon in Sheffield in April 1989, which would suggest that someone was to blame.

They didn't get them. Retired superintendent Bernard Murray, from Pontefract, South Yorkshire, was cleared of the manslaughters of John Anderson and James Aspinall, on Friday. On Monday Mr Justice Hooper discharged the jury when it failed to reach a verdict on retired chief superintendent David Duckenfield, of Torquay, Devon, the match commander on the day, who also faced two manslaughter charges.

During the trial, the families heard the familiar arguments about what happened during what the prosecution described as "eight calamitous minutes on a wonderful sunny spring day" when Liverpool were due to play Nottingham Forest in an FA cup semi-final.

The families had heard those events described many times before: during Lord Taylor's inquiry, which reported in 1990, and again during the inquest in 1991: it lasted 80 days and was the longest in British legal history.

On Tuesday July 18, after hearing 20 days of evidence, the jury of four women and eight men retired to consider their verdicts and the families could do nothing but wait. The strain was obvious on their faces. When a reporter said to one woman: "This wait must be agony for you", she replied sadly, "I've been waiting eleven years, love.''

On Thursday afternoon, when the jury had pondered for 16hrs 14mins the judge told them he would accept a majority verdict. The next day, after five more hours of thinking, they indicated that they had a verdict and the judge told the families that he would not tolerate any display of emotion, which he would interpret as contempt.

So the not guilty verdicts against Mr Murray were heard in total silence, although some tears were shed as the families filed out of court. Mr Murray covered his face with his hands and seemed hugely relieved.

That same afternoon the foreman suggested that the jury might be able to reach a verdict on Mr Duckenfield on Monday. In the end, they could not and the trial ended. The families went back home along the M62 without the result they had desperately hoped for.

On Tuesday the families met and decided that they wanted to go ahead and seek a retrial. But it was not to be. Yesterday Mr Justice Hooper ruled that Mr Duckenfield should not face a new trial.

fields.headline: Punishment, Possibilities and Purgatory
fields.trailText: SWEET (AND SOUR) FA
fields.body:
SWEET (AND SOUR) FA

The FA's disciplinary department doesn't meet all that often. And even when it does it's often more hassle than it's worth, with those members wearing sensory deprivation suits getting lost around Lancaster Gate, and others being refused entrance to the meeting by their dominatrix until they eat some raw chicken. However there's nothing that quite brings the committee together like a new set of stringent punishment guidelines, and so it has proved again today.

From the beginning of the new season, anyone who manhandles a referee will receive at least, that's at least, a 12 match suspension. If they do it again, they'll be banned for a year. Any Premiership club involved in a mass confrontation, whether with officials or the opposition, faces a fine of £250,000. Any club with six bookings or more in a game faces a fine of £25,000 (both sets of fines will be scaled down for lower leagues). All sneaky offences will be liable to be punished by video evidence, to be monitored by a new advisory panel. And finally, anyone who flobs during a match is liable to be flogged.

It may seem harsh to you, but it sure tastes good to the FA's new chief executive, Adam Crozier. "The new disciplinary system provides the clarity, consistency and transparency that everyone in the game demands," he rejoiced this afternoon. "It is designed to be hard but fair in the way that it treats every player, club and manager in the same way. We all hope that it contributes to improving standards of behaviour throughout the game." So does the Fiver, and we're sure the boys and girls in discipline will agree. If they can hear anything with their head up to their neck in boiling bitumen that is.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

FOLLOW THAT FERG!

Struggling to keep up with the latest whinings of the Imperial Lord Ferg? Don't worry, you're not the only one, and to help you keep up to date here's the Fiver's daily cut-out and keep guide.

No. 1: Arsene Wenger "Arsene Wenger disappoints me when he is reluctant to give Manchester United credit for what we have achieved and I don't think his carping has made a good impression on the other Premiership managers. I suppose I will just have to accept that, between Old Trafford and Highbury, appreciation is pretty much a one-way street."

No.2: Ken Bates

"Has any chairman since Mao had more faith in his own opinions than Ken Bates? If laying down the law was an Olympic sport the Chelsea chief would be staggering under the weight of gold medals."

Don't forget to collect the set!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WHAT MIGHT HAVE BEEN

The Fiver, like most people, has spent more time than is good for us staring at a half empty pint of the dark stuff, wondering what if. What if we had had the guts to have asked the lovely Joan - or Jennifer, or whoever it was - out on a date? What if Clive Thomas hadn't blown the final whistle as a Brazilian effort headed goalwards during the 1978 World Cup? Or Ian St John rather than Idwal Robbling had won the BBC's 1970 Find a Commentator competition? What if Luis Figo had joined Manchester City?

You see, £40m Figo, he of the Portuguese dash and the exotic dribble, could have been enjoying the as-much-as-you-can-eat curry buffet at the Royal Darbar instead of measly portions of tapas in the Plaza Major. Because back in 1994 Malcolm Allison, who had just finished a coaching stint at Sporting Lisbon and started scouting for City, recommended a certain Sporting 21-year-old to the then manager, Brian Horton. And better still, he was available for just £1.2m.

According to Big Mal: "At the time not many people had heard of him, and Sporting were looking for some cash, so we thought we might get him." But - and isn't there always a but - "Barcelona got wind of it, and they offered Sporting a more attractive loan deal." As far as might have beens go, this ranks with David Pleat's revelation that he could have signed Norweigan international John Carew for Luton, or Harry Redknapp's admission that he could have signed Andriy Shevchenko, but sent him home after he "didn't pull up any trees" during a reserve game against Barnet.

But perhaps it's better that nothing happened. After all, with English coaching methods and habits (pork scratchings anyone?) it's a fair bet that at least one out of Figo, Shevchenko and Carew would have been suffered the Savo Milosevic syndrome and been sold on as a failure - only to then succeed abroad. What's more, City would probably still have got relegated too.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"This was my first 45 minutes. I'm taking each game as it comes because I didn't play many games for Middlesbrough towards the end of the season - or at the start, or the middle." Gazza's review of the season following last night's friendly between Everton and Dundee United.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

DUNC SLAMMED

The Fiver, in a moment of uncharacteristic snideness, was quick to scoff at Duncan Ferguson's move from Everton to Newcastle. "Too much money", we said, "he's always injured", we said, "doesn't score enough goals", we said. A year and a half later and, for once in our lives, we've been proven right. But we take no pride in these developments because, to our mind, the man with the most distinctive fist waggle in football is being hard done by.

Ever since Rangers chairman David Murray suggested that, following the arrival of Carl Cort at Newcastle, he was being hawked around every club with a vowel in its name (FC Clywd were said to feel very left out), Big Dunc has become the player no one wants. Rangers rejected him, Bryan Robson of all people failed to follow up an interest, and today Manchester City denied wanting to buy Ferguson without even being linked to him! "Any move for Ferguson," said a City spokesman today, "is purely speculation and there is no truth in it, no truth in it at all."

There was really no need for the repetition, no need at all. And how Big Dunc must feel when he hears such things. Even his prospective emotional return to Goodison Park looks likely to end in tears. For a start, Everton are only willing to pay £3m for him. Secondly, Dunc would have to trim his current weekly wage of £40,000 rather drastically if he was to return to Merseyside. And, thirdly, even if he did he'd have to play second fiddle to Kevin Campbell. Honestly, it's enough to make you nut a fellow pro and spend three months in Barlinnie.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Middlesbrough are believed to be close to completing a move for Lazio's unwanted striker Alen Boksic. The 30-year-old Croat would cost Bryan Robson around £2m.

Internazionale have revealed they are interested in signing Robbie Keane this summer. The Milan giants are also pursuing Lazio's Marcelo Salas, but managing director Gabriele Oriali claims Keane is top priority. "First Keane and then eventually, the Chilean," he told the Italian press.

Marc Overmars looks likely to move to Barcelona. "I'm extremely flattered by their interest in me and the prospect of moving to such a huge club would excite any player," the Dutch international said on his personal website.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

South Africa have lodged an appeal for arbitration following the controversial decision earlier this month to award the 2006 World Cup to Irvin Khoza, chairman of South Africa's 2006 Bid Committee, said the South Africa Football Association (SAFA) had sent a letter to FIFA "asking them to set the process in motion."

Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson remained defiant ahead of a meeting this afternoon with Christian Ziege to discuss the German international's future. "There's nothing much to say," said Robson. "Christian has not given us any indication that he wants to leave."

Derby have signed Norwegian international defender Bjorn Otto Bragstad from Rosenborg for £1.5m.

Ade Akinbiyi has signed for Leicester in a £5m deal after passing a medical.

Brazilian midfielder Emerson is joining AS Roma from German club Bayer Leverkusen.

Parma are in talks with Real Zaragoza over the £15m transfer of Savo Milosevic.

Ronaldo is considering a stint with the Major League Soccer, according to the Gazzetta dello Sport. They say he is looking for a softer way back after his knee operation.

Romania have appointed former international midfielder Ladislau Boloni as coach.

The Football League have appointed David Burns as their new chief executive. Burns, an Airtours executive and former solicitor, replaces John McKeown, who left the position in April.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Beach soccer (6.30pm) Fat men in sand.

Six-a-side football - live (7.30pm) Fat men indoors.

International football - Brazil v Argentina (1.30am) Thin men on grass. Thin man with surname like small European grand duchy on verge of sack.

British Eurosport: FC Shelbourne v Rosenborg BK - Live (7.30pm) Can the plucky Irishmen see off the Big Cup big shots? Why am I even bothering to ask the question?

Euro 2000 in review (9.30pm) It's a competition, it happened about two weeks ago, you know the one, don't you?

"Too much money", we said, "he's always injured", we said, "doesn't score enough goals", we said. A year and a half later and, for once in our lives, we've been proven right. But we take no pride in these developments because, to our mind, the man with the most distinctive fist waggle in football is being hard done by. Ever since Rangers chairman David Murray suggested that, following the arrival of Carl Cort at Newcastle, he was being hawked around every club with a vowel in its name (FC Clywd were said to feel very left out), Big Dunc has become the player no one wants. Rangers rejected him, Bryan Robson of all people failed to follow up an interest, and today Manchester City denied wanting to buy Ferguson without even being linked to him! "Any move for Ferguson," said a City spokesman today, "is purely speculation and there is no truth in it, no truth in it at all." There was really no need for the repetition, no need at all. And how Big Dunc must feel when he hears such things. Even his prospective emotional return to Goodison Park looks likely to end in tears. For a start, Everton are only willing to pay £3m for him. Secondly, Dunc would have to trim his current weekly wage of £40,000 rather drastically if he was to return to Merseyside. And, thirdly, even if he did he'd have to play second fiddle to Kevin Campbell. Honestly, it's enough to make you nut a fellow pro and spend three months in Barlinnie. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Middlesbrough are believed to be close to completing a move for Lazio's unwanted striker Alen Boksic. The 30-year-old Croat would cost Bryan Robson around £2m. Internazionale have revealed they are interested in signing Robbie Keane this summer. The Milan giants are also pursuing Lazio's Marcelo Salas, but managing director Gabriele Oriali claims Keane is top priority. "First Keane and then eventually, the Chilean," he told the Italian press. Marc Overmars looks likely to move to Barcelona. "I'm extremely flattered by their interest in me and the prospect of moving to such a huge club would excite any player," the Dutch international said on his personal website. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF South Africa have lodged an appeal for arbitration following the controversial decision earlier this month to award the 2006 World Cup to Irvin Khoza, chairman of South Africa's 2006 Bid Committee, said the South Africa Football Association (SAFA) had sent a letter to FIFA "asking them to set the process in motion." Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson remained defiant ahead of a meeting this afternoon with Christian Ziege to discuss the German international's future. "There's nothing much to say," said Robson. "Christian has not given us any indication that he wants to leave." Derby have signed Norwegian international defender Bjorn Otto Bragstad from Rosenborg for £1.5m. Ade Akinbiyi has signed for Leicester in a £5m deal after passing a medical. Brazilian midfielder Emerson is joining AS Roma from German club Bayer Leverkusen. Parma are in talks with Real Zaragoza over the £15m transfer of Savo Milosevic. Ronaldo is considering a stint with the Major League Soccer, according to the Gazzetta dello Sport. They say he is looking for a softer way back after his knee operation. Romania have appointed former international midfielder Ladislau Boloni as coach. The Football League have appointed David Burns as their new chief executive. Burns, an Airtours executive and former solicitor, replaces John McKeown, who left the position in April. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO Sky Sports 1: Beach soccer (6.30pm) Fat men in sand. Six-a-side football - live (7.30pm) Fat men indoors. International football - Brazil v Argentina (1.30am) Thin men on grass. Thin man with surname like small European grand duchy on verge of sack. British Eurosport: FC Shelbourne v Rosenborg BK - Live (7.30pm) Can the plucky Irishmen see off the Big Cup big shots? Why am I even bothering to ask the question? Euro 2000 in review (9.30pm) It's a competition, it happened about two weeks ago, you know the one, don't you?

webTitle: Boothroyd's warning to Commons in farewell speech

fields.headline: Boothroyd's warning to Commons in farewell speech
fields.standfirst:
Jonathan Freedland: Tony Benn would make the best Commons speaker

Tony Benn: The speaker we need

John O'Farrell: Happy hols, and give us all a break
fields.trailText: In her valedictory speech to Parliament today, Betty Boothroyd spoke of her pride and enjoyment in her eight-year role as speaker of the House of Commons.
fields.body:
In her valedictory speech to Parliament today, Betty Boothroyd spoke of her pride and enjoyment in her eight-year role as speaker of the House of Commons.

But she warned that the key role of parliament, that of legislative and executive scrutiny, must be upheld. Giving her retirement speech after prime minister's question time this afternoon, she said:

"Being speaker has afforded me a unique opportunity to serve parliament, for which I am immensely grateful." She added; "The function of parliament is to hold the executive to account. We should never overlook the primacy of parliament."

She went on to express disappointment at what she termed "slow progress" in the development of question time, and described legislative scrutiny as "an area ripe for improvement".

The speaker added: "The high reputation of Westminster abroad is not entirely reflected at home." She spoke of increasing political disillusionment and cynicism amongst the public, especially the young. "Their alienation from the democratic process is troubling," she commented.

She ended by urging members to rejoice in their inheritance: "Defend your rights, and remember that the privilege of this house was dearly won."

In spite of calls in parliament yesterday for her to defer her retirement until a successor is elected, Ms Boothroyd will step down as speaker and as MP for West Bromwich West before the Commons returns from its summer recess in October, as she announced in parliament on July 12.

As parliament's first female speaker, she has served since 1992. In the Commons yesterday Tam Dalyell, MP for Linlithgow, raised concerns over the election procedure. He called for Ms Boothroyd to postpone her departure until November to help MPs elect her successor to "enable the House to make up its mind in a sensible fashion".

With at least a dozen candidates in the running for the post, the election, which will be held in a free vote on the opening of parliament after the summer recess, looks wide open.

Although tradition dictates that the chair should alternate between Conservatives and Labour, it is expected that a Labour or Liberal Democrat MP will win the vote. Rumoured to enjoy the support of the prime minister, Tony Blair, Liberal Democrat veteran Menzies Campbell may be a favourite. If elected, Mr Campbell would be the first Liberal speaker since 1924.

webTitle: The trials of being a Northants fan

fields.headline: The trials of being a Northants fan
fields.trailText: OK, that's it. A Northants fan can only take so much. After months of simmering at my team's ineptitude, it's time to let rip. My previous from-the-heart rant about the state of the Steelbacks elicited a not-too-favourable response from another, more senior, member of the Wisden staff, himself a Northamptonshire man. On that occasion, I had called for the abolition of my team in a moment of dark despair (Northants had reduced Kent to 41 for 7, yet lost by an innings). On this occasion, well, not a lot's changed really.
fields.body:
OK, that's it. A Northants fan can only take so much. After months of simmering at my team's ineptitude, it's time to let rip. My previous from-the-heart rant about the state of the Steelbacks elicited a not-too-favourable response from another, more senior, member of the Wisden staff, himself a Northamptonshire man. On that occasion, I had called for the abolition of my team in a moment of dark despair (Northants had reduced Kent to 41 for 7, yet lost by an innings). On this occasion, well, not a lot's changed really.

Northants are still jam-packed with young cricketers who fail to convert talent into runs and wickets. And they still blow games they seem to be strolling. Take last week. Northants were over 300 ahead in a low-scoring game at Cardiff with four second-innings wickets to fall. Then David Ripley, who had been batting with a runner, fell for 33 (fair enough). Michael Strong followed first ball (mild irritation), and Darren Cousins was stumped for 0 (angry cursing). In the next over Tony Penberthy was caught for 57 (tears of rage). The last four wickets had fallen without addition and Glamorgan needed 309. On a pitch that was taking some turn, they did it with ease against our two offspinners, Graeme Swann and Jason Brown. There are times when it feels like supporting the county version of England.

Between 1992 and '95, Northants were the only side in the country to finish in the top five of the County Championship each year. They won the NatWest in '92, and in '95 pushed Warwickshire all the way in the Championship before fading at the last. Until very recently, they were actually quite good. Since then they've underperformed horribly.

The curse is continuing. The captain Matthew Hayden, one of seven Australian left-handers on the county circuit, has passed 30 on 17 occasions in all competitions. Only once has he gone on to make a century. If he did that for Queensland, they'd be asking serious questions, mate. His opening partner, the equally barrel-chested Adrian Rollins, is worryingly all-or-nothing: of his 22 innings 12 have ended in single figures while the other ten have exceeded 20.

Then there's the Strange Case of Malachy Loye. Two years ago he was voted cricketer of the year by his fellow professionals, and he began last season as next in line for an England spot. He duly had a shocker (302 Championship runs at 16.77) and everyone agreed he wasn't strong enough mentally. This year he's shown an alarming tendency to get off to a flyer before throwing it away. David Sales has been even more annoying. He either gets in and stays in or doesn't get in at all: either side of his 276 against Notts were scores of 0, 5, 1, 25, 3, then 30, 1, 2, 2, and 18.

Penberthy is dependable but dour and Swann can't be trusted to make the most of a good start. The only unqualified success has been the Sydney-born but English-qualified Jeff Cook, who hit 137 at Cheltenham recently, yet he's only played three Championship games. It all adds up to a worrying lack of stability at the top of the order. So far, so Northants.

The bowling has been even more infuriating. Paul Taylor has been injured and is yet to take the field for the first team in his benefit year, while Devon Malcolm, who still thinks he can do a job for England, has found himself trying to do one for Northants Second XI instead.

But perhaps the most disappointing feature of the Wantage Road catalogue of woes has been the spin bowling. In Swann, Brown and left-armer Michael Davies, Northants boast, in theory, the best young trio of twirlers in the country. But Davies had an attack of the yips in the innings defeat by Warwickshire and hasn't been seen since, while Swann doesn't seem to have got over his winter of inactivity in South Africa with England. Brown has been the pick of the three but blotted his copybook in that defeat by Glamorgan.

Losing four out of the last five Championship games is bad enough. Losing to Oxford Universities in between (and allowing their No. 11 to make 87) was plain cruel. The last straw never quite comes for Northants fans - we're too masochistic for that - but if they lose their NatWest quarter-final today against Gloucestershire, the rest of the season could be even bleaker.

Come on Northants. Please.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com. To read his previous County View, a team-by-team half-term report,click here

fields.headline: Assemblies all round
fields.standfirst:
Enthusiasm for regional assemblies is growing. Could English devolution be the big constitutional reform of a second Labour term?
Special report: devolution in Britain
fields.trailText: John Prescott is evangelical. The prime minister is sceptical. Some ministers are enthusiastic. But most are agnostic. Until recently, when the subject of English regional devolution was raised in the loftiest political meetings, support was at best tentative. There was a common reaction: "Who wants it?"
fields.body:
John Prescott is evangelical. The prime minister is sceptical. Some ministers are enthusiastic. But most are agnostic. Until recently, when the subject of English regional devolution was raised in the loftiest political meetings, support was at best tentative. There was a common reaction: "Who wants it?"

Suddenly, however, a dormant issue is becoming active. Some even believe that Prescott's evangelism is converting hardened opponents. "Scotland and Wales?" the deputy prime minister asked rhetorically earlier this year, with Tony Blair's closest confidant, Lord Falconer, sitting alongside.

"You set up administrations that are democratically accountable to people ... that's one of the things about democratic accountability ... people who are answerable to and acting for the regions. It happened in Scotland and Wales and I see no difference in England."

Even the regions and local government minister, Hilary Armstrong, one of Prescott's deputies, found his passion over the top. Now she is more supportive and Tony Blair says he will not stand in the way if people want more constitutional change.

On the surface, the case for English devolution - in other words, eight directly elected regional assemblies - appears academic in a centralised nation where most power since 1945 has rested at Westminster. Scotland got its parliament, Wales and London their assemblies.

Why go further? Yet, on the back of Scottish and Welsh devolution, the government last year created eight English regional development agencies - business-led quangos, appointed by Prescott, charged with improving provincial economies. The RDAs were seen as a sop to Prescott, a long-time advocate of regional planning. But their budgets were modest, less than £1bn for the lot of them, and disillusionment soon set in.

Last week, however, the eight were given a big spending boost, with the prospect of £500m extra by 2003. Equally importantly, they were promised more freedom to operate outside Whitehall's tight control (a principal source of complaint) with the promise of a single budget, drawn from three main departments, giving them the ability to tailor policies to particular regions. Significantly, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, appeared with Prescott to give a form of English devolution his blessing.

This, however, could be just the start. Behind the scenes over the past year, regional "chambers", invariably now renamed "assemblies", have been set up to shadow the RDAs. Comprising councillors, business people, trade unionists and religious leaders, they have been given the blessing of John Prescott. Full-time secretariats have been established, regional plans prepared and, in some cases, concordats signed with the RDAs.

As a report on the RDAs by Professor Brian Robson, Manchester University's veteran geographer and regionalist, concluded recently: "At the very least, their creation has altered the landscape of English governance by bringing to the fore a regional dimension which seems unlikely to be reversed." It quoted a string of interviewees telling the Robson team: "The regional genie is out of the bottle and can't be put back."

Then, earlier this month, Labour's national policy forum met in Exeter to begin the long task of agreeing the fine print of the party's next manifesto. Prescott's aides had clearly been working overtime. Delegates agreed that the party had to recognise the "legitimate aspirations of the English regions and believes that the creation of elected regional assemblies is the essential next step in our programme of renewing the constitution and empowering citizens."

Of course, a lot of argument still has to take place. But supporters of Prescott, to the obvious concern of some policy advisers in Downing Street, believe they are on the way to committing the next Labour government to publishing a white paper on English devolution - the essential first step to legislation. At the very least, they want a firm commitment for regional referendums in Labour's second term, similar to those held in Scotland, Wales and London, to test support for devolution.

Such a move might have to be coupled with another round of local government reform to create single-tier authorities in England (similar to those in Scotland and Wales), abolishing the county councils. But it is clear that that support is slowly rising.

No one could yet pretend that the electorate is buzzing with excitement. A poll in the Economist last year found that the north-east was the only region outside London that agreed with the hypothesis that a regional assembly would "look after its interests better than central government". But from the north-west to the south-east (where a regional "assembly" is now chaired by a senior Tory councillor) the chattering classes are sitting up and taking notice. Hundreds turned out for a big north-west debate in Manchester recently.

Armstrong, MP for Durham North West, indicated that ministers had moved ground substantially when speaking at another debate in the north-east. Pre-empting Labour's national policy forum, she bravely went so far to pledge that Labour would bring forward legislation to test public opinion in referendums if it won a second term.

Tony Blair might not go that far. But with regions, like his adopted north-east, languishing well behind - London and the south-east in the national wealth league, he knows that Labour will have to offer its wavering heartland supporters something more than platitudes if it is to win back support. With unemployment three times more than in the south-east, they want jobs. That partly explains the renewed interest in regional development agencies, charged with creating broader economies. It also explains why Tony Blair would not now dare to dismiss English devolution as a pipe dream.

 Peter Hetherington is the Guardian's regional affairs correspondent.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: As a headteacher warns that children with career parents are being neglected, we ask: is 'quality not quantity' still the mantra for working mothers and fathers?
fields.trailText: The Question: As a headteacher warns that children with career parents are being neglected, we ask: is 'quality not quantity' still the mantra for working mothers and fathers?
fields.body:
Emma Burstall Features editor, Family Circle magazine and mother of two

Parents who work long hours are making a mistake. Children need them around. I'm lucky because I've been able to negotiate Fridays at home. I can keep in touch with the children's schools - it means you're more involved in your children's lives and they appreciate it. There's also homework to consider - it's hard to believe a carer can substitute for a parent where that's concerned. It's good for children to see their parents working, rather than being frustrated at home - but it's no good working all the time or they'll grow up hardly knowing you.
Verdict: No

Dorit Braun Chief executive of Parentline Plus helpline for parents

Many parents who contact us work and find it hard to balance the needs of their children, themselves and their partner. But when you talk the issues through, it often becomes clear that the idea of not working simply isn't financially feasible, and work also gives them a life of their own, which they both want and need. Working gives people self-worth and makes them feel they contribute to society, which in turn makes them feel better about themselves and so better at dealing with everything in their lives - and that includes their children.
Verdict: Yes

Sue Monk Chief executive of Parents At Work

It's not helpful to working parents or their children if discussions on balancing work and home are dominated by thinly disguised attempts to force mothers back into the home. Quality time is useful but there is a danger that working longer hours can make time with children too pressured. Research shows that children worry when parents seem exhausted and anxious. They want time to be around their parents. This applies particularly to teenagers, who find it hard to open up and simply won't if you only see them for half an hour a day.
Verdict: No

Penny Stafford Nanny looking after a two-year-old child full time

I love children and I know I'm good at what I do, but I can never take the place of a child's mother and father. Parents need to give what time they can. And the time they can give is appreciated. If you're working full time and you can call home during the day, a child will love it. Or if you can work from home a day a week so you can see a bit more of your children, they will love that, too. But working parents have to be careful with quality time - there can be a tendency to go for lots of treats, yet what the child values best is just your time.
Verdict: No

John Coe Spokesman, the National Association for Primary Education

From an educational point of view you see huge benefits from quality time with parents, which includes trips to museums and days out. As teachers, we often find that children with problems are insecure, which may come from not having had enough regularity and continuity in their lives. By adolescence a child inevitably breaks away from his or her parents, and at that point it's crucial that the child has had both quality of care and quantity of care from their parents if they're to survive the turbulence.
Verdict: They need both

Jan Parker Co-author of Raising Happy Children (Hodder & Stoughton)

This is a complicated debate - it's not as simple as quality time, bad; at-home parents, good. fields.headline: Prime suspect
fields.standfirst: Police have them, Olympic committees have them - and now you can have one, too.  Patrick Weir reports on a drug testing kit for worried parents
fields.trailText: Police have them, Olympic committees have them - and now you can have one, too. Patrick Weir reports on a drug testing kit for worried parents.
fields.body:
So your 16-year-old daughter is looking out of sorts. Keeping later nights, she seems to be surviving on little sleep and is generally vague and irritable when you ask her how things are. You can't be sure, but hasn't your 15-year-old son lost a little weight recently? Not wolfing down the food with quite his customary gusto? Aren't you worried?

Judging by the alarm bells ringing at Surescreen Diagnostics Ltd, your child could actually be a walking, mumbling repository for any number of drugs doing the rounds in the pubs and clubs where he spends so much time losing himself. Between 40% and 50% of young people in Britain today have tried one substance or another, so who knows? But don't panic; Surescreen has the answer: if you can get your recalcitrant teenager to give you a urine sample before he crawls into bed, the Derby firm's home drug-screening kit will do the rest.

Currently obtainable by mail order and due to be marketed nationally in the next few weeks by a chain of major chemists, the At Home Drug Test is the first screening kit in the UK that has been approved by the US Food and Drug Administration. Costing £24.99, the one-use kit offers a 99% accurate test for amphetamines, cannabis, cocaine, ecstasy and heroin. Surescreen's principal scientific officer, Jim Campbell, insists that the test has a beneficial role to play for both parents and children.

"Whether referred to us by their GP or an NHS trust treatment centre, an increasing number of anxious parents have contacted us over the last two years to buy the test. There is a very real demand."

The kit comprises a urine cup, gloves, an instruction manual and five test strips. Once armed with your urine sample (this one will surely stump most parents) you dip the test strips into it; if you get a positive result you then send the strips and urine to Surescreen, who will run further tests to determine which drug has been used. The presence of prescription drugs won't trigger an inaccurately positive reading.

"When the parent rings us for the results, the interpretations of a positive result, in terms of the drug's effects and its health risks, are discussed," says Campbell. Simple.

However, many drugs experts are sceptical about the benefits of the kits. Home testing can establish whether a drug has or has not been recently taken, but it cannot determine previous or future use. And the effects on the parent-child relationship, they say, could be devastating.

"I'll give you a gold clock if you can show me a relationship between a 15-year-old and a parent where such testing would help," says Gerv McGrath, director of Addaction, a drug counselling group in Derby. The kit, he says, is simply a cynical exploitation of parents which has no therapeutic value in the home.

"It's not conducted in an informed way by the parent as it doesn't recognise that alcohol is the main entry point to drug abuse. The test can't show this. And how could a parent possibly use it in a trusting relationship? Working from the position that says, 'I don't trust you,' it has no benefit whatsoever. It certainly won't help a difficult relationship."

What's more, he adds: "If the test is negative, it doesn't tell you much. Your child might not have been using drugs today or last week, but what about three months ago or next year?"

McGrath advises worried parents to spend the £25 on taking the child out for a meal and talking things through. "Testing won't prevent drug abuse and is a complete waste of time and money. And how parents with three or four children are expected to shell out for it is anyone's guess."

Dr Harry Markantonakis, a consultant child and adolescent psychiatrist at West Bromwich's Edward Street hospital, insists that trust has been broken once a child tries drugs. But while he would consider using the test on his own children, he is also aware of the risks he would be running.

"If a parent were to suddenly ask a child to take the test, without any prior dialogue, that would be very wrong. Otherwise, how you do it is crucial, but in good relationships I'm not convinced that it would always necessarily cause conflict.

"But a parent could overreact to symptoms that are typical in teenagers. Seeing your daughter flushed and bleary-eyed on occasions is nothing to worry about, and if you're asking me if that represents a case for this test, I'd say forget it."

fields.headline: Role reversal
fields.standfirst: Dea Birkett  wants to relive her youth by taking her daughter to a music festival. But the seven-year-old just wants to grow up
fields.trailText: Dea Birkett wants to relive her youth by taking her daughter to a music festival. But the seven-year-old just wants to grow up.
fields.body:
I remember sleeping under canvas in muddy fields, with clear nights and a fuzzy head. I remember seeing Dylan and Hawkwind as spots on a distant stage. I remember what it was like to be 17. And now, fortysomething, I have decided it is time to take my seven-year-old daughter to her first outdoor music festival. "You're so uncool, mum," she groans.

The truth is, I would never have gone to Womad without my daughter. Alone, I would have simply felt like a sad, middle-aged woman trying to relive her youth. But she gives me an excuse to act young. Each year, more children are taken along to the biggest world music festival, probably with similar parental intentions. Last weekend, there were over 3,000 under-13s.

Womad is an enchanted land. The site next to the Rivermead Leisure Centre in Reading is unpromising and huge, yet during the festival it seems intimate. I looked at the city of tents with envy. Arriving late on Friday night, I had begged my daughter to help me put up our battered tent. She was having none of it. "I'd rather stay in a hotel," she said, like a shrunk 40-year-old. We did a deal that we'd retreat to a hotel for the first night, then try to put up the tent the next morning when it was light. But the swimming pool seduced her and the tent stayed in our car. It was the first sign that my daughter would not collude in my quest to spend a weekend in childish revelry. All she wants to do is grow up.

Once a dedicated festivalgoer, I wanted to share my knowledge of how to behave with my daughter. I attempted to demonstrate how to lie contemplatively on your back, staring up at the massive fluorescent cobwebs which hung from the roof surrounding the main stage. "It's quite creative," said my daughter, like some waist-high Ofsted inspector. "Wicked," I murmured.

On stage, Czech gypsy singer Vera Bila entranced us. My daughter may be far more sensible than I am, but she hasn't yet learnt the strict division between the senses adults develop. (Pink fur still feels better than boring brown fur; food tastes good if it's shaped like a dinosaur.) It wasn't Bila's stirring songs that fascinated her, but her size. Bila was a great singer, according to my daughter, simply because she was so fabulously fat.

Womad isn't about individual acts, it's about atmosphere and belonging to a crowd. My daughter stared enviously at the fading tattoo of a mohican on a man's arm. Soon afterwards, her shin was temporarily tattooed with a smiling moon, her hair braided in pink and silver thread. She looked like a child of the 70s. Yet it was I who had been one.

We argued over the programme. She wanted to go to a salsa workshop; I was desperate to see Rolf Harris. "Rolf Harris sounds boring," said my daughter. But the stage was mobbed with parents who had also dragged along their recalcitrant children.

By the end of the day, I was humming Jake the Peg while my daughter was beating out the rhythm of a djembe drum. Our ages were beginning to cross over. She was approaching her 20s; I was a teenager again, a cross between Harry Enfield's Kevin and Ali G.

As we left the enchanted Womad encampment, the spell was broken. Driving home, I became the concerned mother. "You better have a bath before you go to bed; you're filthy," I barked. "OK mum," shrugged my daughter, a child once more.

I've already checked up the dates of next year's Womad. My daughter will be eight by then, very old. I hope she'll sleep in a tent.

Missed Womad? Try these instead: Guildford Live 2000, 28-30 July, 01483 454159, www.guildford-live.co.uk; Cambridge Folk Festival, 27-30 July, 01223 457245, www.cam-folkfest.co.uk; V2000, 19-20 August, www.gigsandtours.com; Leeds Festival, 26-28 August, 020-8963 0940, www.leedsfestival.com; Reading Festival, 25-27 August, 020-8963 0940, www.readingfestival.com. Next year's Womad details from www.womad.org.

fields.headline: The day my baby died
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair was full of praise for the team at the Chelsea and Westminster hospital where his son, Leo, was born.  Laura Gerahty has a very different view
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was full of praise for the team at the Chelsea and Westminster hospital where his son, Leo, was born. Laura Gerahty has a very different view.
fields.body:
When Tony Blair emerged from No 10 Downing Street full of praise for "the team" from the Chelsea and Westminster hospital who had safely delivered his son I had to take several deep breaths. The Blairs' experience clearly bore no relation to my own at the same hospital.

In the same ward three and a half years ago our baby daughter, Stella, was born and later died of complications due to asphyxia at birth. This simple statement of fact, like all private tragedies, conceals a shattering sequence of events in which our whole life view was savagely altered in the space of a few hours, transformed as we were from a state of careless optimism to bewildered loss.

I have a photograph of myself standing on the steps of our house hugely pregnant on the way to the hospital, at once nervous and excited. It belongs to the same batch of photographs as ones of myself hunched sadly over the crib in the neonatal unit tending a baby with a mass of tubes attached to her. They seem to be of two completely different people.

I was extremely healthy throughout my pregnancy. Complications could not have been further from my mind. Like Cherie, I too had three older children, two boys and a girl, and this, my fourth baby, was a lovely surprise, coming seven years after our youngest son. The fact that according to my notes I was of advanced maternal age seemed insignificant. I had always given birth swiftly and easily.

My consultant at the hospital had recommended that I should be induced there so as not to run the risk of giving birth precipitately, at home or elsewhere. And so I was induced, albeit reluctantly, at the Chelsea and Westminster hospital on October 2 1996, a week before she was due, though she was not "engaged".

I was put on a syntocin drip and wired up to a monitor. Just after midnight, when I was close to giving birth, the monitor registered acute foetal distress. It was decided that I needed to deliver the baby quickly but it became apparent that she was facing the wrong way, possibly as a consequence of the induction process. A decision was made not to use forceps, but to go for an emergency caesarean section. When she was finally delivered she had suffered massive brain damage due to asphyxia contracted in that period.

Up until the moment of birth I was unaware of the true gravity of the situation, but as soon as she was born I knew something was terribly wrong. She was limp and silent. I had never realised how tuned a mother is to the cry of her newborn. "Why doesn't she cry?" I called out in panic. "Oh God, please not brain damage," but no one was prepared to commit themselves to anything more than that she was poorly. I wanted to hold her and see her but instead I was wheeled back to the labour ward and left there for seven hours with the eerie sounds of women giving birth in the twilight hours and the terrible feeling that I had failed to do what other women all around were able to do.

As dawn rose over London we stared out of the window in utter desolation. In a brusque fashion the midwife came back to ask after my "wound". No mention of my baby. I looked at her strangely. The pain in my abdomen from an emergency caesarean was as nothing to the real wound in my heart.

She died a week later. I found it unbearable to give her up to be taken from my arms to the cold mortuary. We took her away to be buried in the Devon countryside. Milk was pouring from my breasts at the funeral.

The obstetric team seemed elusive and defensive. Richard Smith, the consultant, arrived in the morning following the birth. My husband pointed out that the notes had been annotated after the event, times clumsily crossed out and rewritten, but the consultant claimed that "these small changes" were not significant, as he felt there was only a 10-minute period which could be disputed and there was, after all, a CTG trace [of the foetal heartbeat] as a record.

With extraordinary difficulty, we tried to gather together all those responsible for the delivery. The midwife was not available until four days after the birth. She was newly qualified and complained when summoned that she had had a terrible few days and it was not fair to question her. Another midwife present could not be traced at all. We were told that she had left the hospital to work in the community. We tried to get the head of midwifery to come to see us but she never came, despite many requests.

Other departments were left to pick up the pieces. Hospital officialdom lurched into action. A reverend Brenda was sent to sit by my bed and told me she was very good at listening. I felt that good manners obliged me to say something, but there was nothing I could think of to say so we lapsed into an uncomfortable silence. A leaflet was handed to me entitled "Complaints: listening ... acting ... improving". We registered our complaint and were sent a letter a month later from someone we had never met on behalf of the chief executive to say that they were "extremely sorry at the sad loss" but ... it was nothing to do with them. As an exercise in public relations this letter badly misfired. It smelt of bureaucracy and amounted to an insult. What was missing was any real sense of sorrow. We seemed instead to be part of some sort of hideous bereavement package. We were offered a "precious memory booklet" which included Stella's handprints, footprints and identity bracelet. Hospital counsellors made soothing noises; we felt fobbed off and most emphatically did not want to hear their platitudes on grief.

Last year and quite by accident I found myself face to face with Richard Smith, the consultant. He failed to recognise me, despite prompting.

We had decided not to sue because we believed at the time that suing the hospital would achieve nothing. It could not bring her back and we would be forced to relive the circumstances of her birth and death time and time again, and to what end? Even if a court found that someone was to blame, the law cannot properly compensate for a broken heart. However, it is not sufficient for the medical staff to turn away while counsellors clear up the mess. This had the effect of redoubling our sense of injustice and grief.

Of course mistakes are made. We made the mistake of being taken in by the glamorous exterior of the Chelsea and Westminster. All those big clean breezy spaces and art on the walls. Anyone who has ever been there knows that it bears little resemblance to other NHS hospitals, and we were impressed. Interestingly the Blairs chose it in preference to the scruffy but excellent St Thomas's hospital, which is much closer to Downing Street. What we failed to realise then was that this glossy exterior means nothing. The hospital is paradoxically a classic product of Thatcherism. Much of the labour has been contracted out. The cleaners, for instance, seemed sloppy and demoralised. The word "team" to describe those in the obstetric department responsible for me seemed to us to be a complete misnomer. As we struggled to gather them together after the event, we formed the strong impression that they didn't work as regularly together as the word implies. There was no consultant in the ward that night, and the only senior doctor present seemed very overstretched. The night of Leo Blair's birth I gather that Cherie was attended by her consultant, with four other senior doctors waiting in a nearby room. In other words she was better attended than at any private hospital. Delightful and happy outcome but not, of course, a standard NHS delivery. More a royal birth.

As an exercise in public relations this letter badly misfired. It smelt of bureaucracy and amounted to an insult. What was missing was any real sense of sorrow. We seemed instead to be part of some sort of hideous bereavement package. We were offered a "precious memory booklet" which included Stella's handprints, footprints and identity bracelet. Hospital counsellors made soothing noises; we felt fobbed off and most emphatically did not want to hear their platitudes on grief. Last year and quite by accident I found myself face to face with Richard Smith, the consultant. He failed to recognise me, despite prompting. We had decided not to sue because we believed at the time that suing the hospital would achieve nothing. It could not bring her back and we would be forced to relive the circumstances of her birth and death time and time again, and to what end? Even if a court found that someone was to blame, the law cannot properly compensate for a broken heart. However, it is not sufficient for the medical staff to turn away while counsellors clear up the mess. This had the effect of redoubling our sense of injustice and grief. Of course mistakes are made. We made the mistake of being taken in by the glamorous exterior of the Chelsea and Westminster. All those big clean breezy spaces and art on the walls. Anyone who has ever been there knows that it bears little resemblance to other NHS hospitals, and we were impressed. Interestingly the Blairs chose it in preference to the scruffy but excellent St Thomas's hospital, which is much closer to Downing Street. What we failed to realise then was that this glossy exterior means nothing. The hospital is paradoxically a classic product of Thatcherism. Much of the labour has been contracted out. The cleaners, for instance, seemed sloppy and demoralised. The word "team" to describe those in the obstetric department responsible for me seemed to us to be a complete misnomer. As we struggled to gather them together after the event, we formed the strong impression that they didn't work as regularly together as the word implies. There was no consultant in the ward that night, and the only senior doctor present seemed very overstretched. The night of Leo Blair's birth I gather that Cherie was attended by her consultant, with four other senior doctors waiting in a nearby room. In other words she was better attended than at any private hospital. Delightful and happy outcome but not, of course, a standard NHS delivery. More a royal birth.

fields.headline: Handing down a family tradition
fields.standfirst: The diary of a part-time father
fields.trailText: The diary of a part-time father
fields.body:
Last Thursday I became 40 years old. It is an age for calm reflection, for taking stock. So I began the day by gathering up my nearly-two-year-old Estelle, throwing her onto the sofa and torturing her until she could take no more.

"Come on, now! Out with it!" I demanded, digging my fingertips into her ribs and wiggling them about. "Are you a ticklish little girl?" She giggled madly and shrieked: "Dada! Dada!"

"I must warn you, Miss Stone, that resistance is futile! I repeat: are you a ticklish little girl?"

I tickled and tickled and tickled: terrible, merciless tickling, and with cruel variations too. Sometimes I'd suddenly stop tickling, raise my fingers above her in a ready-to-tickle position, growl like an agitated Yorkshire terrier - or maybe a Scottish one, I never can decide - then, after letting the tension rise to an unbearable peak, launch myself into further tickling, making Estelle squeal with delight.

Other times I simply feigned these wicked lunges and instead of resuming tickling planted a huge, rude raspberry upon her tummy, hoping that, in her helplessness, she wouldn't pee on the upholstery.

"I give you this stern pledge, Miss Stone: if there is ticklishness in this house, I won't rest until it's rooted out!"

How we adore this stupid game, though not for wholly the same reasons. Of course, it's mostly an expression of her total trust in me, my sheer delight in her, our excited exploration of a shared sense of the sensual, the scary, the absurd and - should it need pointing out - an expression of our deep mutual love.

But while Estelle experiences Tickling Terror as a hysterical adventure, for me it is piquantly nostalgic.

Tickling Terror is a family tradition, one of several I'm determined to preserve. Others include the handing down of those few sentimental items of children's clothing that Dilys, my dear ex, didn't abscond with when she left me for the atrocious Chris the Pillock; and the stern ejection of monsters discovered hiding in tots' wardrobes come bedtime.

Gloria, my eldest, was especially taken with this last one when she was about four, joining in excitedly as I stood there, hand on hip, wagging my index finger at imaginary trolls and tigers lurking among the frocks and socks, and insisting that they disperse into the garden ("I've told you before: this is no place for beasties with big teeth. And close the door behind you!").

Dilys used to enjoy this kind of nonsense, too, though she'd never admit it now, being utterly insistent that no man alive is more fluently conversant with his Inner Infant than Chris. According to Jed and Billy, she even boasts that he has a pedigree as a children's performer - believing that improvised street theatre is a form of entertainment rather than a reason to give fellows such as Chris the sort of big red nose that requires medical attention.

Being spinned against by Dilys in this abysmal way makes conventions such as Tickling Terror even more important, a bridge between part-time siblings and, most importantly, a reminder that they all have the same one-and-only father who can actually, at times, be a happy, laughing guy.

Gloria, being 12, is too old for such frivolity now - not to mention too resoundingly sententious - but the bubbling Billy, four, and even the unreachable Jed, eight, can still be brought to snorting, writhing, loving-it submission if caught unawares and in the right frame of mind.

So, as I enter middle age, I slowly realise that my tickling of Estelle serves many a subtle purpose. It's not only a bit of boisterous, bonding pleasure between her and me but also an act of consolidation, an assertion of the link between a turbulent present and a flawed yet valuable past that's under siege.

In knowing that Tickling Terror is visited upon their part-time little sister just as it's been visited on them for years, Gloria, Jed and Billy may know that she has inherited a fragment of their history that lives on, despite the best efforts of Dilys to make it disappear.

fields.headline: Spin and the government
fields.standfirst: As Tony Blair prepares to give his response to Lord Neill's spin doctor report, Jamie Wilson explains why the peer in charge of the committee on standards in public life wants a code of conduct for Whitehall
fields.trailText: As Tony Blair prepares to give his response to Lord Neill's spin doctor report, we explain why the peer in charge of the committee on standards in public life wants a code of conduct for Whitehall
fields.body:
Who is Lord Neill?
Lord Neill is the chairman of the committee on standards in public life, a body set up by the former prime minister, John Major, in the wake of the sleaze allegations that rocked his government.

Why is he in the news?
In a report published in January, Lord Neill called for a cap on the number of special advisers appointed in Whitehall and a code of conduct for spin doctors. The government is due to publish its response to the report today, and there has been speculation that the prime minister, Tony Blair, will reject the recommendations.

What is all the fuss about?
The escalating number of special advisers under Labour has provoked accusations that Tony Blair is building up a presidential-style power base, giving him unprecedented control over Whitehall. Senior civil servants have expressed alarm that special advisers are controlling the link between ministers and civil servants. The special advisers have also been accused of using spin to influence the media to support their minister, often briefing against members of the cabinet. Charlie Whelan, former adviser to Gordon Brown, was forced to resign after being accused of briefing against Peter Mandelson over his home loan from Geoffrey Robinson - a charge Mr Whelan has always denied. In his report Lord Neill said that while the committee had not concluded that the growth in the use of advisers had led to the civil service being "politicised", he believed it was time to "take stock" of the situation.

How does Lord Neill plan to do that?
The report said a new code of conduct should be introduced, making it clear that special advisers had a specific duty to uphold the impartiality of the civil service as well as regulating their contacts with the media.

How many special advisers are there?
The number of ministerial aides has jumped from 35 to 77 since Labour was elected, while the number in Downing Street has risen from eight to 28 in two years.

What do they get paid?
The cost of special advisers to the taxpayer has risen from £1.8m in 1997 to £3.9m today, of which £1.5m is concentrated in Downing Street. Salaries range from £26,000 to £80,000 for most special advisers, although there are exceptions: Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press secretary, and Jonathan Powell, Mr Blair's chief of staff, each earn £93,000.

Did Lord Neill make any other recommendations?
In his report he called on the government to make good its promise to turn the bribery of MPs and peers into a criminal offence. He also recommended sweeping changes in the appeal procedures for MPs facing misconduct charges in the wake of the cash for questions scandal, in which Sir Gordon Downey, the former parliamentary commissioner for standards, found "compelling" evidence that former minister Neil Hamilton had accepted £25,000 from Mohamed Al Fayed to ask questions in the Commons.

Anything else?
The report has called for curbs on task forces set up by the Labour government; the recording of all formal meetings with lobbyists and ministers; and the disclosure of sponsorship of government events above £5,000.
