webTitle: Blair pledges to press on with abolition of section 28

fields.headline: Blair pledges to press on with abolition of section 28
fields.standfirst:
During their weekly Commons confrontation, the prime minister told William Hague section 28 was fundamentally prejudiced, writes Gwyn Topham
More about section 28
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 4pm: During their weekly Commons confrontation, the prime minister told William Hague section 28 was fundamentally prejudiced, writes Gwyn Topham.
fields.body:
Tony Blair today during prime minister's questions reaffirmed his commitment to scrapping section 28 despite opposition from the Lords, denouncing as "prejudice and propaganda" claims that its removal would force children to be taught about homosexual sex.

Challenged by Conservative leader William Hague that he was "out of touch" with the nation's wishes over the controversial clause, which prohibits the promotion of homosexuality in schools, the prime minister said: "Clause 28 is prejudiced, and I remain committed to removing it."

Referring to Monday's government defeat in the House of Lords over the attempted reform, Mr Hague said: "If the prime minister doesn't recognise how in touch the Lords is with the country, then it shows how out of touch he has become."

The Lords, Mr Hague added, had "accurately reflected public opinion".

However, Mr Blair attacked the Conservative leader for seizing on issues such as asylum seekers and section 28. He said: "He [Mr Hague] is pandering to prejudice, and it is not a pretty sight."

The prime minister invited the leader of the opposition to "debate the real policies" of spending and public services. Amendments to the government's learning and skills bill had taken account of objections to the scrapping of section 28, allowing parents to opt their children out of any sex education programmes, Mr Blair said. Now opposition to reform was "a piece of prejudice, pure and simple".

He reiterated: "I believe we took the right position and I will continue to hold to it."

Questioned by the Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy however, Mr Blair would give no firm date to push through the reform.

fields.headline: Dick Cheney: the high-flying hawk
fields.standfirst: Martin Kettle in Washington charts the rise to power of George W Bush's running mate
fields.trailText: Martin Kettle in Washington charts the rise to power of George W Bush's running mate.
fields.body:
As a former White House chief of staff and a former defence secretary, Dick Cheney may seem like a figure from the political past, but he has always been identified as a man with a big political future.

Now, confirmed as George W Bush's running mate, Mr Cheney is an election campaign away from becoming US vice-president in November - and then a step away from the highest office of all.

In 1996, he even contemplated a run for the Republican presidential nomination himself - proof positive that Mr Cheney's move from Washington and into the international oil business in Texas was only a temporary one.

Mr Cheney is best known internationally for the four years he spent as defence secretary in President George Bush's administration between 1989 and 1993. The central event of those years was the Gulf war, in which Mr Cheney presided over the largest US military operation since Vietnam.

For a man with a reputation as a military hawk, Mr Cheney's own Vietnam era record is less belligerent. As a student, he secured five successive draft deferments, including one on the grounds that he had a young family. Mr Cheney and his wife Lynne, who was his high school sweetheart, have two daughters.

But Mr Cheney has long been seen as a political high-flyer. At 26, he was hired by Richard Nixon's White House to work on anti-inflation policy. At 33, as a protege of another former defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, he became Gerald Ford's chief of staff.

When Ford was defeated by Jimmy Carter, Mr Cheney went home to Wyoming - he is a graduate of the University of Wyoming - to run for congress. The tough part was the battle to win the Republican nomination, since the sparsely-populated mountain state has only one seat in congress, which is routinely dominated by the Republicans. Though he suffered a mild heart-attack during the campaign - he was only 37 at the time - he won easily, and served six terms in congress.

The 1978 heart attack was followed by another in 1984 and a third in 1988. Mr Cheney had quadruple heart bypass surgery in 1988 before taking on the job of defence secretary. Mr Cheney's doctors said this week that he was "up to a strenuous campaign".

Mr Cheney's voting record in congress was strictly conservative, but his abilities were quickly recognised in both parties, and he became a key player on Capitol Hill with great ease. By the mid-80s, the influential Almanac of American Politics tipped Mr Cheney as "clearly a major national politician" and a future party leader.

He was "the natural candidate of moderates who viscerally prefer a Ford to a Reagan - and the record on issues to be the first choice of a great many Reaganites".

That voting record was being pored over by friend and foe alike yesterday, and is certain to become an issue in the upcoming campaign. It includes an absolute opposition, common in Wyoming, to gun control - Mr Cheney was one of only four congressmen to vote against a proposed ban on plastic guns which could foil airport security scanners, a ban which even the National Rifle Association did not oppose.

But perhaps the crucial set of votes as far as the November 2000 election is concerned are the ones that Mr Cheney has cast against abortion, against the equal rights act for women in 1983, and against the Head Start education programme for minorities. In an election in which women's support is likely to determine the outcome, Democrats are certain to make maximum use of Mr Cheney's record to paint the Bush-Cheney ticket as conservative on women's issues.

Mr Cheney's high level and immensely profitable links with the Texas oil industry - also the source of the Bush family's wealth - will be another big issue in November, not least with environmentalists. Since 1995, he has been chief executive officer and chairman of the Halliburton Corporation, the Dallas based multinational giant which is the world's largest supplier of "energy services" - provision of construction, engineering and maintenance equipment and services to the oil industry.

Mr Cheney is understood to have earned around $2m (£1.3m) last year in salary, benefits and options at Halliburton. Last month, profiting spectacularly from the electorally sensitive worldwide increase in oil prices, Mr Cheney sold around 100,000 of his Halliburton shares - approximately half of his personal holding in the company, raising an estimated $5.1m.

Another intensely sensitive aspect of the Halliburton connection - which could lead to conflict of interest allegations - is the company's stake in two American oil industry companies, Dresser-Rand and Ingersoll-Dresser Pump Co, which are involved in trying to reconstruct the Iraqi oil industry after the Gulf war. Halliburton also major interests in the Russian oil industry.

After Mr Bush won the Republican primary elections this year, Mr Cheney was asked to head the search for a vice-presidential running mate. As recently as last month, Mr Cheney made clear that he did not wish to be considered for the post. But by last week there were clear signs that Mr Bush had managed to change Mr Cheney's mind.

webTitle: Tony Benn would make the best Commons speaker

fields.headline: Tony Benn would make the best Commons speaker
fields.standfirst:
As Betty Boothroyd makes her valedictory speech, Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland argues that the MP for Chesterfield would best uphold the values of parliament
Comment by Tony Benn: The speaker we need
fields.trailText: As Betty Boothroyd makes her valedictory speech, Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland argues that the MP for Chesterfield would best uphold the values of parliament.
fields.body:
When Betty Boothroyd makes her farewell address to the House of Commons this afternoon, listen out for another sound besides the snuffles of weepy MPs and the rustle of Kleenex: you'll hear the wheels of political calculation grinding furiously into life.

Close to a dozen MPs have already declared their interest in succeeding Ms Boothroyd as speaker, from Downing Street darling and Lib Dem veteran Menzies Campbell, to the bookies' favourite and old Labour warhorse, Michael Martin. But I have another hat to throw in the ring: Tony Benn.

Check out the storming piece he wrote in the Guardian today. It is a stirring call for a speaker brave enough to fight for a truly independent lawmaking chamber, separate from the executive in Downing Street. Benn's article is meant to be a job description. But read between the lines: it's a job application.

Parliamentary democracy has been transformed into a spectator sport, warns Benn. All that can save it is a "determined new speaker, armed with the authority of the House and absolutely free from executive control." And just who might be determined enough to be completely independent? Take a wild guess.

Put aside the image of Tony Benn as the man of the far left. The reason why he is respected on the Tory as well as Labour benches is that Benn is, above all, a believer in the near-sanctity of an elected chamber.

For him a parliament elected by the people is a core value - even when it votes against him and his principles. That's why there need be no fear that Benn would use the speaker's chair as a platform for his own ultra-left agenda. He would fall over himself to be scrupulously fair: a defender not of the left, but of parliament itself.

His biggest problem is his age. At 75, he could well be in the job into his 80s. But he is as alert and bright as ever - and remains perhaps the best public speaker in the country. Labour MPs are too tribal to vote for a Lib Dem such as Campbell. But they can do better than a lacklustre, if likeable stalwart like Martin. Parliament has the chance to elect one of its most distinguished figures. It should seize it.

The reason why he is respected on the Tory as well as Labour benches is that Benn is, above all, a believer in the near-sanctity of an elected chamber. That's why there need be no fear that Benn would use the speaker's chair as a platform for his own ultra-left agenda. fields.headline: The speaker we need
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Jonathan Freedland: Tony Benn would make the best commons speaker
fields.trailText: Betty Boothroyd, who makes her valedictory speech today, has been an outstanding speaker who has earned respect and affection from the whole House, not only for her personal qualities, but for the firm stand she has taken in the defence of parliament.
fields.body:
Betty Boothroyd, who makes her valedictory speech today, has been an outstanding speaker who has earned respect and affection from the whole House, not only for her personal qualities, but for the firm stand she has taken in the defence of parliament.

The speaker has, over the centuries, been the voice of the Commons in a centralised political system in which the crown sought to control everything. Even today the powers of the crown remain unaltered, although they are now exercised by the prime minister who can, using the royal prerogatives, take us to war, sign treaties, make laws in Brussels and exercise immense powers of patronage, appointing bishops, judges, peers, ministers, European commissioners all without getting parliamentary consent.

The slow advance towards democracy in this country, by the extension of the franchise, only gave every man and woman a vote at the same age in my lifetime. This conferred on them a power no MP dare ignore, although the people of this country are still denied the right to elect their head of state or members of the second chamber.

There are likely to be more changes in the future, as new centres of power seek to dominate the political agenda. Today Britain, as a member of the EU, can have its laws repealed if they are found to conflict with legislation made by the Council of Ministers, in secret, in Brussels. The Commons has no say in the matter. And if Britain were to join the single currency all major economic decisions would be automatically excluded from any form of democratic accountability through parliament to the electors.

Today the US has military bases in Britain entirely outside our control, from which nuclear strikes can be launched anywhere in the world. These are controlled by the president in Washington without any role for the Commons in Westminster.

The mass media, occupying the position once held by the medieval church, are now very influential and the grand forum of the nation has moved from the chamber to the TV studios. Globalisation has produced multinational corporations which are more powerful than many nation states, currency speculation can inflict serious damage and the IMF, World Bank and WTO, all unelected, have in effect become a world government with no claim to democratic legitimacy.

Set against those new power structures many people ask how their own interests can be effectively represented and indeed what is the future for democracy itself. Tight centralised executive control from Downing Street has replaced cabinet government and transformed parliamentary democracy into a spectator sport, a practice which is unlikely to change, even under a Conservative government.

If we are to be expected to accept a president instead of a prime minister then we need a house of representatives, free to support, amend or reject proposals that come from the government of the day - a genuinely independent legislative assembly. A determined new speaker, armed with the authority of the House and absolutely free from executive control could raise these questions and hand down rulings from the chair which upheld the role of MPs as representing their constituents' interests, making ministers more accountable.

There is no doubt that unless we can restore the vitality of representative democracy more and more people will conclude that they are just pawns in an unending political game to be managed and manipulated for the convenience of those at the top. This may help explain the falling turnout in elections, the growth of apathy and the sense of disenchantment with politics and parliament.

Sooner or later this erosion of democracy has to be faced and corrected if we are to avoid the danger that some rightwing demagogue could come along, as happened in Europe in the 30s and has re-appeared recently in Austria.

Over the centuries all real progress has come from below and parliament has usually been the last place to get the message. Any resumption of the campaign for democracy will have to start outside. That is why, after 50 years in the Commons, I have decided not to stand again so as to be free to devote more time to politics.

What is needed now is a deliberate strategy to make political power accountable and to use democracy to protect us from the abuse of global economic power, which we are told we have to accept. Such a sustained public campaign would have overwhelming public support, especially from those active people who are working for progress but despair at the way the political system excludes them. If the Commons elects another strong speaker it would be a good start in shifting the balance back in our favour.

Tony Benn is a former cabinet minister. He will stand down as MP for Chesterfield at the next election.

fields.headline: The cradle of death
fields.standfirst: West turns a blind eye to Russia's nuclear waste problems
fields.trailText: West turns a blind eye to Russia's nuclear waste problems.
fields.body:
Yuri Pirogov, with his gnarled face, looked older than his 62 years as he took the podium to talk to nuclear experts at an international conference discussing Russia's unsolved nuclear waste problems.

The conference was held as Russia's President Putin and US President Clinton prepared to sign a deal that will involve countries of the G8 top industrial nations funding a huge expansion of nuclear power in Russia, based on plutonium mixed oxide fuel (MOX). Russia wants to build 29 new reactors and consume 33,000kg of former warhead plutonium in its controversial new atomic programme. But in its anxiety to solve the plutonium problem, the west and Russia are turning a blind eye to past practices and Pirogov's current problems. He had a chilling tale to tell.

All his life, save some time as a military mercenary, Pirogov had lived in the village of Atomanova on the eastern banks of the mighty Yenisei River - at nearly 3,500km long, the greatest in Siberia. Atomanova is 5km downstream from a vast nuclear complex formerly called Krasnoyarsk-26, now called the Mining Chemical Combine (MCC), at Zhelenzngorsk, one of three Sellafield-type nuclear combines in Russia.

Built in 1950, it houses a reprocessing plant, nuclear waste stores, a part-built fast breeder plutonium fuel reactor, called RT-2, and a unique plutonium production reactor constructed entirely underground in a vast rock cavern to protect it against US nuclear attack in the Cold War. Zhelenzngorsk is one of 10 former Zatos - secret and closed military cities in Russia - now opened up.

Pirigov said that, before 1988, the villagers of Atomanova did not even suspect that such a nuclear complex existed so close to their homes. But when they noticed large pipes being laid by the far bank of the Yenisei from their village, they inquired what was happening. Soon they discovered the pipes were for liquid nuclear waste disposal.

Officials from the MCC gave the villagers a briefing about radiation effects on humans. With curiosity - and no little fear - aroused, the villagers put questions to the local administration, who knew little more than Pirigov and his neighbours.

Angered but undeterred, the villagers petitioned the Krasnoyarsk Krai, the regional territory government responsible for an area 10 times the size of Britain. Even the professors at the city's university were in the dark about the Zato.

Pirigov said that with the help of Vladimir Mikheev, director of the Krasnoyarsk citizen centre on non-proliferation, the Atomanova villagers finally discovered the pipes were for chanelling the nuclear waste deep underground.

In all, the MCC planned to discharge over 25m cubic metres of plutonium-contaminated wastes deep into the earth. Pirigov was later pestered by the MCC security police, and told: "You are helping the damned Americans with your fuss."

On the nearby bank of the Yenisei, young girls would swim in the unusually warm water. It became clear to the villagers that the warmth had come from nuclear discharges at the MCC. As belated compensation, in 1996, Atomanova was offered 5m roubles to improve the village infrastructure. Two ambulances were bought for 520,000 roubles, yet the village failed to benefit from electricity generated at the reactors across the river.

In support of Pirigov's claims, Dr Irina Osokina, chief of the endocrinology department at the Insititute for Medical Problems of the North, in Krasnoyarsk, unveiled research demonstrating that plutonium contamination in the area around the "special protection zone" at the MCC was between eight and 17 times the measurable plutonium from atmospheric weapons tests.

Radioactive contamination has been found as far as 1,400km downstream on the Yenisei, which pours nearly 20,000 cubic metres of water per second into the Arctic. Expeditions by the Siberian Institute of Biophysics have found "hot" radioactive particles in many spots along the Yenisei riverbank, even at a forest campsite. The institute scientists estimate that the ill-fated campers would have unknowingly received a year's radiation dose in just three hours as they had fun in the forest.

The worst radioactive contamination has been found on Gorodskoi island, near Atomanova, close to the radioactive effluent discharge pipe. Other surveys by the Siberian branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences have found contamination on the island, and at the nearby downstream village of Bolshoi Balchung, up to 1,000 times the caesium-137 discharged in the Chernobyl accident in 1986. Hot particles have also been found in the Yenisei flood plain and at Yeniseik City, nearly 400km north of MCC.

German Kukashin, a former senior nuclear fuel scientist at the Mayak Chemical Combine nuclear complex, told of a serious accident at research reactors at the State Scientific Centre Research Insititute of Atomic Reactors, at Dimitrovgrad, in the Ulyanovsk region east of Moscow. Kukashin was later sacked for his attempts to publicise the accident risks.

The Mayak complex is one of the most polluted places on the planet. In 1957, a nuclear waste storage tank exploded, scattering highly toxic waste over the local villages. They were not evacuated for two weeks, despite the Soviet atomic authorities knowing people had to be moved within 36 hours to ensure protective measures might work.

One village has never been evacuated. Despite being in the centre of the danger zone, the 4,500 people of Muslumova have stayed for decades because it is the local railway halt. Every summer children still flock to the village by rail to see their grandparents. In Yekaterinburg, famous for being the site of the murder in 1919 of the last tsar, Nicholas Romanov and his family, scientists revealed at the public hearings, that by the years 2020/2030 every second child born to parents in the Chelyabinsk region will suffer "severe genetic deficiencies". The Soviet authorities are still not anxious to discuss these problems as they plough ahead with plans for new reactors with new fuel.

A former local state duma (parliament) member, Natalia Mironova and local Chelyabinsk lawyer, Anna Ilyina, told the Guardian that they were now pressing for proper compensation for families afflicted by the Mayak accidents, so far without result.

 David Lowry is a researcher for a number of anti-nuclear MPs

fields.headline: Time to get a life
fields.standfirst: Jenny Sinclair explains why she and many others are fed up with fostering
fields.trailText: Jenny Sinclair explains why she and many others are fed up with fostering
fields.body:
So there is a dire shortage of foster carers for adolescents, we are told. But is it surprising? As somebody who fosters troubled teenagers, I have to say the experience has shattered my idealism and faith in the system.

We all know teenagers can be difficult. Even those from "normal" families put their parents through hell at times. It goes without saying that young people who have been traumatised by negative experiences, then suffered the consequences of being in care, are bound to be problematic.

I recently watched a television chat show obviously designed to promote the government's drive to recruit more foster carers. Unfortunately, the programme reinforced the old- fashioned, sentimental stereotype of fostering, instead of awaking the public to the fact that, if we are to accommodate the growing numbers of adolescents in need of placements, we must change our traditional views of the role of fostering.

Our society is ever more complex and confused, and the teenagers who, for whatever reason, cannot remain with their own families reflect this in their behaviour. Is it not naive to expect well-meaning but untrained people to give up their time, energy and - most importantly - their quality of life in return for pin money, and then wonder why the drop-out rate in fostering is so high?

I foster for an agency which provides experienced carers for what are euphemistically labelled "challenging" youngsters aged 11-18. This scheme promised to "change the face of fostering". We would be seen as equal, full-time workers, receiving a weekly salary in addition to the care allowance. We would be given regular training on different aspects of behaviour management and there would be 24-hour emergency support.

When I first joined, I was fired with enthusiasm. I felt that, at last, steps were being taken towards valuing foster carers as skilled, knowledgeable professionals, and I saw my new job as a career I could really put my heart into. I fully understood that, owing to all the cases of abuse by carers that have come to light, very thorough assessments and monitoring of placements were necessary. What I failed to realise was that the checks were as much about covering the backs of the management as about protecting the children.

Now, two years later, I am disillusioned and very pessimistic about fostering. This is not because of the young people who have been placed with me during this time - although I have had more than my fair share of challenging behaviour to cope with - but because of the unrealistic and unreasonable restrictions placed on myself and my family, and the fact that young people in care do not receive the consideration they deserve.

Nobody, for example, is allowed to stay overnight under my roof unless they have been police checked. (Abuse, apparently, only happens at night). These checks take two to three months, so as soon as I was accepted by the project - and knowing I would have little opportunity to go out to socialise from then on - I got all friends and family members who stay overnight occasionally with us to submit forms for police checks.

Shortly after, a memo was circulated to all carers, stating that unless a person had "substantial, unsupervised contact" with our foster children the agency would not agree (for financial reasons) to carry out the checks. When we pointed out we would never leave our young people in the care of visitors, we were told to say - in order to get the checks done - that we did. I refused because I did not want to portray myself as somebody who leaves her foster children with all and sundry.

So until the project manager agreed, months later, to accept "subject access" police checks, which are not as thorough but can be applied for at police stations, I could not see many of my friends or family who did not live locally. Even my mother and elder daughter were not allowed to sleep at my house. When my sister, who lives abroad, needed to stay with me in a sudden emergency, I was told that if she did I would be classed as "unavailable" and my salary would be stopped.

When my partner's daughter and her family became homeless, he moved in with me temporarily so that they could use his flat. I explained this to my link worker and was informed that, even though my partner had already been investigated as stringently as myself, he would have to move out until a six-month assessment of our relationship had been completed, leaving him homeless.

Then there is discipline. I am expected to teach my foster children social behaviour and acceptance of boundaries, yet I am not allowed to punish them in any way. Even when one of my foster children threatened, "I'll show you who can play games," and then made allegations against me, I was told not to let her feel responsible for what she had done. On one occasion, I needed to phone for help because a 13-year-old girl I was fostering had trashed my house and was attempting to break down my bedroom door. The "emergency assistance" I received was advice to ask friends to come over to give me moral support.

Worst of all is the peremptory treatment of carers and those they care for. I formed a particular bond with a 16-year-old girl during the four months she was with me, only for her to be moved to another carer because our relationship was seen as "too close" and not politically correct - being between a white carer and a mixed-race child. She and I were led to believe the move was to give me "respite", whereas her new (black) carer was aware she would not be returning to me but was instructed not to say so.

I do not regret having returned to fostering. It has been what they call "an experience", and I am convinced it should be redefined as a full-time, decently paid profession - particularly for fostering adolescents. I have heard all the rubbish about this not being a good idea because it would attract people "for the wrong reasons". But why is that logic never applied to doctors or social workers?

Now I've had enough. I am tired of being owned, body and soul, and of having to ask permission for anything I want to do. I am fed up with being expected to put my foster children before the needs of my own family. And I am sick of feeling continually stressed in my own house. In short, I want my life back.

 Jenny Sinclair is the pseudonym of a foster carer in the south of England.

In short, I want my life back.  Jenny Sinclair is the pseudonym of a foster carer in the south of England.

fields.headline: On the ninth life
fields.standfirst: The clean-up campaign following Europe's worst oil spill, in 1998, may be the last hope of saving the Iberian lynx.  Ros Coward reports.
fields.trailText: The clean-up campaign following Europe's worst oil spill, in 1998, may be the last hope of saving the Iberian lynx. Ros Coward reports.
fields.body:
Looking at Coto Doñana in this year's sunshine, it's hard to believe only two years ago it was the site of Europe's worst toxic spill. The lagoons and marshes, now drying up for summer, teem with wildlife. Flamingos move in the shallows among wading birds. There are storks' nests on buildings and every so often a black shadow moves across the marshes; usually it's a black kite but occasionally it's a massive, imperial eagle. Doñana looks like the world heritage site it is, designated thus because its complex wetland ecology sustains an astonishing variety of plant, bird and animal species, including Europe's most endangered carnivore, the Iberian lynx.

Late in April 1998, the wall of the tailings pool of Los Frailles mine in Aznalcollar broke, spilling millions of tons of toxic sludge including cadmium, lead, zinc and mercury, into the river Guadiamar, which in turn feeds into the waters of Doñana national park. The effect was catastrophic. All life was destroyed in that river stretch, including 37 tons of dead fish. Many species have disappeared for good.

The enormous scale of the clean-up operations shows the extent of the disaster. Three dams were built, one after another, to prevent the slick's deadly journey. It finally stopped at the entrance to the national park, spreading out on to surrounding land. Affected farmland, stretching for 15,000 acres, has been permanently decommissioned and for two years bulldozers and trucks have been razing up the surface of the land, ferrying their poisonous load back to Aznalcollar. So far the cost, split between the local council, central government and Boliden, the mine's owners, is estimated at 30,000 pesetas (£112m).

Only one village (successfully) opposed the lorries passing through. Most, whose inhabitants work in the mining industry, downplayed the disaster. Now they prove their confidence by eating the local shellfish again. There's some basis for their optimism. Soil pollution levels are back below danger level after the clean up and initial fears that poisons would enter the groundwater have not been confirmed. But sub-lethal effects of these chemicals are long term and evidence so far is unsettling.

Very high zinc concentrations have been found in plants known for their resistance to pollution; these plants are the main food for several bird species on Doñana. This year, scores of white stork have beak deformities never before seen in Andalusia. Local environmentalists are horrified that after such a near miss the mine is coming back into use without new safeguards and guarantees.

Far from overstating the problem, the disaster has highlighted Doñana's extreme vulnerability. In spite of its undisputed ecological importance, the area is under extreme pressure not only from mining. Spain's rapid development, underscored by European Union subsidies, is just as threatening. Where the national park previously merged ambiguously into scrubland, there is now intensive development. On one approach, field on field of strawberries and other vegetables grow under acres of plastic. On another, Matalascanas has grown up, a concrete jungle of apartments for sand and sea tourism. All around, the old cork forests are disappearing and the European Union is financing new roads in the area.

Doñana biologist, Miguel Delibes describes the area as "uniquely threatened". He says: "Most areas of such exceptional environmental value are fixed landscapes, already defined. But technical advances mean people can use this land now so they want to reclaim and transform it." Delibes, the son of another Miguel Delibes, one of Spain's best known novelists, has been working on Doñana for 30 years studying the Iberian lynx which, although protected there and sometimes used as the region's symbol, now borders on extinction. "The lynx's plight is symbolic of the area's problems," he says.

The Iberian lynx is a beautiful animal, resembling the American bobcat in shape and fluid movement but with a more dramatically spotted coat and a distinctive beard around the face. Although smaller than the African big cats, it is bigger than the European wildcat and more savage. Yet in spite of its charisma, it is now the world's most endangered feline species. There are only 600 in Spain and Portugal. On Doñana, there are only 50 and, even with full protection, they are still illegally hunted and trapped.

It's the lynx's isolation in small, scarcely viable populations that puts them at risk. Like all cats, they are territorial and before they reach a year old the cubs set out to find their own territory, but there's no way out to new mates. One radio-tracked lynx managed to travel 200 miles but turned back to be killed on one of Doñana's fast roads. There's only one healthy captive lynx in the world, at the Doñana Biological Research Centre. Researchers are not allowed to trap her a wild mate, but when one jumped into her enclosure permission was given to extract sperm.

The lynx can survive only within a network of viable habitats. Above all that means the dehesa, the traditional cork forests of Iberia. These give the lynx shelter and its main food, rabbits. When a cork forest falls out of use, due among other things to the increased use of plastic corks, depopulation follows. Then big landowners move in, availing themselves of EU grants for fast-growing timber. Between the late 70s and early 90s vast swathes of eucalyptus were planted. In Portugal, where the entire population of Iberian lynxes is now estimated at only 60, this has been nothing short of an ecological catastrophe.

The Iberian lynx's fate says everything about the failures of European environmental legislation. The 1992 habitats directive was meant to ensure "favourable conservation status" of highly endangered species by making countries provide a network of "Natura 2000" sites. Like all other EU countries, Spain is hopelessly behind with proposals for this while happily channelling EU funds and subsidies into projects which undermine the chance of the lynx's survival.

Ironically, the last best chance for Doñana's lynxes has emerged from the mining accident. For years, the local council heard arguments about the lynxes' need for ecological corridors to other lynx populations. Last year it announced that the decommissioned land around the disaster area would become a "green corridor", land permanently set aside to revert to nature and link up with the Sierra Morena, the other lynx area in Spain.

Although environmentalists worry the corridor might not "hit" the Sierra Morena at the right place, they have still thrown themselves into this project. It's popular with locals for providing alternative employment and promising to attract new tourism. And if it offers hope to Doñana's lynx population, perhaps the toxic spill won't have been a total disaster.

fields.headline: In for life
fields.standfirst: What are high-flying graduates doing in prison?  Wendy Moore on how one charity is changing people's prejudices about society
fields.trailText: What are high-flying graduates doing in prison? Wendy Moore on how one charity is changing people's prejudices about society.
fields.body:
By his own admission, William Orgee has led a sheltered life and developed a narrow view of the world. Brought up on a farm in Worcestershire, he studied geography at Nottingham University, before taking a well-paid job with good prospects at Barclays bank. The wider problems of society passed him by. So when the 23 year old, who works as an assistant to a corporate director at Barclays' Birmingham offices, walked though the main gates of Pentonville prison in London earlier this month, he was understandably nervous.

Orgee already had firm views on law and order. "I was under the impression that all nasty people should be banged up and if they reoffended they should be banged up for longer," he says. A morning behind bars, touring Pentonville's gaunt Victorian corridors and bare 13x6 cells, rounded off by a chat about the judicial system with an inmate who is serving time for drug offences and whose parents are both crack addicts, gave him pause for thought.

Even more significant in making him rethink his opinions was the chance to discuss his reactions with other young people on the tour from a mixed bag of jobs in the private, public and voluntary sectors.

"It has challenged my views. I see things in 3D instead of 2D now," he says in the wake of the prison visit. Now, he thinks, he understands why people may become mixed up in crime. He no longer believes prison is the sole answer. "If someone has done a crime I don't think they should just be locked up, but should be looked at as an individual," says the enlightened Orgee.

The transformation is the result of a week-long programme, Navigator, run by charity Common Purpose. Aimed at high-fliers under 30 in their first careers in the private, public and voluntary sectors, it offers a crash course in how modern urban society works. The hope is to grow informed, active citizens for the future.

As well as touring a prison, participants visit a housing regeneration scheme, a hospital and a drugs project; undertake exercises which challenge their attitudes; and get a chance to question panels of leading movers and thinkers from government, the arts, business and caring professions. At the end of the course, each participant produces a project, with help from a leading expert in the field, which they later present to top executives at their own organisation. And ultimately, each course graduate is asked to say what they plan to do personally as a result of their investigations.

The idea, explains programme director Lucy Aspinall, is to encourage people to look beyond themselves and their organisations to see the interconnecting pieces of the city jigsaw. "It changes their lives," she says. "Several have said they will never look at the world in the same way as they did." One civil servant on last year's programme was so impressed by a school visit that she is now training to become a teacher.

Crucially, by throwing together people from public, private and voluntary areas, the programme challenges preconceived notions about those sectors. "It is a big eye-opener for the private sector to find out not everyone in the voluntary sector knits yoghurt at lunchtime," says Aspinall. One past member from business came away astonished to find voluntary sector staff were "almost good enough to work in the private sector". But learning is not all one way. Those in the public and voluntary spheres learn "corporate speak" from their business counterparts and discover that their aims and skills are not necessarily at odds.

Navigator is one of several programmes run by Common Purpose, an educational charity founded little more than a decade ago. Other schemes, with the same general theme, are aimed at senior professionals, people over 50 and school pupils, and the principle has since been exported abroad. The charity's income comes from course fees, with businesses generally subsidising voluntary groups, and private sector sponsorship. Navigator, which has been dubbed the "street-smart MBA", was launched last year and now runs annually in London, Edinburgh and Belfast.

Not everyone on the Navigator programme has such a cathartic experience as Orgee, who disarmingly admits that he began each day with a "narrow set of views" which had changed by the evening. But most of the 22 participants, from organisations including the police, NHS, BBC, Thames Water and Refugee Council, come away somewhat wiser.

"It helps knowing what some of the people I talk to have been through," says Clare Riches, 25, a fundraiser with a London housing association, after meeting Ron, a gently spoken young man about to be released from Pentonville under the experimental tagging scheme.

Stephen Cave, a 26-year-old solicitor with the Department of Environment, Transport and Regions, says the week has highlighted how social issues cannot be seen in isolation. "If you have a reasonable upbringing and reasonable support it is so much easier to achieve what we have achieved," he says. "Perhaps these people haven't had that."

Bhavin Patel, 22, who also works for Barclays after graduating from King's College London last year, says the programme has convinced him that education is the key to changing society. "I never really knew about the poverty that happened in London," says Patel, after visiting an east end housing estate. He is now writing a project on child poverty which he will present to Barclays' managers. He believes many companies have too narrow a view on life and aims to keep in touch with people, such as staff from the Refugee Council, he has met during the week.

Previous Navigator participants have generated valuable contacts. Paula Ross, 27, chief executive of the medical charity Bart's City Life Saver, keeps in touch with the Department of Health civil servant she met on last year's London programme and they each agreed to shadow the other to gain insight into their different worlds. Similar partnerships have emerged from other Common Purpose courses. A senior partner in a law firm, which was asked to help with the bursary for a black headteacher, now meets regularly with the teacher to talk through common issues, like budgeting and personnel.

Magistrate Sandie Blandford, who has helped Navigator participants muddle their way through the criminal justice maze, is herself a Common Purpose graduate. "I just found it so valuable," says Blandford, who works as a chief immigration officer at Heathrow. "It gives you a chance to look at areas you don't know anything about." She forged links with another participant working with a charity for people with learning disabilities and now helps out by staging mock job interviews for his clients.

Certainly as far as William Orgee is concerned, life will never be the same again. He reflects: "I shall certainly be a lot more open-minded."

Changing hearts and minds

Common Purpose is an apolitical educational charity launched in 1989 to bring together key workers in private, public and voluntary sectors in an effort to improve cities. More than 10,000 people have been through its programmes. It runs a range of events, with the same general aim, targeted at different groups. They include:

Matrix runs in more than 30 cities, over 11 days during one year; aimed at senior policy makers.

Profile offers a two-day briefing on what makes a city tick; for experienced leaders new to the city.

20/20 a five-day programme just starting to work at national level; for emerging leaders.

Your Turn brings together 14 year olds from different schools, to learn about their city.

Navigator five-day programme for "rising stars" under 30.

What Next designed for older people looking to change the way they live or work.

fields.headline: Front... to back
fields.trailText: A couple from Cirencester, Gloucestershire, have just been on holiday to the Isle of Man for the 50th year in a row.
fields.body:
Man's best friends A couple from Cirencester, Gloucestershire, have just been on holiday to the Isle of Man for the 50th year in a row. Western Daily Press, 29.6.00 (June Newman, Chichester)

Bending the rules The vicar of a church in Birmingham had to explain to the city's bishop that she could not kneel during a service because of injuries suffered when she used to play football.

Birmingham Post, 5.7.00 (Monica Foot, Birmingham)

Arabian lite A gardener from Stourbridge, West Midland, who makes slug traps baited with beer has devised a non-alcoholic model in response to a sales order from Saudi Arabia. Express and Star, 5.7.00 (C Caldwell, Stourbridge)

Deep embarrassment One of the paramedics in the ambulance called out when a man fell down a manhole in the garden of his home in Marlborough, Wiltshire, was his wife. Yorkshire Post, 7.7.00 (Sally England, Sheffield)

Rocket manners Fireworks with silencers were used at a ball at Powderham Castle, near Exeter, to avoid scaring pregnant deer in the grounds. Birmingham Evening Mail, 7.7.00 (Simon Harley, Redditch)

Named and shamed A "guess the goat's name" competition at a village fete near Horsham, Sussex, had to be abandoned when the animal ran away and its owner called out, "Come back, Jake." Birmingham Evening Mail, 29.6.00 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Strong drink Two dustmen in Harpenden, Hertfordshire, were taken to hospital after being overcome by fumes from containers of concentrated orange juice. St Albans Review, 5.7.00 (M Johnston, St Albans)

Missing link Parents are now able to check up on an internet link being piloted at a school in Holloway, north London, to see whether their children are playing truant. Islington Gazette, 15.6.00 (Elwyn Griffiths, London N1)

Spirited response A psychic expert is offering to help boost the housing market in Ipswich, Suffolk, by exorcising ghosts and spirits from properties which will not sell.

Birmingham Evening Mail, 3.7.00 (M Harbourne, Birmingham)

Swept to sea The driver of a council sweeper truck cleaning the lower decks of a freighter in Heysham harbour, Lancashire, was at sea for four hours after the ship set sail with him still on board. Lancaster Guardian, 7.7.00 (B Teasdale, Lancaster)

Plenty of front A burglar bundled out of the back door by a couple after they caught him in their house in Plymouth knocked and asked to be let out of the front because he couldn't climb over the garden wall. Western Morning News, 10.7.00 (Nicola Neale, Sidmouth)

Cod excuse Coastguards and police called off a full-scale search operation at Aberavon, south Wales, when it was discovered that a man who had left his clothes on the beach had just gone to buy some fish and chips. South Wales Evening Post, 6.7.00 (Patricia Glynn, Swansea)

Growing pain A man from Lower Peover, Cheshire, was injured when his car crashed into a tree he planted in the village as a contribution to the Britain in Bloom competition. Birmingham Evening Mail, 22.6.00 (H Lamont, Smethwick

Flagged intent Parish councillors in Cuckfield, West Sussex, have decided to shame irresponsible dog owners by using yellow flags to mark each pile of excrement left in the churchyard. Mid-Sussex Times, 6.7.00 (T Hallett, Burgess Hill)

 Cuttings, preferably from local papers, which reflect interesting or amusing aspects of life in Britain, must be sent on a postcard (with source) to: Society, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. £15 will be paid for each one used.

fields.headline: Stark vision
fields.standfirst: Known for his trenchant opinions, maverick historian David Starkey talks to  Chris Arnot  about what's wrong with Britain's economy while below, Charlotte Denny, the Guardian's economics reporter, argues back
fields.trailText: Known for his trenchant opinions, maverick historian David Starkey talks to Chris Arnot about what's wrong with Britain's economy.
fields.body:
A copy of David Starkey's book on Elizabeth I lies on a long stool, next to one of the author's feet. He needs to take the weight off it, having just returned from a visit to hospital. A physiotherapist has apparently been working on an area which some of his adversaries in academia and the media have been trying to discover for years: his achilles heel.

Starkey's waspish wit and trenchant libertarian-Conservative views have guaranteed him plenty of air time and review space to supplement his day job as a historian at the London School of Economics. Channel 4 recently broadcast the televisionseries to go with his book on Elizabeth. And on August 6 he will pop up again, on BBC1 this time, as an interviewee in Peter Jay's series on the history of money.

Starkey's appearance in The Road to Riches is little more than a cameo role, or "vignette" as he prefers to call it. But he is characteristically disruptive, thrusting the equivalent of a stick into the wheels of Jay's stately, linear progress through the history of the industrial revolution. Starkey points out that the technological change that transformed this country's economy would never have happened without a massive demand for household goods.

"We've got to stand the idea of the industrial revolution on its head. Market first, smoke-stack industry second," he tells Jay as they travel around Bath on a bus. The city beyond the window is, he says, the first designed just to attract the consumer. Back home in his elegant mid-Victorian house in Highbury, north London, he rests his other foot on the stool, leans back and warms to his theme. "Bath was the Bluewater of the 18th century," he says, "only with better taste. It worked because of the extraordinarily wide distribution of wealth in England, compared with continental Europe. Look at the substantial number of Georgian houses, items of furniture and silverware which have survived and you begin to appreciate the scale of this middling prosperity."

On screen and at home, he quotes approvingly from Dr Bernard de Mandeville, a Dutch émigré who came to England in the early 18th century and put himself at odds with the Church. It was not virtue and self-restraint but vice that drove a powerful economy, he maintained. And Starkey agrees.

"Suppose we practised charity, self- denial and honesty, women were chaste and we didn't fight wars," he muses, paraphrasing de Mandeville. "The entire economy would collapse. What happened in the 18th century was a revolution in the appurtenances of living. A significant number of people had bigger houses with more rooms for possessions. I would argue that there's a straight line from there to the America of the 21st century."

What about the UK? "We're getting there," he says. "The economies that thrive are the consuming economies."

Ironically enough, it was winning the environmental studies prize at primary school in 1956 that set him off on this train of thought. He was handed a book called The History of Everyday Things in England and it seems to have had a profound effect on him. Indeed, he removes both feet from the stool and limps over to pluck it lovingly from one of his crowded shelves. Then - irony upon irony - this avowed rightwinger goes on to recommend that I re-read English Journey by that old socialist, JB Priestley.

"As long ago as the 1930s, Priestley could see that the North was in decline and the Midlands were drifting," he says. "Even then the future lay in the new America: those art deco factories around the North Circular Road [in London], turning out vacuum cleaners and cameras."

Starkey proudly proclaims himself to be a supporter of the "candyfloss economy", being acutely conscious that "shopping matters". The old smoke-stack industries, he feels, were allowed to outstay their sell-by date because of the second world war and the trend of post-war governments to buck the markets with the help of a civil service "designed to administer an empire rather than an entrepreneurial society".

The coming of Margaret Thatcher in 1979 began "the long march" away from all that. But if Starkey has his way, we'll be marching back towards the 18th century in search of a solution to the social problems thrown up by our 21st-century consumer economy. What we need, apparently, is a return to craft working and domestic service.

"We should recognise that only around a third of the population can be in internationally competitive jobs," he says. "So we need to develop a middle-band craft economy like the one the French have so cleverly maintained. The wealthy are bored with mass-produced goods. But to meet the growing demand for craftsmanship there would have to be a reinstatement of apprenticeships.

"At the same time we should be thinking about reconstituting a genuine service economy. The mere mention of domestic service brings some people out in spots of outrage, but there is a crying need for relatively low-level employment. It's ridiculous that people at the top are killing themselves in demanding jobs and then coming home to mow their own lawns.

"If Blair and Brown are serious about cutting long-term benefits then those at the bottom are going to have to be found work. Floating the idea that every kid in Brixton can become a whizkid at information technology is dishonest."

If there seems to be a whiff of racism about that remark, then perhaps it's misleading. Whatever else you might think about David Starkey, he does appear to be an enthusiastic champion of minorities - by race, religion and sexual orientation - albeit as vital contributors to a dynamic economy. "Often excluded from the normal processes of government and mainstream society, they've had no alternative but to work hard and make money," he says, citing the Jews, the Huguenots, the Quakers, many modern Asians and "increasing numbers of West Indian women".

Starkey himself has links with two minority groups. He's openly gay and he was brought up a Quaker. Not that he has much time for the Quakers. "When I was growing up, they had lost their hard-headed commercial edge and become rather socialist, like the Guardian at prayer." It's evident that the young David was only too happy to escape from his rather stiflingly austere upbringing in the north of England - first to Cambridge University and then to London. "You could say that my life since has been a sustained act of luxurious rebellion," he confides with a mischievous smile.

He looks on his fellow homosexuals as a very significant economic force, not only as creators in fields like fashion and interior design but also as above-average spenders. "We don't have children," he says, "and a large percentage of us tend to be in high- income jobs. The level of disposable income is enormous".

No wonder Starkey looks pleased with himself, despite his achilles heel. He's in demand as author, pundit and critic, boosting his income from academia and enabling him to fulfil what he would deem a vital social role - as a rampant consumer.

A nation of shop assistants?

Is David Starkey right to suggest that consuming things matters more than making them? It's certainly the case that Britain, like most advanced economies, is shifting from an industrial economy to a services-based economy, writes Charlotte Denny .

Twenty years ago, manufacturing accounted for about a quarter of the economy; today, it has shrunk to just over a fifth. Jobs in manufacturing now account for 16% of total employment; 20 years ago, it was 28%. The new jobs are all in the service sector, such as retailing, business services and call centres.

Conventional economic thinking has always portrayed this shift as a natural progression - a sort of economic version of the theory of evolution. Advanced economies will find their industrial base is gradually eroded by competition from low-wage economies in the developing world. The US, as always, is seen to be the leader; manufacturing there accounts for just 15% of jobs.

So does it matter if we end up as a nation of shoppers and shopkeepers? The problem is that many of the new jobs in the service economy are just not that attractive in terms of pay and conditions. The advantage of the manufacturing sector is that it provides relatively well paid jobs for a wide range of abilities.

Eamonn Fingleton, author of In Praise of Hard Industries, points out that the countries with the highest per capita incomes - Germany, Switzerland, Japan - all have strong manufacturing bases. "This is a reflection of the fact that [manufacturing] workers are typically backed by large amounts of capital and proprietary production know-how," he says. "These greatly enhance workers' productivity, and greater productivity is the royal road to higher wages."

Britain could become a nation of shop assistants and domestic service workers - with a lucky few employed in the professions, able to enjoy the fruits of the consumer economy. But as personal service and retail jobs are among the worst paid occupations, there is a strong case for seeking to remain a nation of producers rather than sellers.

 The Road to Riches is on BBC1 on Sunday week (August 6) at 8pm

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Hang on to the holistic
fields.body:
Hang on to the holistic

I warmly support the proposal for a new category of multi-skilled healthcare worker to co-ordinate provision for elderly users (A juggling of power, July 12). I am, however, alarmed by the likelihood that such a worker will be placed under control of the NHS.

I speak from experience of being old and suffering from cumulative decrepitude. As such, my needs are multiple. The NHS treats each of my ailments separately, so that I am parcelled out between a range of consultants at their discretion. To them, I am a patient - not a person.

Community care services, on the other hand, are organised to deal with me as a human being with complex needs which go far beyond the strictly medical. To them, the focus is on me, not on my complaints.

I would urge the health secretary, Alan Milburn, to listen to the advice of his own action team on partnerships that community care should continue as a specialism in its own right. Placed under control of the NHS, its role must inevitably be that of a mere handmaiden to mop up the mess created by others. That would spell disaster for all who, like me, are dependent on the comprehensive service offered by community care.
Margaret Simey
Liverpool

The long walk from violence

The excellent article on domestic violence and the NHS (Suffering in silence, July 19) highlighted some interesting points. But there is, as always, another side to the coin.

As a health visitor working in a large city, I was aware of this problem and felt I was doing my utmost. Mary, with three young children, was being systematically abused by her partner and lived in fear of him. She confided in me and I supported, but did not lead, her to arrange a move. After leaving him and living in a hostel for two days, she returned to him and his abuse. This was worse than before, and subsequently no health professional was allowed in the house for whatever reason.

Acceptance of domestic violence is a symptom of our society; it reflects the way we turn a blind eye to anything uncomfortable. It is not only, or even primarily, the responsibility of health professionals. Surely it is up to each and every one of us to nurture a society that cares, that is aware and is prepared to do something to help anyone who needs it.
Pamela Eaton
Chief officer
Blackpool community health council

Friends of Rainham

The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds's acquisition of the Ministry of Defence's part of Rainham marshes (Eco soundings, July 19) is good news for those of us concerned with protection of London's wild places. However, the impression is given that the RSPB has been campaigning to save the marshes for 20 years.

In fact, it has been others such as London Wildlife Trust, Friends of Rainham Marshes and Friends of the Earth that have been carrying the candle for the marshes against many threats since the 80s. To many of us working to conserve biodiversity in the capital, the RSPB has been a johnny-come-lately.

I hope the RSPB can turn Rainham marshes into a treasured place for London's wildlife and people, but it is a shame that it appears to have taken the lion's share of the kudos for work undertaken by Londoners.
Ray Noutria
London

Strategy on HIV

The mergers among HIV charities led by the Terrence Higgins Trust do indeed provide a welcome opportunity to reduce duplication in service delivery to people with HIV (Survival of the fittest, July 19). But this reconfiguration of the sector in itself is not a panacea for the current lack of strategic coordination in response to HIV. The government's strategy for England has taken nearly three years to develop since it was first announced.

In London, where the majority of HIV cases are reported, there has been little pan-London commissioning of services, resulting in a patchwork of provision. Body Positive, the oldest HIV self-help group which closed its doors suddenly in May, was in part an avoidable casualty of this lack of strategic planning.

The National Aids Trust recently published radical proposals for the fight against HIV. Establishing a pan-London strategy, quality standards and a co-ordinated social research programme are just some of the things we propose. These ideas need to be embraced if the mergers of today are to result in appropriate services and fewer people with HIV tomorrow.
Derek Bodell
Chief executive
National Aids Trust

Alien context

It is an interesting experience when you read your own words in a major newspaper in a context that implies something entirely alien. I was quoted as "admitting" that relatively few psychologists work in the field of schizophrenia (It's good to talk, June 28).

Psychologists are actively working in the field of "serious mental illness" and have much to offer in terms of scientific understanding and psychological therapy. As our report (Recent Advances in Understanding Mental Illness and Psychotic Experiences) highlights, however, these developments are being made against a mindset that views "schizophrenia" as a purely biomedical disease, diagnosis as valid and reliable, "schizophrenics" as unpredictable and dangerous, drugs as our only hope and psychology as applicable only to "middle-class angst".

As a profession, clinical psychology is working to change assumptions. Clearly we have far to go.
Peter Kinderman
Reader in clinical psychology
Liverpool University

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Field of dreams | Short answers | Ploughing in money
fields.body:
Field of dreams
Tony Blair's comments to the Sort Out Sellafield campaign would confirm his ability to fall out of touch with the public mood. He promised SOS, when a delegation visited No 10 last week, that he would raise with the Japanese at G8 talks the need for them to sign new reprocessing contracts with British Nuclear Fuels. The meeting was less than a week after Labour's policy forum produced a blueprint for the next party manifesto, calling for reprocessing to end and BNFL to move into waste management. Helen Liddell, the energy minister, and the PM are also clearly not listening to the DTI select committee of MPs, which rapped the government for having no understanding of the company's finances and operations and asked ministers to get a grip. While Blair continues at the helm, Sellafield's future is clearly secure.

Short answers
Outside the DTI in Scotland the mumbo jumbo of nuclear economics is being confronted. The Lib-Dem MSP, Tavish Scott, has discovered that Scotland's nuclear power generators are not paying the full cost of inspections by SEPA, the devolved environment protection agency, which was paid £48,000 for inspections at Torness nuclear station, £47,000 for work at BNFL's Chapelcross and £186,000 for the UK Atomic Authority's Dounreay complex. The true cost, according to parliamentary answers, is £61,000 each for the two power stations and £280,000 at the UKAEA - a shortfall of £127,000. Clearly, the actual costs of the nuclear industry are still not properly accounted for.

Ploughing in money
Advanta Seeds, the company that accidently sold to British farmers rape seed contaminated with GM genes, reveals it had its own contingency plan to avert the crisis before Nick Brown, the agriculture secretary, stepped in and advised farmers to plough up the offending crop. Advanta wanted to segregate the crop, harvest it as normal and then export it to a market with consumers less sensitive than those in Europe. According to the company, when Brown's preference for a plough-in became known it was "a complete surprise". Advanta, in a memo to MPs, says Brown's advice was unnecessary and wasteful. It is consulting lawyers to see if they can recoup from the government the money they have since had to pay out in compensation to farmers.

The true cost, according to parliamentary answers, is £61,000 each for the two power stations and £280,000 at the UKAEA - a shortfall of £127,000. fields.headline: Faith in the community
fields.standfirst: Mary Walmsley, a nun with a calling for education
fields.trailText: Profile: Mary Walmsley, a nun with a calling for education
fields.body:
The revelation which transformed Sister Aelred, a nun teaching at the Institute of the Blessed Virgin Mary in York, into Mary Walmsley, director of the East London Schools' Fund, administering a £1m-plus annual wage bill, came 10 years ago at a Church Action on Poverty conference in Leeds.

She was 51 and on sabbatical as head of lower school at All Saints, the comprehensive formed by amalgamation of the Bar Convent grammar and Catholic secondary moderns in York. "I had burnt out," she recalls. "I had done 30 years teaching without a break."

Sister Mary - she has long since returned to her baptismal name - had taught in primary, secondary and boarding schools, but was without experience outside Catholicism. "I had no real experience even of other Christians, let alone other faiths. At the conference, an elderly white person was talking about the needs of the Bangladeshi immigrants in Tower Hamlets. She said 500 had no school places. I thought: 'I need to know more.'"

Through that contact, she began work in London's east end, initially in Tower Hamlets at Central Foundation, a girl's school with mainly Muslim pupils. Central Foundation put her in touch with Langdon Park in Poplar, east London, the state comprehensive in which the schools' fund, which runs home-school liaison and truancy services, had started in 1977.

The fund's founder director, Bridget Cramp, recruited her as the sixth worker and she became director on Cramp's retirement in 1995. The charity then worked in 25 schools. Now it has 83 schools on its books, a staff of 100, and it offers consultancy to other charities.

Sister Mary's first job as director was to set up a professional financial administration. A year ago, she handed on the administrative directorship to become development director, setting up the consultancy, School Home Support UK, and running staff mentoring and a welfare fund for families. These arms, she says, help the administrators stay in touch with grassroots needs.

"The issue is always the same - attendance. It is the underlying causes that change. Every application is different. We have just had a sixth-form student living alone and working in McDonald's who wanted a month off for revision."

Her directorship might seem a far cry from her religious life, but it is, she says, in the tradition of Mary Ward, founder of her order. She was a 17th-century Yorkshire woman who went to prison for her right to educate.

Mary Walmsley was born in Hertfordshire, daughter of a teacher mother and a father who worked for London Midland and Scottish railways. The family spent annual holidays in Yorkshire. "One day, my parents said why don't we live in York," she recalls.

For the young Mary, 15 and working for O-levels, moving was disruptive. "But I survived." She returned south to train as a primary teacher, then taught for two years before going as a novice nun to a convent in Ascot, Berkshire. "In the first year, we did the washing up and sorting clothes for our boarding school. In the second year, I did some teaching. We did everything, made meals, played games, put them to bed."

In 1976, she was sent to York when the city was going comprehensive and her order realised the Bar Convent school had to amalgamate. It was a time of religious upheaval, with nuns moving out of the walled institution into the community. Two of her closest friends left the order, but she did not have that struggle. "I work better from a community," she says.

At the grammar school, she was put in charge of year seven. On amalgamation, she applied for the headship of All Saints lower school. It was her first experience of applying, previous moves having been directed by the order. "When I went to York, I was just summoned to the parlour and told," she says

All Saints was, she says, "a lovely school, truly comprehensive". But it did not prepare her for London. When she said she needed a break, her "provincial" - the head of the order in Britain - suggested she move to a small house being established in north London. Until the Leeds conference, six weeks after she moved, she had no idea what work she might do in the capital.

The Central Foundation school put her on "the steepest learning curve", she says. "The Muslim families were a revelation. They were so hospitable, but it was so sensitive. I felt very helpless. I had done some work in York on inter-faith, but it was all from books, totally head stuff."

Now, a decade of sharp-end experience later, Sister Mary is about to return to York to become superior of the 400-year-old Bar convent, running its conference and resource centres. She will, she says, be going back a much rounder person. She found the administration of the schools' fund sometimes tedious, dealing with payrolls and pensions. "One of the hardest things is to be a good employer," she acknowledges. "The interests are totally mixed."

Now it is time to put something back into the order. As superior, she says, the buck will stop with her. But after the east end, it will be like stepping back in time. "There are still very few non-white faces. Maybe there will be some work to do."

fields.headline: Dark side of the economy
fields.standfirst: Laurie Taylor
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
One of the commonest assumptions made by politicians when they turn their attention to the causes of crime is that "bad" leads to "bad". (Take your pick from bad genes, bad parenting, bad neighbourhood and bad companions). It will, therefore, be fascinating to see how seriously Blair and Straw react to research evidence, from Dick Hobbs and colleagues at Durham University, which shows that if we want to know the reasons for the dramatic recent increase in violent crime we need to look no further than the exciting expansion of the "night-time economy" in our city centres.

Manchester, Leeds and Glasgow have led the way in a series of urban "beauty contests" in which increasingly liberal attitudes to alcohol and entertainment licensing help provide a better "image" of one's town and attract the type of massive capital investment which is no longer forthcoming from the office or retail market.

Last year, Mike Payne, of First Leisure, confidently said: "There has been a change in the city centre environment. Councils encourage bars. Now the nightclub scene is where the future is." Payne can hardly be accused of talking up his own business. The statistics show that in 1993 there were 142m admissions to nightclubs, 199m by 1998, and by 2002 it is expected to rise to 238m. The anticipated revenue from this growth according to Mintel is £2.5bn.

It isn't the mere increase in numbers that causes drunken brawling but the compactness of many of the leisure zones that have been created by an alliance of local authorities and big business. In Manchester, as many as 90,000 people pack into a small buzzing city centre area that, in Hobbs's words, "floats on alcohol". In Nottingham, 30,000 people jostle for admission to over 380 licensed premises.

What concerns Hobbs is the uncontrolled nature of this situation. Hooliganism at football matches was gradually checked by the development of major new forms of regulation but, he says, "we've got mini Hillsboroughs and Heysels going on every Friday and Saturday night in our towns: stabbings, shootings, severe beatings and racial and sexual harassment".

Any control that does exist in these settings is largely in the hands of bouncers; one estimate suggests that, on a weekend evening in Nottingham, there are around 400 bouncers on duty and between 12-14 police officers. "The state," says Hobbs, "has got to recognise that there's a major problem here, and not just say it's young people going through a stage".

 Laurie Taylor talks to Professor Dick Hobbs about violence and the night-time economy on Radio 4's Thinking Allowed, 4 pm today

fields.headline: Clipped wings
fields.standfirst: Deportation protests spread to airports
fields.trailText: Deportation protests spread to airports.
fields.body:
A British Airways plane was forced to abandon take-off after being targeted as part of a wave of new-style airport protests by campaigners against deportation of asylum seekers. Campaign groups Cage and the Bristol Defend Asylum Seekers Campaign used tactics learned from activists in Europe, who lobby check-in queues and board flights to get deported asylum seekers removed.

British groups last week began leafleting the check-in queues of BA flights from Heathrow and Gatwick that were due to carry deported asylum seekers to Germany. Under the Dublin convention, Britain can deport asylum seekers if they have come via another EU state.

Campaigners succeeded in getting two asylum seekers removed from flights and their deportations deferred. In one case, at Heathrow, the captain of a flight to Frankfurt refused to take off until Salim Rambo, a 23-year-old asylum-seeker from the Democratic Republic of Congo, was removed, along with a protester.

Rambo, a farmer and political activist who had been in Britain for eight months, later spoke to the Guardian from a detention room at Heathrow. He said Germany had previously rejected his asylum application. "Home means death."

In the second case, protesters from the Bristol anti-deportation group leafleted passengers at Gatwick and one activist boarded a Munich flight due to carry a deported Kurdish asylum seeker, 34-year-old Amanj Gafor. But he had already been taken off the flight after the group approached Valerie Davey, Labour MP for Bristol West.

Michael Taylor, of the Bristol group, said it would be the first of many protests. The group planned to ask people to donate "air miles" so activists could board flights and refuse to sit down until deported asylum-seekers were removed. The group was also appealing to the pilots' union, Balpa, to refuse to fly planes with deportees on board.

 Bristol Defend Asylum Seekers Campaign can be contacted at bdasc@hotmail.com; Cage: www.veggies.org.uk/cage or telephone 07931 401962
