fields.headline: Cure or curse?
fields.standfirst: Tomorrow a new plan for the health service is laid before us.  Charles Webster, official historian of the NHS, fears it may be just another botch job
fields.trailText: Tomorrow a new plan for the health service is laid before us. Charles Webster, official historian of the NHS, fears it may be just another botch job.
fields.body:
The new national plan for the NHS, due to be launched tomorrow, is being hailed the biggest overhaul of the health service since its creation in 1948. It signifies a fresh start in the government's modernisation campaign, designed to boost confidence in the ability of the NHS to raise standards to levels our fellow Europeans take for granted. But in the light of hard experience, people will wonder, understandably, whether once again they are being handed a false prospectus. They will need some convincing that this latest overhaul is superior to all those past efforts that governments would rather like them to forget.

The historical record confirms that such scepticism is justified. The 20th century was littered with botched refits of the service, with the time intervals between them growing progressively shorter. This galloping instability of policy has been damaging to morale within the NHS and to public confidence.

The characteristics of the healthcare problem have long been familiar. As far back as 1920, the Dawson report identified the challenge and provided a cogent outline of a scheme for a modern health service. Dawson acknowledged that "insufficiency of organisation" was already preventing the advantages of modern medical knowledge reaching the people.

That report proposed a remarkably far-sighted plan for a co-ordinated system of primary, secondary and tertiary care, based on a system of health centres and involving the unification of preventive and curative medicine. Despite the acknowledged wisdom of this scheme, in major respects it still remains largely unrealised.

Tragically, the Dawson scheme was left to gather dust, with the important consequence that already during the interwar period, Britain was begin ning to slip down the league tables of healthcare. Even at the start of the second world war, when action to modernise healthcare was inescapable, the government failed to take decisive action. Its hand was finally forced by William Beveridge, who insisted that his scheme for social security must be underpinned by his "assumption B", entailing commitment to a comprehensive health service.

This broke the log jam, but the government squandered its opportunity and spent the rest of the war squabbling with the British Medical Association over the shape of a future health service. Horsetrading ended with a blueprint of impossible complexity that was incapable of implementation. By supreme good fortune, however, the health portfolio of the 1945 Labour government went to Aneurin Bevan, the youngest member of Clem Attlee's cabinet. Bevan had the audacity to scrap the previous plans and adopt an entirely different framework. Although his scheme was very much a hasty contrivance, involving some important concessions to vested interests, it proved an adequate working arrangement that persisted for some 25 years.

The main problem during this period was resource starvation, a difficulty that set in at an early stage and famously led to Bevan's resignation from the government.

From the mid-60s on, a decade of deliberation over reorganisation represented a staggering record of ineptitude on the part of both Labour and Conservative governments. The result was a worst-of-worlds blueprint in the form of the 1974 reorganisation.

This promised "a fully integrated health service" capable of making up for lost time and realising the ambitious humanitarian objectives adopted in 1948. This goal was to be attained through imposition of a "sound management structure created at all levels". Governments were initially confident that the management solution would clear up the problems of the NHS without calling for additional resources. And, at least initially, the new system attracted a positive response from within the service.

However, outside critics were sceptical, seeing the reforms as what the independent office of health economics called a "political device intended not to alter standards of health care but to impress the public with merely symbolic changes". At first, the government and NHS establishment fought to preserve the essence of the new system, but support melted away and it soon became evident that the 1974 reorganisation was a gigantic mistake.

This was a watershed. From the 70s on, every year was dogged by crisis. Cosmetic changes were tried, but under the relentless pressure of resource starvation it became evident the creaking system was under intolerable strain. Despite growing public alarm, however, no attempt was made to achieve a new consensus on the way forward. Instead, as a response to the winter crisis of 1987, the Thatcher government embarked on a confidential review, which launched the NHS into its "internal market" reforms.

Announced as the biggest overhaul of the NHS since its creation, these offered all the benefits that had been claimed for the 1974 reorganisation. The internal market blueprint was sold in 1991 with a far more sophisticated public relations campaign than that used 17 years previously, and an appearance of success was achieved by a short-lived burst of additional spending. This secured temporary relief from the relentless cycle of crisis, but the spending controls were soon reapplied and no amount of public relations spin was able to prevent collapse of public confidence.

The Labour opposition deftly exploited the public mood and in this undoubtedly contributed to its massive electoral success in 1997. Within a matter of months, the new government - with Frank Dobson at the helm of health - came up with its own blueprint for the future. Conscious of the momentous changes it was introducing, the white paper of December 1997, The New NHS, borrowed its title from Bevan's leaflet describing the NHS in 1948.

Dobson announced that his scheme was a 10-year programme of modernisation. And Labour invested so much confidence in its own form of "integrated care" that it felt able to commit itself to the Tories' parsimonious spending plans - with the inevitable consequence that the NHS once more plunged back into its cycle of crisis. Now, with Dobson thrown overboard, health secretary Alan Milburn is starting afresh with yet another 10-year modernisation programme, promising a more radical approach than previously adopted.

Milburn, however, possesses one incomparable advantage denied all of his predecessors. For the first time in the history of the health service, he is promised that the level of resources will rise commensurately with the massive scale of the task to which he is committed. To stand a chance of success, he must demand that the promise is fulfilled and renewed.

 Charles Webster is a fellow of All Souls College, Oxford, and is official historian of the NHS

fields.headline: Born homeless
fields.standfirst: Plight of being pregnant and in a hostel
fields.trailText: Plight of being pregnant and in a hostel.
fields.body:
With many young, single women facing motherhood while living in hostels for the homeless, a report this week reveals confusion among agencies there to help them - and explodes the myth that the easy way for a teenager to get council housing is to become a mum.

One in four women residents of London hostels in the 16 to 24 age range was pregnant last year, says the report by Health Action for Homeless People, part of the charity Crisis. Launched yesterday by Tessa Jowell, minister for women, the report says that with most such women choosing not to have an abortion, their problems are compounded by wrangles over accommodation when the baby is due. Some hostels evict women late in their pregnancy; staff at other hostels have to go to court to force local authorities to fulfil their duty to house single mums-to-be.

Some councils put these women in B&Baccommodation, a stop-gap arrangement which often lasts months. This compounds the problems of women who may have ended up in hostels because of abuse and neglect within their own families, and raises the odds that infants brought up in such circumstances will ultimately be taken into care.

At the heart of the muddle lies confusion over what hostels should be doing. The report, Homeless Young Woman and Pregnancy, says hostels should adopt policies on the provision of information, advice, support and training for residents. This would cover sexual health (condoms should be provided), rela tionships (fathers-to-be should be allowed to stay the night); self-esteem (often low among female hostel residents), and on parenting. "It would be helpful if managers clarified for staff what their role is in relation to these issues, and offered ongoing support to project workers who are dealing with the stressful circumstances of their tenants," the report suggests.

The government should make a commitment to ending the use of bed-and-breakfast facilities for pregnant women with young children, the report argues. Local housing authorities, for their part, should accept that young women who are pregnant and homeless, including those in hostels, are priority cases from the time an accommo- dation request is made.

There needs to be more cooperation between housing authorities and hostels; and councils should draw up plans over the next three years to provide semi-supported accommodation for young single mothers. Social services are called on to make "prompt and proper" assessments of the needs of these vulnerable mothers-to-be, recognising that long waits and uncertainty adds to their stress.

Shaks Ghosh, Crisis's chief executive, says: "A future without hope can destroy an already low sense of self-worth and this is when the risk of pregnancy becomes very real."

fields.headline: Budget boarding
fields.standfirst: Local authorities avoid paying for high quality care places
fields.trailText: Local authorities avoid paying for high quality care places
fields.body:
One way of achieving better social care may be to pay more for it. But a new survey suggests barely one in 10 local authorities is paying higher fees for higher quality care.

According to the survey of 107 authorities in England, Scotland and Wales, only 21% have community care purchasing policies that differentiate among independent providers on the basis of quality. Only 11% take this further by having differential fees.

The Continuing Care Conference (CCC), which carried out the survey and is a coalition of organisations working towards improved long-term care, describes the finding as very disappointing. And it is warning that the overall purchasing policies of authorities are so unsophisti- cated they will face trouble under the "best value" regime requiring routine comparison of service costs.

The survey found that while authorities use "block" purchasing to contract for places in their own care homes, or in those of arms-length operators running ex-council homes, 64% rely exclusively on "spot" purchasing of places in the private sector. The other 36% use mainly spot purchasing: less than a third of the care they buy in the sector is under block contracts and only three authorities were found to be buying more than half their private sector care on a block basis.

The CCC says this is patently unfair on private providers. In negotiating block contracts, 100% occu- pation can be assumed; on a spot basis, however, providers have to assume a certain level of vacancies. Inevitably, there is a cost and price differential between the sectors.

Bob Lewis, who chairs the CCC's consumer issues group and is a former president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, says: "This is clearly putting often cheaper independent care providers in a very difficult situation and clear guidance from the government would be welcome."

The survey also found that while almost all authorities have policies for review of the care needs of elderly people after they have entered residential care, such reviews tend to be short term. More than one in two authorities has a review at six weeks, but only 13% do so after a year. On the other hand, some authorities do not hold an initial review for up to six months.

 Copies of the survey findings are available from Alison Cornell on 020-7222 1265

fields.headline: An unknown act
fields.standfirst: Confusion surrounds the assessment of the needs of carers
fields.trailText: Confusion surrounds the assessment of the needs of carers.
fields.body:
Carers have not rushed forward since they became entitled to an assessment of their needs under the 1995 Carers Act. But a new study suggests this may have more to do with ignorance than indifference.

In findings given added importance by passing last week of the Carers and Disabled Children Act, enhancing rights to assessment, the study says that even half those carers who have had an assessment are not fully aware of it, or of its implications. Knowledge of the 1995 act was found to be "limited".

The study, funded by the Department of Health, was carried out by researchers from the social policy research unit at York University. Unlike most previous work on the act, it took a long-term view, that involved interviewing 51 carers twice, six months apart, over a two-year period to last autumn. The carers came under four different social services authorities in northern England.

Almost all the carers were providing intensive assistance of more than 35 hours a week, although one was as old as 87. All had received an assessment of their needs, but only two had requested it and most had been assessed as part of an appraisal of the needs of the person or persons they cared for.

One carer told the researchers: "I think they should tell you when they are coming to assess you and give you a chance to think about it before they come . . . like I say, I still don't know if I've had an assessment. I mean I might have had, I don't know."

In the second, follow-up interviews, at least half the carers said they had not received confirmation of the results of their assessment and were unsure what, if anything, would happen next.

The researchers - Hilary Arksey, David Hepworth and Hazel Qureshi - say assessment should become a more inclusive process. Procedures for working with older carers, in particular, should be reviewed and authorities should not rely on self-assessment (as one of the four study authorities had done). Carers should be given the results of any assessment, together with details of named contacts and review arrangements.

 Carers' Needs and the Carers Act is available (£7.50 inc) from SPRU Information Office, University of York, Heslington, York YO10 5DD

fields.headline: Art and soul
fields.standfirst: Sharon Garfinkel and David Brindle on how funding festivals is helping to regenerate rundown areas
fields.trailText: Sharon Garfinkel and David Brindle on how funding festivals is helping to regenerate rundown areas
fields.body:
Every self-respecting community now has its own festival, it seems. And Kilburn, the north London suburb renowned for its Irishness, is no exception. Earlier this month, it staged the first, three-day Kilburn arts festival. And it was widely judged a great success.

What was remarkable about this festival, however, was that it claimed to be the first in Britain to benefit from single regeneration budget (SRB) funding. This pot of government money is more usually devoted to training, employment, health, housing, capital improvement and attracting inward investment. But SRB cash underwrote the Kilburn event to the grand sum of £115,700. And even more is promised for an equivalent festival in 2001: over the two years together, up to £264,000 is being made available.

The rationale of this is that the disparate communities of Kilburn, coming from the boroughs of Camden and Brent and straddling the Kilburn High Road, will be brought together under the all-embracing banner of regeneration. In all, the SRB is pouring £6.6m into the area, directed into projects aimed at improving the town centre, local health, employment and education, community safety and community development.

It is hoped that the area - often unkindly described as dismal - will be spiced up by the festival, which aims to celebrate the cultural diver sity of Kilburn, unify both sides of the high road, establish a strong local arts network, develop artistic skills in the local community, generate a higher profile for Kilburn and attract visitors to the area. Although the festival lasted only three days, the intention is that work towards these objectives will be continued all year round in community programmes.

This year's festivities showcased the work of local groups and businesses and, in doing so, promoted the local arts and entertainment sector. Many of the acts - including Christine Tobin, The Popes, Wisdom and Bap Kennedy - reflected different ethnic groups within the locality.

Kerry Wilkins, Kilburn town centre manager, says: "SRB money can do a lot for the physical regeneration of an area, but arts are the best way of engaging people."

Phil Newby, director of the Kilburn SRB project, insists that the festival fully met funding criteria. "For too long the area has been seen in a negative light; 40% of residents have said that there is nothing that they are proud of in the neighbourhood. The government investment will undoubtedly improve the area. The festival was about empowering people. They have been offered skills in many things, including DJ-ing and mixing, which they can then transfer elsewhere. "

The SRB bid was made last year. One of the reasons it achieved success was because it addressed the area's cultural diversity, as well as having a commitment to give people the skills to make a difference to their communities. Glenda Jackson, Labour MP for Hampstead and Highgate, holds a monthly surgery in Kilburn. She says: "For a time, Kilburn has been seen as a danger area. The SRB money will go a long way to improving things and the festival was an ideal opportunity for Kilburn to celebrate its diversity."

For Fiona Kilkelly, festival director, a great strength of the event was its rooting in the local community. "Wherever possible we engaged local performers and involved local businesses," she says. Despite the general welcome, there were inevitably hiccups. Wilkins acknowledges: "We had too short a run-in to fully develop the community aspect of the festival. There were inevitably difficulties of sourcing the right people to get involved and legitimising ourselves."

This failing has been reflected in the negative reactions of a number of local people. One residents' leader, who does not wish to be identified, says: "Although the festival generated tremendous community spirit, there are many people who think it was a total waste of money. As far as I can see, the only improvement to the area are three new 'pound shops'. The festival parade created disruption along the high road and we weren't adequately briefed that it was going to happen. There's so much overall wrong with the area and I don't see a festival as improving things."

The Greater London Authority member for Brent, Lord Harris of Haringey, recognises the need for thorough planning of such events. He says: "Bids for festivals should only be made if they are sustainable in the long run and will have a lasting impact on the cohesion of the area. It will be a slow process, but I'm sure this will happen in Kilburn."

Wilkins cautions other areas thinking of staging an SRB-funded festival that there is a heavy administrative workload. "You've also got to be accountable, which is not necessarily a bad thing. Early on you should prime people so that they are ready to join in with your plans. Give thought to the impact that festivals will have on the community."

Although lead time for the Kilburn festival was short, and not all communities felt adequately involved in what was happening, organisers are confident that a pending evaluation will be positive. This will include measuring the numbers of jobs created, of young people benefiting from personal and social development and of voluntary organisations supported by the process.

Wilkins says: "How do you measure success? In the last few weeks I've been getting many calls for Kilburn town hall. There isn't one. At least now people are beginning to think of Kilburn as a separate part of Brent and Camden."

Bids on the table

The next national allocation of SRB funding is due any day. Bids were invited last December and about £1bn is expected to be distributed by Whitehall.

Begun in 1994, the SRB brought together a number of government programmes with the aim of streamlining support for regeneration. Since then, in five allocations, more than 750 schemes have been funded for up to seven years at a total cost of £4.4bn.

Official estimates suggest that the grants have in turn generated more than £8.6bn private sector investment and an unquantified amount of European funding. Some 790,000 jobs have been, or are being, created or safeguarded, about 296,000 homes improved or completed, 103,000 community organisations supported and 94,000 new businesses backed.

The stated priority of the SRB is to "enhance the quality of life of local people in areas of need by reducing the gap between deprived and other areas, and between different groups".

fields.trailText: Frank Dobson MP has asked us to make clear that, contrary to what we may have suggested in a report on page 11, July 25, he has at all times complied with the rules laid down for the registration of members' interests. Having at the outset of his campaign sought the advice of the Registrar of Members' Interests, he declared all registrable donations he received towards the cost of his campaign to be selected as official Labour candidate for mayor of London. The costs of his subsequent election campaign were met by the Labour party. Elizabeth   Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, advised Mr Dobson in March that such funding by the Labour party was not a registrable interest. We apologise to Mr Dobson for any suggestion that he had not complied with the rules.

webTitle: What the French and German papers said

fields.headline: What the French and German papers said
fields.standfirst: These were among the views expressed on the crash today in the German and French papers
fields.trailText:
<B>Gerard Dupuy in Liberation, France, July 26:</B
>
"[Concorde] embodies a definite idea of French success, [even though] the French gladly forget that it is half British...In spite of the important progress made in the field of air security, the best planes in the world can crash. This catastrophe, with all its victims, is as tragic as any other. But this accident has a more sombre resonance because it concerns a plane which is not like any other. A beautiful dream was tragically shattered at Goness - glistening and sharp like the ConcordeÕs wings."
fields.byline: The Editor section of the Guardian
fields.body:
Gerard Dupuy in Liberation, France, July 26: "[Concorde] embodies a definite idea of French success, [even though] the French gladly forget that it is half British...In spite of the important progress made in the field of air security, the best planes in the world can crash. This catastrophe, with all its victims, is as tragic as any other. But this accident has a more sombre resonance because it concerns a plane which is not like any other. A beautiful dream was tragically shattered at Goness - glistening and sharp like the ConcordeÕs wings."

Bruno Mazurier in Le Parisien, France, July 26: "Even before the crash, questions were already being asked about whether Concorde was still a reliable aircraft...This technological marvel, this aeronautical 'diamond' which puts New York less than three-and-a-half hours from Paris, probably can't go on forever. It is a tragic irony of fate that on Tuesday, on the eve of the catastrophe, Air France announced the appearance of microscropic cracks in four of its six aircraft. Four years ago, specialists said that just 'one Concorde crash' would condemn all the others to death."

Commentary in Frankfurter Neue Presse, Germany, July 26: "Fast as lightening, prestigious and safe - these were the attributes attached to the supersonic jet Concorde. For thirty years it flew over the Atlantic. Until yesterday it was the only jet aircraft in aviation history which had not experienced any fatal accidents. Flight AF 4590 put an end to this success story."

Torsten Krauel in Die Welt, Germany, July 26: "The catastrophe in Paris is not the end of the 'Titanic'. The ship sank on its maiden voyage; Concorde flew millions of kilometres for a quarter of a century without incident. Concorde doesn't symbolise hubris, rather necessity. It was not merely an exotic aircraft that crashed...A few days after the discovery of cracks in a sister plane, the apparatus of globalisation - which especially fascinated the Germans, as Germany was particularly reliant on Concorde - was smashed to pieces along with the Air France Concorde. One of the factors on which todays German economy depends crashed along with Concorde."

Translated for Guardian Unlimited by The Editor section of the Guardian, which will include further press reaction this Friday

Commentary in Frankfurter Neue Presse, Germany, July 26: "Fast as lightening, prestigious and safe - these were the attributes attached to the supersonic jet Concorde. For thirty years it flew over the Atlantic. Until yesterday it was the only jet aircraft in aviation history which had not experienced any fatal accidents. Flight AF 4590 put an end to this success story." Torsten Krauel in Die Welt, Germany, July 26: "The catastrophe in Paris is not the end of the 'Titanic'. The ship sank on its maiden voyage; Concorde flew millions of kilometres for a quarter of a century without incident. Concorde doesn't symbolise hubris, rather necessity. It was not merely an exotic aircraft that crashed...A few days after the discovery of cracks in a sister plane, the apparatus of globalisation - which especially fascinated the Germans, as Germany was particularly reliant on Concorde - was smashed to pieces along with the Air France Concorde. One of the factors on which todays German economy depends crashed along with Concorde." Translated for Guardian Unlimited by The Editor section of the Guardian, which will include further press reaction this Friday

webTitle: Pay post-doctoral researchers and halt the brain drain

fields.headline: Pay post-doctoral researchers and halt the brain drain
fields.standfirst: As the government spends £4m in an effort to stem the brain drain, higher education editor Lee Elliot-Major argues that it would do better to spend more on impoverished post-doctoral contract researchers
fields.trailText: As the government spends £4m in an effort to stem the brain drain, higher education editor Lee Elliot-Major argues that it would do better to spend more on impoverished post-doctoral contract researchers.
fields.body:
The government's science minister, Lord Sainsbury, is apparently chuffed about the £4m package to boost the salaries of top scientists announced today as part of the government's white paper on science and innovation.

The money is intended to halt the brain drain of academic high flyers leaving the country for prestigious research teams in the United States. It comes on top of the announcement earlier this month by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, that an extra £1bn is to be allocated to update university laboratories.

Sounds impressive. But there are many reasons why the country's scientific community may not be as delirious as ministers might make out. For a start, only 50 scientists - selected by the club of elite academic elders at the Royal Society - will benefit from the funds, seeing salaries increase to £100,000 a year.

Sainsbury says that the money will also be used to lure some top scientists working in the States back to the UK.

The funds for this elite cohort will only be available for one year, but the government hopes to find a way of continuing the scheme after this.

Mirroring previous science investments, the government will also only partly fund the salaries. The Department of Trade and Industry and research charity the Wolfson Foundation are both contributing £2m. Will this money persuade a few scientists to come back to the country? Although academics can secure salaries four times bigger in the States, the reasons for moving to the US are much more complex than simply pay.

The US Ivy League institution, Dartmouth College, this month announced that it was hiring Professor Neil Macrae, a prominent social psychologist who holds a chair in psychology at the University of Bristol. The offer included: a better salary; a new building; a group of researchers; and new laboratory equipment. Macrae's move to the US is also likely to be an important stage of his scientific career: sampling the latest ideas and trends in the larger research community based in the States.

The truth is that know one knows whether there is a brain drain or brain gain in this country, and indeed whether this is a good or bad thing. The Royal Society recently reported that the proportion of its membership working in the US had doubled in the past 30 years, to more than 12%.

Yet the government's chief scientific adviser, Sir Bob May, argues that there is as much anecdotal evidence suggesting that top universities such as Oxford and Cambridge are still attracting scientific stars as part of the natural moves among the global research community.

More facts are known about the 30,000 or so postdoctoral researchers in British universities. In their late 20s or early 30s, it is the army of postdocs which does most of the research work in universities. Yet most are paid a pittance on a series of short-term contracts at the beginning of their research careers.

If the government wants to stem the drain of talent from our universities - in science and the humanities - it would do well to focus attention on this group. The problem is, it would probably require £4bn rather than £4m to do anything about it.

webTitle: Fiji: The coup is over but there's still trouble in paradise

fields.headline: The coup is over but there's still trouble in paradise
fields.standfirst: Rebel leader George Speight may have been arrested but the crisis in Fiji will continue to rumble on while ethnic differences remain, writes Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Rebel leader George Speight may have been arrested but the crisis in Fiji will continue to rumble on while ethnic differences remain, writes Derek Brown
fields.body:
The reported arrest of Fijian coup leader George Speight may signal an end to the dangerous stand-off between his rag-tag forces and the national army - but equally it could spark a new battle for power.

The army had already been placed on high alert, as caretaker president Ratu Josefa Iloilo struggled to form a credible government. He is expected to announce his cabinet imminently but Speight has insisted that he, not the president, will have the final word.

The crisis is now more than two months old. Speight and his followers, claiming to be the champions of ethnic Fijians, seized the parliamentary compound on May 19, taking hostage the ethnic Indian prime minister Mahendra Chaudhry. Chaudhry and some 30 other hostages have all been released, but up to this morning, Speight was still holding court in the parliament building, and issuing bombastic demands to the military rulers of the island nation.

His rebel followers have taken control of at least four tourist resorts and other locations, and there have been several small-scale mutinies by elements in the armed forces sympathetic to Speight's nakedly racist cause. Effectively, Speight has already won most of his demands. The 1997 constitution, guaranteeing multi-ethnic rule, has been scrapped. Power was being shared by the army and a conservative council of district chiefs, who meekly accepted rebel demands for Iloilo to be named president.

In reality, the country is in chaos. Iloilo is a somewhat pathetic figurehead; a septuagenarian in poor health with no power base except the whim of Speight. Even that has been withdrawn, since the two men fell out over the choice of prime minister.

Meanwhile, the Fijian economy is in tatters. The USA, Australia and New Zealand have all imposed sanctions, and the EU has signalled that it will follow suit unless democracy is restored. The loss of European trade privileges could be a mortal blow for many livelihoods in the Pacific archipelago, which has already seen its tourist trade evaporate.

Most Fijian businesses are run by ethnic Indians, who make up 44% of the population but are now queuing up to leave the country. Many in the ethnic Fijian community too are lining up to seek security in emigration.

fields.headline: Clearing survivors
fields.standfirst: Pippa Crerar speaks to five students who went through clearing - and made it work for them
fields.trailText: Corinne Abrams, 19, is in her first year of European Union studies at Nottingham University. I knew I wasnt going to do well in my A-levels but was still disappointed when the results came out. I had applied to study politics and really wanted to go to Nottingham.
fields.body:
Corinne Abrams, 19, is in her first year of European Union studies at Nottingham University. I knew I wasnt going to do well in my A-levels but was still disappointed when the results came out. I had applied to study politics and really wanted to go to Nottingham.

"I was very excited when they made me a conditional offer but then they said theyd made a mistake - they wrote and asked if Id consider a new European Union course instead. There was nothing about it in the prospectus and I really wasnt sure so I said no. So I accepted conditional offers from Leeds and Sheffield. I needed three Bs and got an A and two Cs. When both universities said they couldnt take me I panicked, but Mum was really calm and sent me out to buy the newspaper with all the clearing tables.

"I rang all the old universities and eventually started on the old polys, but Mum said stick with the ones you really want. So I rang Nottingham. The politics department admissions tutor said they only had places left... on a new course called European Union studies! He explained the course was very similar to politics and I could do German too. I really shouldve found out about it sooner! I love the course, its brilliant.

"I didnt get into halls because I came here through clearing. We got sent off-campus to a really dodgy area where it wasnt safe for 18-year-olds to wander around and there was no proper transport. I felt very isolated and we had to push really hard to eventually get a place in halls. It is worth checking whether your university accomodates students off-campus. Id urge people to work harder in the first place. I was incredibly lucky but it really is worth it to avoid all the worry of clearing.

Laura Eliis, 20, is in her second year of combined arts at Leicester University. Halfway through the summer holidays I changed my mind about going to uni and rejected my offers. I had places to study psychology in London, but by the summer Id had enough of exams.

"And I had a full-time job and was getting used to money! Mum and I struck a deal - if my A-level results were good then Id go to uni. If not, I could stay in my job. In the end it wasnt down to my results, I just realised that all my friends were going to uni. So I changed my mind again!

"Before the results came out I looked around universities in the Midlands - London was just too big. Leicester were great - they gave me a guided tour and lots of advice. I had worried that uni would no longer be an option, but they said Id definitely get a place. Over the summer I kept ringing them up and pestering them so they knew I was interested. When my results came through in August I just rang the combined arts secretary and by 9.10am I had a place - it was easy!

"So dont worry if you have to go through clearing because you can get into the uni you want with a little persistence. Its easier than you think doing it off your own back.

Aftab Aslam, 20, is in his first year of a social science degree at Westminster University. Next year he specialises in politics and international relations.

I couldnt decide what I wanted to do at university so I applied for computing - my brother told me IT was the future. But then Ucas told me that if I got the points I would have to take the place. Ive never really been very interested in IT and only applied because I was undecided, so a friend and I pulled out and waited for clearing. I wanted to do something I enjoyed.

"When clearing came around I ended up taking a place to do computing at Westminster. Then I changed my mind and my degree a couple more times! I wanted to be happy with my choice - I didnt want to get half way through and drop out, so I took social sciences.

"My friend stuck with the computer course but is now unhappy and is thinking about dropping out. In hindsight I made the right decision changing when I did.

"Clearing is perfectly easy if you prepare yourself and do some research. Its worth it even if you dont expect to be in that position. I spoke to my college careers advisor and read a few prospectuses beforehand. If you plan you wont need to make decisions on instinct.

"The biggest hurdle everybody faces is the engaged tone - you need to get to the phones early and persevere, else you could miss out on a course. I went down to my local library as soon as the results came out because they had the paper and prospectuses there. I had to wait 40 minutes before I got through to Westminster but I had my place by midday. Persistence is the key.

Emily Fagan, 21, is in her final year of a pharmacology degree at Southampton University and has got a place to do a masters in audiology next year. I was desperate to study pharmacology and had offers from Sheffield and Bath. They both wanted 20 A-level points, but I only got 18, and as it was the year before tuition fees were implemented - both oversubscribed and couldnt give me a place. I was gutted. Id been prepared though and had bought a paper earlier that morning - just in case!

"I looked up all the unis which still had places for pharmacology and Southampton grabbed my attention. I got through to them first time and they said I should come to visit and see if I liked it. I did both so I handed in my Ucas clearing form to the department.

"It was a relief - I hadnt planned on not going to university that September and dont know what I wouldve done otherwise. I was given advice by my school to take any place at clearing just so I could go to uni, but there was nothing else I wanted to do. Go for the course you want to do. Its also important to go to look around and dont just choose a course out of desperation. Now Ive got one of only 30 places in the country to study audiology so coming through clearing has never held me back academically. That was never an issue.

Chris West, 20, is in second year of philosophy and politics at Sussex University.

Like most people, I went through clearing because I didnt get my grades. Everything was one grade below - I got BCC when Id expected ABB. I suppose I was being a bit elitist, saying to myself that I was going to get the grades to go to a good uni. I hadnt backed myself up with a decent insurance offer of three Cs.

"The night before the results came out I went to the pub with all my friends. We decided that it would be a good idea to camp in tents on the school field, so wed be there the next morning. The police visited us twice during the night and the next morning the teachers came out to have a look but none of them minded too much! It was unnerving when I got my results because I wasnt quite sure what to do. Id read all the leaflets but hadnt really considered clearing.

"So we all went back to the pub. After one drink I called my Mum who metaphorically slapped me around the face because I wasnt doing anything about clearing. So I went back down to school where there were teachers around to help. I checked all the courses that did philosophy and politics and I saw that Sussex had a place. I knew that it was my friends first choice and I trusted his judgement so I took a leap of faith and rang.

"Before you can take your place through clearing you must be released from your original choices. LSE, my second choice, released me immediately but Warwick, my first choice, took four days. Luckily Sussex still had the place and so I applied for my clearing form and sent it off to them. It was all fairly stressful, but I had a fair amount of help from my family and teachers and the formal part of the process was fairly clear.

"My best piece of advice was from my Mum who told me to get off my arse and do something. However low your grades, there are always options.

fields.headline: Premiership money helps school soccer
fields.trailText: British sport received some good news yesterday, after the disappointing summer, with a government announcement of new funds and the launch of a group designed to invest millions in grassroots football.
fields.body:
British sport received some good news yesterday, after the disappointing summer, with a government announcement of new funds and the launch of a group designed to invest millions in grassroots football.

Speaking in the Commons yesterday, Chris Smith, the culture secretary, introduced the biggest increase in government funding for sport, with an emphasis on boosting activities in schools, particularly at competitive levels. Spending will double from £52m this year to £102m by 2003-04.

The bulk of the money, almost £60m, will go towards establishing school sports co-ordinators who will work on improving performance in schools, developing emerging talent and increasing links between sports clubs. The initial figure given for 600 co-ordinators working in the schools has been increased to 1,000.

The government has also announced £10.5m for the Commonwealth Games, to be held in Manchester in 2002, and a further £4m for improving facilities provided by the UK Sports Institute, which still does not have a headquarters and which has been criticised for not doing enough to develop British sport.

Mr Smith said that his department's spending would increase by 13.5% and that the government was committed to increasing access to sport and improving performance. "The Tories tore the heart out of school sport, with after-school activity, in particular, disappearing across the country," he said.

"Today, I am able to take the first steps to repair that damage and help put English sport back on its feet."

Mr Smith also told the Commons that the Football Foundation, a body launched yesterday, would help to create modern facilities for grassroots football. Unveiled by Tony Blair and Kevin Keegan, the England manager, the foundation will oversee the investment of millions in developing talent as well as facilities. It will be funded by the Premier League - which is giving money from the sale of its television rights - and the Football Association as well as the government.

The foundation will have £24m to invest during the coming football season, but this will be increased to £60m by 2001, when it will receive 5% of the Premier League's £1.6bn television deal. The league acted after criticism that it was doing little to help the game at grassroots level.

About 40,000 football clubs will benefit from new equipment and changing rooms as well as improved pitches. Money will also be invested in coaching, community and education initiatives and in the establishment of mini-soccer centres, to encourage youngsters to play.

The prime minister said yesterday at the launch of the foundation: "If we don't make the investment in sport in our country there are many children who just won't get the chance to develop their sporting ability."

Keegan said: "This is a fantastic step. We at the FA, and particularly the players, will do everything we can to make sure the kids get to meet some of the players and hear from the horse's mouth how important football is."

Dave Richards, chairman of the Premier League, said: "This is an exciting and important moment for English football. The launch of the foundation marks a new beginning for the funding of grassroots football and the start of a new partnership between football and the government.

"We have worked hard with colleagues from the FA, Sport England, and the government to put together the new body, and we can now look forward with confidence to the delivery of quality facilities for young footballers up and down the country."

Money will also be invested in coaching, community and education initiatives and in the establishment of mini-soccer centres, to encourage youngsters to play. The prime minister said yesterday at the launch of the foundation: "If we don't make the investment in sport in our country there are many children who just won't get the chance to develop their sporting ability." Keegan said: "This is a fantastic step. We at the FA, and particularly the players, will do everything we can to make sure the kids get to meet some of the players and hear from the horse's mouth how important football is." Dave Richards, chairman of the Premier League, said: "This is an exciting and important moment for English football. The launch of the foundation marks a new beginning for the funding of grassroots football and the start of a new partnership between football and the government. "We have worked hard with colleagues from the FA, Sport England, and the government to put together the new body, and we can now look forward with confidence to the delivery of quality facilities for young footballers up and down the country."

fields.headline: Judge rejects Fayed passport appeal
fields.trailText: Mohamed Al Fayed today lost another battle in his quest for a British passport when the court of appeal found in favour of the home secretary's decision that the Harrods boss had a "general defect in his character" and should be refused citizenship.
fields.body:
Mohamed Al Fayed today lost another battle in his quest for a British passport when the court of appeal found in favour of the home secretary's decision that the Harrods boss had a "general defect in his character" and should be refused citizenship.

Lords Justices Nourse, Kennedy and Rix dismissed Mr Fayed's appeal that Mr Straw had been biased when he refused Mr Fayed citizenship and his decision should be quashed.

Michael Beloff QC, representing Mr Fayed, had told the court of appeal that Mr Straw did not treat his client's application for citizenship "with an open mind" when he refused it on the grounds that he was not satisfied that Mr Fayed was of "good character".

Mr Straw had based his views on two events - Mr Fayed's admitted presence when the safe deposit box belonging to his business rival Tiny Rowland was opened and his payment of money to MPs to ask questions on his behalf in the House of Commons.

Lord Justice Nourse, giving his judgment today, said of the deposit box break-ins: "The home secretary's view was that it constituted more than a minor blemish on Mr Al Fayed's character and that it 'illustrated' a serious want of probity on his part; in other words, that it was indicative of a general defect in his character.

"In my judgment it is plain that that was a view which could reasonably be taken in the circumstances and, once taken, that that in itself was enough to justify the home secretary's inability to be satisfied that Mr Al Fayed was of good character."

The judges refused permission to take the case to the House of Lords.

Mr Fayed said in a statement after the ruling: "While I am disappointed with the decision I am not surprised.

"The establishment and judiciary have long shown bias against me unlike the majority of the great British public who have been nothing but supportive.

"My legal advisers are reviewing the situation."

webTitle: 'I'm so lucky to be alive': British crash survivor talks

fields.headline: 'I'm so lucky to be alive': British crash survivor talks
fields.trailText: A 21-year-old British woman who escaped from the hotel demolished in the Concorde crash in Paris has talked about her ordeal.
fields.body:
A 21-year-old British woman who escaped from the hotel demolished in the Concorde crash in Paris has talked about her ordeal.

Alice Brooking, who was working as a tour manager for Club Europe, told Radio One Newsbeat that if she had been elsewhere in the hotel she would not have survived.

She was in room in the first floor in front of the carpark of the Hotelissimo, and was on the phone to her sister Nathalie, 24, in London at the time of the crash.

She told BBC Radio 1: "I went to my bedroom door, opened the door and there were flames everywhere, so I just rushed to the window.

"I looked out of the window and saw the receptionist down beneath me in the carpark so I said to him 'what should I do? He said, 'you have to jump' so I jumped.

"For some reason, I didn't let the panic get to me and I just jumped."

She said she didn't know what had happened to the hotel until she was told later - then she realised how lucky she had been.

She ran, shoeless, across roads and fields to get away from the flames. "There was a big, big field kind of in the middle of nowhere, so I ran, bare foot across the fields, as I'd left my shoes in my room,but didn't have time to think about anything - then tried calling the attention of the car drivers, and then basically get myself away, that was my first concern.

She said her first thought was to phone her sister to let her know she was all right. But she saw little of the devastation caused by the horrific crash.

"I didn't see anything to do with the plane. By the time I was out of the hotel, it was all in flames, and you couldn't see anything, so I really didn't have anything bad or terrible to have to cope with."

Nathalie, who is now on her way to Paris to be with her sister, said: "She is very shaken up. She needs to take her time and relax before coming back. I can't wait to get out there and see for myself that she is okay.

"We are not so worried about physical scars, but we are about mental ones. But she is a very strong person."

Parents Hugh and Francine Brooking, of Hildenborough, near Tonbridge, Kent, said their daughter had had a "miraculous escape".

Alice was waiting at Hotelissimo to meet a group of 13 to 19-year-old students from the Suffolk Youth Wind Band, due to arrive in the area shortly.

She was working as a tour manager with Club Europe, who are school tour operator specialists, but she was due to return home shortly to start the fourth and final year of her modern languages degree at Selwyn College, Cambridge University.

fields.headline: Ferguson attacks 'carping' Wenger and 'Mao' Bates
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson has hit out at "carping" Arsene Wenger and compared Ken Bates to chairman Mao in the latest series of revelations from his updated autobiography 'Managing My Life.'
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson has hit out at "carping" Arsene Wenger and compared Ken Bates to chairman Mao in the latest series of revelations from his updated autobiography 'Managing My Life.'

The Manchester United manager is upset that Wenger refused to give his side credit for winning the Premiership title last season. "Anyone who looks at the 18-point gap that separated our two clubs last season must wonder why he still appears to doubt our worthiness as champions," he said.

"Arsene Wenger disappoints me when he is reluctant to give Manchester United credit for what we have achieved and I don't think his carping has made a good impression on the other Premiership managers.

"When Arsenal captured the Double in 1998 I held my hands up and praised them unreservedly for the storming finish to the season that had pushed us aside and given them the glory.

"I could have dwelt on the damage done to our chances by our horrendous toll of injuries but I knew the hour belonged to Arsenal and saluted an exceptional team and their exceptional manager.

"I suppose I will just have to accept that, between Old Trafford and Highbury, appreciation is pretty much a one-way street."

Ferguson, whose book is being serialised in The Times, is also unimpressed by Bates' outbursts from his position of power at Stamford Bridge. The United boss says: "Has any chairman since Mao had more faith in his own opinions than Ken Bates? If laying down the law was an Olympic sport the Chelsea chief would be staggering under the weight of gold medals.

"I don't suppose he will ever change. Just about everybody in the game has had to take the sharp end of his tongue or put up with being a target for the aggression he pours into his writings in the club programme.

"Any manager or player who said half as much would never be out of Lancaster Gate."

Ferguson has already been criticised for voicing his disappointment with David Beckham before last season's encounter with Leeds, and the United boss will undoubtedly come under more fire for letting his feelings be known in print.

webTitle: Judge rules out new Hillsborough trial

fields.headline: Judge rules out new Hillsborough trial
fields.standfirst: More about Hillsborough
fields.trailText: The senior police officer in charge at the Hillsborough disaster should not face a fresh trial on manslaughter charges, a crown court judge  ruled today.
fields.body:
The senior police officer in charge at the Hillsborough disaster should not face a fresh trial on manslaughter charges, a crown court judge ruled today.

Mr Justice Hooper agreed to order a stay on the proceedings brought against former Chief Superintendent David Duckenfield, 55, by relatives of the victims.

A jury at Leeds Crown Court earlier this week failed to agree on charges that Duckenfield, of Bournemouth, Dorset, had caused the death of fans at the FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest in April 1989.

They cleared his deputy, former Superintendent Bernard Murray, 58, of the same charges.

Today Alun Jones QC told the judge at Leeds Crown Court that he was seeking a re-trial of the two sample manslaughter charges against Mr Duckenfield after consulting the families of the 96 victims.

But Mr Duckenfield's counsel, William Clegg QC successfully argued that a new trial, which might not take place for several months, would put unfair pressure on the former officer and his family.

He also said that there was no realistic prospect of a conviction if a new trial were to take place.

fields.headline: Jerry Springer
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about Jerry Springer and how appearing on his show can be terminally bad for you
fields.trailText: All you need to know about Jerry Springer and how appearing on his show can be terminally bad for you
fields.body:
1. Police in Florida are looking for Ralf and Eleanor Panitz, following the murder of Ralf's ex-wife, Nancy. All three appeared on a pre-recorded Jerry Springer show, which was broadcast at about the time Nancy was killed on Monday evening.

2. On the show, Ralf and Eleanor entertained the studio audience by accusing Nancy of stalking them. Ralf revealed that for the two nights before the recording, he'd been sleeping with his ex-wife, even through he had just remarried. Eleanor won applause for calling Nancy old and fat. Nancy countered with her own entertaining tales of harassment and assault, before stalking offstage. That was two months ago.

3. On Monday morning, the embittered trio had appeared in a court, where Nancy sought a restraining order against Ralf. She claimed he had kicked and battered her, and threatened her with a knife. Later, as the Jerry Springer show went on air, Nancy went to the Sarasota County home which both she and Eleanor both claimed as their own. Neighbours heard shouting and called the county sheriff's office.

4. Officers went to the house, and found Nancy's body.

5. The Miami Herald, Florida's premier newspaper, has - so far - primly restricted its coverage of the murder to a staid agency dispatch

6. Not so the splendid locally produced Herald-Tribune Newscoast, which is offering full coverage and even a video clip of the show.

7. A spokeswoman for the Springer circus called the affair "a terrible tragedy". There is of course no mention of it on the TV talk-show host's official website.

8. Springer, who apropos of nothing was born in London and is a former mayor of Cincinnati. He is surrounded by all the adulatory tripe of the telly mega-celeb.

9. There are tribute web pages and fan clubs galore, and that ultimate accolade, the spoof biography.

10. His show may be considered by some to be exploitative, voyeuristic and cruel but for US audiences it's top of the pops.

webTitle: End of 'take it or leave it'

fields.headline: End of 'take it or leave it'
fields.standfirst: Government plans to offer choice to social housing tenants
fields.trailText: Government plans to offer choice to social housing tenants.
fields.body:
Housing minister Nick Raynsford this week set out his vision of a reformed, lower-cost rental market with potential tenants becoming consumers with a wide variety of choices, rather than recipients of welfare.

Bolstered with an extra £1.6bn for social housing by 2003-04, and the prospect of up to 100,000 new, affordable homes in areas of high demand, Raynsford spoke of a radical overhaul of the way housing is delivered to offer "quality and choice" to people on low and average incomes.

Outlining his radical plan, the minister insisted that competition for social housing underpinned his revolution for affordable properties. "We've left behind the 20th century framework where, on the whole, the ethos was based on assumptions that the state would provide and people should be grateful for being allocated the benefit of a home," he said. "We're moving to a century where people in housing, as in every other field of their life, want to exercise some choice and not be told you can have this on a take it or leave it basis."

His comments will be underlined tomorrow in a major report from the Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) - the result of a year-long study by leading housing experts - which calls for a reinvention of social housing under a "community homes" label and more private investment to match public resources.

It suggests the national adoption of a "gold award" scheme, being pioneered by Irwell Valley Housing Association in Greater Manchester, which rewards tenants who pay rent on time and keep to tenancy agreements. This includes special bonuses as well as discounts for insurance, household goods, and other services.

With the government now pledged to tackling a £19bn repairs backlog in council housing within 10 years, Raynsford told the Guardian that ministers were determined to ensure a radical overhaul of the way services are delivered with a wider range of social housing providers.

To meet the repairs backlog, this means driving through the transfer of council houses to housing associations, special trusts and new social companies. So far, 450,000 have been hived off in England alone - with a further 165,000 likely to go in this financial year - although 3.2m properties remain in council hands.

John Perry, policy director of the Institute of Housing, said the government could quite clearly meet its 10-year repairs target provided 200,000 homes are annually transferred from council ownership - thus allowing the new landlords to borrow on the open market to fund a massive improvement programme. Birmingham, England's largest social landlord, is negotiating with Whitehall in the hope of transferring its 90,000 properties to a series of community companies over the next year or so.

But contrary to earlier expectations, councils keen to hang on to their housing stock will be allowed to form new hands-off companies - also with powers to borrow on the open market - provided they are approved by a new national housing inspectorate. More than 20 councils have now told the government they want to go down this route.

Raynsford insisted he was determined to avoid the creation of new "monopoly landlords" once houses were transferred. "There'll be more choice. We want competition between the providers of social housing and choice in terms of lettings and allocations. People should be able to go to a source of housing... and told not simply where they're going to be allocated, but should be free to express a choice."

webTitle: Feature: What Britain's biggest cinema complex says about us.

fields.headline: The big picture
fields.standfirst: Star City, which opened just outside Birmingham last week, is Britain's biggest cinema complex. It expects 4,000 visitors a day, and has 30 screens showing both Hollywood and Bollywood movies. Is this multicultural Britain rendered in concrete and celluloid?  Gary Younge  went to find out
fields.trailText: Where Bollywood mets Hollywood and what Britain's biggest cinema complex says about us.
fields.body:
On screen three in Star City, a bride-to-be breaks into song. With a wiggle of her hips, replicated by the 30 or so dancers behind her, she sways with just a hint of sensuality, leaving the gushing water fountains that surround her to do the rest. On screen 13, a transsexual is finding love, identity and homophobia in the American midwest with the help of vicious beatings and a gruesome inspection of her genitalia. On screen 19, John Cusack is having trouble with commitment and mulling over the direction his life is taking to a breezy soundtrack spanning three decades of pop.

In this 30-screen multiplex cinema on the outskirts of Birmingham globalised culture has been carved into celluloid slots and sold with popcorn. Bichoo, Boys Don't Cry and High Fidelity are just a few of the films showing within a few hundred metres of each other, but those who are watching exist alongside each other as in a parallel universe. This is where Hollywood meets Bollywood (to which six screens have been dedicated) and where different ethnicities congregate but rarely coalesce - a segregated experience within an integrated space.

Star City announces itself with a swirl of neon and a 30ft model of Batman, standing tall against a backdrop of the brownfield suburban desolation just off the A47. Its opening last week was as surreal as its appearance. Far away from the red carpets of Leicester Square, accompanied by the roar of traffic on the nearby Spaghetti Junction and the shrieks of adoring women, George Clooney arrived for the premiere of The Perfect Storm. Geographically, Star City may be only a few miles from Birmingham, but economically and culturally it occupies a territory all its own. It is the largest multiplex in Britain, an enormous commercial monument to the disparate, competing and, at times, contradictory forces that are shaping British culture.

From abroad comes the inexorable drift towards Americana; from home come the commercial and cultural influences of our own multi-ethnicity. The American influence goes way beyond Clooney and Gotham City's favourite son to the site itself, which already houses sev eral restaurants, bars and a megabowl and, when completed, will include a huge gym as well. By that stage it will be not be a multiplex but a leisure park. An opportunity to spend at every turn. "You don't think it's going to be too expensive when you set out," says Gavin Palmer, who came to see Chicken Run with his two boys. "But by the time you've bought the popcorn and cokes before you go in, had a go on the computer games when you come out and then had a Burger King it soon adds up. They love it so it's great, but it's more like going to the funfair than going to the cinema really."

This is not just a huge indoor shopping centre but a signifier of an all-embracing philosophy with its roots in the US, whereby retail provides the starting point for much of human interaction. "If the shopping centre becomes a place that not only provides suburbanites with their physical living requirements, but simultaneously serves their civic, cultural and social community needs," said Victor Gruen, the man who built the first mall in Minnesota in 1956, "it will make a most significant contribution to the enrichment of our lives."

This puts going to the cinema on a par with going to a football match or a demonstration. It is a mass, anonymous experience. Projections for Star City's Warner Village cinema are that it should attract 1.5m visitors per year - more than 4,000 a day.

While malls are nowhere near as prevalent here as they are in the US, they will none the less soon dominate our consumer culture. It is only 24 years since Britain got its first air-conditioned mall in Brent Cross, north London. Today the top three retail sites in Britain, judged by turnover and profitability per square foot, are all malls - the MetroCentre in Gateshead, Meadowhall, near Sheffield, and Merry Hill in the West Midlands. Oxford Street came 11th and Princes Street in Edinburgh 12th. And while public transport is available Star City is built for the car, as is the case in most of the US.

The building was designed by US architect Jon Jerde a man with a portfolio that reads like a roll call of the world's more flamboyant malls, including the Universal City Walk in Los Angeles, Canal City Hakarta in Japan and the Fremont experience in Las Vegas. The huge counters selling ice creams and popcorn bear the names not of British or Indian stars but Americans - Errol Flynn, Humphrey Bogart and Clint Eastwood. The huge murals inside the foyer were hand-painted in California and then shipped to Britain.

The Asian influence is far more subtle. For several years now Bollywood films have attracted a huge following in Britain. We are now the biggest export market for Bollywood. There are cinemas dedicated to Bollywood films all over the country, from Glasgow to Southall. Over the last two years four Indian films - Dil Se, Kuch Kuch Hota Hai, Biwi Number One and Hum Dil De Chuke Sanam - have broken box-office records and entered the UK top 20 on release. Last month the Indian equivalent of the Oscars was held in the Dome, hosted by the Indian Miss World, Yukta Mookhey. The most popular foreign location for filming Bollywood films outside India is Scotland.

Central to their attraction is that with no sex, only cartoonish violence, simple plots and plenty of dancing, they span generations. No ethical quandaries here. Good always triumphs over evil; love always conquers all."When a Bollywood film is on it becomes a real family outing," says Andy Stone, the manager of the Warner Village cinema. "Mum, dad, grandma, the kids - they all come along. The films have very traditional values which make for proper family entertainment."

There are few areas where this would be a bigger hit than Birmingham, where Asians comprise 14% of the population. With Star City hoping to provide a day out for people from Leicester, Derby, Nottingham and Wolverhampton, which also have large Asian populations, there is plenty of scope to expand. "I'm amazed it took them so long," says Manjit Singh, visiting Star City with his wife, mother and three children. "There's so much money in Indian films and none of the big names were really taking advantage of it. We used to go sometimes to one of the cinemas in town or watch videos at home. But this seems much better. There's more for everyone to do. More of an atmosphere."

Bollywood has started to respond to its British audience in kind. While the films at Star City are in Hindi, subtitles are becoming more widespread; films, well known for being epic in length, are getting shorter; and many of the actors and storylines are becoming more western in their orientation.

But it is the area's industrial history, rather than its ethnic diversity, that convinced Jerde that this small patch of the depressed Midlands was an ideal venue for his latest creation. "Birmingham's rich tradition as the birthplace of the industrial revolution has shaped Star City - a new generation of urban entertainment. Nearby masonry and steel warehouse buildings and transportation canals have been an inspiration for the design of the project."

None of this is obvious to the naked eye, but even Jerde's aspiration tells a tale. Built on the site of a former power station, Star City stands as a marker of the shifts that are taking place in the British economy; a thriving service industry is taking the place of ailing heavy industry. A culture of consumption is taking over from a tradition of production.

In truth, were it not for the accents, you would have little idea that you were anywhere near Birmingham. The mall is embossed with a collection of national and global imprints. Burger King, Warner Bros, Baskin Robbins, New Orleans, Nando's, MVC, Megabowl, Books etc and a New Orleans Restaurant. These are brands you can see everywhere, which gives you the sense that you could be anywhere. You are essentially divorced from any definite sense of place. Consumption has not only replaced production; it has trumped location. The consumers may be diverse, but the outlets are standardised.

Back in the mall the parallel universes remain equidistant and shows few signs of converging. None of the white people that the Guardian spoke to there were aware that the multiplex even showed Bollywood films. That is not surprising. For, while the Warner Brothers may have discovered a niche market in Bollywood that has drawn more Asians to Star City, there seems scant evidence that anyone else has spotted a business opportunity in directing their trade specifically towards the large number of Asians that come here. Of the several posters advertising films in the entrance of the multiplex, none is for Bollywood movies. There is not even an Indian restaurant, let alone an ambala sweet store or a sari shop.

What interaction there is is between whites and Asians or whites and Afro-Caribbeans, but very rarely between Afro-Caribbeans and Asians. Old women in saris walk past young women in short skirts as though invisible to each other. Divided by ethnicity; united by consumption.

fields.headline: Amazon loses its chief
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Joe Galli, the president and chief operating officer at Amazon.com, announced yesterday that he was leaving the online retailer after little more than a year, to join another internet company.
fields.body:
Joe Galli, the president and chief operating officer at Amazon.com, announced yesterday that he was leaving the online retailer after little more than a year, to join another internet company.

Shares in Amazon fell 14% on the news that the company, already hit by cash flow concerns, is to lose its second senior executive since the start of the year. But they recovered some momentum in the afternoon to trade down by about 3%.

The company cited personal reasons for Mr Galli's decision to join VerticalNet, a business-to-business firm, as chief executive.

Mr Galli's family has continued to live on the east coast of the US, close to the Pennsylvania headquarters of VerticalNet - the other side of the country to Seattle-based Amazon.

Jeff Bezos, the company's founder and chief executive, said: " I believe he is making the right decision for him and his family circumstances."

One analyst said that Mr Bezos, who will take over his deputy's duties, sent a heartfelt email to staff, pointing out that he had personally vouched for Mr Galli to his new employers. The signs that Mr Galli was not leaving because of disagreements helped the share price to recover.

The former Black & Decker marketing executive was said to have received options to purchase 3.92m shares when he joined Amazon in June last year.

His departure from Amazon follows that of chief financial officer Joy Covey, who left the company earlier this year.

fields.headline: Concorde flies again
fields.trailText:
A British Airways Concorde took off from London's Heathrow airport today - less than 24 hours after one of the supersonic aircraft
crashed in Paris killing 113 people.
fields.body:
A British Airways Concorde took off from London's Heathrow airport today - less than 24 hours after one of the supersonic aircraft crashed in Paris killing 113 people.

BA took the decision to go ahead with the flight to New York after carrying out extensive checks overnight on its fleet.

"We have complete confidence in our Concorde aircraft and we believe there is no technical, safety or operational evidence to suggest that Concorde should not operate safely into the future," said BA's customer services and operations director Mike Street.

Today's flight was believed to be half full. A least one passenger opted for a subsonic flight in the wake of the crash, but many more turned down offers of a refund or alternative flights.

BA had cancelled its two evening Concorde services last night in the immediate aftermath of yesterday's crash of an Air France Concorde moments after take-off from Paris.

All 100 passengers and nine crew on board the flight were killed. The plane had been chartered by a German tour operator and was taking tourists to New York to link up with a cruise ship.

Four people on the ground were killed when the plane crashed in the grounds of a hotel in Gonesse just outside Paris.

Alice Brooking, 21, a student from Hildenborough, near Tonbridge, in Kent, managed to escape from the first floor of the hotel. She told London's Evening Standard: "I just keep saying to myself over and over again: 'I'm alive, I'm alive, I'm alive'."

Air France said today that it would not be flying its Paris-New York Concorde services, but BA confirmed that it was business as usual less than one hour before the first Concorde of the day - BA001 from Heathrow to New York - was due to leave.

Mr Street said: "BA's first concern is always safety. All our aircraft are subject to continuing and exhaustive safety checks.

"We have complete confidence in our Concorde aircraft. We cancelled last night's two services while initial information on the Air France tragedy was coming in."

Mr Street went on: "Now we have had initial information from Air France and other relevant organisations from yesterday's incident. We have carried out extensive checks overnight to our Concordes operating today - to engines, airframes, hydraulic and other systems.

"We have liaised closely with the relevant air safety authorities and the aircraft and engine manufacturers. We believe there is no technical, safety or operational evidence to suggest that Concorde should not operate safely in the future."

He said that there was "no information from Air France or the French or British airworthiness authorities which leads us to believe that we should ground BA's Concorde fleet".

Mr Street added: "Meantime, our thoughts and sympathies remain with our colleagues at Air France, and those involved in this tragedy. We have been in touch with Air France regularly since yesterday's tragedy and offered any assistance we can provide."

BA operates four Concordes a day between London and New York. The other America-bound supersonic flight leaves Heathrow at 7pm.

The two flights which depart from New York's John F. Kennedy airport take off at 8.30am and 5.25pm US time, landing in London at 5.25pm and 10.25pm British time respectively.

Speaking at Heathrow today where he was checking in for the supersonic London-New York flight with BA, Brian Pople, 60, said he was determined to fly on Concorde.

He went on: "Lightning doesn't strike twice. From what I can see on the news it was probably something that happened on the ground. There was nothing wrong with its design. They've been using them long enough. It's only happened once in 30 years."

Electrical contractor Mr Pople, from Watford in Hertfordshire, was travelling to the US with his wife Wendy for a five-day break.

But the president of US TV network CNBC told how he could not face the emotional ordeal of a flight back to New York on Concorde.

Bill Bolster, 56, who transferred to a subsonic flight, said: "This is nothing to do with anything other than an emotional response. I am going to satisfy my emotions and go on another plane.

"I have total confidence in the engineers and pilot of this Concorde but I just can't face it."
