webTitle: Arafat seeks common Arab position on Jerusalem

fields.headline: Arafat seeks common Arab position on Jerusalem
fields.trailText: The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, was today greeted by cheering crowds in Alexandria, Egypt, as he stopped to brief President Hosni Mubarak on why the Camp David negotiations collapsed yesterday.
fields.body:
The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, was today greeted by cheering crowds in Alexandria, Egypt, as he stopped to brief President Hosni Mubarak on why the Camp David negotiations collapsed yesterday.

Egyptians gathered along the route to the Ras el-Tin palace, where the talks were to be held, to give Mr Arafat a hero's welcome. His reception indicated that the Palestinian leader's stock is high despite the failure to achieve a breakthrough on peace in the Middle East.

Mr Arafat will be keen to capitalise on this groundswell of support as he tours Arab countries to get soundings on whether Palestinians should consider accepting some form of control in Arab neighbourhoods of east Jerusalem. That is more than Israel has ever offered before, but falls short of Palestinians' long-standing sovereignty demands.

Arab leaders have made it clear they consider the status of Jerusalem a pan-Arab issue, and Mr Arafat has in effect to negotiate with Arab leaders as well as Israel. The US-brokered talks at Camp David collapsed over Jerusalem, which both Israel and the Palestinians claim as their capital. During the summit, President Mubarak held a flurry of talks with Arab leaders to assess their views. Egypt, which in 1979 became the first Arab country to make peace with Israel, has said the eastern part of Jerusalem should be the capital of a Palestinian state. The Palestinians have said they would declare statehood on September 13, when a deadline set by the Israelis and Palestinians for reaching an accord expires.

After the collapse of the Camp David talks, both sides pledged in a joint statement to avoid violence and unilateral actions and to keep seeking a negotiated settlement to the 52-year-old Israeli-Palestinian struggle. Palestinian officials said Mr Arafat had written to the US president, Bill Clinton, during Monday night saying there was no point in continuing the talks as long as the US and Israel stuck to unacceptable proposals on sharing Jerusalem.

Palestinian officials said that in final discussions on Jerusalem, Mr Arafat rejected an Israeli proposal, backed by the US, to give Israel "residual sovereignty" over all the holy sites in the Old City. But this would have amounted to mere symbolic sovereignty for the Palestinians, according to Palestinian officials. The Palestinians were adamant about their demand for full sovereignty over all of Arab East Jerusalem, including the Old City with the exception of the Jewish quarter and the Western Wall, Judaism's holiest site. It was Mr Arafat's refusal to buckle to US pressure on Jerusalem, which has boosted his stock in the Arab world.

Although the Camp David talks foundered on Jerusalem, commentators in Israel have noted the fact that both sides' willingness to discuss this emotional issue broke an important taboo.

webTitle: Concorde crash: work done on engine just before take-off

fields.headline: Concorde crash: work done on engine just before take-off
fields.trailText: The Air France Concorde which crashed in Paris was delayed for up to 30 minutes while work was carried out on an engine, it emerged today.
fields.body:
The Air France Concorde which crashed in Paris was delayed for up to 30 minutes while work was carried out on an engine, it emerged today.

Airline spokesman Francois Brousse told reporters at a press conference at Charles de Gaulle airport: "There was work done on the plane just before the flight, there was a slight delay then the plane took off."

When asked what the work involved, he replied: "It was work on an engine but at the present moment we can't absolutely know if it has something do with the cause of the crash, we are waiting for information from our industrial department."

Mr Brousse said the engine work took a few minutes and was not unusual before a flight. He would not confirm whether it involved the jet's left or right engines.

Flames poured from at least one of the jet's left wing engines as it took off from Charles de Gaulle airport yesterday. Moments later it ploughed into the two-star Hotelissimo in Gonesse, killing all 109 passengers and crew and four people on the ground in an impact one witness described as being "like an atomic bomb".

Air France today grounded its remaining Concorde fleet while inquiries continued into the first crash involving the veteran supersonic jet in its 30-year history. But British Airways decided to go ahead with its scheduled New York flights from Heathrow after offering passengers refunds or alternative flights. A half-full BA Concorde took off from Heathrow at 10.45am.

Meanwhile, details were emerging of an incredible escape from the stricken hotel by a British tour guide. Alice Brooking, 21, a student from Hildenborough, near Tonbridge, in Kent, leaped from the first floor of the hotel, escaping with just a burn to the arm.

She told London's Evening Standard: "I just keep saying to myself over and over again: 'I'm alive, I'm alive, I'm alive'."

Earlier crash investigators recovered two black box flight recorders from the charred remains of the Concorde. Both were damaged.

French legal experts are also beginning the grim task of examining the bodies of the 113 victims, mainly German tourists, to establish their identities as relatives prepare to fly into the French capital.

Investigators - including three British experts from the Air Accident Investigation Branch - were trying to determine what started the fire.

Ninety-six of the passengers on Flight AF4590 were from Germany, 17 from the town of Mönchengladbach, on the border with the Netherlands. There were two Danes, one Austrian and one American, a retired Air France employee. Three of the victims were children.

The European passengers on board were all en route from Charles de Gaulle airport to New York where they were due to join a luxury cruise liner heading for the Caribbean.

Witnesses described the stricken jet trailing a sheet of flame hundreds of feet long from one of its Olympus engines before smashing into the hotel, sending a plume of smoke 1,000ft into the afternoon sky and showering hot debris over a wide area.

It was the first serious accident involving Concorde, which has been flying for 30 years.

The Queen has sent messages of sympathy to the French president, Jacques Chirac, and the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, also wrote to the leaders to express his "shock and sympathy" on behalf of the government, a Downing Street spokesman said.

The US president, Bill Clinton, sent a message of condolence to the relatives of those who died.

The crashed airliner had been in service since 1980 and had flown 12,000 hours, said the president of Air France, Jean-Cyril Spinetta. It had its last mandatory safety check just four days before the tragedy.

President Chirac was due to visit the crash scene today as relatives of the victims began gathering in Paris.
fields.bodyText: The Air France Concorde which crashed in Paris was delayed for up to 30 minutes while work was carried out on an engine, it emerged today. Airline spokesman Francois Brousse told reporters at a press conference at Charles de Gaulle airport: "There was work done on the plane just before the flight, there was a slight delay then the plane took off." When asked what the work involved, he replied: "It was work on an engine but at the present moment we can't absolutely know if it has something do with the cause of the crash, we are waiting for information from our industrial department." Mr Brousse said the engine work took a few minutes and was not unusual before a flight. He would not confirm whether it involved the jet's left or right engines. Flames poured from at least one of the jet's left wing engines as it took off from Charles de Gaulle airport yesterday. Moments later it ploughed into the two-star Hotelissimo in Gonesse, killing all 109 passengers and crew and four people on the ground in an impact one witness described as being "like an atomic bomb". Air France today grounded its remaining Concorde fleet while inquiries continued into the first crash involving the veteran supersonic jet in its 30-year history. But British Airways decided to go ahead with its scheduled New York flights from Heathrow after offering passengers refunds or alternative flights. A half-full BA Concorde took off from Heathrow at 10.45am. Meanwhile, details were emerging of an incredible escape from the stricken hotel by a British tour guide. Alice Brooking, 21, a student from Hildenborough, near Tonbridge, in Kent, leaped from the first floor of the hotel, escaping with just a burn to the arm. She told London's Evening Standard: "I just keep saying to myself over and over again: 'I'm alive, I'm alive, I'm alive'." Earlier crash investigators recovered two black box flight recorders from the charred remains of the Concorde. Both were damaged. French legal experts are also beginning the grim task of examining the bodies of the 113 victims, mainly German tourists, to establish their identities as relatives prepare to fly into the French capital. Investigators - including three British experts from the Air Accident Investigation Branch - were trying to determine what started the fire. Ninety-six of the passengers on Flight AF4590 were from Germany, 17 from the town of Mönchengladbach, on the border with the Netherlands. There were two Danes, one Austrian and one American, a retired Air France employee. Three of the victims were children. The European passengers on board were all en route from Charles de Gaulle airport to New York where they were due to join a luxury cruise liner heading for the Caribbean. Witnesses described the stricken jet trailing a sheet of flame hundreds of feet long from one of its Olympus engines before smashing into the hotel, sending a plume of smoke 1,000ft into the afternoon sky and showering hot debris over a wide area. It was the first serious accident involving Concorde, which has been flying for 30 years. The Queen has sent messages of sympathy to the French president, Jacques Chirac, and the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder. The prime minister, Tony Blair, also wrote to the leaders to express his "shock and sympathy" on behalf of the government, a Downing Street spokesman said. The US president, Bill Clinton, sent a message of condolence to the relatives of those who died. The crashed airliner had been in service since 1980 and had flown 12,000 hours, said the president of Air France, Jean-Cyril Spinetta. It had its last mandatory safety check just four days before the tragedy. President Chirac was due to visit the crash scene today as relatives of the victims began gathering in Paris.

fields.headline: Fiji: Speight reported arrested
fields.trailText: Fiji coup leader George Speight was today arrested by the Pacific island nation's military forces.
fields.body:
Fiji coup leader George Speight was today arrested by the Pacific island nation's military forces.

Speight was arrested - along with three others including media advisor Jo Nata - after a shoot-out with security forces as he travelled to his base at Kalabu school on the outskirts of Suva, press agency AFP has reported Meanwhile, Fiji's military said today it had bolstered its presence across the awaiting an announcement of a new government following the coup in May.

Amid threats of reprisals from coup rebels, Fiji's President Ratu Josefa Iloilo on has kept up efforts to form the new government, although reports that the Cabinet would be announced later in the day proved wrong.

Military spokesman Lieutenant Ro Alipate Mataitini said extra troops had been posted throughout Fiji and warned that rebels could expect a tough response if they tried to cause unrest.

"The military has deployed soldiers around the country in anticipation of a negative reaction by George Speight supporters to the announcement of the new Cabinet lineup," Mataitini told Fiji One TV.

The European Union is the latest economic group to move toward sanctions. Australia, New Zealand and the United States have already imposed them.

"It is essential that the rule of law be restored and that the political rights of all elements of the Fijian nation be respected," the 15 EU nations said in a statement yesterday.

The EU warned it could suspend Fiji's trade privileges and development aid granted under the Lome Agreement between the EU and 71 African, Caribbean and Pacific nations.

Under the agreement, the EU can demand consultations on non-respect of democracy and human rights. Based on those consultations, it can suspend aid and trade preferences.

Under the agreement, the EU pays Fiji around 25 million euros ($23 million) yearly in development aid. Favourable trade terms in the agreement allow Fiji to export some 140 million euros ($130 million) a year to the EU, mostly sugar products.

webTitle: July 26: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: In brief and casting news
fields.standfirst: A storm over George Clooney's latest flick;  Claudia Schiffer's less-than-model acting ability; Leo DiCaprio's criminal role; and decision time for Tim Roth
fields.trailText: A storm over George Clooney's latest flick; Claudia Schiffer's less-than-model acting ability; Leo DiCaprio's criminal role; and decision time for Tim Roth
fields.body:
 The makers of the summer blockbuster The Perfect Storm may be facing legal action after the widow of Bill Tyne, the true-life skipper played in the film by George Clooney, alleged it had tarnished her husband's memory. Jodie Tyne claims the Warner Bros' picture portrays her late husband as an irresponsible maverick who endangered the lives of his crew, and contends that the movie's publicity is crass and insensitive. "Thanks to this movie I can't put him to rest," she told reporters. Tyne died when his boat sunk off the coast of Nova Scotia in the storms of 1991, and his story was immortalised in the 1997 bestseller by Sebastian Junger, later adapted by director Wolfgang Petersen. Mrs Tyne's lawyer claims that the Junger book is "half fantasy" and "an inaccurate source for the movie".

 Model-turned-actress Claudia Schiffer has come in for criticism in her homeland for refusing to dub her own voice into German. Schiffer made her film debut last year speaking English in the Hollywood picture Black and White, but was unwilling to provide a German language version. Perhaps the scathing reviews have scared her off. When Black and White opened in the US recently, New York Times critic Elvis Mitchell scoffed at Schiffer's "efforts to wrestle English to the floor and pin it", while co-star William Lee Scott reportedly criticised her acting ability, remarking to a British paper that "she can hardly come through an open door without instruction".

 Parker Posey has signed up to co-star in Fine Line's The Anniversary Party, an ensemble drama also featuring Gwyneth Paltrow, John C Reilly and Kevin Kline. The film will mark the directorial debut of actress Jennifer Jason Leigh.

 DreamWorks is reported to be have its heart set on roping Leonardo DiCaprio into its forthcoming crime drama, Catch Me If You Can. The Hollywood Reporter reports that the studio is eager to have DiCaprio star in the biopic of criminal Frank Abagnale, the youngest man to make the FBI's most-wanted list.

 Tim Roth could be facing a major decision this week. Unnamed sources claim the British actor is being forced to choose between two high-profile roles. Rumour has it that Roth has been offered the role of Professor Snape in the Harry Potter picture and the part of a wicked simian in Tim Burton's remake of The Planet of the Apes. Both films are due to roll before the cameras at the same time.

webTitle: Doctor struck off 15 years after first alert

fields.headline: Doctor struck off 15 years after first alert
fields.trailText: Richard Neale, the disgraced gynaecologist who botched operations, failed to get proper consent from patients and lied to them and to the authorities, was yesterday struck off the medical register in Britain, 15 years after he was banned from practising as a doctor in Canada.
fields.body:
Richard Neale, the disgraced gynaecologist who botched operations, failed to get proper consent from patients and lied to them and to the authorities, was yesterday struck off the medical register in Britain, 15 years after he was banned from practising as a doctor in Canada.

Ken Hobbs, the chairman of the professional conduct committee of the General Medical Council which last week found 34 out of 35 allegations proved against Neale, told the doctor that his history of professional errors, failure to accept responsibility and dishonesty left the committee in no doubt that he was guilty of serious professional misconduct.

Although Neale has 28 days to appeal, his registration will be suspended immediately.

Neale issued a statement through the Medical Protection Society, claiming that the cases against him represented only 0.14% of his professional work over a 10 years. "My family and I are totally devastated by this decision, the events of recent weeks and the two years it has taken to bring evidence before the GMC. My life and career are now in ruins," it said.

"I would like to apologise fully and unreservedly to those patients whose cases have been the subject of this hearing. I am very sorry for the physical and psychological suffering they and their families have endured. It is a tragedy not just for them but for me also."

The General Medical Council, which was told in 1985 that Neale had been banned from working as a doctor in Canada and the Friarage hospital in North Yorkshire, which gave him a pay-off and a good reference 10 years later in spite of concerns about his performance, have already come under heavy fire for their failure to protect patients.

Sir Donald Irvine, president of the GMC, called the case "shocking and disturbing". He added: "Yet again one tiny minority of bad doctors discredits the excellent work of the vast majority of doctors in this country." But he said he would not try to defend the conduct of the GMC in 1985, when it was informed by the Canadian medical authorities that Neale had been banned from practising in Canada. The GMC decided to take no action and is thought to have destroyed the papers relating to Neale three years later, as was its practice at the time.

Sir Donald said he was writing to the health secretary, Alan Milburn, asking for a change in the law to allow the GMC to act against a doctor on the basis of findings overseas. At the moment, the GMC has to re-try the case against the doctor.

The Department of Health said it would be working with the GMC on loopholes shown up by the case. "We have taken and are taking concerted and thorough action to put these procedures in place to minimise the risk of similar cases happening in the future," a spokesman said.

The Friarage hospital in Northallerton has been severely criticised for giving Neale a £100,000 severance payment in 1995 and a clean reference, which enabled him to get work in hospitals in Leicester, London and the Isle of Wight. But yesterday, commenting on the case for the first time, the chief executive, Tony Bruce, said they did not feel they were to blame. The cases against Neale had come to light after he left the hospital, he said.

The reference was based on the findings of a clinical panel set up by the Northallerton NHS trust in October 1993 to investigate Mr Neale in the light of concerns over the Canadian judgment and also a police caution he received in September 1991 relating to soliciting in public toilets.

The panel sat to January 1994. It took evidence from other doctors and patients, and found they were "overwhelmingly supportive" of Mr Neale, the trust said.

Neale was then suspended in August 1995 following allegations of his "unavailability when he was on call, public misrepresentation of his role and fraudulent expense claims". There was no suggestion of any harm to patients, the trust said, and a legal agreement was reached to terminate his employment involving a lump sum of £100,000, representing a year's wages. Disciplinary action would have taken two years and, the trust said, its advice was that it would be unlikely to succeed.

In August 1996, the trust received a complaint from the Leicester royal infirmary about the reference it had supplied for Neale. The trust said this was a surprise as "it had expected him to be able to work successfully at other hospitals".

As a result, it did not supply a reference for Neale again - which did not stop him getting work as a locum in a private hospital in London and on the Isle of Wight.

There are now more than 60 complaints outstanding against Neale, some of which are being investigated by the police, including two in Canada.

The failure of both his NHS employers and the GMC to stop Neale very much earlier sets the scene for reforms about to be introduced through the NHS modernisation plan on Thursday.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Today's gossip, buried in a tomb, and discovered thousands of years later by a group of explorers, who are then cursed
fields.trailText: Marc Overmars looks likely to move to Barcelona after making this statement on his personal website at icons.com: "Of course, I'm extremely flattered by their interest in me and the prospect of moving to such a huge club would excite any player. For the time being at least, I remain an Arsenal player."
fields.body:
Marc Overmars looks likely to move to Barcelona after making this statement on his personal website at icons.com: "Of course, I'm extremely flattered by their interest in me and the prospect of moving to such a huge club would excite any player. For the time being at least, I remain an Arsenal player."

Meanwhile Barcelona defender Winston Bogarde has told the same site that he wants a move to the Premiership. "I'd be delighted to join an English team and play in the Premiership," he said. "It's a fantastic league to watch and I'm sure it would be exciting to play in." In the past week Bogarde has been linked with a move to Chelsea.

Barcelona will join AC Milan in attempting to lure David Beckham to foreign shores. The Mirror quotes new Barca president Joan Gaspart as saying: "I note with interest that Sir Alex Ferguson and David Beckham seem to have a difference of opinion that has not gone away." Whether Gaspart will follow up his observation with some hard cash remains to be seen however.

Another Barcelona target, according to Planet Football, is Sylvain Wiltord. The Bordeaux striker has long been expected to move to Arsenal but Barca could scupper any deal with a late offer for the 27-year-old.

Internazionale have confirmed their interest in Coventry's Robbie Keane. Inter's managing director, Gabriele Oriali, has been quoted in the Italian press as saying that any move for Lazio's Marcelo Salas will come second to an attempt to land Keane. "First Keane and then, eventually, the Chilean," he said.

George Weah will sign for Fulham, reports the Daily Express - but only if he is given a coaching role at the club.

The Express also claims that Christian Ziege does have a get out clause in his contract, and that Bryan Robson has only just learnt of it. It has been suggested many times in the press that the German international is allowed to talk to any club that makes a transfer offer of over £5m (as Liverpool have recently done). Robson has always the existence of the clause, but the Express claims they learnt the truth this week from Boro's chief executive Charles Lamb.

fields.headline: Swimming with turtles
fields.standfirst: For the past two weeks we have been carrying reports from the Dragon School's cricket tour to Barbados. Today is the last excerpt in the series, but click here to read reports from the previous fortnight, written by the captain of cricket James Schneider
fields.trailText: Day 14
fields.body:
Day 14

We all rise early, have breakfast in our rooms and prepare for a day of sailing and snorkelling. The tour party boards the Tiami II and heads off north up the West coast, which is studded with coral reefs and groups of marine turtles. We had flying fish and Bajan style beef stew for lunch, then I worked off my four helpings by snorkelling over a wreck of a drug-runners' boat. We were also successful in finding a small colony of turtles. They gladly swam with us in return for being hand-fed titbits.

In the evening we returned to The Lucky Horseshoe Saloon, an American western-style restaurant next door to our hotel. We dined heartily on spicy fare served to us on the upstairs balcony. Throughout the meal the staff presented tour awards, together with a photograph of everyone at the Kensington Oval. My award was the Roget Award for the widest vocabulary, (mainly used in this article, and not when briefing the team) as well as being commended for my captaincy. Most of the awards were light-hearted, such as the When In Rome and Turnip of the Tour gongs, with outstanding cricketing achievements also given recognition. The parents and families who came along to cheer us were also an important part of the fun.

I speak for all Dragons when I say what a great pleasure and privilege it has been to represent our school and to compete in an atmosphere full of love for the game. The beauty and interest of our surroundings and the friendliness we have met are icing on the cake.

Finally, I wish to express my thanks to RAK, JC, Rob Dow plus Noll and Vicky Jenkins for a fantastic tour and my gratitude to the Dragon and all its staff for a brilliant time at the school, on and off the playing field.

webTitle: Feature: Sarah Ebner  asks why film studios and publishers are suddenly so fixated with what happened before.

fields.headline: Here's one we made earlier
fields.standfirst: As a new Flintstones prequel arrives in cinemas,  Sarah Ebner  asks why film studios and publishers are suddenly so fixated with what happened before
fields.trailText: As a new Flintstones prequel arrives in cinemas, Sarah Ebner asks why film studios and publishers are suddenly so fixated with what happened before.
fields.body:
The Flintstones are back, but this time it's before they were a family. In the new version, out this Friday, Mark Addy, of Full Monty fame, is Fred, a bachelor boy about to meet Wilma, while Dino, their pet dinosaur, starts out as an egg. It's the latest in a new trend - the prequel.

A prequel is something that is made after the original, but set before. And The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas isn't the only prequel around. Whereas we were once desperate to find out "what happened next", we now seem keener to discover what went before. Suddenly we're putting films and books on the psychiatrist's chair, trying to discover what actors have talked about for years: a character's motivation.

Brian Levant directed both the first and second Flintstones films. He spent years trying to come up with an idea for a sequel and couldn't. Then someone suggested a prequel and it all fell into place. "If you're dealing with characters that you have a relationship with," he says, "it's very interesting to go back and learn more about them and what elements forged them into the people that we know today."

This seems to be the key to prequel making, and one of the reasons they can be satisfying to view or read. All the questions we have about why someone ended up as they did are answered - although perhaps not in the way we expected them to be.

Christopher Bigsby is the author of Hester: A Romance, a prequel to Nathaniel Hawthorne's The Scarlet Letter. Bigsby says he wrote the book because Hawthorne's original left certain mysteries open and he wanted to know the answers to the various questions that were implied but never answered. He admits Hawthorne himself probably wouldn't have come up with the same solution, but says that isn't a problem. "I'm working with characters given to me," he says. "And I'm trying to be consistent. I'm not damaging or destroying the existing book. If anything I'm doing this out of respect for it. It could bring others to the original."

Bringing people back to the original could be said of all prequels, not least John Updike's Gertrude and Claudius. Updike's not scared of taking on established characters and giving them a past, though it may not be the one Shakespeare had in mind. And the book may surprise some, as it more or less absolves Claudius of guilt.

"Putting aside the cover-up of the murder," Updike writes in his afterword - although surely the point of Hamlet is that you can't just "put aside" that murder - "Claudius seems a capable king, Gertrude a noble queen, Ophelia a treasure of sweetness, Polonius a tedious but not evil counsellor, Laertes a generic young man. Hamlet pulls them all into death."

With Gertrude and Claudius, Updike is practising something that has lately been much in the news - spinning. By creating a new "back story" to the play, he can start the characters off however he wants. All he has to do is make sure the book ends ready for Shakespeare's play to begin. One of the most famous prequels - Wide Sargasso Sea, a prequel to Jane Eyre - similarly plays with Charlotte Brontë's characters, explaining why the first Mrs Rochester went mad.

"You can go backwards and forwards, inner space or outer, and that suits the fans. They want to be able to use their imagination, to go into a different world from this one."

fields.headline: Freud goes country
fields.standfirst: Jaeger seeks wit, fun and frippery
fields.trailText: Jaeger seeks wit, fun and frippery
fields.body:
Pleated skirts, tweed jackets and warm jumpers could soon be a thing of the past at Jaeger. The century-old label beloved of well-off countrywomen has appointed Bella Freud, the fashion designer, to update its image with a more contemporary range of clothing for autumn 2001.

Freud, a former assistant to Vivienne Westwood, is known for her quirky designs. Her trademarks include kitsch, colourful knitwear - Scottie dogs are a favourite motif - and curvy modern tailoring. The daughter of the painter Lucian Freud and great-granddaughter of the psychoanalyst Sigmund Freud, she has dressed celebrities, including Madonna, Courtney Love, Jerry Hall and Kate Moss, none of whom is known to be a devotee of Jaeger.

But Freud's English humour could be the catalyst Jaeger needs for a revival along the lines of that other country house favourite, Burberry.

Freud's collections often feature traditional English fabrics, especially tweed, a Jaeger favourite.

"I have always looked to English traditions and classics as a source of inspiration in my work," the designer said.

"Working with Jaeger will be a wonderful opportunity to collaborate with a house so grounded in the traditions of quality and craftsmanship."

Jaeger's new chief executive, Pat Burnett, who believes that "people are staying younger for longer", says forty- and fiftysomething core customers want more modern-looking clothes than they are currently offered.

"Freud will add a bit of wit, fun and frippery," she said.

Over the past 20 years Jaeger, a mainstay of the upmarket high street during the 1960s and 1970s, has been hit by increasingly tough competition from European brands such as MaxMara.

A series of management changes in the past three years has left the brand faltering.

But of the prospects for regenerating the Jaeger brand, which is owned by Coats Viyella, Burnett says: "It's going to take time to turn it round, but I believe it can be done."

fields.headline: A question of race
fields.standfirst: This week and last we have been carrying reports from the Dragon School's cricket tour to Barbados. Find out how the First XI and the Under-12s got on by reading regular updates from James Schneider, captain of cricket, on wisden.com
fields.trailText: Day 13
fields.body:
Day 13

Today (Saturday) we are at the beach and the playing part of the tour is over. Before we go to the beach, I watch a little of the Zimbabwe innings in the final of the Triangular Tournament from Lord's, live on Barbados television. Tomorrow we have a catamaran cruise and the closing dinner. On Monday the group go home, but I am joining my family for another few days. No doubt, Timothy will have me at work as his net bowler.

With a strange, sad sensation, I realise that my cricket career at the Dragon is over. Oddly, it ended as it began. I went to the Dragon at half term in the summer term of 1999. I went straight into the second XI and took a wicket with my first ball in a match. Yesterday I took a wicket with my last ball as a Dragon. In September, I go to Winchester College and will have to start all over again.

Mathew Engel wrote in last year's Wisden about racism in English cricket. My generation seems to be colour-blind. Last season, I was playing a game and two players, one white, one black were batting under helmets. The scorer (aged about 12) could not tell them apart, nor could any of us, until the difference in skin colour was pointed out by the adult umpires. On this tour, I noticed that two of the sides we played were from "white bajan" clubs. One of the clubs you wouldn't know unless you looked carefully that it was a "white" club; the other it is blatantly obvious. The sides we played were mixed.

Fifty years ago it was inconceivable that West Indies would have a black captain (the first being Sir Frank Worrell). Now, I am told, it is inconceivable that a white player, however good, will ever consistently be in an island team, let alone the national side.

Discrimination in English cricket took a different form, that of amateur v professional. Only a few years before Sir Frank Worrell led the Windies did a professional, Sir Len Hutton, captain the England side. Yet now I hear talk of a return of amateurs, at least to the English county cricket game.

Discrimination follows strange cycles, perhaps like that of facial hair. As Sir Tom Stoppard points out in "New Found Land", it was fashionable in the reign of King George V to have a big beard; now it is a sign of being respectable if you are clean-shaven.

fields.headline: Tax raids spotlight Azharuddin again
fields.trailText: The Lord giveth and the taxman taketh away. Last month on wisden.com, we warned that India's cricketers faced a reckoning from the taxman. Even so, the recent raids on the homes, businesses, and lockers of some of the biggest names in Indian cricket took the world by surprise. The tax department (IT) can hit people where it hurts - in the bank balance.
fields.body:
The Lord giveth and the taxman taketh away. Last month on wisden.com, we warned that India's cricketers faced a reckoning from the taxman. Even so, the recent raids on the homes, businesses, and lockers of some of the biggest names in Indian cricket took the world by surprise. The tax department (IT) can hit people where it hurts - in the bank balance.

How dare they? Bullying no-good bookies and second-rate cricketers is standard fare, but subjecting legends in their filthy-rich lifetimes to public humiliation is a feat previously thought impossible. For sheer audacity alone, the guys at IT should take a bow. And it was done in the best possible taste. Precisely what you would expect from a mission code-named Operation Gentleman. They might have homed in on the usual suspects but, wow, what a collection of scalps bowled middle stump, offering no stroke. Until very recently, Kapil Dev, Jagmohan Dalmiya and Mark Mascarenhas were a triad of big cheeses, names of fame and power. The visits they had from IT show how suspicion can cut across all disciplines: player-coach, administrator-businessman, and agent/media mogul.

Even though, according to India Today, the prime target of the raids was Dalmiya, it turned out to be another dismal episode for Kapil. He is reported to have blubbed five times during the raid on his house, but this time he had good reason. He also had a chapter of his autobiography removed from a school curriculum in Gujarat. The World of Kapil Dev must be more interesting and better essay-fodder than Ring of Bright Water, which I yawned through at school.

Despite IT's general diligence, however, there is one chink. How did the boy from Bombay, Sunil Gavaskar, avoid a raid? Gavaskar has been frequently dogged by match-fixing allegations and his locker at Bombay Gymkhana was recently forced open, allegedly disclosing a large amount of hard currency. This might be a stink that Gavaskar wants to ignore now that he is chairman of ICC's cricket committee, but it will inevitably come back to disturb his nostrils if he doesn't deal with it as soundly as he used to see off the West Indian pacemen.

Yet the man with the most to answer, and probably lose, is Mohammad Azharuddin, whose surname actually means Light of the Faith. And his faith is a key issue here. Azhar says that he is a ready scapegoat because he is a Muslim. There is naturally some truth in that, but Azhar has also much to thank India's largely Hindu fans and administrators for. He is India's longest-serving and most successful captain. Cricket has made him incredibly rich.

Azhar's wealth, though, cannot be explained by income from cricket. Recently, an Indian cricketer declared a vast sum of money during a tax amnesty, and although the cricketer's identity has not been officially revealed, it is widely held to be Azhar, even before the revelation in an Australian TV documentary that Azhar's wealth was $US50 million. This is a sum surely beyond Azhar's star status, acumen, and the pulling power of his not-that-successful Bollywood actress wife. It also makes a mockery of the 80p that the UK's Inland Revenue insist I owe them.

So where did Azhar's millions come from? To his credit, he quickly contacted IT to promise a full statement on his return to India after the July 29 charity match at The Oval, and he continues to protest his innocence from accusations of match-fixing. Azhar needs a watertight explanation, however, because the match-fixing controversy, from Rashid Latif's blows of the whistle to the King Enquiry, has thrown his name up as often as any other. He has also been accused of having links with the Muslim mafia bosses of Bombay, the alleged kingpins of match-fixing.

Faith, again, is muddying the waters, as it has done for much of India's history and Azhar's career. Shine a light please, Azhar, because IT's noose looks too tight for even your magical wrists to wriggle out of.

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is editor of the Bulletin of the World Health Organisation. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on Cricket Unlimited and wisden.com. To read his previous column, on the brown-white split in international cricket,click here. Next Wednesday Orin Gordon returns with his Anglo-Caribbean View.

webTitle: Ann Widdecombe: a maximum conviction politician

fields.headline: Ann Widdecombe: a maximum conviction politician
fields.standfirst:
The shadow home secretary offers a confused and unpopular Tory party a rare beacon of hope, writes Julian Glover

Talk to Ann Widdecombe here at Guardian Unlimited at 1pm on Friday July 28

Ann Widdecombe factfile
fields.trailText: The shadow home secretary offers a confused and unpopular Tory party a rare beacon of hope, writes Julian Glover.
fields.body:
When Tony Blair complained in his leaked memo that the government had lost touch with the "gut instincts of the British people", the Conservative party's attacks on his law and order policy were at the forefront of his mind. And that counts as a triumph for Ann Widdecombe.

The success story of the Tory party's three years in opposition, the shadow home secretary has risen from the middle ranks of John Major's government to the top of William Hague's shadow cabinet. She is the one Tory politician, including the party's leader, who can count on immediate public recognition. Her website - the Widdy Web - is the busiest of any MP.

In a House of Commons packed with bland, middling, competent, boring suits, Widdecombe shines out as an oddball. While others fret about focus groups, she seems not to care a fig.

As a Home Office minister, she was branded "Doris Karloff" after defending the shackling of a pregnant woman prisoner to a hospital bed.

But she was the first opposition MP to rise from the grave after the Tories' election catastrophe, lashing out at her former boss, Michael Howard, as a man with "something of the night about him" - scuppering his chances of becoming party leader at a stroke.

She speaks happily of her spinsterish ways, of her virginity and of her disdain for the liberal consensus. She is a career woman, but with no time for feminism - "what a whinge!". Widdecombe famously defected to Catholicism rather than accept female Anglican priests.

She has kept alive the social conservatism that marked the Margaret Thatcher era in a party which, in the form of Michael Portillo, has timidly tried to adjust its world view. Passionately anti-abortion, to the extent that images of aborted foetuses hang on the walls of her Commons office, Widdecombe subscribes to most of the traditional nostrums of the right. Pro-hanging, pro-flogging and so-called "family values", many find Widdecombe's views shocking.

Her directness pulls much of the sting. "I am toothy, dumpy, ugly, overweight, a spinster what the hell!" she once said.

Like that other Tory MP of the take-me-as-you-find school of politics, Ken Clarke, Widdecombe knows how to persuade voters to lower the guard which cuts them off from colleagues of a more processed variety.

Widdecombe is not shy of the media and - in private at least - revels in the nickname Doris Karloff. She likes talking to journalists and her brusque exterior hides a calculating public performer with a strong sense of image-building: something apparent in her party conference speeches as a shadow cabinet member.

In 1998, as shadow health secretary, she strode to the front of the Ikea-designed set used by the Tories that year and lectured the hall without notes for 45 minutes on the inadequacies of the NHS. It was a memorable and rather frightening experience but the party loved it.

Last year she repeated the show in Blackpool, this time as shadow home secretary. As she marched to the front to begin the harangue, two party workers walked on, unbolted the podium used by lesser speakers unable to perform without notes, and carried it off. The hall gave its biggest cheer of the week.

What was noticeable about the speech, though, was its content. The thought of hearing Widdecombe address the Conservative party conference must chill any liberal - but had such a liberal ventured to Blackpool they would have found themselves agreeing with much of what she said.

Her focus was the importance of prison, but without the simplistic "prison works" tones of Michael Howard, her one-time boss. Education, reform and the need for good conditions were the dominant themes; the words of someone who believes in the possibility of self-improvement.

But her policies and her confidence do not always stand close scrutiny. Colleagues complain about her willingness to call for unquantifiably-expensive pledges - locking up asylum-seekers, for instance - that make a mockery of Portillo's desire to create a workable policy on public finance. It does not inspire confidence that she is ready to cope with the subtleties of running the Home Office.

Whispering voices from Tory ranks also questioned her subdued profile over the case of Tony Martin, the Norfolk farmer jailed for shooting dead a young trespasser. It was Hague, not his shadow home secretary, who put the government on the spot.

She is entirely atypical as a politician in that she had a career before her election to parliament in 1987: at Unilever and then as an administrator at the University of London. Earlier this year she published a best-selling novel, The Clematis Tree. The Guardian's Sally Weale said Widdecombe's "vision of life in this book is cruel and unforgiving".

Widdecombe would be a powerful contender for the leadership of her party, if William Hague failed to stay the course. But for now, she seems content to set out her policy stall in the belief that rising crime figures and growing public discontent will prove her right and Jack Straw wrong. Expect her to be everywhere during the general election. And afterwards? Wait and see.

webTitle: Cyberspace Star Wars over bogus trailer

fields.headline: Cyberspace Star Wars over bogus trailer
fields.trailText: An expertly packaged trailer for the new Star Wars picture is currently causing understandable confusion on the web. Complete with official-looking logos from Fox and Lucasfilm, the promo boasts engrossing battle scenes and footage of Ewan McGregor, Natalie Portman, Hayden Christensen. One can even catch a glimpse of Gabriel Byrne, who has yet to confirm that he's even in the movie. Lest you haven't already guessed, the one problem with the trailer is that it's 100% bogus.
fields.body:
An expertly packaged trailer for the new Star Wars picture is currently causing understandable confusion on the web. Complete with official-looking logos from Fox and Lucasfilm, the promo boasts engrossing battle scenes and footage of Ewan McGregor, Natalie Portman, Hayden Christensen. One can even catch a glimpse of Gabriel Byrne, who has yet to confirm that he's even in the movie. Lest you haven't already guessed, the one problem with the trailer is that it's 100% bogus.

The promo is the brainchild of an American Star Wars fan who has adopted the pseudonym "TFN", presumably in order to avoid a legal broadside from George Lucas, who is renowned for policing his film franchise with an iron fist. In assembling the phoney trailer, TFN cannibalised battle-scenes from Braveheart, then added in glowing light-sabres. He doctored images of Gabriel Byrne from, his recent horror flick Stigmata, and dug up pictures of the little-known Hayden Christensen (who is to play Annakin Skywalker) from the young actor's cable TV show Higher Ground. The result is a classic of DIY innovation. Until the real McCoy rolls along sometime next summer, TFN's Star Wars trailer will have to suffice.

webTitle: Feature: The City Slickers, sacked by the Mirror for suspect dealing, have written a book.

fields.headline: The insiders' story
fields.standfirst: The City Slickers, sacked by the Mirror for suspect dealing, have written a book about making it rich. But would you take a tip from these two, asks  Paul Murphy
fields.trailText: The City Slickers, sacked by the Mirror for suspect dealing, have written a book about making it rich. But would you take a tip from these two, asks Paul Murphy.
fields.body:
These two scallywags: Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell. For a couple of years they were living a fast life in the perceived slow lane of financial journalism, putting some "show" into the world of business as the Mirror newspaper's very own City Slickers, tipping shares and promising to make their readers rich overnight.

In the process, they came close to parting Piers Morgan, the Mirror's editor, from his job and subsequently landed themselves (and Morgan) with a full-colour Department of Trade insider-dealing investigation.

And five months after being unceremoniously bundled out of the newspaper's Canary Wharf offices, having been found to be in flagrant breach of the Press Complaints Commission code on journalists' stock market dealings, the City's premier financial watchdog, the Financial Services Authority, popped up yesterday to declare that it would finally be bringing down the hammer on rampant stock market abuse.

The FSA has new powers for fighting financial crime. But for Bhoyrul and Hipwell, a rough-looking 34 and 32 respectively, the timing could not have been better. They are out and about promoting their new book, Make a Million in Twelve Months. So when the exotic-sounding Gay Wisbey, director of the markets and exchanges division at the FSA , said her officials would be having a word in the right ears about tightening the rules governing the financial affairs of business journalists, these two chancers can rightly claim to have made their mark, albeit unwittingly.

The book itself took two weeks to write - 150 pages apiece - and reads as such. "Well, it's just a laugh," says Bhoyrul, "it's for Mirror readers, not your sophisticated types."

If fact, it is just a bad joke, which kicks off with the italicised front cover claim of "We did!" alongside the Make a Million challenge.

No, they haven't. The two men are now on Mohamed Al Fayed's payroll as Punch columnists, while working on other unspecified projects for the great Egyptian entrepreneur. They claim to be earning more than they did as Mirror hacks, but Hipwell still hasn't been able to clear an £18,000 legal bill sitting at City lawyers Taylor Joynson Garrett since the Slicker affair. Bhoyrul is still clearly trying to get his head round the fact that at the Mirror, through his own dubious share dealings, he struggled to make even a tenth of the money (£20,000) his editor, Morgan, made on the one stock market trade that got him in deep, hot water.

The share dealing concerned a computer company called Viglen, controlled by Amstrad boss Sir Alan Sugar. Mr Morgan bought the stock just before the Slickers puffed the company in their daily column, which in turn had the share price-moving influence that comes when tens of thousands of Mirror readers rush out and buy a particular stock on one day.

Bhoyrul is threatening a book dedicated to the affair, under the working title A Tip Too Far, before he returns to his native Mauritius.

"I'm looking at doing another magazine launch and the book, but then it's more than likely I'll go back. I'm not going to work on newspapers again.

"In a year's time I would like to be settled with kids. I've been very lucky. At 34 I have done everything you could want to do in journalism. I would like to run a little bar on the beach. It's too stressful round here."

Hipwell, conversely, is not at all sure what he is going to do. He likes Punch, but a recently diagnosed kidney complaint means he will need a transplant at some stage. And, predictably, one or two of his old friends in the Square Mile have already offered to launch a campaign to get Morgan to donate one of his own organs.

This book, 300 knocked-off pages that read like a hastily assembled guide to personal finance with one or two limp jokes, is the end of the Slickers partnership. "I'm sick of it. The Punch column has a natural shelf life and it will probably be the last thing we do together," says Hipwell.

The sanctuary of Punch was offered by Mr Fayed in the wake of the Mirror scandal, with the Harrods owner presenting his fearless tipsters with £100,000 and a challenge to turn the money into £1m in the space of 12 months.

Five months in and the £100,000 has shrunk to £70,000. "We've got seven months left and we'll do it," laughs Bhoyrul, before reiterating the Slickers' claim that in their Mirror days they made their readers real money.

He points to tip after tip which rocketed after being featured on the Slicker page, but still refuses to face up to the reality that most of these shares later came back to earth like the proverbial stick - with Mirror readers, still holding the shares, left to count their losses.

But they have also experienced the wrath of Mirror readers when share prices did not move in the desired direction. "The abuse and the hate mail you would get was incredible," says Hipwell, with Bhoyrul throwing in his view that "all the readers were tossers. Piers told us that. In fact he said that most couldn't even read."

Along the way, they have some advice for Susie Jagger, the young financial hack from the Telegraph who broke the original story about Morgan's dealings, and who has been hired by the Mirror from this week to replace the Slickers with her own Susie in the City column. "We have already told her, 'Don't do it', but now she is she should not take it too seriously and should not get too close to the stock market itself," says Hipwell. "Beware of the readers," adds Bhoyrul. "Make one mistake and she'll get 2,000 calls in the space of five minutes. If a share price goes down, they will be outside her house, threatening to lynch her."

The book is aimed at what Bhoyrul and Hipwell perceive to be Mirror readers. It throws in some history about the lads' newspaper japes and their alleged extraordinary ability to beat the City at its own game, opening up a mysterious world to the lumpen private investor. It provides a bit of reference material, such as the best investment magazines to read, and also describes a few technical matters, such as how share trades are settled.

But there is not much more other than a strange chapter which seems to be an attempt to justify the book's cover title, slugged as a "Twelve-month guide to a million".

This runs to 10 pages in all and advises the budding stock market speculator to sit on their hands for a couple of months, before branching out, picking a few sure-fire investment winners and then turning the profit into cash.

The plan for Month Twelve, for example, is as follows: "Add up the value of every single share you have, and how much profit you are sitting on. Having played the market right, this could be a huge amount of dosh - hopefully £1m. If it is, and we hope it is, we have some very simple advice for you. Sell all your shares, take the cash and enjoy the rest of your life - and never more play the stock market. It will never get this good again."

Insightful stuff. Bhoyrul and Hipwell know the joke is no longer funny. They know they will never be given the chance to try again.

Make A Million In Twelve Months is published by John Blake Publishing, £5.99.

fields.headline: Godfathers and Monsters
fields.trailText: Francis Coppola is to serve as executive producer on the latest Hal Hartley film, Monster. The deal effectively brings together two generations of American cinema, as seventies titan Coppola signs up with nineties indie auteur Hartley. But it also suggests that Coppola is increasingly turning his back on film directing in favour of lucrative behind-the-scenes work.
fields.body:
Francis Coppola is to serve as executive producer on the latest Hal Hartley film, Monster. The deal effectively brings together two generations of American cinema, as seventies titan Coppola signs up with nineties indie auteur Hartley. But it also suggests that Coppola is increasingly turning his back on film directing in favour of lucrative behind-the-scenes work.

The precise nature of Monster's script remains a closely guarded secret, but the Hartley project is believed to offer a wry update on the likes of Beauty and the Beast. Insiders report that the oddball story follows a Manhattan journalist who trails her missing boyfriend to Iceland only to fall under the spell of a mythical snow creature. No cast members have been confirmed, though Hartley regular Robert John Burke (The Unbelievable Truth, Simple Men, Flirt) is rumoured to be on board.

Monster will be 40-year-old Hartley's first feature since his underrated Henry Fool opened in 1998. But Coppola's own work rate has been even more patchy. Since directing Bram Stoker's Dracula in 1991, the acclaimed creator of The Godfather and Apocalypse Now has been behind the camera just twice - directing the universally panned Jack in 1995 and the adequate John Grisham adaptation The Rainmaker in 1997. In the meantime, he has served as an executive producer on Tim Burton's Sleepy Hollow and helped produce his daughter Sofia's film debut, The Virgin Suicides. Coppola was also reported to have had a hand in the editing of this year's failed sci-fi romp Supernova.

Monster begins shooting in September in locations around Iceland and New York. It will be produced by Coppola's production company American Zoetrope and distributed by United Artists.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.trailText: "I am aware that Manchester is divided on sectarian lines: United are catholic; City are protestant. Are there any other such divisions in the English leagues?" asked cbobt last week.
fields.body:
"I am aware that Manchester is divided on sectarian lines: United are catholic; City are protestant. Are there any other such divisions in the English leagues?" asked cbobt last week.

"Manchester divided on sectarian lines?" fumes an unconvinced Stephen O'Malley. "I don't bloody think so. As a (lapsed) catholic Manchester United fan, I can assure Mr Bott that the Mancunian United fans (which there are quite a few of us) do not hold with the religious bigotry shown in Glasgow. The last time Celtic played at Old Trafford, the Celtic fans started a sectarian chant, which was shouted down by all United fans - much to Celtic's displeasure."

So where does the rumour come from? "If you know your history, United's supposed Catholicism comes from the fact that the 'father' of United, Louis Rocca, was an immigrant Italian who employed a network of catholic priests to scout for boys to play for United," says Stephen. "Matt Busby's appointment continued the Catholic link, but it died out in the seventies."

Liverpool is another city "definitely" divided on sectarian lines, claims Lee Calvert, who says that historically it is the only place in England that holds Orange Parades. However he reckons the oft-made assumption that Liverpool are the catholic team while Everton are protestant is wide of the mark.

"Goodison Park is built next to a catholic church, which would seem to suggest that from way back they were a catholic team. However they have always had strong links with Glasgow Rangers (kit, Mo Johnstone, Walter Smith, Duncan Ferguson) and Everton Valley in Liverpool is a deeply protestant area.

"Liverpool on the other hand seem to have stronger links with Celtic (Dalglish), but their directors are protestant and it is noticeable that Ulster protestants support them along with Rangers. As you can see it is a tricky one, but I am sure that Everton are in fact the Catholic team." Does anyone disagree?

"Thanks for your explanation of why the Italian kit is blue. Can anyone then explain why the German away strip is green?" asked Clayton Fossett.

We've had the biggest response ever to Knowledge Unlimited for this question. All of you agree that it dates back to a friendly between Ireland and Germany shortly after the second world war.

As Enda Kelly tells it: "After world war II, the Republic of Ireland was the first country to play Germany. Naturally the teams changed shirts after the match. One version of the story says that the Germans were so poor (I hasten to add financially, just in case there's any confusion with the present team), that they could not afford an away strip for their next match, and thus used the Irish shirts with the crest replaced. Thus began the tradition."

The second version, which Enda thinks is more likely - and is supported by everyone else - is that Germany was a bit of a pariah nation at the time, "and to show their gratitude to the Irish for bringing them back into the international football scene they chose green as their away strip."

Where can I find a full table of Premiership fixtures for next season? asked so many of you that we're not going to mention names.

Just click on the following link: (http://www.fa-premier.com/home.html)

After hours of heated debate my friends and I are still in disagreement on this one. Who was the first East German to represent the unified team? I think it may be Thomas Doll but a lot of people tell me that it'sMatthias Sammer and others have been mentioned. Can anyone help? asks Martin Widdicks.

Yes they can Martin. Thomas Snelker and others - including the rather improbably named Hal E. Lujah - all say it was definitely Matthias Sammer. The then VfB Stuttgart player was the only East German in the starting line-up for the unified Germany's first game, against Switzerland in Stuttgart on the 19th December 1990.

He played until the 74th minute, when he was replaced by another East German Andreas Thom - who went on to score the third goal in Germany's 4-0 victory. Meanwhile Thomas Doll didn't make his debut for the unified team until their next game, a 2-1 win over Russia on the 27th March 1991.

Can you help?

On the subject of national team colours: Why have England traditionally played in white shirts and blue shorts, when the flag of St. George is white and red? asks a puzzled Rob Hancock.

"I have a vivid memory of Socrates taking a penalty and bursting the net. Did it ever happen - or was it just the work of an over excited brain whilst sleeping? And if Socrates did not burst the net with one of his penalty kicks, has anyone else achieved such a feat?" wonders Jonathon Norman.

Any questions?

Send your football asks tothe.boss@theguardian.com the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to give you some answers.

fields.headline: Fonts of wisdom
fields.standfirst: Books with a difference
fields.trailText: Books with a difference
fields.body:
Two new books have given me immense pleasure this week. Before long, I'll actually read them. Despite what they say about not judging a book by its cover, some books demand to be judged by their layout. Among them are debuts by American writers Mark Z Danielewski and Dave Eggers - respectively, House of Leaves (Anchor, £13) and A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius (Picador, £14.99), or AHWOSG, as it says in tiny letters at the top of each page. Both so prominently feature tricks of design that they remind you, at every moment, that they are books, things of paper and print. We think of books as no more than transparent vehicles for meaning, so when a book asserts its bookness, it's as disconcerting as if it carried a big Magritte blurb announcing: "This Is Not A Book."

The Eggers volume seems simple enough: an autobiographical piece, largely played straight, typographically speaking, but prefaced by 39 pages of sarcasm in a smaller typeface, offering rules and suggestions, a jokey contents list, a flow chart illustrating the book's themes, and a little drawing of a stapler. And this self-reflexive wrapping extends to parts of the book normally considered off- limits to authors. Eggers has doctored the copyright line to read: "First published 2000 by Simon and Schuster, a division of a larger and more powerful company called Viacom Inc, which is wealthier and more populous than 18 of the official states of America." If you remove the jacket, you find he's even had the cover embossed with a pair of enigmatic aphorisms.

Eggers is effectively etching sarcastic graffiti onto his sober slab of text. But that's nothing to what Danielewski does. Rival texts by two narrators (one in the Times font, the other in Courier) consume each other in floods of footnotes; in turn, the two narratives are spiked with musical staves and Derrida-like crossings-out, with print going upside-down, right to left, reversed. Sometimes the text does what it describes: when a passageway gets narrower, so does the printed page; when a rope snaps, the word rope is stretched to breaking until a single letter floats unanchored in a void of white paper.

Both books are beautifully executed art objects - as close to avant-garde coffee-table volumes as novels can be. Both have been touted as the hippest new things in print, and yet a few years ago they probably would have been dismissed as outmoded formalist navel-gazing, the sort of masturbatory narcissism that was long ago driven off the shelves by hard-knuckled realism.

But every now and then there's a resurgence of books that flaunt themselves, in a tradition going back to the 18th century and Lawrence Sterne's Tristram Shandy, which turned the book into an unruly trick-box of traps and mirrors, customising it with squiggly lines, stars, black pages, pages that looked like marble slabs, and blank chapters.

The 60s were a high point for Sternean experiments. The books of French novelist Michel Butor gradually disintegrated to resemble the spaciest Mallarmé poems, sometimes in multi-coloured print. Perhaps the ultimate 60s book-as-thing was by novelist BS Johnson: The Unfortunates (1969, recently reissued by Picador), which came as a box of separate sections to be read in random order. There was a spate of 60s science fiction in which the text was gobbled up by computer print-out (Jeff Noon's 1998 novel Nymphomation reactivates this tradition). In the US, John Barth's collection Lost in the Funhouse (1968) contained a one-sentence story in the form of a cut-out-and-glue Moebius strip, and a story featuring so many layers of quoted speech that the page disappears in a swarm of inverted commas.

There's nothing new about House of Leaves or AHWOSG. However, typographical fancies were once regarded as a subversive tactic to disrupt narrative, to explode story in a bloodbath of pure signifier. With Danielewski and Eggers, the tactic has entered the narrative mainstream. Both books now look like plausible bestseller material in ways that Butor's or Johnson's never were. Is it that the once sinister and destructive typographical twist has been domesticated?

Or is it that innovations in design elsewhere - on the net, on CD sleeves and club flyers, in magazines such as Raygun - are having a knock-on effect on the staidness of the literary page? Two years from now, we may be all tearing our hair and complaining about the extinction of horizontal print. But for now I'm clearing my coffee table - in reality, a slab of marble designed to resemble a page of Tristram Shandy - for more strange works of staggering genius.

fields.headline: Breathing space
fields.standfirst: New parameters set for care home accommodation
fields.trailText: New parameters set for care home accommodation.
fields.body:
The government appears to have achieved a workable compromise on national standards for room sizes in care homes. In an announcement on Friday, John Hutton, the social care minister, stuck to the basic principle that by 2007 single rooms in existing homes should be at least 10 sq metres. In addition, each resident should have a minimum of 4.1 sq metres of communal space within the home.

But after months of negotiation with care home proprietors, he has accepted there can be some trading off between these two standards. Care homes with slightly smaller rooms will be allowed to stay open if they can offer more spacious communal facilities, and vice versa. The alternative would have been to force lots of well-run homes out of business, risking a shortage of supply of suitable accommodation, notably in West and East Sussex and Kent, where many rooms would have missed the new standard by less than 10%.

Age Concern said it sympathised with the care home owners' problem and backed the compromise.

According to the new rules, existing care homes "of good quality" will be allowed to continue offering rooms slightly smaller than the minimum standard after 2007 if they meet an alternative set of criteria.

The first is "an expectation that no room should fall below 9.3 sq metres (equivalent to 100 sq feet) provided compensatory space is available in the form of en-suite facilities or additional day space which residents can use individually if they wish".

The second is that "homes which provide spacious individual rooms, but do not currently meet the standard of 4.1 sq metres communal space for residents will be allowed to comply with a lower minimum of 3.7 sq metres".

For newly-built care homes, the government is sticking to the original proposal in last year's consultation document, Fit for the Future, that single rooms should have 12 sq metres of space.

Other minimum standards include 12 sq metre rooms for all wheelchair users, with door widths of 800mm for their own accommodation and for communal rooms. By 2002, shared rooms in existing homes will be allowed to make up no more than 20% of the total resident places.

Sheila Scott, chief executive of the National Care Homes Association, said: "The government has been realistic in accepting that you can't destabilise a massive independent sector by raising standards too quickly."

The new standards are expected to cause problems for some care homes in Lancashire and the Isle of Wight, where rooms of about 7.5 sq feet are commonplace. But market forces were already reducing demand for such facilities.

A spokesman for Age Concern said it backed the government's proposals. "We do have sympathy for people who are struggling to keep homes open," he said. "They have a financial predicament and lots of homes have closed over the last 18 months. If the government has come near to meeting those considerations, that is acceptable as long as the main thrust of standards legislation is retained."

In its consultation paper last year, the government said the current regulations were "incomplete, patchy and have developed in a piecemeal fashion". A set of national minimum standards will be published later this year, covering staffing, training and other aspects of provision in residential and nursing homes for older people.

webTitle: Brown and Cook at odds over single currency membership

fields.headline: Brown and Cook at odds over single currency membership
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Tensions within the cabinet over the single currency came to the surface again yesterday when chancellor Gordon Brown said that Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, was wrong to say that British membership was "inevitable".
fields.body:
Tensions within the cabinet over the single currency came to the surface again yesterday when chancellor Gordon Brown said that Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, was wrong to say that British membership was "inevitable".

With the latest polls showing a plunge in public support for Britain's entry into monetary union, the chancellor distanced himself from Mr Cook's remarks while giving evidence to MPs on the treasury select committee.

Mr Brown said that unless the government's five economic tests for entry were met, there was a risk of repeating the experience of Britain's ill-fated membership of the exchange rate mechanism. Any recommendation by the government to adopt the single currency would have to be endorsed in a referendum, he added. "It's hardly the case that, if the tests have got to be met and the people would have to make a decision, then the decision is a foregone conclusion."

Asked by the Liberal Democrat MP Edward Davey whether economic policy was being set to meet the five economic tests - which include the impact of monetary union on jobs, investment and flexibility - the chancellor replied: "Economic policy is being set in the interests of Britain and the British economy and [this is] what we will continue to do."

Mr Brown said that the cabinet was united in its support for the policy he had outlined in October 1997 - support for membership in principle, but with entry dependent on long-term economic convergence and support in a nation-wide plebiscite.

While the chancellor told the committee that growth and investment in the euroland economies were rising and unemployment was falling, he stressed that the five tests would have to be met.

Questioned about the impact of the £43bn boost to public spending announced last week, Mr Brown warned public sector workers that the injection of extra cash did not mean the government would sanction inflation-busting pay awards.

He said the main purpose of the boost to spending was to increase capital investment and improve public services rather than to give a green light to big pay awards.

"The rise in spending ought not to be equated with automatic pressure for public sector pay rises. I would caution anyone from the view that because we are able to do more on public spending, that is a signal for public sector pay rises. Public sector workers should expect affordable pay rises not unaffordable ones," he said.
