webTitle: Comment: So few Britons are keen on Europe. There's a surprise

fields.headline: So few Britons are keen on Europe. There's a surprise
fields.standfirst:
They've been playing politics for years with our Euro-membership

Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: The least surprising news of the year was formally announced from Brussels yesterday. Support within the United Kingdom for our membership of the European Union is now at the lowest level ever recorded.
fields.body:
The least surprising news of the year was formally announced from Brussels yesterday. Support within the United Kingdom for our membership of the European Union is now at the lowest level ever recorded.

It is apparently the worst batch of figures that the pollsters have produced since we joined. We don't like Europe. We think, like Nancy Mitford's Uncle Matt, that "abroad" is unutterably bloody and peopled by fiends and our experience of membership has done nothing to convince us otherwise. We are far and away the least enthusiastic member state according to any statistic that you care to measure. Well, surprise, surprise.

The poor unfortunate put forward by the commission in Brussels to comment upon these results did himself few favours, however, when he suggested that it would need "a long time" to explain why this should be the case. We expect people in Brussels to make mistakes, but he could not have been more wrong.

The reason for these figures can be given very simply and in next to no time: the EU and all its works is unpopular in the United Kingdom because British politicians have used the issue remorselessly throughout the past 30 years as a political football, playing alternatively to the narrow nationalism of the right or the socialist idealism of the left.

Thus in the 70s the Labour left portrayed British membership of Europe as a force designed to prevent the pursuit and introduction of radical socialist policies, while throughout the 80s Margaret Thatcher deployed it as an inhibiting factor on her pursuit of unrestricted laissez-faire capitalism.

Through much of the 90s, partly as a result of the well-meaning but profoundly weak premiership of John Major, it was allowed to develop into a touchstone issue which divided the Conservative party and rendered it politically incredible. That prepared a path for William Hague who has since pursued an approach apparently based on the belief that political - or, at least, electoral - salvation lies in a direct appeal to the basest amoral instincts of a nationalistic island race and hang the consequences.

One person who understands this is Geoffrey Martin, the head of the European Commission office in the UK, who long ago recognised the pointlessness of attempting to do anything to try to improve the image of Europe in this country, and who was telling anyone who asked him yesterday that the situation was deteriorating and was likely to get worse.

And was he surprised by this fact or these figures? He was not. No one could be surprised when the serious players did not want to discuss the matters involved seriously, and it was perfectly evident that in the forthcoming general election, the European issue would figure as it has so often before as a divisive factor within and between our political parties.

They are still puzzled in continental Europe, in the rest of the union where all the statistics in the other 14 member states indicate a cheerful degree of acceptance and the acceptability of membership. The trade commissioner, Pascal Lamy, was in the UK on a fact-finding mission earlier this month, talking to business leaders through the Confederation of British Industry, opinion-forming politicians, journalists and assorted policy wonks, in a committed attempt to try to understand what is going on and why we make our international political relationships so difficult for ourselves.

He could have saved himself the journey because the answer is that actually we don't - it is not we, innocent members of the electorate, worrying about the weather or the children or the mortgage, who are to blame. It is rather, as usual, the politicians.

So the next question is: what happens now? Is withdrawal from membership of Europe a possibility? Is it an option? Does anyone, even Mr Hague, happily reconciled as he seems to be with consigning much of his party's history and political philosophy to the memory hole, really believe that this is so? It seems improbable.

The next developments will all be political and should be interpreted entirely within the context of the run-up to the next election. They will be concerned almost exclusively with the tiresome business of the single currency but, controversial though this currently may be, there is a view around, at home and abroad, that the outcome of this debate might eventually resolve the future of Britain's role in Europe.

That depends, however, on how the government decides to play it. There are probably few members of the government who still have a subscription to Tribune, but it might repay someone with an interest in how to win the next election (given the acknowledged brand recognition problem) to nip out and get hold of the current issue.

There they will find some tips on how to stay on in government offered in a dispassionate fashion by Bob Worcester, the opinion poll sage who runs Mori. It is a foolish politician who does not pay attention when Bob Worcester has something significant to say. He is a wise old cassowary and he knows what he is talking about.

His theory goes like this: the Conservative party is perceived to be divided on the issue of Europe and therefore what the Labour party most needs to do is to ensure that its leading members do not attempt to steal the headlines by displaying their own differences. Gordon Brown, in Worcester's view, has got this absolutely right. Meanwhile Tony Blair should muzzle Peter Mandelson, shut up Stephen Byers - "That would not be difficult," he observes, somewhat acidly - and tell Robin Cook his job is on the line.

The people who are going to decide the next election are the people who are least likely to be paying close attention to the debate that is taking place on the question of a single currency, nor will they pay attention until the run-up to the referendum on a single currency. After Labour has won the election, the prime minister should promptly announce the date of the referendum.

And the opinion polls? In 1975 before the referendum on whether Britain should remain a member of the then EEC, the opinion polls showed that 55% of the electorate would vote to leave, as opposed to 45% who wanted to remain. The result, five months later in June, was 67% in favour of Britain remaining as a member and 33% against. In five months a coalition of the government backed by much of the political establishment - and, of course, the Conservative opposition - had secured a 22% swing.

It was a remarkable achievement and Bob Worcester believes it can be pulled off again. Indeed he has written as much in a pamphlet for the Foreign Policy Centre, How the Euro Referendum Will be Won: Lessons from the 1975 Referendum. And he is rather hurt that he has been branded a cynic. He is quite right to be offended. He is more politically realistic than almost anyone else who has so far joined in this debate.

fields.bodyText: The least surprising news of the year was formally announced from Brussels yesterday. webTitle: Cook champions bigger EU and urges deadline

fields.headline: Cook champions bigger EU and urges deadline
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European Commission
fields.trailText: Britain yesterday pledged to be the "champion" of enlarging the EU to embrace former communist countries and warned against creating a two-tier Europe in which newcomers would be second class citizens.
fields.body:
Britain yesterday pledged to be the "champion" of enlarging the EU to embrace former communist countries and warned against creating a two-tier Europe in which newcomers would be second class citizens.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, used a visit to Hungary to insist that Britain wanted a date for an end to negotiations by candidate countries increasingly frustrated that the union's big players are getting cold feet about taking in new members.

"Britain will be a champion of enlargement throughout the negotiations," he told diplomats in Budapest, in a speech designed to restore a sense of vision to the complex and highly technical business of joining the club. "Existing members of the European Union should remember that enlargement is not a project which the EU is doing as a favour to the applicants. Enlargement is in the EU's own interests."

Mr Cook's heavily-trailed remarks fused British backing for enlargement with strong opposition to controversial Franco-German plans for a "pioneer group" of integrationist-minded states which could leave laggards behind. "Europe cannot be a two-storey house in which some people are tenants and the other people are the owners," he warned, in a clear reference to French President Chirac's controversial call for a "pioneering group" to forge ahead.

Britain's strategy is to circumvent the discomfort of the single currency issue to back enlargement as the biggest challenge facing the EU, and to push for the completion of long overdue institutional reforms in the treaty of Nice in December. France, current holder of the EU presidency, does not want to issue deadlines for joining as Paris and Berlin worry about the costs of subsidising farmers, environmental problems and an influx of cheap labour.

Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Slovenia and Cyprus are already negotiating membership, while Romania, Bulgaria, Slovakia, Latvia, Lithuania and Malta form the second wave.

Mr Cook said: "The greatest challenge the EU faces is to complete the reunion of Europe. The fall of the iron curtain ended the division of our continent by political systems. Enlargement will end the division of our continent by standards of prosperity."

fields.headline: Windfall rescues regional theatre
fields.trailText: Chris Smith, the culture secretary, yesterday unveiled a bold rescue package for the arts, promising millions for the rejuvenation of an arts infrastructure devastated by almost two decades of neglect.
fields.body:
Chris Smith, the culture secretary, yesterday unveiled a bold rescue package for the arts, promising millions for the rejuvenation of an arts infrastructure devastated by almost two decades of neglect.

The Arts Council will receive an extra £100m a year from 2003, the biggest increase in funding in its 44-year history. There will be smaller phased increases of £15m and £45m a year before then, with a large portion of the money staunching the near meltdown in regional theatre.

The rise is well short of the extra £100m a year demanded by the council's chairman, Gerry Robinson. But last night Mr Robinson called the settlement "remarkable" and described it as a "step change in the support for the arts".

Mr Robinson said: "I have looked at the arts sector coolly as a businessman. There's no doubt we have historically underfunded the arts. I am absolutely delighted. We made clear that the government had put down a deposit on the arts in its first spending review and we trusted them to deliver the balance - today they have delivered."

The move is a personal triumph for Mr Smith, who said that arts funding had now increased by 60% in real terms in five years.

Of the funding, in two years' time, £12m will go to reviving the battered regional theatre companies, with an extra £25m the following year. The largest sum - about £40m - will pay for a new Creative Partnerships initiative to bring art, theatre and film to schools and deprived communities. Again, regional theatres are likely to be among the main beneficiaries.

Sir Richard Eyre, former head of the Royal National Theatre, who had grown impatient with government policy, yesterday welcomed the move. "This at last is promising news. This is also a considerable vote of confidence in Chris Smith. This government came into office saying the arts were at the core of their thinking. This is good news, but I hope it's just the beginning."

Philip Headley, of the Theatre Royal Stratford East, a tireless critic of successive governments, was delighted by the changes. "It's really terrific. For the first time I can remember we are being treated like adults and being left to get on with our jobs. My only worry is that the money may come too late for some who have been clinging on by their fingernails."

Sources close to the government last night stressed that the money would be directed towards rebuilding the arts infrastructure.

Jude Kelly, artistic director of the West Yorkshire Playhouse in Leeds, whose education and community programmes inspired Creative Partnerships, said the money was proof that the arts really mattered to the government.

"What it says is that access to arts and creativity is a basic, like health and education," she said yesterday

Only Sir Peter Hall, the theatre director, was less generous in his praise. "It is something but more is needed, and it is too late. I just hope there is a regional theatre left by the time the money comes through." Speaking from Denver, in the United States, where he is directing a season of work, he said he was relieved to be "working somewhere where art is valued and properly funded".

The precise breakdown of funding for the museums sector has been left dangling. It may be late September or early October before the arts bodies, which include Resource, the renamed museums, galleries, libraries and archives commission, and English Heritage get precise details about their government grants for the next three years.

webTitle: Leader: Mr Mandelson has a right to his money pay

fields.headline: A spell in the sin bin
fields.standfirst:
Mr Mandelson has a right to his money pay

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Cabinet ministers are in many ways fortunate people. They are paid big salaries, driven around in chauffeured cars, and expensively entertained in sought-after restaurants. The former Conservative cabinet minister Chris Patten summed it up best: none of his colleagues, he said, seemed to own a raincoat.
fields.body:
Cabinet ministers are in many ways fortunate people. They are paid big salaries, driven around in chauffeured cars, and expensively entertained in sought-after restaurants. The former Conservative cabinet minister Chris Patten summed it up best: none of his colleagues, he said, seemed to own a raincoat.

Yet they live under a shadow. At any moment, there may be a call from the boss and the privileged days will be over. Except for those who are already rich, a journey home on the bus and a miserable family conclave on how to cut costs may follow.

That is why, when they lose their jobs, they now qualify for severance payments. People who believe in fair terms of employment should not quarrel with that. What they may find less acceptable is the case of Peter Mandelson, who had to resign in December 1998 after the trouble over his home loan, but was back in the cabinet team the following October.

His pay cut - from £90,000 to £45,000 over those 10 months, a loss of approximately £37,500 - was cushioned by a severance payment of £11,250. Liberal MP Norman Baker says this is wrong. He will not be alone in doing so.

But the rules are the rules, and they have to apply just as much to a minister who is widely distrusted as they would to someone hugely popular; Mo Mowlam for instance. If MPs think Mr Mandelson has been treated more generously than he should have been, the answer is: change the rules.

They might try to eliminate payments for those merely serving time, as it were, in the sin bin, rather than banished for good, though devising watertight regulations for that would demand an ingenuity given to few. Stipulate, for instance, a minimum qualification of one year out in the cold, and future Mandelsons would simply stay out of office for 13 months. If Mr Mandelson, musing on his good fortune, were to choose to return the money, or give it to an appropriate charity, well and good. But he ought not to be coerced.

fields.headline: The fall of Concorde
fields.standfirst:
We expected perfection. That was unreal

Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: The deadly crash of a Concorde aircraft shortly after take-off in Paris yesterday was firstly a human tragedy - for the 100 passengers killed, for the crew of nine, for their bereaved families and the people killed in the hotel into which the doomed plane ploughed.
fields.body:
The deadly crash of a Concorde aircraft shortly after take-off in Paris yesterday was firstly a human tragedy - for the 100 passengers killed, for the crew of nine, for their bereaved families and the people killed in the hotel into which the doomed plane ploughed. Concorde, which first flew on March 2, 1969, had an enviable safety record with no crashes at all over a 30-year span until yesterday afternoon, when flight AF4590 took off from Charles De Gaulle airport and smashed into a hotel at Gonesse two minutes later at 4 44pm.

The crash acquired an eerie resonance, coming only a day after a BA Concorde was grounded after the discovery of small cracks - though nothing at all has emerged so far to associate that discovery with yesterday's disaster, when at least one engine appears to have caught fire. Less than two hours later, television pictures were showing the scale of the tragedy to the world, with thick black smoke still billowing into the sky and no survivors reported. At least four people on the ground were also dead.

For many people in France and Britain this was also the death of a dream. No aircraft has inspired such pride in its performance as Concorde, even among people without the resources to hope that they might one day travel in one. It was, and still will be, the only plane that stops people in their tracks on the street when it soars through the skies with its distinctive drone, its curious upward tilt and inquisitive bird-like nose. There has been no more beautiful aeroplane. Even now its sleek lines look ahead of their time.

Concorde also embodied the technological dreams of the two nations when they jointly built a supersonic plane capable of flying to New York in three and a half hours. It was a commercial disaster for the two governments who financed its construction, its costs soaring effortlessly out of control, but British Airways and Air France were able to operate their small fleets on a commercial basis after most of the original investment had been written off.

We may never see anything like it again. There are no plans to build a successor. Last year Boeing withdrew from a research project for a new supersonic plane because of the daunting cost. Any new supersonic venture which might be built would need to have a much larger production run to justify the huge investment costs - and would therefore attract much more opposition from environmental lobbies than Concorde ever did. An unsullied safety record swelled pride in Concorde's technical achievement as the years passed. That too is shattered now.

And the death toll could well have been worse. Four people are thought to have died in the Hotel Issimo. There could have been many more had the departing plane been flying over densely populated parts of the city rather than a comparatively isolated area of countryside outside Paris.

Because Concorde has stamped its image so powerfully on the public mind, what happened yesterday may cast a disproportionate shadow over air travel as a whole. That would be irrational. The plane remains among the very safest forms of travelling and is getting safer. There were no major fatal UK air passenger crashes in either 1998 or 1999. Road accidents claim far more victims per passenger mile. But the symbolism remains. We had come to believe that Concorde was not just impossibly graceful but infallible too. We ascribed to it a degree of perfection which cannot exist. That illusion, too, died at Gonesse yesterday afternoon.

webTitle: Leader: Camp David's failure will be exploited

fields.headline: Deadlock and danger
fields.standfirst:
Camp David's failure will be exploited

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: What, if anything, can be salvaged from the collapse of the Middle East peace summit at Camp David? To all appearances, this failure is a disaster unmitigated by even the thinnest of face-saving formulas.
fields.body:
What, if anything, can be salvaged from the collapse of the Middle East peace summit at Camp David? To all appearances, this failure is a disaster unmitigated by even the thinnest of face-saving formulas. After more than two weeks of extraordinary effort, during which Israel's prime minister Ehud Barak and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, became virtual prisoners inside Bill Clinton's Maryland retreat, here is a bitter, bitter harvest which seems to presage a return only to extremism and violence.

The Hamas leader, Sheikh Ahmed Yassin, opposed to the talks from the outset, was quick to make clear his vision of the future. "The only choice we have is resistance," he declared. "Only by force are we able to retain our rights." And indeed, Mr Arafat may now have difficulty restraining such hardliners. With his leadership already weakened by a variety of factors, it is increasingly doubtful whether he can maintain his grip on an angry, dispossessed nation which had given him one last chance to talk his way to peace.

The Palestinians are now committed to declaring an independent state by September 13. As matters stand, Israel will oppose it, possibly by unilaterally annexing areas of the West Bank. If this looming confrontation turns violent, Mr Arafat may well not be in control of it.

Mr Barak, who offered more by way of concessions on Jerusalem than most had expected, faces an equally uncertain future. The Camp David collapse may help defuse the immediate crisis within his coalition. But with the Syrian track also at a standstill, he is in danger of becoming a prime minister without a platform. His Likud rivals will crow, his allies will shake their heads, and the 50% or more of the population who hoped against hope that he could pull it off, despite all the unpalatable concessions, may drift away. Early elections could yet bring an end to all Mr Barak's brave hopes.

So is all lost? Not quite. Substantial progress was made on the issues of land and borders, the right of return, and settlements. The two sides came far closer on Jerusalem than most had predicted. Mr Clinton, robbed for now of the great success for which he had hoped, is dispatching an envoy to see what can be done next. He will not give up just yet. But time is desperately short. And waiting to pounce, on both sides of the divide, are the men of violence, opposed to any form of compromise or deal. For them, this is a moment of ugly vindication.

His Likud rivals will crow, his allies will shake their heads, and the 50% or more of the population who hoped against hope that he could pull it off, despite all the unpalatable concessions, may drift away. Early elections could yet bring an end to all Mr Barak's brave hopes. So is all lost? Not quite. Substantial progress was made on the issues of land and borders, the right of return, and settlements. The two sides came far closer on Jerusalem than most had predicted. Mr Clinton, robbed for now of the great success for which he had hoped, is dispatching an envoy to see what can be done next. He will not give up just yet. But time is desperately short. And waiting to pounce, on both sides of the divide, are the men of violence, opposed to any form of compromise or deal. For them, this is a moment of ugly vindication.

webTitle: Killer Martin 'should serve eight years' says Judge

fields.headline: Killer Martin 'should serve eight years' says Judge
fields.standfirst: Special report: The Tony Martin murder case
fields.trailText: A top British judge recommended that farmer Tony Martin should serve a minimum of eight rather than nine years, for shooting dead a teenage burglar at his home, in August last year.
fields.body:
A top British judge recommended that farmer Tony Martin should serve a minimum of eight rather than nine years, for shooting dead a teenage burglar at his home, in August last year.

Trial judge Mr Justice Owen jailed Martin for life for the murder of 16-year-old Fred Barras, but recommended he serve a nine-year minimum or "tariff", according to ITV's Tonight with Trevor MacDonald. But the Lord Chief Justice, Lord Woolf, believes mitigating circumstances mean that he should be considered for release in eight years time, the programme's makers say.

Mr Justice Owen made his nine-year recommendation in a report to the home secretary, who is responsible for setting the final tariff. However, the copy sent to Mr Straw contained hand-written case notes from the Lord Chief Justice, the programme claims.

Martin, who was recently moved to Gartree high-security jail in Leicestershire, is currently appealing against his conviction at Norwich crown court. Jurors found him guilty of murder by a 10-2 majority after hearing how he shot Fred Barras, who had attempted to burgle his remote farmhouse in Emneth Hungate, Norfolk.

Tonight with Trevor MacDonald's producers say Lord Woolf wrote: "I note he initially considered fixing the tariff figure at eight years and, on the facts described, that is the figure I would have selected rather than the nine years on which the judge decided."

A spokesman for Lord Woolf declined to comment on the reports and expressed concern about how the document had been obtained.

Mr Justice Owen's report, which was also obtained by the Tonight programme, talks about public sympathy for Martin, who has reportedly had a £60,000 contract placed on his life since the killing.

"Understandably there has been considerable sympathy for Martin who was a man without convictions, whose home was broken into and had it not been for the burglars he would not have committed his crimes," the judge is said to have written.

"However, much of that sympathy is based on very inadequate accounts of the evidence. [The burglars] were given no chance to escape and Martin was not acting in reasonable self-defence. He fired intending really serious injury and certainly risked the lives of each of the burglars. He is never likely to re-offend but he deserves punishment," he added.

fields.headline: When death strikes
fields.standfirst:
Last night's Concorde crash and the killing of Sarah Payne expose the helplessness of the human condition
Special report: the Concorde crash
More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: Last night's Concorde crash and the killing of Sarah Payne expose the helplessness of the human condition.
fields.body:
We are helpless. Yesterday a plane fell out of the sky: all the wealth and accomplishments of the passengers on board could not save them. They were utterly weak, entirely without power, in the face of the great fireball that pulled them out of the clouds and into the ground. They could do nothing except pray or panic.

At that same moment, the family of Sarah Payne was inspecting the 80-metre-long cellophane blanket of flowers that has grown in memory of their slain daughter. They were powerless, too: a family who could not save their child. So were the tens of thousands of mourners who had flocked to a Sussex roadside to write cards or light candles for a girl they never knew. From Paris to Pulborough, helpless grief chokes the air.

They are far apart, these two moments of calamity. One feels random and unavoidable, a natural disaster; the other an act of deliberate evil. No matter that an aircraft is man-made; the crashing of a Concorde jet seems as arbitrary and amoral as a hurricane or typhoon - an act of God. Think of those two Polynesian students minding their own business, making the beds in the Hotel Lessemo yesterday when, like a thunderbolt from the sky, a jet plane crashed through the window and consumed them in flames. The murder of Sarah is random, too: a little girl who happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time. But her death was no accident. It was the product of a human decision to do harm - an act of the devil.

They are miles apart, yet these catastrophes cry out with a shared message, one we usually strain every sinew to avoid. It is that there are hard, unbreakable limits to our power - that sometimes there is simply nothing we can do.

These disasters have more in common than that, of course. For each plays on one of our deepest fears. The prospect of falling to earth has terrified man since he first looked upwards, whether it was Lucifer tumbling out of heaven or Icarus flying too close to the sun. In our own time that fear has sharpened by becoming more real. It is not just the flying-phobics who find the very idea of air travel daunting. There cannot be an air passenger anywhere who has not at least once muttered a private prayer to an unnamed god - just in case.

With the Concorde, there is an extra element: call it Titanic syndrome. The fact that the ill-fated aircraft had been admired for three decades as the sleekest, fastest and safest in the skies adds to our sense of vulnerability. For if the plane that would not crash, like the ship that could not sink, hits disaster then what hope is there for the rest of us? The fall of Concorde strikes another mythic note: it is as if man's arrogance in seeking to travel faster than the speed of sound is at last being punished, hubris meeting its nemesis.

Sarah's death hit us in a mythic way, too. After all, the child-snatching stranger is a terror of timeless, fairy-tale pedigree. From the big bad wolf in Little Red Riding Hood to the evil-faced "childcatcher" in Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, our culture is replete with predators whose taste is for children. The statistics insist such cases are extremely rare: somewhere between four and nine a year. Rationally, we know that most of the children who are killed die either on the roads or at the hands of their own parents.

And yet it is the rare exception that terrifies us. It is not logical, but it is easy to understand. It stands to reason that, when we learned this week of the horrific case of the Mochrie family in South Wales - where the father had killed his four children, his wife and finally himself - we feel little of the emotion that surged for Sarah. That's because few of us fear that we might one day murder our own children. But we all related to the Payne family. We looked at those parents and imagined ourselves: "There, but for the grace of God..."

So both the child murder and the plane crash have a folkloric, almost biblical quality. Will they produce the same reaction? It's unlikely. For one thing, harsh though it sounds, an eight-year-old English girl arouses more sympathy than a hundred well-off German tourists. We find it easier to empathise with one story than a hundred and we still imagine the death of an innocent child to be somehow more undeserved than the death of equally innocent adults.

Sarah's story exerted a tighter grip for a further reason: it was a real story. For two weeks people held on, hoping against hope that there might be a surprise happy ending. People listened to the news each evening, just in case the little girl lost had been found alive. There was no such drama or suspense in the journey of Flight AF 4590; this story was over as soon as we knew about it.

So we are not likely to see a second outpouring of the emotion that has been on display on the banks of the A29 - not for the dead of yesterday's plane crash, at any rate. We will repeat it eventually though. Susie Orbach, the writer and one-time psychotherapist for Princess Diana, suggests that we have now developed a need for these moments of collective feeling. Over successive summers we have come together to mourn Diana, cheer for the England football team and even gaze at the eclipse. "It's an attempt to form a civil society, since so many of us feel we don't have one anymore," says Orbach. The Diana week is the archetype.

"We created a new form of national mourning that week," she says: witness the Diana-style cellophane bouquets, the inscriptions, the teddy bears brought out for Sarah. Note, too, the roadside shrines which appear wherever there has been a lethal car accident: miniature Kensington Gardens of flowers and farewell messages.

But Concorde will probably not perform the same function; it will not morph into the blank screen Sarah became - on which countless strangers could project their own private pains and losses. Our instinctive horror of helplessness will see to that.

With Sarah the feeling of sheer impotence was too powerful to ignore. People know that there will always be men sick enough to want to have sex with and hurt a child - and there is almost nothing one can do. We cannot lock up our children; we cannot hunt down and lock away every child molester. Yet the urge to do something is overwhelming. For the News of the World, that meant naming and shaming 50 or so paedophiles; for some of the paper's readers, it meant circling the home of a man they (wrongly) believed was on the list. But for most people, the urge to act translated into a poem, a candle or a flower.

The reaction to Concorde will be different. Those who died on board will have felt utterly powerless. But those of us alive and on the ground can think of plenty to do. We'll run around, talking about new safety procedures, tighter rules and improved designs. We'll act as if there is much we can do to make sure this never happens again. We won't admit for a moment our sheer helplessness. For that would fill us with absolute terror.

fields.headline: Hospital sacks surgeon for 'serious misconduct'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: A consultant surgeon accused of bungling dozens of operations was last night facing disciplinary action and compensation claims following a decision by hospital managers to sack him.
fields.body:
A consultant surgeon accused of bungling dozens of operations was last night facing disciplinary action and compensation claims following a decision by hospital managers to sack him.

Christopher Ingoldby, 52, was dismissed without notice by the Pinderfields and Pontefract NHS trust in Wakefield after an independent review of his performance concluded he had committed "serious acts of misconduct and misjudgment".

He will now face disciplinary action from the General Medical Council and claims for compensation from dozens of former patients.

The trust's decision marked the end of a two-and-a-half year campaign to remove the gastro-intestinal surgeon, who was suspended in January 1998 after an inquest jury recorded a verdict of misadventure on the death of a cancer patient in his care. Brian McDermott, 64, bled to death after stitches holding a severed artery worked loose following an operation. The family of the former Wakefield rugby league player are now suing Mr Ingoldby.

That case prompted dozens of Mr Ingoldby's patients to come forward. The trust confirmed it had received 84 complaints, including the deaths of 14 patients between 1989 and 1997. The surgeon, from Roundhay, Leeds, has denied the accusations.

He was sacked by the trust after a second independent inquiry, commissioned by the Pinderfields and Pontefract NHS trust and conducted by the NHS executive, delivered its findings.

The report will go to the GMC which will refer it to the preliminary proceedings committee to decide whether the case should go before the professional conduct committee.

Mr Ingoldby, a surgeon for more than 20 years, was said to be saddened by his sacking.

fields.headline: Vivendi adjusts Canal Plus plans
fields.trailText: French broadcasting regulator CSA is expected to clear Vivendi's merger with Seagram and Canal Plus today after Vivendi agreed to change the structure of its pay TV unit.
fields.body:
French broadcasting regulator CSA is expected to clear Vivendi's merger with Seagram and Canal Plus today after Vivendi agreed to change the structure of its pay TV unit.

The merger to create Vivendi Universal, a global media operation to rival Time Warner-America Online, had hit a legal hitch over the way it carves up the French business of the pay-television group Canal Plus. The CSA asked Vivendi to rework its proposals.

The CSA said yesterday that it had met managers from Vivendi, Canal Plus and representatives from the French cinema industry but had yet to take a decision on the merger which will create a group with a $100bn market capitalisation.

"The project is still under review. No decision has been taken at this stage," said Olivier Zegna Rata, the director of the private office of the CSA chairman, Herve Bourges.

The problem derives from a French law that bans any single shareholder from owning more than 49% of a national TV station. Vivendi Universal would own 100% of Canal Plus, which is now a 49%-held subsidiary of Vivendi.

The plan is to stay within the law by hiving off Canal's French channel into separately quoted Canal Plus Programmes, 49% owned by Vivendi Universal. Canal's French subscribers would not be grouped under this entity, and would come entirely under Vivendi Universal according to his initial plan.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: I am shocked into a fit of the vapours by an attack from my old friend Gerald Kaufman, one so uncharacteristically vicious that at first I take it for a spoof.
fields.body:
 I am shocked into a fit of the vapours by an attack from my old friend Gerald Kaufman, one so uncharacteristically vicious that at first I take it for a spoof.

We two go back so far - in the days when Gerald was tea boy in Harold Wilson's kitchen cabinet, we went to all the big musicals together (has he forgotten the night we were thrown out of Hello, Dolly! for singing along too loudly?) - so imagine how I feel on reading in the Independent why he gave up on this newspaper.

"Its gossip column did not seek to reveal or satirise," he writes, "but deliberately to set out to find victims and hurt them. That I became one of its targets did not trouble me. What I deeply deplored was its deliberate policy of finding defenceless subjects and tormenting them day after day." How very true. Mr Tony Blair, Alastair Campbell, weirdo chancellor Gordon Brown, O'Mandy Mandelson, alopecian Sun editor David Yelland... with "defenceless", Gerald unerringly finds the mot juste.Yet I retain hopes that he may be enticed back into the fold - and to this end am pleased to announce that August will be Gerald Kaufman month. All friendly anecdotes most welcome.

 Following the item about the BNP magazine, Freedom, reluctantly carrying an advert for a Japanese car, it transpires that the number printed was incorrect. Oddly, by transposing the last two numbers of the area code to 01938 and dialling the rest (820560), however, you reach the answer-phone of BNP leader Nick Griffin. Mischief making by a sub-editor, or can it be that Mr Griffin has been driving a foreign car himself? I do not know, but I think we should be told.

 That defenceless victim Mr Tony Blair has been having a tough time lately, so it's good to hear of people passing his office door being startled by screams of laughter. The cause of Mr T's mirth is a mounted fish with a motion sensor on the plaque, so that when anyone moves close enough to inspect it (and Mr T invites all visitors to do so), it sings Take Me To The River or Don't Worry, Be Happy, suddenly turning its head like a nightclub crooner and lip-synching the words rather accurately (well, not bad for a fish).

A call to Harrods discovers that Bigmouth Billy Bass is available at £29.95. However, the one sent to us was given by Mohamed Al Fayed, who has a record of making us piscine gifts (you will recall the cod fax), and this is first prize in our new competition. In no more than 12 words, complete the sentence "I love Gerald Kaufman because..." More details to follow.

 Particularly unimpressed with the News of the World paedophile nonsense is the Scout Association, whose press officer John Fogg says he was treated by reporter Paul McMullan to a heady mixture of proffered bribes and threats designed to inveigle access to confidential records.

When money failed, Mr McMullan said: "You don't want a story on Sunday saying the Scouts refused to help in the murder investigation [of Sarah Payne]." Despite being sent away with only a few press clippings, the paper still claimed the Scouts were opening up their files. "In my capacity," says Mr McMullan (what?), "I am not allowed to talk to other newspapers." Mm. "Someone has misunderstood."

 Our most beloved Mo Mowlam was sensational on Nick Hancock's BBC chat show on Monday, and even found time to hail the north-east as birthplace of Paul Daniels. Tomorrow, in honour of Mo, we return to Under No Illusion (Blake Publishing, £16.99) for a particularly charming sexual reminiscence.

fields.body:
The German chancellor Gerhard Schröder cancelled his appointments last night as the country reacted with shock to the disaster. As the transport minister, Reinhard Klimmt, sped to Paris, crisis units were set up at the foreign ministry and by the German company which had chartered the plane.

The German tourists who died in the Concorde crash were on their way to join the cruise ship MS Deutschland for a luxurious holiday that was to end at the Sydney Olympics.

Desri Omer, in the London office of Peter Deilmann Reederei, said: "Concorde was the special little extra add-on. I mean, everyone dreams of going to New York on Concorde." Flights to join the vessel in New York normally go direct from Frankfurt. The MS Deutschland, which arrived in New York this week from Plymouth, was to carry 510 passengers booked through Deilmann. Fewer than 100 had been booked through the firm's London office.

None of the British customers of the travel agency had been given the option of flying on the supersonic jet. Uwe Schwarze, the company's London-based manager, said that most of the holidaymakers who had booked through his office had flown direct from London on economy or first-class tickets.

Most of the passengers were expected to board the MS Deutschland today after arriving at New York's JFK airport for a cruise that would take them down the eastern seaboard of the United States, through the Panama canal to Ecuadorand on to Australia.

The luxury liner, aimed at the wealthy and elderly, was scheduled to arrive in Sydney harbour on September 13, two days before the Olympics begin. It was to remain moored at one of the city's prime sites, near the Opera House, where it was to serve as the official premises of the German national Olympic committee.

It was not clear last night how many of yesterday's victims had booked all the way to Sydney. The MS Deutschland was to have stopped at Manta in Ecuador and at Papetee in Tahiti on the way.

The head of the charter company said he was "deeply shocked" by the tragedy. Peter Deilmann said that his company had chartered the Concorde to fly 99 passengers - nearly all of whom were believed to be Germans - from Paris to New York.

"Based on our records there were 99 passengers booked on the plane," Mr Deilmann told Germany's ZDF public television last night. "I can't be 100% certain, but ... nearly all were German."

The 574-ft MS Deutschland is best known as the setting for a popular German television series, Traumschiff (Dream Ship). The second publicly-owned channel, ZDF, was planning to host its coverage of the Olympics from the deck of the vessel.

Mr Deilmann's firm, which had a turnover last year of 200m marks (£65m), is among the world leaders in the booming cruise business. It is based in the Baltic port of Neustadt.

The MS Deutschland is its flagship and Germany's only five-star liner. It was given an extensive refit in March 1999. It was delivered to Deilmann in May 1998.

fields.headline: Flying legend built on speed, safety and style
fields.standfirst:
For 30 years a supersonic Anglo-French success story
Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: When Concorde - the world's only supersonic commercial aircraft - lifted its exclusive band of inaugural passengers into the sky on January 21 1976, experts predicted that it would be not only the fastest, but also the safest, flight.
fields.body:
When Concorde - the world's only supersonic commercial aircraft - lifted its exclusive band of inaugural passengers into the sky on January 21 1976, experts predicted that it would be not only the fastest, but also the safest, flight.

The futuristic craft, with its distinctive narrow nose and slim lines, was the brainchild of two nations, Britain and France, which had been wrestling for 20 years to create an aircraft that would travel at twice the speed of sound.

Pooling their resources in 1962, they had been testing prototypes since March 1969, and, by the time the commercial service was launched, with simultaneous flights from London to Bahrain and Paris to Rio de Janeiro, the plane had been subjected to 5,000 hours of testing, making it the most vetted aircraft in aviation history.

Aviation experts at the time also attested to its safety. William Magruder, a test pilot assigned by the US government to assess the plane's safety, insisted: "It is my opinion - after 30 years of flight testing, designing and engineering airplanes - that this could be the safest airplane ever built."

Even last night - with its accident-free safety record dramatically shattered a day after it emerged that cracks had appeared in the wings of 11 of the 13 aircraft - the industry appeared not to countenance the idea that the plane was dangerous.

Aviation analyst Paul Beaver said: "Concorde has an excellent safety record and in the last 20 years, it has been doing a sterling job.

"It is an amazing aircraft - it still makes everyone stop and look up - and it's a remarkable sight, designed to fly well and look beautiful."

The pride of Britain's air fleet, Concorde has always been the preserve of the rich and famous, with the likes of model Claudia Schiffer, the late Diana, Princess of Wales, designer Calvin Klein, and the former Beatles, Paul McCartney and George Harrison, frequently opting to pay the £6,290 to fly from Heathrow to JFK, New York, in around three and a half hours - less than half the usual journey time.

Two flights depart each way every day, with one flight each way a day from JFK to Paris Charles de Gaulle.

But money has always been a sore point for the Concorde project, which took seven years and £1.5bn to develop.

Dubbed the most expensive marketing experiment in history, the plane gave rise the phrase "Concorde fallacy" - the term given to the belief that it is a waste of money to end a project once considerable sums have been invested in it.

A victim of the first oil crisis in 1973, only 20 were made - instead of the predicted 400 - and these were virtually given by the French and British governments to British Aerospace and Air France.

Yet, despite the fleet's age, in the 30 years since Concorde 001, the first prototype, took off from the Aerospatiale airfield in Toulouse, in March 1969, it has remained peerless.

While some military planes can meet her cruising speed of 1,350mph at a height of 60,000 feet, none can do so for as long. "Military pilots can't sustain Mach 2 for two and a half hours," said Dave Rowland, an experienced Concorde captain.

"Nobody can do what we do."

webTitle: Suicidal rats hint at mindbending parasite

fields.headline: Suicidal rats hint at mindbending parasite
fields.trailText: Oxford scientists have shown how a parasite can take control of the mind of its host. They report today that a tiny microbe that also infects humans can persuade a rat into a suicidal attraction to cats.
fields.body:
Oxford scientists have shown how a parasite can take control of the mind of its host. They report today that a tiny microbe that also infects humans can persuade a rat into a suicidal attraction to cats.

Toxoplasma gondii is a protozoan which infects many mammals - and one Briton in five. But like many parasites, it needs a particular class of host in which to complete its life cycle. Toxoplasma gondii is common in rodents, but can only replicate in cats.

So, according to Manuel Berdoy, David Macdonald and Joanne Webster, in the latest Proceedings of the the Royal Society, the parasite has to make sure the rat it infects is killed and eaten by a cat.

Toxoplasma can cause spontaneous abortion in pregnant women and even birth defects. But it was thought in most cases to have no obvious effect on its human hosts.

"Before I did the original work, all the standard textbooks said it had no effects on rodents either," said Dr Webster. "But it does have subtle effects. It makes them more active and decreases neophobia - fear of novelty - and in this study, decreased fear of cats."

The scientists set up a wild enclosure for rats, with different smells in each corner. Rats infected by the parasite were attracted to the smell of cat urine.

"It all started because I looked for the reservoir of the parasite in the wild and found that it was about 35% of the rodent population," said Dr Webster. "The very fact that it lives in the host's brain makes it in an ideal position to manipulate behaviour. I started looking to see if there was any behavioural defect that may increase predation rate."

Rats are suspicious of anything new, which is why they are difficult to trap, but infected rats seemed to lose their neophobia. And a rat attracted to places marked by a prowling cat would make an easy victim.

The toxoplasma research might throw light on the parasite's effect on humans. Infection rate in Britain is 22%, but in France - with a greater appetite for rare or undercooked meat - it has reached 84%. The next question is: what does it do to humans?

"These results may explain the reports of altered personality and IQ levels in some humans," said Dr Berdoy. Toxoplasma becomes a much more dangerous companion in people whose immune systems have been suppressed. But it remains apparently harmless in most cases.

webTitle: Camp David talks break down over Jerusalem

fields.headline: Camp David talks break down over Jerusalem
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Middle East peace talks at Camp David broke down yesterday after Israeli and Palestinian negotiators were unable to overcome fundamental differences on the future of Jerusalem, though both sides vowed not to abandon efforts to find a lasting settlement.
fields.body:
The Middle East peace talks at Camp David broke down yesterday after Israeli and Palestinian negotiators were unable to overcome fundamental differences on the future of Jerusalem, though both sides vowed not to abandon efforts to find a lasting settlement.

After hosting two weeks of intensive negotiations, President Bill Clinton insisted that significant progress had been made, but that ultimately "they couldn't get there".

The talks marked the closest the two sides had come to a comprehensive agreement in 52 years of conflict and uneasy cohabitation. Their collapse was a severe blow to Mr Clinton, who was seeking a historic success to help erase the stain of scandal on his legacy.

As security services in Israel and the Palestinian territories prepared for possible violence, Mr Clinton said both delegations would return home for consultations in the hope of resuming talks before September 13, when the Palestinians have threatened to declare their statehood unilaterally.

The White House said the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, had agreed "to commit themselves to continue efforts to conclude an agreement on all permanent status issues as soon as possible".

The two leaders also pledged to avoid unilateral actions that would prejudge the outcome of negotiations, a reference to Mr Arafat's threat to declare a state and Israeli counter-threats to annex Jewish settlements on the West Bank.

But Mr Barak blamed Mr Arafat for refusing to accept Israel's offer of municipal autonomy in some areas of East Jerusalem and access to Islamic holy sites in the Old City.

Speaking to reporters afterwards, Mr Clinton also said Mr Barak had "moved forward more from his initial position than Chairman Arafat".

fields.headline: First the smoke, then just a huge fireball
fields.standfirst:
Eyewitnesses describe how supersonic airliner fell from the sky
Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: The one hundred passengers on privately chartered Flight AF4590 had been promised the holiday of a lifetime in America and the Caribbean.
fields.body:
The one hundred passengers on privately chartered Flight AF4590 had been promised the holiday of a lifetime in America and the Caribbean.

And as they strapped in for take-off after a glass of champagne to welcome them on board on an overcast summer's afternoon, perhaps some considered there was no better way to start the trip than on the world's most elegant aircraft.

Concorde's four Rolls-Royce Olympus engines roared like thunder and the plane, carrying 26,286 gallons of fuel, accelerated down the runway at Charles de Gaulle airport, racing to reach the 250mph needed to lift it from the ground.

As ever, many witnesses who heard the distinctive growl turned to watch, but they saw something unique in the 30 years and 900,000 hours of Concorde's flights.

The aircraft, which has the power to take it to 1,336mph, or twice the speed of sound, was struggling to gain height.

The engines were screaming as the pilot demanded more thrust, but the plane was not climbing.

Nathalie Wycisk, an office worker in a building that stands just beyond the airport runway, said the plane "fell straight down".

She said: "The pilot realised there was an enormous problem. When it tried to accelerate it caught fire behind. Everything was shaking."

Sylvie Lucas, who was watching in astonishment from an airport lounge, thought Concorde was on fire even before it left the ground.

"The flames were coming from the back of the plane. We were waiting to hear the explosion because we thought it was going to fall here [at the airport]."

From a nearby hotel, Sid Hare, an American pilot for the courier company Federal Express, saw clouds of smoke just above the runway.

As he looked up at Concorde, flames 200ft long trailed from two engines on the left-hand side of the plane.

"My thought was that the left-side engine had a catastrophic failure on takeoff and damaged the one next to it, so the airplane was then trying to climb on only two out of four engines.

"He kept trying to get the nose up to gain altitude, which eventually caused a stall. The nose pitched straight up in the air, and the airplane just started rolling over and back-sliding down toward the ground."

Grant Mitchell, a Briton staying at another hotel, added: "It came across our hotel and it felt like it was going to go through it - it was that low."

Falling

As it disappeared out of sight behind a line of buildings, the plane was falling, slowly, inexorably.

Frederic Savery, 21, was driving home when the plane passed over just 60ft above. "The whole back end of the plane was on fire. All of a sudden, everything was black, we stopped right there and called the firefighters."

Samir Hossein, 15, a student who was playing tennis with friends, described the last moments of the flight.

The pilot seemed to be heading for open fields beyond Gonesse, a small town surrounded by farmland to the north of the airport.

But his battle to keep the plane in the air was almost over.

"It chopped off those trees and headed to the ground. The pilot tried to bank but the plane rolled over and smacked into a hotel, nose first and turned over."

Witnesses said the tip of the wing hit the ground first.

Mr Hare said the explosion was like "a mini-atomic bomb ... It was sickening sight. There was just a huge fireball".

A British businessman, Jamie Ritchie, described a "plume of smoke some 1,000-feet high."

The owner of the Relais Bleu hotel at Gonesse said the plane missed his hotel by a few metres and hurtled into the nearby two-star Hotelissimo, a modern hotel popular with businessmen.

"I thought the plane was going to land on my desk. I saw it heading towards me, in flames. I let go the telephone and ran."

He said the Hotelissimo owner was safe and he saw a guest jump out of a window to safety. "There were some staff and some trainees inside. I believe they are dead," he said. Emergency services confirmed four people were killed on the ground.

"I heard a huge explosion, then a second and I ran to the window and saw flames bigger than trees," another office worker said.

"One of my colleagues had a piece of metal land on the roof of her car."

Shortly after firefighters and ambulance crews were scrambled to the scene, news of the disaster spread around the world.

Within half an hour, agencies were reporting scant details, shocking industry experts who had gathered at the Farnborough air show in Hampshire.

Within 90 minutes, the French interior ministry admitted there were no survivors among the 100 passengers and nine crew on board.

A bald statement from Air France followed. "Air France announces that one of its Concordes crashed on take-off from Charles de Gaulle at 1644 local time (1444 GMT). Flight AF4590 was chartered by the German tour operator Deilmann ... and were on their way to New York to join a cruise."

Air France later confirmed that of the 100 passengers on board, 97 were Germans, along with two Danes and one American.

The five remaining Air France Concordes were quickly grounded. After hasty discussions with senior executives, British Airways, which has seven Concordes, followed suit.

In a statement, British Airways said: "We have complete confidence in our Concorde aircraft and our engineering. Nevertheless, in these circumstances - and while information is still coming in - we have taken the unprecedented step of cancelling tonight's flights. We will be holding discussions with our technical counterparts at Air France and reviewing tomorrow's operations overnight."

Passengers due to board the 7pm flight on Concorde from London Heathrow to New York were the first to be affected. Their mood was mixed.

American businessman Tim Marcott, was relieved. "I wasn't looking forward to it. It's a wise decision, better safe than sorry."

Japanese businessman Cyrus Tsui agreed and said he would never fly Concorde again. "With the news yesterday about the cracks in the wings of Concorde and with this crash I will have second thoughts about getting on a Concorde ever again."

webTitle: Concorde ablaze and just seconds from disaster

fields.headline: Concorde ablaze and just seconds from disaster
fields.standfirst:
113 die as supersonic jet hits the ground 'like an atomic bomb'

Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: An Air France Concorde carrying tourists bound for a luxury cruise slammed into a hotel shortly after takeoff at Paris's main international airport yesterday, killing all 109 passengers and crew aboard and four people on the ground.
fields.byline: Jason Burke  at Gonesse and David Hearst  in Paris
fields.body:
An Air France Concorde carrying tourists bound for a luxury cruise slammed into a hotel shortly after takeoff at Paris's main international airport yesterday, killing all 109 passengers and crew aboard and four people on the ground.

It was the first time in almost 30 years of service that the supersonic Concorde had suffered a catastrophic failure of its British-built engines. An extraordinary photograph taken by a Hungarian plane spotter on holiday in Paris shows that the aircraft was belching flames even as it left the runway at Charles de Gaulle.

Concordes get up to 250mph before lifting off, and there was speculation last night that although an engine had caught fire, the pilot was unable to abort takeoff because the runway was too short to stop.

Three minutes after takeoff, with flames shooting hundreds of feet from two of its engines, the Concorde banked left and ploughed nose first into a hotel, demolishing the three-storey structure. The pilot apparently struggled to put the flaming aircraft down in open fields beyond Gonesse, a small industrial town just beyond the runway.

Marc Olivier, 25, was playing basketball when he saw the plane coming in low from the direction of Charles de Gaulle airport. "We saw the plane coming out over the town. Obviously the pilot saw the town and tried to avoid it.

"He turned hard to the right and came round and then, as he tried to straighten up, he was so low that the left wing clipped the top of the trees. The plane was rolling from side to side and there were flames pouring from its left side. The left wing hit the earth and the plane slipped over and hit the ground."

Sid Hare, a pilot for the Fedex courier company, said the plane hit the ground in a fireball "like a mini atomic bomb".

Huge clouds of black smoke could be seen for miles around and an acrid smell filled the area. Police blocked off all roads leading to the scene of the crash, backing up traffic on all the rural roads in the farm fields just north-east of the airport.

It took up to 400 firefighters and police almost two hours to douse the flames from the blackened hulk of what was once the pride of the Air France fleet.

Leon Francesque, 40, said he watched the plane come over the lorry he was driving and flip over. "There was an explosion on the left side and then a second later on the right. After the second explosion the plane split in two."

Antonio Ferreira was tending his garden when he said the Concorde's engines suddenly fell silent. "It was like an atomic bomb, a mushroom cloud in the sky," he said.

Samir Hossein, a 15-year-old student, was playing tennis when he and four friends saw the plane go by, fire pouring from the rear.

"It chopped off the tops of those trees and headed to the ground. The pilot tried to bank but the plane rolled over and smacked into the hotel."

No one on board or in the near empty Hotelissimo hotel which the plane struck survived. A makeshift mortuary was set up in a local sports hall in Gonesse. At least 17 other people in the town were injured, none critically.

The victims were mainly Germans on their way to New York to board a cruise liner. There were also two Danes, an Austrian and an American on board. All nine of the crew were French. The passengers comprised 47 men, 50 women and three children.

A spokesman in London for Peter Deilmann, the Baltic shipping firm that chartered Concorde, said the passengers were flying out to join the MS Deutschland for a cruise.

The authorities in Berlin were not releasing the identities of the passengers last night. Gerhard Schröder, Germany's chancellor, cancelled all appointments after hearing news of the crash, while Lionel Jospin, the French prime minster, went to the scene.

Within two hours, British Airways announced that it had cancelled its next two Concorde flights.

The disaster came days after the news that microscopic cracks had been found in the wings of the Concorde fleet, though Air France stressed last night that there was no connection with the engine problem linked to the crash.

All French Concordes were grounded pending the investigation. The black box recorder and voice recorder which may offer clues to the causes of the crash have yet to be recovered.

The plane was 20 years old and had flown 12,000 hours. Last night it emerged that the aircraft had just finished a big refit four days ago. Jean Cyril Spinetta, director of Air France said: "There was a problem with the engines. It has undergone a complete refit for the past year, which finished four days before the accident."

Concorde, a triumph of the 1960s, was built to fly at twice the speed of sound. But it was always highly uneconomical and only 20 were built. A total of 13 are in service, seven with BA and six with Air France.

Rolls-Royce, the builder of the engines for Concorde aircraft, said it was seeking more information on the crash. "It is premature to speculate," a spokesman said.

fields.headline: Nightmare ending to 40-year dream
fields.standfirst:
Design icon: flawed beauty that became a glorious anachronism
Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: The timing was uncanny. Yesterday, little more than 24 hours after news of cracks in Concorde's wings emerged, an Air France Concorde crashed shortly after take-off from Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris on a charter flight to New York. Engine failure, structural failure or sabotage, it does not matter. Lives have been lost. For the Anglo-French Concorde fleet and those who have maintained, flown and believed in this beautiful and gloriously redundant aircraft, it must seem like the end of a flawed 40-year dream.
fields.body:
The timing was uncanny. Yesterday, little more than 24 hours after news of cracks in Concorde's wings emerged, an Air France Concorde crashed shortly after take-off from Charles de Gaulle airport in Paris on a charter flight to New York. Engine failure, structural failure or sabotage, it does not matter. Lives have been lost. For the Anglo-French Concorde fleet and those who have maintained, flown and believed in this beautiful and gloriously redundant aircraft, it must seem like the end of a flawed 40-year dream.

Concorde has enjoyed a perfect safety record for 24 years in service and has been involved in no major scares since its tyres blew out during a bad landing on its British maiden flight in March 1969. Last night British Airways was at pains to stress that the supersonic aircraft that roar across the Atlantic as fast as the fastest jet fighters are safe.

Brave words and doubtless true, yet Concorde, for all its noisy and gas-guzzling magnificence, has been marginalised as never before. It is not just the French plane's fatal fall from grace; yesterday the Dubai-based Emirates airline pledged £1bn for the purchase of the first five Airbus 3XX double-deckers. Seating up to 656 passengers, these planes promise to be easy on fuel, easy on the eardrums and, above all, easy on passengers' credit cards. They look, though, like barrage balloons compared to the sylph-like Concorde.

Concorde has been a glorious anachronism since it first flew in commercial service. The dream of supersonic international flight was already all but over: the Boeing 747 Jumbo jet took off shortly before Concorde, bringing cheap fares, if no increase in speed, over the previous generation of 707s, DC8s and VC10s. The Jumbo ushered in an era of cheap, reliable and profitable mass intercontinental travel. More than a thousand Jumbos have been sold, compared to just 14 of a total 20 Concordes built.

At current prices each Concorde cost the British taxpayer £1bn, the price of 10 Jumbos. Each Concorde passenger has been subsidised to the tune of approximately £3,300. Each has unwittingly consumed 250 gallons of kerosene on every transatlantic flight and been willing to pay a pound a mile for the privilege of flying in an aircraft that soars twice as high and more than twice as fast as the Boeing, McDonell-Douglas and Airbus crowd.

Concorde is the only time machine that civilians are able to experience: a Concorde lifting off from Heathrow lands passengers at New York's JFK airport 90 minutes before they take off - local time of course, but the effect is magical. As is the aircraft itself. Only the most churlish or ecologically correct will deny the captivating aesthetic of this Anglo-French beauty as it struts on long hydraulic legs between crowds of dumpy, 300-seaters. Cruising at 60,000ft, the passengers shoe-horned into Concorde's dinky cabin can see the curvature of the earth below. This is the territory of Chuck Yeager, Top Guns, Valkyries and God.

Concorde, although an Anglo-French project, was perhaps the peak of Britain's post-war drive to prove that it could still make it big, fast, nuclear and supersonic in a world increasingly dominated by Soviet satellites, the Nasa space programme and the transistor technology dawning in the Land of the Rising Sun.

A brilliant team of engineers, including at least one from Werner Von Braun's Nazi rocket team, produced this jet-age fighter stretched into a civilian plane. Back-of-shed, pipe-smoking British boffin know-how at Farnborough met the best of French engineering at Toulouse and, in the process, created a machine that looked like a stylised stork on the ground, an origami arrow in the stratosphere. In flight, Concorde exhibits a fitness for purpose and absolute beauty rivalled by only the most perfect works of art.

It is let down, not of course in terms of performance, by its formidable and deafening four Olympus engines. Derived from military prototypes, there was nothing else to match them at the time that the Anglo-French agreement which breathed Concorde into life was signed in November 1962.

But ecology was not on the menu as the recipe for this great adventure in the sky was written. In a blaze of white-hot technology, Concorde took to the sky at the tail end of Harold Wilson's second Labour government. Like the Channel tunnel, the droop-nosed aircraft was a legend in its own design-time.

Concorde was alone in a sky dominated by solid, competent, economical jets, and was easy prey to critics. Yes it is a plane for the rich and showy. It is unlikely to be replaced in any recognisable shape or form. Yet to lose Concorde, will, when the day comes for the final and hopefully safe landing, be like losing the British Telecom tower in London, the Eiffel tower, and the Empire State building in New York.

fields.headline: Smooth path for hi-tech leaders
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: A scheme allowing foreign "business innovators", particularly e-business entrepreneurs, to settle in Britain was announced yesterday as the first step in the government's plan to relax the immigration rules to encourage some categories of economic migrants.
fields.body:
A scheme allowing foreign "business innovators", particularly e-business entrepreneurs, to settle in Britain was announced yesterday as the first step in the government's plan to relax the immigration rules to encourage some categories of economic migrants.

A pilot scheme, to be introduced in September, will waive the rules requiring such individuals to invest at least £1m or buy a British company worth at least £200,000.

Ministers, who yesterday talked about the "global war for talent", intend the scheme to be used to attract innovators who want to set up science, technology and e-commerce based businesses which would contribute to economic growth.

Barbara Roche, the immigration minister, said: "It is important that our immigration policy encourages people with innovative business proposals and valuable skills to bring these to the UK. Many such people whose presence here would result in significant economic benefit to the nation are not catered for under existing rules."

Those who apply under the scheme will have to submit a business plan, including an assessment of the business's potential economic benefit to Britain. Ministers have promised to produce more proposals as to how changes in the rules could "meet emerging social and economic needs" in September.

The details of the scheme were unveiled as the latest asylum figures showed a small fall in the numbers applying for refugee status in the past month. Some 5,900 applications were lodged in June, down 285 on the previous month. The backlog of claims waiting for a decision has fallen by 5,000 to 85,000 as an emergency £600m cash injection begins to take effect.

Most applications came from Sri Lanka, followed by the former Yugoslavia and Iran. Some 265 Kosovans who entered Britain under the UN humanitarian evacuation programme have applied to remain as refugees.

webTitle: Clifford role in Labour memo leaks

fields.headline: Clifford role in Labour memo leaks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour in power
fields.trailText: Max Clifford emerged last night as a secret go-between in the leaking of five Downing Street memos in an act of revenge against New Labour.
fields.body:
Max Clifford emerged last night as a secret go-between in the leaking of five Downing Street memos in an act of revenge against New Labour.

The high-profile PR man is believed to have placed the confidential letters, including one written by Tony Blair, with Rupert Murdoch's newspapers after they were recovered from rubbish by a mysterious figure known as "Benji the Binman".

Mr Clifford, who effectively acts as Benjamin Pell's agent, passed on the documents retrieved and pieced together from waste thrown out by Downing Street aides including pollster Philip Gould.

Special Branch officers last week suspected a Downing Street insider was to blame for an embarrassing series of leaks over recent months.

But the breakthrough came when detectives discovered a Gould memo published last week in the Sun and Times was a first draft ripped up into small pieces and left by the pollster in a black plastic bin bag outside his home in north London.

Mr Gould had disposed of the single draft copy and made 49 changes to the document, which warned that the New Labour brand was "contaminated", before circulating it to Mr Blair and other senior figures. Many of the changes to the memo were trivial, including new punctuation, but crucial phrases were also changed and new passages added.

The leaks rocked the government as they portrayed Labour as a party obsessed with presentation and dominated by a small clique gathered around Mr Blair. They were detonated at crucial moments, overshadowing Gordon Brown's spending plans.

Mr Clifford, who played a part in defeating the Tories with his exposure of a string of sex scandals, has fallen out with Labour.

He is angry at the government's failure to help the disabled and improve the NHS, and Peter Mandelson, who rang him regularly in opposition, has stopped phoning.

Mr Clifford and a senior News International executive last night both publicly maintained that he had played no role in the leaks.

Mr Pell could not be contacted last night, but a close associate said off the record that Mr Clifford was involved.

Mr Clifford is understood to have used another person last weekend to hand the Blair "touchstone issues" memo to Sun and Times journalists. Both papers maintained they did not pay.

"Benji got the memos, Max handed them on. It was not just the money. Benji loves the excitement and Max is unhappy with the government," said the associate.

Executives on all three Murdoch titles are known to have contacts with Mr Pell, a jobless former trainee solicitor who specialises in raking through the rubbish of the rich and famous.

Mr Pell was convicted last November on five counts of "stealing documentary waste" from a law firm and the court was told he suffers from an obsessive compulsive personality disorder in the form of a collection mania. Police found at least 200,000 documents in his garden shed.

Mr Pell, in his mid-30s, was asked by a source outside News International this year to target the home addresses of Mr Gould and Lord Levy, the Labour fundraiser embarrassed when the Sunday Times recently revealed he paid only £5,000 tax in 1998-99. That source never received any documents.

A News International invoice dated June 18 1999, obtained by the Guardian, discloses that the Sunday Times paid Mr Pell £3,375 through account 526631 for three stories - on Jonathan Aitken, James Hewitt and alleged ballot-rigging in Hackney - at the end of April last year.

webTitle: Uncontained engine blaze seems likely cause of crash

fields.headline: Uncontained engine blaze seems likely cause of crash
fields.standfirst:
The theory: pilot helpless to prevent disaster after fire started on runway
Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: A raging fire in an engine on the Concorde charter flight from Paris to New York appears to have been the most likely reason for the crash yesterday.
fields.body:
A raging fire in an engine on the Concorde charter flight from Paris to New York appears to have been the most likely reason for the crash yesterday.

The pilot of another aircraft waiting to take off at Charles de Gaulle airport saw the fire in the engine as the Concorde taxied down the runway, but said that there was no reaction from inside the supersonic plane. Within minutes it crashed, engulfed in a fireball from 100 tonnes of fuel for the transatlantic flight.

Eyewitnesses were astonished that the plane took off with its wing on fire. They said that under normal circumstances the pilot would have been aware of the blaze both through observation and from danger warnings on his in strument panel. Engineers said the pilot should have been alerted to the problem by a red light at the controls and should have immediately warned air traffic control.

The four engines have a thrust of 38,000lb each. They are the most powerful pure jet engines flying commercially.

The pilot may have been so far down the runway, travelling at a speed approaching 250mph that he would not have been able to brake in time. He would have had no option but to take off, desperately hoping that he could circle and land again.

A senior British Airways engineer, while stressing that Concorde was the safest aircraft in the world and had a record second to none, said the crash could have been caused by "an uncontained failure" in the Rolls-Royce Olympus engine. This suggests that there was an explosion in the engine which ripped through the protective cowling, and over which the pilot would have had no control.

A fire would have spread quickly, and as the pilot was in the middle of a steep climb, there was nothing he could do to prevent the catastrophe.

The BA engineer said that if there had been a "controlled failure" in the engine, the problem would have been contained in the engine, which would have simply cut out. With three engines left, the pilot could have been expected to complete his take-off, circle the airport and land again safely.
