webTitle: Leaders seeking a place in history

fields.headline: Leaders seeking a place in history
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: This was going to be the year that finally ended decades of Arab-Israeli conflict. Bill Clinton would win his place in history as a peace broker and Yasser Arafat, Ehud Barak and Hafez al-Assad would take a Nobel prize.
fields.body:
This was going to be the year that finally ended decades of Arab-Israeli conflict. Bill Clinton would win his place in history as a peace broker and Yasser Arafat, Ehud Barak and Hafez al-Assad would take a Nobel prize.

But strand by strand, the hopes have unravelled.

None of this means that a comprehensive peace settlement is a long way off, but it now looks most unlikely to happen during Mr Clinton's presidency.

President Clinton

President Clinton had set great store by what cynics describe as his "legacy project" - earning a place in history as the man who finally brought peace to the Middle East. To him, the failure of Camp David is a personal failure, inviting unfavourable comparisons with the meeting 22 years ago when his Democratic predecessor Jimmy Carter brokered peace between Israel and Egypt. Mr Clinton's two big Middle East initiatives this year -the Geneva summit with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria in spring and now Camp David - have both flopped. He will claim the credit for trying, and pin the blame on the intractable differences between the two sides. But Mr Clinton cannot claim tom hafe been surprised by that.

Indeed, there is no indication that he had anything up his sleeve that could have turned Camp David into the success he craved.

The Americans seem to have assumed that congenial surroundings and the presence of the most powerful man in the world could lead to a breakthrough, regardless of whether they had a plan to bridge the gaps between the protagonists.

President Clinton seems to have made little effort to win their confidence as an honest broker. Last weekend, according to leaks, the Americans were forced to withdraw their bridging proposal in the face of Palestinian objections that it was basically a re-working of Israeli proposals.

Ehud Barak

When Mr Barak returns home to nurse his sickly coalition he will, at least, be spared the cries of treachery that would have accompanied a peace agreement.

Israeli hardliners will be relieved by his firmness, though Palestinians are likely to regard it as intransigence. Freih Abu Meddein, the Palestinian justice minister, said yesterday: "Barak did not go to the summit to make peace. He went there to prove to his people that he could stick to Israeli red lines."

But beyond Mr Barak's immediate problems with his government, the question is where he goes from here. He was elected, primarily, to make peace. If he cannot do that, Israelis may ask if they have any further need for him.

They may also question the cost-benefits of the pull-out from Lebanon which has certainly saved lives but may make a comprehensive peace more difficult to achieve.

Ordinary Arabs constantly remark on the apparent ease with which, after years of reluctance, Israel finally complied with UN resolutions on Lebanon and ask why it cannot do the same in the occupied territories.

Arab activists, meanwhile, contrast the lumbering performance and compromises of the Palestinian leadership with the "victory" - albeit a bloody one - of Hizbullah in Lebanon.

Yasser Arafat

Mr Arafat and his team emerge from Camp David unscathed but scarcely any further forward. Despite their weak negotiating position they have not, as many of their supporters feared, caved in under American pressure.

But Mr Arafat, like Mr Barak, faces the problem of what to do next. He is publicly committed to declaring a Palestinian state at some time this year, if not by the September 13 deadline.

At this stage no one can be certain whether it would put pressure on the Israelis or be taken as a largely symbolic gesture.The Israelis have threatened a tough response to any unilateral declaration of a Palestinian state, and have been stepping up security around the settlements. There could be a new intifada, but perhaps only if the Israelis react as they have threatened.

Mr Arafat can argue that patience will eventually bring results but tactically he may need a show of defiance to placate critics who say that negotiation has failed and it is time to change course. His problem is how to retain control of mass action once it starts. Street protests in May quickly got out of hand.

Mr Arafat's difficulties will be compounded if Mr Barak, in his need to keep the peace process alive, now switches his attention back to Syria. Little more than a month after the death of his father, President Bashar al-Assad may not be ready to talk, and the shores of Galilee may still be a sticking point, but if there were a way to make a separate peace with Syria it would be a severe blow to the Palestinians.

webTitle: Holy City remains an unbridgeable chasm

fields.headline: Holy City remains an unbridgeable chasm
fields.standfirst:
Chronology:
they tried to keep talking but it all hinged on Jerusalem
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: For almost a week before the Camp David peace talks were finally allowed to die, they appeared to be kept on artificial life support, shrouded by pessimism and fear of what might follow in the wake of a breakdown.
fields.body:
For almost a week before the Camp David peace talks were finally allowed to die, they appeared to be kept on artificial life support, shrouded by pessimism and fear of what might follow in the wake of a breakdown.

The White House first announced the summit's collapse last Wednesday night, as President Clinton prepared to leave for the Okinawa G8 economic summit.

But barely an hour later it emerged that the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, had agreed to Mr Clinton's last-ditch appealto stay on while he was in Japan.

That respite sent out a ripple of optimism, suggesting that the two leaders were more afraid of failure than of a compromise peace.

But the agreement to keep talking could not obscure the gaping divide between the two sides, particularly over the fate of Jerusalem.

The two Middle East leaders arrived at the presidential retreat on July 11 without a clear idea how the ancient sovereignty dispute over the holy city could be resolved.

The mood was friendly and positive, but the problems were obvious. This was encapsulated by a moment just after the first joint appearance by the leaders. Neither could agree on who should enter the presidential cabin first, both insisting that the other should have precedence. The impasse ended with Mr Barak shoving the protesting Mr Arafat over the threshold.

The Palestinians came to the talks only reluctantly, concerned that Mr Arafat might come under combined Israeli-US pressure to make concessions on Jerusalem which would be unacceptable to his own people and the wider Arab world.

Progress was made quickly on the other key issues. The Israeli delegation put forward a compromise solution to the question of the 3.6m Palestinian refugees, under which about 100,000 would be allowed to return to the homes they fled in the 1948 and 1967 wars, as part of a family reunification programme.

The rest would be compensated from an international fund. The Palestinians made it clear that they were willing to accept that position as a starting point for negotiations.

Meanwhile, the sides quickly came to a rough agreement on the the borders of a future Palestinian state, incorporating the Gaza Strip and about 90% of the West Bank. The most densely populated Jewish settlements, with about 80% of the Jewish population on the West Bank, would be annexed by Israel, perhaps in return for territory within Israel itself.

The fate of Jerusalem, however, continued to present an obstacle to progress, and failure to make progress on the issue triggered the first breakdown last Wednesday. Mr Arafat insisted that the Palestinians must retain sovereignty over the Islamic holy sites - the Dome of the Rock, the Al-Aqsa mosque and their neighbourhood.

Mr Barak gave orders to the Israeli delegation to prepare to leave and took the unusual step of addressing an open letter to Mr Clinton.

He wrote: "The Palestinians arrived at Camp David lacking good faith, and are not ready to have a substantive discussion about a lasting peace and to make historic decisions . . .

"Unless there are last-minute changes, the Palestinians will have to rue the tragic consequences of a missed opportunity."

Mr Clinton held emergency talks with both leaders, and made hasty telephone calls to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, King Abdullah of Jordan and other Middle East leaders, looking for regional support for the talks.

But it was only around midnight, after the presidential motorcade was packed and Mr Clinton's limousine prepared for his departure, that word came from the Israeli and Palestinian negotiators that they were ready to stay on.

Sources close to the negotiators hinted that this was more out of respect for Mr Clinton and his peace efforts than any indication that the divide over Jerusalem had narrowed.

A weary Bill Clinton left for Okinawa in the early hours, declaring: "Both leaders feel the weight of history but both, I believe, recognise this is a moment in history which they can seize."

The talks continued on Thursday under the guidance of the secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, and the Israeli delegation went another step towards offering what it termed "joint sovereignty" over Jerusalem.

According to the scheme, leaked to the Israeli press, the Palestinians would run their own municipal affairs in a number of East Jerusalem districts and would perhaps even fly their own flag over their holy sites in the Old City, but sovereignty would remain in Israeli hands.

Back in Jerusalem, the Palestinian spokeswoman, Hanan Ashrawi, said the offer represented nothing new, but it fostered optimism in Washington and Mr Clinton cut short his programme in Okinawa on Sunday to fly back to Camp David.

But that glimmer of optimism came to nothing. Despite prolonged negotiations stretching until 5am yesterday, Mr Clinton was unable to square the circle in Jerusalem.

The issue of sovereignty, particularly over the Islamic holy sites, remained intractable.

The US president and the negotiators slept for a few hours, and on waking made the decision to abandon the talks.

Mr Clinton was due to attend a friend's funeral in Arkansas, and had offered to fly straight back to Camp David if there were any faint sparks of optimism, but none remained.

webTitle: Redwood pledges fight to join US trade bloc

fields.headline: Redwood pledges fight to join US trade bloc
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: the European Commission
fields.trailText: William Hague intensified his campaign against Brussels yesterday when the Tory leadership warned of a legal battle with the EU if a Conservative government is blocked from forging a new trading link with the United States.
fields.body:
William Hague intensified his campaign against Brussels yesterday when the Tory leadership warned of a legal battle with the EU if a Conservative government is blocked from forging a new trading link with the United States.

The Tory policy was recently described in a leaked Foreign Office memo as "barmy" because both London and Washington believe that Britain could not combine its membership of the EU with a place in the North Atlantic Free Trade Area.

However, John Redwood, the Tories' new "spin buster", insisted yesterday that Britain could be a member of both organisations. Any attempt to block British membership of Nafta, he added, would lead to a legal battle with a future Conservative government.

Asked what would happen if Brussels attempted to block a British application to join Nafta, Mr Redwood said: "It may even be against World Trade Organisation rules ... so you'd have an interesting conflict of interest."

His remarks, in an interview with the YouGov political website, were seized on by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who said they made "a nonsense of the Tory party's claims that it wants Britain to stay in the EU'.

"Membership of Nafta is incompatible with the Treaty of Rome and would require Britain to withdraw from the EU," Mr Cook added.

webTitle: Breakdown leaves West Bank facing bloodshed

fields.headline: Breakdown leaves West Bank facing bloodshed
fields.standfirst:
Violence:
forces on alert as September countdown gathers pace
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The prophets of doom went to work immediately yesterday. Even before the Israeli and Palestinian negotiators were airborne for their return from the failed Camp David peace summit, there were warnings of a convulsion of violence at home.
fields.body:
The prophets of doom went to work immediately yesterday. Even before the Israeli and Palestinian negotiators were airborne for their return from the failed Camp David peace summit, there were warnings of a convulsion of violence at home.

On September 13, just six weeks from now, the Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat could declare a Palestinian state. With the hope of Israeli recognition now in tatters, and Israel threatening to retaliate for a unilateral declaration, there is a growing fear that the new state will be born in bloodshed - unless the two negotiating teams can be coaxed back to the table again.

Earlier yesterday the Israeli army chief told the security committee of the Knesset that he foresaw violent protests in the West Bank, and that Israeli forces there had been put on alert.

The briefing by General Shaul Mofaz and his chief of military intelligence amplified dire scenarios that have been circulating in the Israeli media for several days.

Newspapers have carried almost daily reports of intelligence officials claiming to have sniffed out plots by Palestinians to storm Jewish settlements in the West Bank.

They also say that there could be violent protests by Palestinians in East Jerusalem, which has been occupied by Israel since 1967.

There are plenty of people willing to feed such fears. In Gaza and the West Bank, leaders of Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement have been conducting military training for young Palestinians.

The exercises, which consist of young people crawling across the desert firing at imaginary Israeli soldiers, are mainly bluster, but they provide an important outlet for the frustration which has been bubbling up in Gaza and the West Bank in the past few months, and which, given a pretext, could explode, given a pretext.

With unemployment running at 20%, and the average Gazan earning one-17th of what an Israeli worker takes home, it has become increasingly difficult for Mr Arafat to keep a lid the tension.

Many in the squalid refugee camps of the West Bank and Gaza now talk about a new intifada - directed not so much against the Israeli army as against Mr Arafat's corrupt and incompetent regime.

Meanwhile Jewish settlements in the West Bank have begun giving weapons training to their women.

"I am afraid that in the short run both sides are sliding towards a confrontation - or a series of small confrontations that could escalate," said Menachem Klein, a fellow at the Israeli Institute for Jerusalem Affairs, which helped draft some of the Israeli side's positions before Camp David.

Many in the squalid refugee camps of the West Bank and Gaza now talk about a new intifada - directed not so much against the Israeli army as against Mr Arafat's corrupt and incompetent regime. Meanwhile Jewish settlements in the West Bank have begun giving weapons training to their women. "I am afraid that in the short run both sides are sliding towards a confrontation - or a series of small confrontations that could escalate," said Menachem Klein, a fellow at the Israeli Institute for Jerusalem Affairs, which helped draft some of the Israeli side's positions before Camp David.

webTitle: Barak rushes to blame unyielding Arafat

fields.headline: Barak rushes to blame unyielding Arafat
fields.standfirst:
Sticking points:
row over territory soured debate on other issues
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Ehud Barak reverted to his familiar warrior persona last night, launching a full-frontal attack on the Palestinians, in which he accused them of causing the Camp David summit to collapse.
fields.body:
Ehud Barak reverted to his familiar warrior persona last night, launching a full-frontal attack on the Palestinians, in which he accused them of causing the Camp David summit to collapse.

In a news conference for Israeli journalists, he said the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, was single-handedly responsible for the summit's failure because of his unwillingness to yield ground on Jerusalem.

"We went as far as we could go," he said. "But it takes two to tango."

Mr Barak's bravado was expected. When he faces the Israeli public today he will claim to be the brave general who refused to sacrifice Jewish interests to the Palestinians.

Nevertheless, he said that all was not lost, and that he wanted to try again to make a deal before September 13, when Mr Arafat has vowed to unilaterally declare a Palestin ian state. "There is still hope for peace," he said. "Peace is not dead."

But if not dead, it appeared to be mortally wounded by the failure of the Israeli and Palestinian negotiators to agree on a formula to reconcile competing claims to Jerusalem.

Mr Arafat was adamant that Israel must relinquish all the parts of East Jerusalem which it has occupied since the 1967 war - including the walled city, which is home to the holiest relics of Islam, Judaism and Christianity.

Israel - and the Americans, it now appears - were trying to get Mr Arafat to settle for much less: shared sovereignty of some far-flung districts of East Jerusalem. This American stand represents a departure from the UN resolutions which have previously guided its policy on Jerusalem. They call for the return of the occupied east of the Holy City in its entirety.

Mr Barak said last night that Israel had had no intention of surrendering about a dozen new settlements it had built in East Jerusalem to solidify Jewish claims to the city.

He was also unwilling to countenance an Israeli surrender of the old walled city, or to see the Wailing Wall fall under Palestinian control.

Sources close to the talks said the dispute over Jerusalem poisoned other areas on which there had previously been some accord.

Ghassan Khatib, of the Jerusalem Media and Communications Centre, said: "Failure to agree on Jerusalem caused the Israelis to retreat from their positions on other issues. The Israelis tried to use the progress on the other issues as a carrot to encourage the Palestinians to make big concessions on Jerusalem."

But although the summit failed to produce a deal, it does appear to have caused a shift in Israeli public opinion.

Polls published yesterday showed that, at the very least, the summit has managed to wean some Israelis away from their mantra of Jerusalem as the "undivided and eternal capital" of the Jewish state.

"All it takes is for someone to cast the first stone, and a lot of people who had been quietly thinking similar thoughts feel emboldened," said Mark Heller of the Jaffee Centre of Tel Aviv University.

"By beginning to negotiate, they have demystified the issue of Jerusalem. Rather than thinking of Jerusalem as an image, or a symbol, people are beginning to think about the reality."

The city embodies the other points of contention between Israelis and Palestinians, however: the plight of 3.6m registered Palestinian refugees, and the future of some 200 Jewish settlements build on occupied land.

The talks appeared to have made some progress - particularly on proposals under which Mr Barak would have given up parcels of land in Israel proper in exchange for Jewish settlements in the West Bank.

Israel is also believed to have agreed to contribute to an international fund that will compensate Palestinian refugees for the loss of their homes and lands when the Jewish state was created in 1948. By Israeli standards, this also represents the shattering of a taboo.

But Mr Barak is believed to have balked at Palestinian insistence that Israel admit guilt for driving the refugees from their homes.

Even so, despite the collapse of this summit, many are cheered by the mere fact that Israeli and Palestinian negotiators were even able to talk about such contentious issues. They hope that the talks here will provide guidelines for the future.

"Even with no agreement, the summit laid down the terms of reference for a new deal," said Menachem Klein, of the Israeli Institute for Jerusalem Affairs, which drafted some of the proposals on the table at Camp David.

"There is no way back - only forward. This is the big achievement from Camp David."

webTitle: Britain set to pull out of dam project

fields.headline: Britain set to pull out of dam project
fields.standfirst:
New guidelines linking export credits to sustainable development and human rights debar Turkish scheme
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: The government is about to withdraw its support for the Ilisu dam project in Turkey.
fields.body:
The government is about to withdraw its support for the Ilisu dam project in Turkey.

In an remarkable about turn, ministers have agreed to publish new guidelines for export credits guarantees, taking account of the government's policies of sustainable development, human rights and good governance.

Cabinet level sources said the guidelines, once they are in force in a new mission statement, would debar export credits from being granted to the dam.

The $2bn hydro-electricity project, including construction work by Balfour Beatty, was expected to be funded with the help of $200m of British export credit guarantees. It has caused huge controversy amid concerns that the dam will require the enforced resettlement of thousands of villagers, despoil a beautiful environment and wreck sites of great architectural interest.

The all party international development select committee has twice condemned the provision of any credits, saying the dam "was from the outset conceived and planned in contravention of international standards".

Turkey wants the dam, flooding large parts of the Tigris Valley, to increase its power supply and feed its fast growing economy.

Last December the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said he was minded to grant export credits, conditional on the Turkish authorities addressing concerns.

These included concerns over a resettlement programme, provision of upstream water treatment plants, permanent retention of downstream flows to Syria and Iraq and a detailed plan to preserve sites such as the archaeological site of Hasankeyf.

Ministerial sources said yesterday the Turkish authorities had not responded well to these demands, partly due to its objections in principle to interference from foreign governments. There has been little evidence, for instance, that Turkey is willing to consult the downstream countries on use of the waters of the Tigris.

Syria and Iraq have protested to the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, over Turkey's reluctance to talk to them.

Mr Byers refused to comment in detail yesterday, saying only: "It is only if the Turkish authorities meet each condition in full that export credits will be granted."

However, it is understood that there is now consensus in Whitehall that the export credits guarantee department must move away from backing big projects, such as the dam, and towards smaller projects.

It is also understood that Mr Byers has intervened to require the ECGD to guarantee contracts for the building of low cost housing in Romania.

The year-long ECGD review published yesterday states: "The UK has important international policies to promote sustainable development, human rights and good governance throughout the world and to secure improvements in global security and economic prospects. It is appropriate for the ECGD to promote these objectives, given that it is relying on the taxpayer to stand behind the guarantees it issues."

Publishing a review of the department, which insures exporters against the risk of foreign buyers defaulting, Mr Byers said: "The review will ensure that ECGD is able to meet the challenges of the years ahead. As a result of this review I now expect ECGD to be able to do more to help the poorest countries to emerge from debt and poverty burdens and to return to the international trading community."

But campaigners said the review was a damage limitation exercise which added a gloss of human rights and sustainable development rhetoric to the mission of a flawed institution.

Barry Coates, director of the World Development Movement, said: "It is a complete cave-in to corporate interests. The government seems to have a corporate welfare, rather than an ethical, dimension at the centre of its foreign policy."

He said the ECGD would still provide cover for defence exports, which represent more than 50% of the department's business.

Bowen Wells, chairman of the international development commitee, said the mission statement still did not put human rights issues at the heart of the ECGD's principles. The decision on the Ilusu dam project would be the test case of its efficacy.

webTitle: Nasty moment as Kaufman grows lyrical

fields.headline: Nasty moment as Kaufman grows lyrical
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: I see that Gerald Kaufman, the chairman of the culture committee, has stopped reading the Guardian on the grounds that we are only interested in writing a "daily sneer".
fields.body:
I see that Gerald Kaufman, the chairman of the culture committee, has stopped reading the Guardian on the grounds that we are only interested in writing a "daily sneer".

As someone who regards sneering as a crucial public service element of my job, I must say that to be termed a sneerer by Gerald is quite a tribute - like being called "tasty" by Claudia Schiffer. He's the expert. Which made his contribution to the discussion on funding for leisure yesterday all the stranger. Chris Smith, the culture secretary, had declared that there was to be an enormous rise in spending on sport and the arts. He was barracked almost continuously by five Tory hard men - John Redwood, Nick Soames, John Bercow, Eric Forth and Michael Fabricant - (well, four Tory hard men) so that he resembled a downmarket Oscar Wilde facing the rugger buggers of Oxford.

"Artistic life nurtures the civilised society," he averred, to Tory cries of "sez who?" "Arts funding will increase by 60%," he went on. "Shame!" shouted one Tory. "More dead sheep," chortled another. In the manner of one waving a defiant bunch of lilies, Mr Smith kept departing from his script to blame the Tories for all our ills, including by implication British failures in football, cricket, tennis and underwater lacrosse. There had been 18 years of decline. "We are now reaping the results of that damage today!"

No wonder Peter Ainsworth, his Tory shadow, was cross. A recent independent review of the culture, media and sport department had called it "the pale yellow amoeba," he said, adding: "You have turned your department into something resembling the lowest form of life, with no backbone, and a tendency to spread itself by random osmosis." For ages Mr Ainsworth was thought the most obscure of all Mr Hague's lacklustre frontbench. But so often was he called the least known that he became notorious for it. He was a talking point. If a celebrity is a person who is famous for being famous, Mr Ainsworth is the first politician to be renowned for being utterly unknown.

And with this curious fame has come confidence. His attack on Mr Smith had some bravura, and his charge of double, triple and quintuple counting carried some heft.

So I was slightly surprised to hear Mr Kaufman, who is chairman of the Commons culture committee, describe his intervention as "an outpouring of inarticulate rubbish which, unbelievably, he must have spent time preparing". Mr Kaufman went on to praise Mr Smith lyrically, adding that he could hardly wait for more. "We look forward to his next review, when his news will be even better!"

Now Gerald Kaufman is not famed for his admiration and liking for Mr Smith, or for any of his ministers. Indeed, having attended many culture commitee meetings, I would describe his attitude as something close to sneering, except that as we know, only Guardian writers sneer. So what was this about? I cannot say, though I guess Mr Kaufman is saving Mr Smith for later. The general impression was of Hannibal Lecter telling someone: "I shall not eat you - tonight."

Minutes later Tam Dalyell was getting agitated about finding a fair system for electing the new Speaker from a field which is growing by the day. But it could be worse, he pointed out: "The Canadian parliament has a system by which everyone is a candidate, unless they rule themselves out." As MPs groaned, I reflected on the prospect that the winner would have to be Michael Fabricant. Think of the money they'd save on a wig.

(I'm sorry; that was a typical Guardian sneer, for which I apologise.)

fields.headline: Indie sounds rock Mercury Prize
fields.standfirst: Fringe groups and singers dominate nominations for Europe's leading music award
fields.trailText: A singer-songwriter who has to use her young person's rail card to get to gigs is in the running for the Mercury Prize.
fields.body:
A singer-songwriter who has to use her young person's rail card to get to gigs is in the running for the Mercury Prize.

In any other year, Kathryn Williams, a Liverpudlian with a neat line in self-deprecation and the darkly twisted lyric, would be a rank outsider for Europe's top music prize. But with few obvious contenders from mainstream rock, this year's shortlist is dominated by underground acts.

The only real pop pin-up in contention is Richard Ashcroft, the phlegmatic former frontman of the Verve, whose debut solo album Alone With Everybody had polite but hardly enthusiastic notices. That has not stopped him, however, being made second-favourite for the prize by bookmakers William Hill.

In contrast, Williams, 26, made her critically acclaimed first album for £80 after setting up her own record label in the spare room of her terraced house in Newcastle because "no one was that interested in me".

Her second, Little Black Numbers - for which she earned her nomination - was made for the price of a third-hand car and paid for with a mixture of goodwill and waitressing.

She said: "Three thousand pounds mightn't sound a lot, I know, but it felt like a lot to me. Face Studios in Newcastle were really good to me and let me record tracks in between other people.

"I run everything from the desk in my spare room. I have this big old fax from the 70s that my parents gave me and I use that to deal with the distributor and the people who pressed the CDs. I've had a lot of kindness along the way."

The fairytale behind-the-scenes story of her success is in ironic contrast to the tone of some of her songs. Leonard Cohen is one of her idols, and she has a touch of his laconic graveyard humour.

Yesterday she was refusing to get too carried away with being shortlisted alongside Ashcroft, Leftfield, Nitin Sawhney and the Doves.

"I don't think it is going to affect me. Really, I don't. It's great and all, and I'm so excited in that I'm smoking like mad just so I remember to keep breathing."

She added: "In fact, I'm smoking that much my voice is going to be crap at Dingwalls and the rest of my gigs this week. But who cares?"

Another voice from the fringe, Badly Drawn Boy (aka Damon Gough), could be a clever outside bet.

Simon Frith, the chairman of the judges, said he had never seen a more wide open or eclectic field. "This is a very unusual year. For a start I like every single record, which rarely happens, and there was not the big records this year of the kind that demanded we take them into account or that create a controversy when we leave them out. We were all taken by surprise by our choices, which can only be good for the future of Britain music."

The clear bookies' favourite are Coldplay and their album Parachutes is at 3-1, while Ashcroft is joint second-favourite with Leftfield. Williams is at 20-1 with this year's lone classical artist, Nicholas Maw.

The winner will be announced on September 12.

Parachutes 3/1 favourites

Leftfield
Rhythm & Stealth 4/1

Richard Ashcroft
Alone With Everybody 4/1

Death In Vegas
The Contino Sessions 7/1

MJ Cole
Sincere 7/1

Badly Drawn Boy
The Hour of Bewilderbeas 10/1

Doves
Lost Souls 10/1

Nitin Sawhney
Beyond Skin 14/1

The Delgados
The Great Eastern 16/1

Helicopter Girl
How to Steal the World 16/1

Nicholas Maw
Violin Concerto 20/1

Kathryn Williams
Little Black Numbers 20/1

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
MI5 fails to stop Shayler article
An article by David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, on the circumstances surrounding the IRA bombing of Bishopsgate in the City of London in 1993 has been published in today's Punch magazine despite MI5 claims that it would damage national security. Mr Shayler says that, before the bombing, special branch could have arrested members of an IRA active service unit.
fields.body:
MI5 fails to stop Shayler article
An article by David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, on the circumstances surrounding the IRA bombing of Bishopsgate in the City of London in 1993 has been published in today's Punch magazine despite MI5 claims that it would damage national security. Mr Shayler says that, before the bombing, special branch could have arrested members of an IRA active service unit.

Omagh families to get legal aid
Relatives of the 29 Omagh bomb victims will be entitled to civil legal aid when the inquests open in September, the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, announced yesterday. Legal aid provisions do not apply to coroners' courts in Northern Ireland, but he said the circumstances were so exceptional that he had agreed to make funding available.

Vinnie lands lead Hollywood role
Former soccer hard man Vinnie Jones, 35, who made his name as an actor in the British film Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, has landed his first major Hollywood starring role, in the £60m thriller Swordfish.

Signatures on net made legal
Electronic signatures used to sign documents on the internet yesterday became legally admissible in court as handwritten signatures, the Department of Trade announced.

BBC wins fight over 'cult boy'
The BBC yesterday won the right to broadcast an interview with a teenager believed to have fled with members of a cult. Mr Justice Munby at the high court set aside an injunction which banned any interviews with Bobby Kelly, 16, from Romford, Essex, or members of the Jesus Christians group.

Two battle to stay in TV show

fields.headline: £140m plan to develop 'seedbeds of invention'
fields.trailText: A £140m fund to encourage and cultivate scientific entrepreneurs is to be unveiled today by the government in an attempt to turn British universities into US-style seedbeds of commercial innovation.
fields.body:
A £140m fund to encourage and cultivate scientific entrepreneurs is to be unveiled today by the government in an attempt to turn British universities into US-style seedbeds of commercial innovation.

The proposal will form the centrepiece of a science white paper, Excellence and Opportunity. The science minister, Lord Sainsbury, will portray the higher education innovation fund as a third stream of core funding for universities to be set alongside funding for teaching and pure research.

The white paper will also call for science ambassadors in schools to convince children that scientists can make money and earn respect.

It will call for improved communication strategy for scientists about their experiments and inventions.

In addition, money will be made available to match the salaries of scientists who have quit Britain for the US in the so-called science brain drain.

The proposals were welcomed by Chris Evans, chairman of Merlin Ventures and one of Britain's most successful science entrepreneurs.

He said yesterday: "The innovation fund is a large amount of money and means scientists will be able to get cash from within universities to develop their ideas commercially, rather than having to go with begging bowls to venture capitalists.

"We still have a quality science base, but we have been going backwards over the past 10 years. This sets out a vision to create more scientific entrepreneurs.

"There are not enough of us around. I am over 40 now, but made my first £1m by 28. Where are the 28-year-olds of today?"

Ministers believe the new emphasis on knowledge transfer from laboratory to the boardroom will not undermine scientific rigour.

Evidence from the US suggests the most rigorous research bases tend to be the most innovative commercially.

In 1998, a total of 223 businesses spun out of UK higher education institutions, but ministers believe this represents only a small fraction of the potential to develop enterprise universities.

Ministers expect the knowledge driven economy to require an ever higher research base.

Universities in the future could develop a strategic economic role within their region.

The £140m fund over three years, secured in the spending review, will be used to develop a closer understanding of the skills and knowledge that university research bases can bring to companies.

The money will also be deployed to bring businesses into educational institutions to help train academics and researchers to develop commercial skills such as filing patents, securing venture capital and writing business plans.

Finally, the money will be used to set up incubator units near universities in which small companies specialising for instance in health care, chemical and pharmaceutical industries can be established, drawing on the expertise in the university.

Lord Sainsbury and the industry secretary, Stephen Byers, are expected today to praise academic entrepreneurs, including Dr Evans, and successful companies spun out of Cambridge.

The reforms are designed to motivate British scientists, engineers and businesspeople to take advantage of the current scientific revolution to create wealth.

webTitle: MPs demand laws to hit global trade in looted art

fields.headline: MPs demand laws to hit global trade in looted art
fields.trailText: MPs yesterday proposed laws making it a criminal offence to trade in looted artefacts, to combat the growing international market in illegally acquired paintings and other art. The secretive market is thought to be worth between £150m and £2bn a year.
fields.body:
MPs yesterday proposed laws making it a criminal offence to trade in looted artefacts, to combat the growing international market in illegally acquired paintings and other art. The secretive market is thought to be worth between £150m and £2bn a year.

The Commons culture committee also recommended the Home Office set up a national database of stolen art, on advice from the British Art Market Federation that such information would provide "the most important practical step [towards] combating the illicit trade". The committee of MPs, the first for 184 years to look at the issue of the Elgin marbles, praised Glasgow city council for its handling of the return of the Lakota ghost dance shirt from Glasgow museums, describing it as a model process, and the British Museum for taking the lead in wanting to return Nazi-looted art.

The MPs' report demands the government acts with "utmost urgency" on legislation to facilitate the return of objects stolen by the Nazis and to allow museum trustees to return human remains on display in British museums.

The decision by Chris Smith, the culture secretary, not to ratify the recent Unidroit convention on stolen or illegally exported cultural objects, was criticised by the MPs.

webTitle: Stagecoach executive arrested in gay prostitution sting

fields.headline: Stagecoach executive arrested in gay prostitution sting
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: A senior executive has resigned from the company owned by Brian Souter, who led the campaign to keep section 28 in Scotland, after being arrested by undercover police in a gay prostitution sting.
fields.body:
A senior executive has resigned from the company owned by Brian Souter, who led the campaign to keep section 28 in Scotland, after being arrested by undercover police in a gay prostitution sting.

Barry Hinkley, 51, was arrested by vice squad officers in Houston, Texas, after he allegedly telephoned an escort agency in an attempt to procure a black male prostitute for sex.

Mr Hinkley, who is married with three children, was an executive director of Mr Souter's Stagecoach bus company. He was in the US on business when he was arrested on June 28.

Mr Souter bankrolled the Keep the Clause campaign north of the border, putting up £1m of his £310m fortune. He was the public face of the campaign to prevent the Scottish executive from repealing the law which prevents local authorities from promoting the acceptability of homosexuality.

Stagecoach said yesterday morning that Mr Hinkley had been suspended indefinitely, but by early evening he had resigned.

Mr Hinkley, from Bassenthwaite, Cumbria, was on business at Coach USA - the huge American bus company taken over by Stagecoach last year - when he was arrested by a Texan police officer in his Houston hotel room.

It is alleged that at 9.50pm Mr Hinkley telephoned a fictitious escort agency set up by undercover police officers and asked for a black male to visit his room.

A police officer manning the telephone line arranged for a black officer to go to Mr Hinkley's room at the exclusive Omni hotel. At around 10.30pm Mr Hinkley is alleged to have greeted the man he thought was from the escort agency at his room door wearing only his bathrobe. The vice officer asked Mr Hinkley what kind of sex he wanted and he is alleged to have replied: "All of it."

A few minutes later the pair allegedly discussed payment for sex, before the "prostitute" revealed he was an undercover police officer and arrested Mr Hinkley.

He was taken to the nearby Harris County jail, where he spent the night before appearing in court the following morning.

A spokesman for Harris County police yesterday confirmed Mr Hinkley had been charged with attempting to solicit a prostitute.

He denied the charge. He was freed on $500 (£340) bail and ordered to appear before the court on August 24.

If found guilty he could be jailed, but he is more likely to be fined.

Mr Hinkley was unavailable for comment and his attorney, Matt Hennessy, refused to comment. Mr Hinkley had been in charge of all Stagecoach's 20 UK bus operations and was a key player in the takeover of Coach USA, the second largest bus company in the US which now accounts for one quarter of Stagecoach's workforce.

Mr Souter, backed by the main Scottish tabloid dailies, was the driving force behind the movement to keep section 28 in Scotland.

His campaign culminated in a much criticised referendum - the first privately funded referendum in the UK - in which only around a quarter of Scots took part.

He managed to secure some concessions from ministers - notably with legally enforceable guidance stressing the importance of marriage.

But his campaign was ultimately unsuccessful and the section has been scrapped in Scotland, though it remains south of the border.

fields.headline: Researchers link coffee to arthritis
fields.trailText: People who drink more than four cups of coffee a day could be putting themselves at increased risk of developing arthritis, researchers reported yesterday.
fields.body:
People who drink more than four cups of coffee a day could be putting themselves at increased risk of developing arthritis, researchers reported yesterday.

A study carried out in Finland, where coffee drinking is heavy and permeates all social strata, has shown that there is a link between the number of cups drunk each day and the chances of developing rheumatoid factor - a hallmark antibody of rheumatoid arthritis which shows up in tests before any symptoms develop and is a predictor of rheumatoid arthritis.

In the journal Annals of the Rheumatic Diseases, the Finnish researchers report on two large studies carried out on populations of Finns over the age of 30. One was a cross sectional survey of almost 7,000 people, and the other involved almost 19,000 people, who were monitored for around 15 years. None of the study participants had any evidence of arthritis when first tested.

Markku Helivaara, of the National Public Health Institute in Helsinki, and colleagues found a strong association between the number of daily cups of coffee and the presence of rheumatoid factor in the smaller study.

In the larger one, those people who drank four or more cups of coffee a day were twice as likely to test positive for arthritis as those who drank less.

Those who drank 11 or more cups a day were almost 15 times as likely to have rheumatoid factor as non-coffee drinkers.

The researchers said there was known to be a link between smoking and obesity and rheumatoid arthritis, but even after they weighted their findings to remove those factors - and also age, gender, blood cholesterol and education levels - the association between coffee drinking and the disease remained.

As yet, they do not know what it is in coffee that could trigger rheumatoid factor, leading to arthritis.

"It cannot be concluded whether the associations between coffee consumption and rheumatoid factor and rheumatoid arthritis were due to coffee exposure itself or to some lifestyle or dietary factor closely linked with it," they said.

The researchers also noted that many Finns had been switching from the strong unfiltered coffee they traditionally drank, and that the age of developing arthritis had risen over the same period (from 1975 to 1990) from an average of 50.2 to 57.8 years.

The researchers suggested that further studies should look at the type of coffee consumed.

"Possibly some ingredient in coffee, unidentified so far and removable by filtration, might trigger the production of rheumatoid factor," they said.

But they were sufficiently confident of their findings to suggest coffee drinking must now be considered as a risk factor in rheumatoid arthritis.

"If coffee consumption were to show a modest association with either rheumatoid factor or rheumatoid arthritis, the most likely explanation for such a finding would be confounding or chance alone," they wrote.

"That our main results, from two independent studies with different designs and outcomes, point to the same inference clearly suggests that the phenomenon is real, even if its mechanism remains unknown."

webTitle: Motive for murders may remain mystery

fields.headline: Motive for murders may remain mystery
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating the deaths of a family of six at their home in Barry, south Wales, have admitted they may never know the reasons behind the tragedy.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating the deaths of a family of six at their home in Barry, south Wales, have admitted they may never know the reasons behind the tragedy.

No clear motive has yet emerged to explain the apparent suicide of former civil servant Robert Mochrie and the killing of his wife, Catherine, and the couple's four children, who were beaten to death with a blunt instrument.

Police are investigating whether financial worries could have led to the deaths. Detective Superintendent Kevin O'Neill, of South Wales police, said the focus of the investigation was on the family's financial background, their relationships and the couple's marriage, but so far nothing stood out.

"It is difficult because of the period of time between their deaths and when they were discovered. It is more likely probable we will never know what really happened."

The bodies of Catherine Mochrie, 45, and her four children, Bethan, 10, Luke, 14, Sian, 16, and James, 18, were found in bed in their separate bedrooms on Sunday after friends reported they had not seen the family for several days.

Mr Mochrie was discovered hanging on the landing of the house where the family had lived for 15 years.

Police said last night that they had not yet found the blunt instrument used in the assault. Postmortem examinations of the bodies are continuing.

Mr O'Neill said there was no indication that the victims had been restrained before being killed.

Nor was there any evidence they had been drugged, although that was one line of inquiry.

It was initially thought the bodies could have been in the house for up to 11 days.

But Mr O'Neill said Luke Mochrie had spent most of last Tuesday evening in a pub with a friend.

Mrs Mochrie's younger brother, former Wales and British Lions international rugby player Terry Holmes, issued a statement through police yesterday in which he said: "Our family have been completely devastated by the loss of my sister and her family. I simply do not know how to begin putting into words how we are feeling.

"We are supporting each other as best we can through this terrible time and as you can understand we obviously need time to grieve."

fields.headline: Nortel creates 1,300 jobs in Antrim
fields.trailText: Telecommunications group Nortel Networks is to bring 1,300 new jobs to Northern Ireland as part of a global expansion costing more than £1bn.
fields.body:
Telecommunications group Nortel Networks is to bring 1,300 new jobs to Northern Ireland as part of a global expansion costing more than £1bn.

The firm will spend about £89m on its operation at Monkstown, Newtownabbey, Co Antrim, building a new factory and increasing its workforce there to 3,300 by the end of 2001.

Overall, 9,600 workers were being recruited across operations in Europe, north Amer ica and Australia as part of the company's plan to more than double its global optical systems and components production capacity.

The drive is to meet demand for networks systems and components, the firm said.

Nortel has been established at Monkstown for the past 10 years and is recruiting 405 workers as part of an expansion announced earlier this year.

Sir Reg Empey, the Northern Ireland enterprise, trade and investment minister, welcomed the announcement as "spectacular news" which would almost double the workforce at the Monkstown plant.

He said: "I think this puts Northern Ireland firmly on the global map as far as telecoms and associated issues are concerned.

"I think it is something the people of Northern Ireland should be very proud and pleased about" -

webTitle: Payouts for gays sacked by forces

fields.headline: Payouts for gays sacked by forces
fields.trailText: Four former armed services personnel sacked because they were gay were awarded a total of £324,875 compensation yesterday by the European court of human rights in Strasbourg.
fields.body:
Four former armed services personnel sacked because they were gay were awarded a total of £324,875 compensation yesterday by the European court of human rights in Strasbourg.

The government was also ordered to pay £81,200 in costs.

Duncan Lustig-Prean, a former naval commander who has waged a six-year battle to force the services to change their "no gays" policy, was awarded £114,000 - £94,875 for loss of earnings and pension rights and £19,000 for intrusion into his private life.

John Beckett, a former naval rating from Sheffield, was awarded £74,000 in compensation, while a former RAF nurse, Jeanette Smith, from Edinburgh, won £78,000, and an ex-RAF administrator, Graeme Grady, from London, was awarded £59,000. In each case the award included sums for loss of earnings and pension rights, plus £19,000 for intrusion into privacy.

The awards followed a ruling last September that their dismissals because of their sexual orientation violated article eight of the European convention on human rights, which protects individuals from interference by the state with their private life.

That ruling made it legally impossible for the Ministry of Defence to maintain its ban on gays in the armed forces, and the ban was lifted last January.

Mr Lustig-Prean, who enlisted in 1983, was discharged in January 1994 after reporting an attempt to blackmail him on grounds of his homosexuality. He and the other three took their cases to Strasbourg with the help of Stonewall, the gay rights group, and Rank Outsiders, the association of gay ex-service personnel, after losing in the high court and court of appeal. The European court judges said the government's interference with the four applicants' human rights had been "especially grave".

Angela Mason, executive director of Stonewall, said: "The award will go some way to make up the losses suffered by those people who were forced out of the armed services on the grounds of their sexual orientation."

Although the ban has been lifted, gay service personnel will still face disciplinary action if their behaviour undermines the effectiveness of their units.

Patrick Lyster-Todd, of Rank Outsiders, said the four did not want to comment. He added: "They had their lives pulled apart in some instances in a manner whcih brought no credit to the British armed forces." But he said the services were doing a good job of integrating gays now that the ban had been lifted.

webTitle: Judge orders acquittal of au pair's parents

fields.headline: Judge orders acquittal of au pair's parents
fields.trailText: The parents of Louise Woodward, the former au pair convicted of killing a baby in her charge in the US, were cleared yesterday after a jury was instructed to find them not guilty of defrauding their daughter's appeal fund.
fields.body:
The parents of Louise Woodward, the former au pair convicted of killing a baby in her charge in the US, were cleared yesterday after a jury was instructed to find them not guilty of defrauding their daughter's appeal fund.

Gary and Susan Woodward, both 44, had denied forging an invoice in order to claim $15,400 (£9,100) from the fund in living expenses incurred before and during their daughter's murder trial in the US in 1997. They also denied providing false information.

Judge John Rogers QC ordered the jury at Chester crown court to reach a not guilty verdict after ruling that although there was evidence that the invoice was false and that the Woodwards had acted dishonestly, the crown had failed to prove that some money had not been donated solely for their use.

The disputed invoice was for rent apparently paid by Mrs Woodward to her daughter's defence lawyer, Elaine Whitfield Sharp, with whom she was staying. Mrs Whitfield Sharp gave evidence during the trial that she had not made any such charge.

The Louise Woodward and Family Appeal was established after Ms Woodward was arrested for the murder of Matthew Eapen, an eight-month-old child in her charge. More than £250,000 was donated by the public as her parents, now estranged, protested her innocence.

Ms Woodward was arrested in Boston, Massachusetts, in February 1997 for assault and battery after the infant, who was in her care, became ill. She was later charged with his murder. It was alleged that she had shaken him to death.

She was convicted of second-degree murder in October 1997, but the verdict was later reduced to manslaughter by the trial judge and Ms Woodward was released after being sentenced to 279 days, the period she had spent on remand awaiting trial. Ms Woodward continues to deny she killed Matthew Eapen.

Judge Rogers said that while there was evidence that the invoice was false and that the Woodwards had been acting dishonestly, the crucial ques tion was whether the jury could be sure that all the money belonged to the trust and that none of it belonged to Mr and Mrs Woodward.

The judge cited evidence given by Paul Barrow, formerly a lawyer for the trust, who had told the court there was no way of distinguishing between personal donations to the Woodwards and money donated to the appeal.

"It is my responsibility to have to conclude that the crown failed to provide evidence on which any reasonable jury could convict and I have to direct you to return verdicts of not guilty on each count," he told the jury.

After dismissing the jury, Judge Rogers said his decision implied no criticism of the prosecution. "What has occurred was not foreseeable. It simply came out in evidence and no criticism could be made of anybody in this case. Now and again pieces of evidence arise in trials which no one can foresee."

Speaking after their acquittal the Woodwards maintained their innocence, and described their daughter's conviction as a "travesty".

"We hope that today's acquittal will now draw a line under this whole unhappy and upsetting episode and that the press and other news media will leave us and our family alone," they said in a joint statement.

Neil Cobley, solicitor for Mr Woodward, said the couple had no plans to sell their story to a newspaper, but if they did the money would be donated to a children's charity. "It has been very, very traumatic, and you have to ask why they were prosecuted when the trial didn't get past the prosecution case," he said.

Superintendent Phil Thompson of Cheshire police defended the decision to proceed: "The investigation highlighted a number of issues which were raised with the crown prosecution service ... we believe that, given the public interest, it was appropriate that these issues be aired through the legal process," he said.

During the six-day trial the jury heard that Mrs Woodward lived at the Whitfield Sharps' home between April and October 1997. Mrs Whitfield Sharp testified that she had lived there rent free. The disputed invoice came to light when the Woodwards filed for £30,000 in expenses incurred while in the US.

At the start of Louise's trial in October Mrs Woodward moved to an apartment near the court paid for by her daughter's au pair agency, which also paid for air fares, legal bills, hotel rooms and car rental.

The court heard that as well as receiving their full salaries from work while they travelled to and from the US to visit Ms Woodward, the couple had been paid £50,000 by the Daily Mail for their story, a payment they did not disclose.

Mr Woodward has claimed that Mrs Whitfield Sharp was motivated by anger at not being given permission to write a book about Ms Woodward with their cooperation, a claim she denied.

fields.headline: Iobox fetches £140m
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The heavy premium being placed on add-on services for mobile internet devices was illustrated yesterday when fledgling wireless portal Iobox was gobbled up by Terra Mobile for euro230m (£140m).
fields.body:
The heavy premium being placed on add-on services for mobile internet devices was illustrated yesterday when fledgling wireless portal Iobox was gobbled up by Terra Mobile for euro230m (£140m).

The deal gives the Spanish operator access to more than 1m customers in Britain, Finland, Sweden and Germany who have registered to use Iobox's services. These enable users to surf the net, send messages, play games and store addresses and appointments on internet-enabled mobile phones.

Terra Mobile is a joint venture 51% owned by Telefonica Moviles and 49% by Terra Networks, the fast-growing Spanish portal that recently agreed to pay £8.4bn for US search engine Lycos.

Iobox began operations in Finland last year and has partnerships in Britain with Vodafone and One2One. The co-founders, Jari Ovaskainen and Henry Nilert, own about 30% of the business. Mr Ovaskainen said they originally intended Terra Mobile to take only a minority stake but decided to sell up entirely because "we fell in love with their aggression and machismo".

The two will stay with the enlarged group to help it roll out Iobox's service across the continent and new platforms.

"Terra has the brand recognition, significant resources and operational global reach, which combined with our pioneering technology and world class team will give us a very strong position to capture the opportunities of the wireless business," Mr Ovaskainen added.

webTitle: Quiz for lovers claims to predict bliss or bust-up

fields.headline: Quiz for lovers claims to predict bliss or bust-up
fields.trailText: Romeo and Juliet should have wasted less time hanging over balconies and more at their desks with a sharp pencil and a pre-marriage questionnaire, according to a US academic yesterday.
fields.body:
Romeo and Juliet should have wasted less time hanging over balconies and more at their desks with a sharp pencil and a pre-marriage questionnaire, according to a US academic yesterday.

Jeffry Larson, professor of marriage and family studies at Brigham Young University, Utah, claimed that he could lower divorce rates and limit tragic ends to love affairs by asking couples for "true or false" answers to statements such as "people get stuck in marriage".

The test compares a couple's answers with 25 statements on topics such as money, in-laws, ambition and sex to calculate their chances of living happily ever after. If their answers radically differ they may have to call the whole thing off.

Professor Larson based his questions on 20 years' research and more than 100 couple studies.

He said: "Many people think that love is enough to overcome any obstacle, but history continues to prove this is simply not true. Not every couple in love should get married."

The words "Are you sure you love me?" and "Maybe things will be better after we're married" were the equivalent of flashing red lights at a junction.

He said couples should not marry: before they are 23; if they have known each other for a year or less; if one tells the other they are just like their mother or father; or if they consider a day alone together without TV to be unbearable.

Julia Cole, a counsellor for Relate marriage guidance, said the pre-marital questionnaire was like handing a list of questions to a woman who had just given birth and determining whether her child should be removed from her care.

"The success of a marriage, like the success of parenthood, is largely about ability to cope with change... under the pressure of family life." Instead of a questionnaire, she advised pre-marital counselling or a course.

Of the 250,000 couples marrying in Britain this year, more than 100,000 will part. But Jeremy Levison, a partner in a family law and divorce mediation firm, said the questionnaire would not put him out of business.

"Couples get married for thousands of reasons. If two 24-year-olds both answered yes to the question about good sex in marriage in this questionnaire they would forget the other questions and rush straight to the altar."

Couple unfazed by 25% risk factor:

Richard Grocock, 25, and Hannah Dean, 24, are getting married in September in a church in Tickhill, South Yorkshire. He is an entertainment agent and she is a personal assistant in an advertising firm.

The couple, who met in a production of West Side Story when they were 20 and 19, scored 10 out of 15 on the pre-marriage test. According to its author, Jeffry Larson, this means they have a 75% chance of living happily ever after.

But the 25% danger factor predicted may be deceptive.

Mr Grocock said marriage was the one of the most important things in life. His fiancee said it was not. He said women had a more natural ability for childcare. She said they did not. But these questions were ambiguous, he said, and he could answer both true and false to them.

He was able, without speaking to his fiancee, to predict which of her answers would be different from his and why. According to the marriage guidance counsellors Relate, this means the couple communicate and know each other well.

Ms Dean said: "I believe we know how each other feels, and sometimes it takes time to win someone round or compromise.

"What is the point of having everything planned out so exactly? Life's all about dealing with the hiccups along the way. So in a word, yes, this scientist has probably spent someone's money on doing an irrelevant questionnaire - but that's research for you."

Couples should answer true or false to the following statements. The more they disagree over, the poorer their chance of a happy marriage:

1 Being married is the first or second most important thing in life

2 Mothers have more natural ability than fathers in relating to infants

3 Married couples do not need to share many hobbies with each other

4 Sexual intercourse in marriage is key to marital satisfaction

5 Sharing my feelings and concerns about our relationship with family and friends is OK

6 Money may not buy happiness in a family but it does help

7 A couple should delay having children until other important issues are worked out

8 Relationships are unpredictable

9 When I'm upset with my partner I ignore him or her for a while

10 Time will resolve any problems we have as a couple

11 It is important for a husband and wife to have many of the same friends and to like each other's friends

12 Husbands and wives should both look carefully for bargains before buying something they want

13 It is important that my family has the finer things in life

14 People get stuck in marriage

15 In my marriage it would not bother me if the wife earned more than the husband.

webTitle: Britons prefer print as news medium

fields.headline: Britons prefer print as news medium
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Britain has embraced the wonders of the internet but turns to newspapers and television when it comes to getting the news, a poll showed yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain has embraced the wonders of the internet but turns to newspapers and television when it comes to getting the news, a poll showed yesterday.

The survey by business information website Just-sites.com showed 15m British adults have access to the internet but more than eight in 10 would rather catch up on news the old fashioned way.

While the results were a blow to many consumer-oriented news sites, there was new hope for those targeting the business and trade market, the company said.

"A massive 83% of the 1,000 people polled said they will never switch to the internet as their first choice of news service," just-sites.com said. "Just 1% of the sample currently uses the internet for its main source of news, compared with 68% who prefer TV news and 11% who choose national newspapers as their primary source."

Only 3% said they would pay for an online subscription but about 20% agreed the internet was a better means of getting news than the trade press.

"The research also identified some worrying trends for publishers of traditional printed trade media, which is perceived as providing news that is out of date by 40% of the business sample.

"A further 37% agree that there are too many titles to cope with and 7% think that the trade press won't be able to survive in the face of the internet."

webTitle: Swiss court aids Russian fraud inquiry

fields.headline: Swiss court aids Russian fraud inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Pressure on the Russian tycoon Boris Berezovsky has increased with the decision of the Swiss supreme court to let a Russian prosecutor have documents today showing evidence of alleged fraud at Aeroflot during the 1990s.
fields.byline: Peter Capella  in Geneva and  Amelia Gentleman in Moscow
fields.body:
Pressure on the Russian tycoon Boris Berezovsky has increased with the decision of the Swiss supreme court to let a Russian prosecutor have documents today showing evidence of alleged fraud at Aeroflot during the 1990s.

Mr Berezovsky appealed in February against the handover of papers relating to two companies in Switzerland which he part owned. The companies, Andava and Forus, handled the Russian airline's financial affairs.

The court rejected Mr Berezovsky's claim that an investigation launched by prosecutors in Russia last year was politically motivated, and granted the judicial assistance first requested in May last year.

The Russian accusations, detailed for the first time in the Swiss ruling, show that Mr Berezovsky is suspected of placing associates in key positions at Aeroflot after part of the state airline was sold in 1993, so that they could divert profits and other funds to companies he controlled.

The Swiss authorities have frozen bank accounts containing $715m (£472m). Russian prosecutors claim that foreign offices of Aeroflot were ordered in May 1996 to pay 80% of their profits to a Swiss bank account, netting $400m.

Another $200m is alleged to have come from air traffic rights paid by foreign airlines using Russian airspace. A total of $115m was deposited with unidentified companies.

"Berezovsky and his associates allegedly used these laundered funds for financial operations in Russia, to personal ends," the court said in the ruling released this week.

It added that the Russian investigating magistrate, Nikolai Volkov, had presented sufficient evidence of a serious judicial investigation.

"In any case, there is nothing to indicate that the suspicions levelled against [Mr Berezovsky] might have been fabricated or were part of a political conspiracy."

Mr Berezovsky was interviewed by Mr Volkov about the Aeroflot case 10 days ago. Shortly afterwards he resigned from the Russian parliament.

He described his departure as a protest at "authoritarian" trends in Russia. But political analysts in Moscow saw it as a sign that the influential position Mr Berezovsky enjoyed in the Kremlin under Boris Yeltsin was at risk under Russia's new president, Vladimir Putin.

His resignation came just days after five of the country's most prominent tycoons found themselves under scrutiny from government prosecutors and tax police.

Mr Berezovsky made light of the investigations yesterday, dismissing Russian media reports that he planned to leave Russia and request political asylum in France.

The supreme court ruling also reveals that Mr Volkov told the Swiss in November that although he was dropping charges of money laundering against Mr Berezovsky at that time, the proceedings were not closed and he was prepared to revive charges with new evidence from Switzerland.

Charges are pending against two business associates and former Aeroflot managers, Nikolai Gluchkov and Alexander Krasnenker.

Mr Volkov will collect about 200 pages of banking and company documents today. He will also have the opportunity to examine several hundred pages more during his visit.

Forus and Andava, based in Lausanne, have rejected the Russian charges as false and unjustified. They said Mr Berezovsky left the boards of the companies in 1996 and 1997 respectively.

Forus hired the international auditor PricewaterhouseCoopers to examine its transactions with Aeroflot. The auditor said on Monday that it had found no evidence that funds were illegally funnelled to the Swiss company.

fields.headline: In-house stocks go off-menu
fields.trailText: Once might be considered unfortunate, but twice? Broker CSFB yesterday decided to turn negative on another one of its house stocks, satellite broadcaster BSkyB.
fields.body:
Once might be considered unfortunate, but twice? Broker CSFB yesterday decided to turn negative on another one of its house stocks, satellite broadcaster BSkyB.

On the eve of full year figures, CSFB cut its 2001 Ebitda (earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation) forecast on the company to £110m from £302m and raised its pre-tax loss estimate for the same year to £243m from £131m.

The move came just days after CSFB melted out the same treatment to another house stock, Freeserve. Last Thursday, shares in the internet outfit tumbled 8% as it became clear that CSFB had increased its loss forecast for the company in the year to April 2001 to £60.9m from £27.4m. Yesterday they were down 5.25p at 323.5p.

Executives at BSkyB were said to be furious with the timing of the downgrade and the affect it had on the shares, which ended the day 70p lower at £12.37.

That said, the note contained little that was new and the share price decline was a little overdone. CSFB's forecasts were at the more optimistic end of expectations anyway and the reasons for the downgrades (the consolidation of interactive television service Open and the recent acquisition of Sports Internet Group) are hardly new. Moreover, CSFB reckons the shares are worth £14.50.

But the market was in no mood to forgive yesterday, as the recent pattern of skittish trading continued. The FTSE 100 finished marginally higher, up 9.4 points at 6,390.7, as strength in the banking and pharmaceutical sectors was offset by weakness in a handful of heavily weighted telecom stocks.

Dealers are starting to wonder when the pain will stop for cable company Telewest. The shares declined for a third consecutive session yesterday, closing 13p lower at 210p as American investors offloaded huge parcels of the stock. It seems they have turned negative in the wake of last week's announcement from Telewest that it has suspended marketing of its digital TV services due to a shortage of set-top boxes.

There was better news over at Marconi, where the Lord Simpson's move to chairman was greeted with a jump of 45p to £10.70. Of course that was not the real reason for the shares strong performance, that was down to a positive note from Schroder Salomon Smith Barney.

Monday's deal to supply BT with optical electronics for its European broadband network is good news. According to SSSB, Marconi needed to show it could leverage its strong position in SDH into photonics and the deal has done just that.

What all this means in plain English is that the shares should fly. SSSB has set a target price of £14.00 for the stock, which closed at £10.70 last night.

Elsewhere, those who had sold shares in Reuters they did not own (in the hope of buying them cheaper after interim results) were feeling the pain. fields.headline: Laxer Axa
fields.trailText: The plan by French insurer Axa to carve up its £1.7bn "orphan" estate assets should have been good news for the life assurance sector yesterday. But it was not, with the share price of all the leading players moving lower.
fields.body:
The plan by French insurer Axa to carve up its £1.7bn "orphan" estate assets should have been good news for the life assurance sector yesterday. But it was not, with the share price of all the leading players moving lower.

Prudential eased 42p to 978p, Britannic fell 8.5p to £10.72 and even Legal & General where bid speculation refuses to die, lost 5p to 163p.

Analysts said the reaction of the stock market reflected the fact that none of the proceeds will be returned to Axa shareholders. That said, it is still possible that some life assurers will return proceeds, but investors should not get too excited.

Although Axa and the financial services authority have reached a deal, the agreement has to be put before the courts.

As analysts at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson point out, other companies, such as the Prudential, may decide to follow a different route to that of Axa.

fields.headline: HSBC
fields.trailText: HSBC was among the best performers on the stock market yesterday and was being tipped as one bank share which has further scope for gains in the months ahead.
fields.body:
HSBC was among the best performers on the stock market yesterday and was being tipped as one bank share which has further scope for gains in the months ahead.

Just days before it is due to publish its interim results, the two companies which act as its official broker and advisers issued buy recommendations on the stock.

Their hands had been tied until yesterday because of the ongoing takeover of French bank CCF, completed this week. Michael Lever, an analyst at HSBC, set a target of £9.85 for the shares, while the brokers at Cazenove were said to have set their sights higher at £10.10.

Their recommendations also came on the day that UBS Warburg also sent out buy signals for the shares, all of which helped propel HSBC to a new high of £8.88. While some technical factors associated with the acquisition of CCF may have contributed to yesterday's share price rise, the analysts appear to have longer-term reasons for backing the shares.

Mr Lever revealed yesterday that his expectations for the bank's profits on Monday were outside the City consensus of $4.4bn-$4.7bn. He is placing his estimate at $4.9bn. Some of his upgrade is based on the back of the fact that HSBC is basically a bigger bank than it was 18 months ago during which time it has spent $22bn on acquisitions - more than the market capitalisation of some its British rivals.

However, Mr Lever said that one third of his upgraded was based on a "genuine underlying progress" in the bank's business.

He compared HSBC against a number of its British rivals and acknowledges that on some measures it looks expensive. But the bank clearly cannot be regarded as a purely British bank, being so global that it even reports its results in US dollars.

At a time when bank shares are out of fashion in Britain where competition for business appears to be mounting, HSBC may be the one to back appears to be verdict of its own brokers and others.
