fields.headline: Trade gap narrows
fields.standfirst: Analysts say figures are uncomfortably high
fields.trailText: Britain's trading gap with the rest of the world narrowed in May, but analysts warned the deficit was still uncomfortably high.
fields.body:
Britain's trading gap with the rest of the world narrowed in May, but analysts warned the deficit was still uncomfortably high.

Imports outstripped exports by £2.5bn over the month, according to the office for national statistics. Although this was a better performance than the £2.6bn recorded the previous month, it still well above market expectation of a £2.1bn shortfall.

Michael Hume, UK economist with Lehman Brothers described the figures as truly horrific. "Both the global and non-EU deficits were substantially bigger than expected and revisions to earlier data also painted a gloomier picture than had previously been the case."

The deficit on trade with EU countries stood at £740m over the month, the highest since June last year. Despite last month's poor results for trade with EU countries, it is the trade with the rest of the world where most of the deterioration has occurred.

The trade deficit with countries outside the EU widened to £2.1bn in June from £1.8bn the previous month, according to the ONS. Analysts had expected a shortfall of £1.9 bn.

Mr Hume said the figures cast doubt on hopes that the domestic economy was slowing without need for further interest rate rises.

"It seems as though the drag on the economy from net trade in the second quarter was a lot bigger than had been previously thought," he said. "Given that the first estimate of Q2 GDP shows that activity was robust, it also implies that domestic demand must have surged."

Import volumes rose 7% over the month, a sign of rising demand at home, which could prompt the Bank of England to push up interest rates.

"This will not be wasted on the Bank of England and should be seen as increasing slightly the likelihood of a rate hike next week," said Bank America economist Jeremy Hawkins.

The ONS said the latest figures suggested the British trade deficit was getting worse.

webTitle: Serb army tries author of atrocity reports as spy

fields.headline: Serb army tries author of atrocity reports as spy
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: A Serb journalist who reported on atrocities in Kosovo went on trial for espionage in a military court in the Serbian city of Nis yesterday.
fields.body:
A Serb journalist who reported on atrocities in Kosovo went on trial for espionage in a military court in the Serbian city of Nis yesterday.

Miroslav Filipovic's reports on atrocities committed in the province last year included accounts by Yugoslav officers who said they were shocked at some of the brutality they had seen their side perpetrating.

Mr Filipovic, who has already been detained for several weeks, is the first Serb journalist to face such serious charges. His case has aroused extensive international protest and he was recently named the European Internet Journalist of the Year.

Mr Filipovic worked for the web-based Institute for War and Peace Reporting in London, the French news agency Agence France-Presse and a Belgrade paper, Danas.

His hard-hitting pieces have included reports on the defection of generals from the Yugoslav army and the sending of elite army and police units in plain clothes to Kosovo in recent months to incite clashes between Serb and Albanian civilians, with the aim of discrediting international peacekeeping efforts.

The presiding judge, a colonel, ordered the court into closed session soon after the trial opened yesterday, because the deputy military prosecutor, Captain Aleksandar Kalicanin, said Mr Filipovic's testimony would contain sensitive military information.

The charges state that he committed espionage by "collecting secret military data from the beginning of May 1999 until May 2000, with the intention of passing it on to foreign organisations such as IWPR and AFP."

They also say he spread false information - with the intention of provoking civil unrest - by reporting that "the Yugoslav army committed atrocities in Kosovo and Metohija [a mountainous district in the province], and shelled and destroyed villages".

Mr Filipovic's most dramatic story was about an internal army survey into wartime atrocities. He later interviewed officers who had spoken to the investigators. "War-weary Serb officers have spoken for the first time of sickening atrocities committed by the Yugoslav army in Kosovo during the Nato bombing campaign" in mid-1999, he wrote.

"One field commander admitted that he watched in horror as a soldier decapitated a three-year-old boy in front of his family. Another soldier described how tanks in his unit indiscriminately shelled Albanian villages before paramilitary police moved in and massacred the survivors.

"The shocking confessions were made by officers who took part in a survey commissioned by the army intelligence unit in January and February this year."

The military men who spoke to Mr Filipovic claimed to be shocked by the enormity of the crimes committed in Kosovo at the climax of the conflict provoked by the secession attempts of the province's ethnic Albanian majority. Particularly disturbing were the combined testimonies of field officers which suggested that Yugoslav army units were responsible for the death of at least 800 Albanian children under the age of five.

Several officers interviewed by Mr Filipovic said that the army's internal survey had been aimed at gauging their morale at a time when new tension was developing - this time between Serbia and Montenegro. The veterans said they were appalled by the prospect of mounting a military campaign against their ethnic Montenegrin cousins.

Those interviewed said they were traumatised by what they had seen in Kosovo .

One officer, Drazen, said, "I watched with my own eyes as a reservist lined up around 30 Albanian women and children against a wall. I thought he just wanted to frighten them, but then he crouched down behind an anti-aircraft machine gun and pulled the trigger."

webTitle: Skipton pledges to keep on buying trail

fields.headline: Skipton pledges to keep on buying trail
fields.trailText: Skipton Building Society said yesterday it is to continue with its aggressive acquisitions strategy, claiming that its "entrepreneurial philosophy" had enabled it to deliver record profits this year.
fields.body:
Skipton Building Society said yesterday it is to continue with its aggressive acquisitions strategy, claiming that its "entrepreneurial philosophy" had enabled it to deliver record profits this year.

During the past three months Britain's seventh largest building society has acquired majority shareholdings in two companies and sold off a third. Announcing first-half pre-tax profits up to £24.8m from £23.1m a year earlier, the society said it would "continue to seek further acquisitions proactively".

In May Skipton took a majority shareholding in the internet and IT solutions provider Cast Systems, and sold its share dealing arm Dealwise to stockbroker TD Waterhouse for £82m. On Friday it announced its latest acquisition - a majority shareholding in mortgage lending and packaging business Pink Home Loans, bought for an initial £2.75m.

The sale of Dealwise has enabled Skipton to return almost £50m of profits to long-term members in the form of an "interest credit" worth up to £1,000 per person. This scheme, announced last week, will see 290,000 members receiving either extra interest on their savings or a reduction in their September mortgage payment.

John Goodfellow, the North Yorkshire-based company's chief executive, said that even allowing for the money raised by the Dealwise sale, the underlying results demonstrated a strong performance from the society and its nine subsidiaries.

"Each company has a developing business plan, including innovative e-commerce strategies, designed to generate additional profits," he said. "Skipton's entrepreneurial philosophy offers its members something which no other building society does - a share in the commercial success and earnings potential of its subsidiary companies."

webTitle: Notebook: Water regulator's feeling is not mutual

fields.headline: Water regulator's feeling is not mutual
fields.standfirst: Byatt takes consumers' side
fields.trailText: Water industry regulator Sir Ian Byatt's decision to block Kelda's proposal to turn Yorkshire Water's assets - its reservoirs, pipes, sewage works etc - into a mutual has left the industry in a pickle. That does not mean Sir Ian was wrong. Far from it. The Kelda proposal was skewed very much in shareholders' favour. They stood to pick up around £1bn from the plan. The benefits for consumers were more difficult to identify.
fields.body:
Water industry regulator Sir Ian Byatt's decision to block Kelda's proposal to turn Yorkshire Water's assets - its reservoirs, pipes, sewage works etc - into a mutual has left the industry in a pickle. That does not mean Sir Ian was wrong. Far from it. The Kelda proposal was skewed very much in shareholders' favour. They stood to pick up around £1bn from the plan. The benefits for consumers were more difficult to identify.

The question now, however, is where does the water industry go from here? Sir Ian clearly feels that the equity-based firms were delivering on savings to customers, investment and environmental improvement. The snag is that it is the turn of shareholders to feel bruised. Share prices in the sector are down on an average of 40% over the past year and Kelda, for example, is trading at a 15% discount to its regulatory asset base.

Though it is hard to feel much sympathy, it is worth giving a thought to the longer-term implications for an industry which is unable to deliver the sort of returns shareholders not only expect but can easily get elsewhere.

Consumers cannot feel complacent either. Under the present ownership structure water companies may have delivered significant benefits but those have stemmed from a tough regulatory regime, not because the industry has felt the cold wind of competition. There is no guarantee that future regulators will always be as robust as Sir Ian.

Today the industry must go back to the drawing board in terms of its structure and financing. It would be a pity if yesterday's decision were to make mutuality a non-starter. It could prove a better option than the original inappropriate and ideologically driven privatisation programme. Any such proposals, however, must be based not only on significant benefits for consumers but on those consumers getting every opportunity to decide whether they want to accept. Mutuality cannot add up to much without consent.

M&S who's who

The non-executive side of the board of Marks & Spencer is in danger of becoming a who's who of the great and good in the City. The latest recruits are Misys boss Kevin Lomax and BSkyB's chief executive, Tony Ball. They join a star-studded line up which includes Rolls-Royce chairman Sir Ralph Robins, former Guinness boss Brian Baldock and, to add a little extra intrigue, MI5's first female chief Dame Stella Rimington.

There is sound commercial logic in tapping the wisdom of high achievers from other organisations. Dame Stella, for example, has experience of overseeing big changes, while Mr Lomax and Mr Ball know about the "new economy", which is crucial for M&S, given the growth of internet shopping.

But this eclectic mixture of independent directors contrasts starkly with the very in-house look to the executive side of the board table. Apart from chief executive Luc Vandevelde and marketing director Alan McWalter, the group's executives are all M&S careerists, steeped in the bureaucratic culture of Baker Street.

To his credit, Mr Vandevelde has said he wants a greater breadth of "knowledge and experience" alongside him. Since his arrival, three executives have already left the board. Mr Vandevelde now needs to act quickly and decisively to bring in some heavyweight talent on the executive side to match the non-executive recruits.

After all the key role of independent directors is to act as scrutineers, not to run the business on a day-to-day basis. What Marks & Spencer needs is more flair, dynamism and some decent clothes to sell. It may not have that long to deliver. The City wants signs of improvement by the end of the year.

Granada burst

Has Granada Media caught Carlton and United News & Media's defences napping and gone 1-0 up in commercial television's big match? Yesterday's announcement of a broadband joint-venture with Liverpool football club carried all the PR buzz-words you might expect. It said the portal would be pioneering, multi-platform, and global. And with a high-profile brand like Liverpool's involved it was always going to grab the headlines.

Behind the hype there was nothing new. Rupert Murdoch has long described sport as the "battering-ram" for driving television subscriptions; football clubs have been talking about the value of their "content" ever since; and the new Liverpool FC service is unlikely to be operating at full strength for a few seasons yet.

But Granada has become the first broadcaster to sketch out how it plans to make the most of sports content in the new media age. That can only help it in its efforts to persuade the City that it has the necessary foresight to be trusted with leading the consolidation of ITV.

The cost to Granada? £20m. A snip. Lets face it £20m barely buys you a footballer you have heard of these days.

That can only help it in its efforts to persuade the City that it has the necessary foresight to be trusted with leading the consolidation of ITV. The cost to Granada? £20m. A snip. Lets face it £20m barely buys you a footballer you have heard of these days.

webTitle: Marconi signals end of an era

fields.headline: Marconi signals end of an era
fields.standfirst: Changes at top mark industrial demise
fields.trailText: John Mayo, Marconi's finance director, was named yesterday as successor to chief executive Lord Simpson at the fast-growing telecoms and internet equipment maker, marking a decisive break with the group's industrial past.
fields.body:
John Mayo, Marconi's finance director, was named yesterday as successor to chief executive Lord Simpson at the fast-growing telecoms and internet equipment maker, marking a decisive break with the group's industrial past.

Lord [George] Simpson will step down in July next year after completing a five-year contract that will have netted him £10m in long-term incentive bonuses, inflated by Marconi's soaring share price.

Lord Simpson, a Labour peer, will be free to spend more time on his beloved golf courses and be working part-time as chairman of a handful of start-up new economy companies, as well as succeeding Sir Roger Hurn as Marconi's non-executive chairman.

The changes, announced yesterday by Sir Roger at Marconi's annual meeting, signal the end of the Simpson-Mayo combine which has transformed the old GEC, headed by Lord Weinstock for 33 years, from Britain's top heavy engineering group into a global player in the telecoms equipment sector.

Lord Simpson, an affable Scot, and the more cerebral Mr Mayo engineered a makeover of GEC through a series of acquisitions and disposals culminating in last year's lucrative £7bn sale of its defence arm to BAE Systems and the subsequent £4bn takeover of two US telecoms groups, Reltec and Fore.

The two became known, not always favourably, as deal-makers who had to prove they could run a multi-national group for the long term. But insiders said the pair complemented each other, with Lord Simpson underestimating his own financial acumen and Mr Mayo his own managerial flair.

Mr Mayo, who made his name at drugs group Zeneca, overseeing its demerger from ICI, had reportedly been considering job offers from rivals but yesterday's moves, said to have been prompted by Sir Roger, will give him the platform to compete with global players such as Nortel and even begin to challenge networking leaders such as Lucent Technologies.

The clean handling of the succession issue was applauded in the City, where the shares rose 45p to £10.70.

The management changes come a day after Marconi sealed a £2bn, five-year contract with BT to supply optical networking and high-performance SDH (synchronous digital hierarchy) equipment throughout Europe.

Lord Simpson, a former executive with what is now the car group Rover and Lucas, the auto and aerospace components maker, has been criticised for his absences from the House of Lords but used his network of contacts to help the government during the Rover debacle earlier this year.

Marconi is to build a new facility for its communications business in Coventry, creating 2,000 jobs in the west Midlands.

fields.headline: SmithKline profit surge surprises analysts
fields.trailText: SmithKline Beecham yesterday proved it was in robust health ahead of its merger with Glaxo Wellcome by notching up a 14% rise in half-year profits, helped by an outstanding performance from its new diabetes drug, Avandia.
fields.body:
SmithKline Beecham yesterday proved it was in robust health ahead of its merger with Glaxo Wellcome by notching up a 14% rise in half-year profits, helped by an outstanding performance from its new diabetes drug, Avandia.

The pharmaceutical group's figures beat City expectations but were tarnished by news of a month-long delay in completion of the merger, as America's federal trade commission scrutinises the transaction.

The new date for the tie-up to be completed is September 25. SmithKline's chief executive, Jean-Pierre Garnier, said: "Perhaps we were a little optimistic with our original timetable."

Excluding currency effects, interim profits rose 13% to £1.05bn.

SmithKline's top selling product, the antidepressant Paxil, increased its six-month sales by 15% to £705m, while antibiotic Augmentin and the group's vaccines portfolio grew significantly.

However, the star performer was Avandia, which generated revenue of £114m in the second quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of £90m. Mr Garnier said: "Avandia has been talked about as a potential blockbuster but nobody was really quite sure. After this quarter, it's obvious that it is really going places."

Avandia makes insulin work more effectively in regulating the body's sugar levels. Traditional diabetes treatments put extra strain on the already weak pancreas to make it produce more insulin.

Doctors have written more than 3m Avandia prescriptions in America and the product has just reached the market in Britain and Germany. Mr Garnier described it as "a very elegant way of helping mother nature do the right thing".

Mr Garnier, who will be chief executive of the combined Glaxo SmithKline, has come under fire for his potential pay package - he could be awarded share options worth up to 20 times his salary.

The French-born chief executive replied: "If you want Britain to be a place where world champions reside, you have to be pragmatic and see that we are playing on a ball park much bigger than just the UK."

fields.headline: Investors flock to Pharmagene
fields.trailText: Pharmagene, a specialist in testing drugs on discarded human tissue, has become the first biotechnology company to float on the stock exchange since early 1998, raising £37m in a placing of shares with institutions.
fields.body:
Pharmagene, a specialist in testing drugs on discarded human tissue, has become the first biotechnology company to float on the stock exchange since early 1998, raising £37m in a placing of shares with institutions.

The placing was more than four times oversubscribed and Pharmagene has attracted a market capitalisation of £142m.

The company, based near Cambridge, has thousands of samples of frozen human tissue, donated by people who have undergone operations. Its freezers contain samples from livers, hearts and lungs, bones, joints and brain tissue. The group generates revenue by testing drugs on these samples on behalf of other pharmaceuticals companies.

Chief executive Alistair Riddell said: "About 80% of our samples are from living patients. This is all material which has been removed during the normal course of surgical procedures."

Among Pharmagene's clients are SmithKline Beecham, Pfizer and Bayer. By carrying out contract research, the company generates funds to develop its own drugs; its lead product is for irritable bowel syndrome. Pharmagene also sells information from a library of research about the interaction between genes and drugs.

Dr Riddell said: "I'm delighted we've had this success with our flotation and broken the lull in British biotechnology."

The last biotech company to go public successfully on the main market was Oxford Glycosciences in May, 1998.

The shares were priced at 285p by UBS Warburg and trading begins on Monday.

webTitle: New wave Ellison aims to be hands-on Americas Cup tycoon

fields.headline: New wave Ellison aims to be hands-on Americas Cup tycoon
fields.trailText: Larry Ellison, the world's second-richest man, has decided to use part of his estimated $47bn wealth on AmericaOne (above), the yacht that lost the last Americas Cup.
fields.body:
Larry Ellison, the world's second-richest man, has decided to use part of his estimated $47bn wealth on AmericaOne (above), the yacht that lost the last Americas Cup.

Mr Ellison (right), founder and chief executive of the software company Oracle, is understood to want to trump his arch-rival, Bill Gates, by skippering the yacht in an attempt to win back the trophy. Mr Gates, co-founder of Microsoft, has been linked with plans to fund an American challenger.

The 150-year-old Americas Cup has long been of interest to the world's richest men but only recently attracted so many of the new economy's elite.

Seattle communications billionaire Craig McCaw has pledged $75m to win the cup in Auckland in 2003 through a One World Syndicate that will build two boats. He has hired eight New Zealanders, including the designer Laurie Davidson, to win back the trophy the antipodeans won in 1995 and February.

Mr Ellison, whose interests also include flying jet fighters, has signed veteran New Zealand yacht designer Bruce Farr and Chris Dickson, a New Zealand captain, to organise his challenge. But in a further twist the 55-year-old has decided to replace captain Paul Cayard, a 30-year sailing veteran, according to reports in the sports register. Mr Ellison, though an experienced yachtsman, has not sailed in the Americas Cup challenge before.

Mr Ellison appeared in a California court room last week to defend himself against allegations from a yachting broker that he failed to pay a commission fee for a $10m yacht. Michael Rafferty claims he is owed $700,000 after arranging the sale of the 192ft yacht October Rose. The yacht has five floors and an air-conditioned gymnasium.

Mr Ellison said in testimony that he was an innocent bystander.

webTitle: New travel threat against top Iraqis

fields.headline: New travel threat against top Iraqis
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: The US is pressing European countries to detain a core of senior Iraqi leaders, if any of them visit Europe, so they can be charged with war crimes.
fields.body:
The US is pressing European countries to detain a core of senior Iraqi leaders, if any of them visit Europe, so they can be charged with war crimes.

The national obstacles to such an appeal working were immediately apparent yesterday when Moscow welcomed Iraq's deputy prime minister, Tariq Aziz.

Russia, a member of the UN security council, refused to detain Mr Aziz. Sympathetic to Iraq and mindful of future business opportunities there, Russia has repeatedly called for the lifting of UN sanctions imposed against the country when it seized Kuwait in 1990.

A list of five senior members of the Iraqi regime has been sent to the US state department by Indict, an organisation funded by the US government but based in London. It is chaired by the Labour MP Ann Clwyd.

David Scheffer, the state department's general envoy for war crimes issues, has said the Indict list will be used to try to persuade the security council to set up a war crimes tribunal for Iraq, similar to those covering atrocities committed in the Balkans and Rwanda.

Among the suspects previously mentioned by Mr Scheffer are President Saddam Hussein's sons Qusay and Uday.

Next week is the 10th anniversary of Iraq's attempt to take over Kuwait, the act that launched the Gulf war. President Saddam's regime lives on, and the threat of trials - which has so far proved hollow - is aimed at frightening the inner circle from travelling.

Indict has compiled statements from many of President Saddam's victims and evidence from more than 5m Iraqi government papers detailing the regime's atrocities.

"We've got very interesting evidence which can stand up in any court of law," said Ms Clwyd, who heads the Commons all-party human rights group. "We've got signed witness statements, documentary evidence [and] video evidence, which we're told is copper-bottomed."

She added: "The Iraqis, a bit like the Khmer Rouge and the Nazis, kept meticulous details of the things they were doing."

Indict is convinced that it has enough evidence for charges to be laid under the Geneva convention and international conventions on torture.

One of the wanted Iraqis, Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri, vice-chairman of the ruling revolutionary command council, was almost arrested on a brief visit to Vienna a year ago, but was tipped off and left the country.

He went to Jordan earlier this month for medical treatment, but was asked to leave. The request created a diplomatic incident with Iraq, but Jordan later disclosed that it wanted him out of the country so it would not be caught in a squeeze between Iraq and an expected US request for General Douri's arrest.

webTitle: Bush plays safe with Cheney as running mate

fields.headline: Bush plays safe with Cheney as running mate
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush opted for safety yesterday when he named Dick Cheney, defence secretary in his father's 1989-93 administration, as his Republican vice-presidential running mate in this year's battle for the White House.
fields.body:
George W Bush opted for safety yesterday when he named Dick Cheney, defence secretary in his father's 1989-93 administration, as his Republican vice-presidential running mate in this year's battle for the White House.

Mr Bush telephoned Mr Cheney, 59, early yesterday to offer him the post. Mr Cheney accepted immediately, and the two made their first joint campaign appearance in Austin later in the day.

The Texas governor contacted several other senior Republicans whose names had been under consideration to tell them of his decision.

Mr Cheney's emergence as Mr Bush's No 2 on the Republican ticket was widely welcomed by party grandees, who praised his wealth of political experience and his appeal to both wings of the party, but there was an unmistakable tinge of anti-climax to the announcement of what Mr Bush had originally promised would be a "surprising" and "electrifying" choice.

Mr Bush originally asked Mr Cheney to head the process of selecting his running mate.

In the end, though, and to the private irritation of some of those he had intensively vetted, Mr Bush preferred to go for the man himself - a known quantity, an old family friend, a fellow Texas oil magnate and a well-known conservative.

As a former White House chief of staff and defence secretary, Mr Cheney may seem like a man from the past, but he has always been identified as someone with a big future.

He is best known internationally for the four years he spent as defence secretary in President George Bush's administration.

The central event of those years was the Gulf war, in which Mr Cheney presided over the biggest US military operation since the Vietnam war.

For a man with an uncompromising reputation as a military hawk, Mr Cheney's own Vietnam era record is less belligerent. As a student he secured five successive draft deferments.

He and his wife Lynne, his high-school sweetheart, have two adult daughters.

But Mr Cheney has long been seen as a political high-flyer. At 26, he was hired by the Nixon White House to work on anti-inflation policy. At 33, as a protege of another former defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, he became Gerald Ford's chief of staff.

After Mr Ford lost the White House, Mr Cheney went home to Wyoming - he is a graduate of the University of Wyoming - to run for Congress.

Though he suffered a mild heart attack during the campaign when he was only 37, he won easily, and served six terms.

The 1978 heart attack was the first of three he has suffered. The others followed in 1984 and 1988. All three attacks have been described as mild.

Mr Cheney had quadruple heart bypass surgery in 1988 before taking on the job of defence secretary. His doctors said this week that he was "up to a strenuous campaign".

Mr Cheney's abilities were quickly recognised. By the mid-1980s, the Almanac of American Politics tipped him as "clearly a major national politician" and a future party leader. He was "the natural candidate of moderates who viscerally prefer a Ford to a Reagan - and the record on issues to be the first choice of a great many Reaganites".

His strictly conservative voting record in Congress was being pored over by friend and foe alike yesterday, and is certain to become an issue in the campaign.

It includes absolute opposition to gun control. But perhaps the crucial votes as far as the November election is concerned are the ones that Mr Cheney cast against abortion, against the Equal Rights Act for women in 1983, and against the Head Start education programme for minorities.

Mr Cheney's profitable links with the Texas oil industry, which is also the source of the Bush family's wealth, will be another big issue in November, not least with environmentalists. Since 1995 he has been chief executive officer and chairman of the Halliburton Corporation, the Dallas-based multinational which is the world's largest supplier of construction, engineering and maintenance equipment and services to the oil industry.

He is understood to have earned about $2m (£1.3m) last year in salary, benefits and options at Halliburton.

Last month, profiting spectacularly from the electorally sensitive worldwide increase in oil prices, he sold about 100,000 of his Halliburton shares - approximately half his personal holding in the company, raising an estimated $5.1 million.

Another intensely sensitive aspect of the Halliburton connection, which could lead to conflict of interest allegations, is the company's stake in two American oil industry companies, Dresser-Rand and Ingersoll-Dresser Pump, which are involved in trying to reconstruct the Iraqi oil industry after the Gulf war.

Halliburton also has major interests in the Russian oil industry.

Where he stands:

Dick Cheney's voting record in Congress 1978-89

For

 Increasing Pentagon spending

 Aid to Nicaraguan contras

 Postponing new air pollution regulations

 American Indian rights

Against

 Equal Rights Act for women

 Head Start education programme

 Gun control

 Federal funding of abortion provision

fields.headline: Ignite goes for slow-burn strategy
fields.standfirst: BT offshoot's application services division waits until autumn for its big launch
fields.trailText: Sally Davis has shunned the limelight for the past 18 months since being lured to BT from the US. She left Bell Atlantic to become president of BT Ignite's application services division - renting of computer software to small businesses and large corporates.
fields.body:
Sally Davis has shunned the limelight for the past 18 months since being lured to BT from the US. She left Bell Atlantic to become president of BT Ignite's application services division - renting of computer software to small businesses and large corporates.

Under her stewardship the division has grown and now employs 550 staff and boasts blue chip clients such as Powergen and Boots.

Application services is an area that internet and telecommunications company see as a potential goldmine, as more companies seek to outsource their IT departments and rent software to save money.

Ms Davis has, however, waited until now to promote her division and a big launch for application services is planned in the autumn. A reminder that Cable & Wireless has already been making loud noises about its own move into internet application services providers immediately hits a sensitive spot with Ms Davis.

"It's a very hot market where everybody wants to be an ASP as it gives a fillip to your share price," she said. "It is a competitive market but there is also a lot of slide ware [presentations] and advertising, going by the number of companies announcing that they're doing something."

The application services market was worth $1bn (£660m) in 1999, according to telecoms consultants Ovum. It predicts that the application service market will grow to $44bn by 2004 and $136bn by 2006.

Davis says that she expects to be announcing several more blue chip contracts next week worth "multi-millions".

But BT already has a sizeable market to tap for its software packages, with 70,000 small-to- medium size companies already on the company's books and in need of an internet service provider. "We are finding it difficult to keep up with the interest level," said Ms Davis.

BT has agreements to provide software packages with joint venture partners including Microsoft, Commerce One, SAP and Lotus Development Corporation.

fields.headline: Hull phone firm disappoints
fields.trailText: Kingston Communications, the Hull-based telecoms group, disappointed investors yesterday as its first-quarter earnings fell more than one third to £6m.
fields.body:
Kingston Communications, the Hull-based telecoms group, disappointed investors yesterday as its first-quarter earnings fell more than one third to £6m.

Shares in the company shed 7% to 589p, with the fall exacerbated by the decision of Kingston's house broker, ABN Amro, to cut its revenue forecasts for Kingston for the year.

The decline in earnings was affected by management's decision to stop carrying low profit-margin traffic for other telecoms operators and to accelerate the national roll-out of its broadband network.

Turnover for the group grew 12.7% in the three months to £53.2m, with the rise being driven by Kingston's corporate arm, Torch.

Revenues for Torch leapt 28% to £18.7m, but it reported a loss in the quarter of £600,000. Its customer base grew by 24.6% in the period.

Steve Maine, chief executive of Kingston, said: "There is a lot of network expansion tak ing place which will provide the support for customer acquisition going through the rest of the year. Today's results reflect a slight shift in the acceleration of our investment in building our infrastructure."

Kingston is building a national network with Colt Telecom - the carriers are each laying their own lines but sharing the costs of the infrastructure.

Kingston has £106m in cash reserve and may seek some debt financing to fund the network roll-out.

Some analysts yesterday were more positive about the company's prospects.

Sean Johnstone, at SG Securities, said: "These results show positive revenue growth for all business with earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation margins slightly under pressure due to the strong growth and actions undertaken to enhance future profitability." SG has forecast Kingston will report revenues of £240m for the year and a profit of £32.2m.

fields.headline: Granada's play for Liverpool fans
fields.trailText: Granada Media yesterday made a high-profile first foray into the broadband world by announcing a joint venture with Liverpool football club that will allow fans to watch games and buy merchandising using a variety of technologies.
fields.body:
Granada Media yesterday made a high-profile first foray into the broadband world by announcing a joint venture with Liverpool football club that will allow fans to watch games and buy merchandising using a variety of technologies.

The new company, Liverpool FC Broadband, will be 50-50 owned by the two parties and could be floated on the stock market. Granada will invest £20m and technology expertise, while Liverpool will contribute its media and commercial rights for exclusive worldwide use across all digital platforms in perpetuity.

The globally available Liverpool FC portal will allow the club's estimated 10m fans to watch recordings of classic games through their mobile phones, buy replica kits, place bets and listen to live match commentaries in their own languages.

Steve Morrison, chief executive of Granada Media, said the partners wished to exploit foreign markets by offering a range of educational products, including star players providing language tuition.

"Liverpool has a huge following in China, a country where there are more people learning English than live in the USA," he said. "Imagine the attraction of a player like Michael Owen teaching English, even if to start with it is just words like 'goal'."

Football clubs and media companies have long talked about the potential rewards of combining to exploit their global fan bases through the internet and digital TV.

Manchester United and its commercial partner Vodafone are working on similar plans but Granada and Liverpool are the first to outline details of their offering, although it will be three or four years before the portal is fully developed.

Local distribution partners operating in interactive television and mobile phones will also be sought. Fans will be charged on either a subscription or pay-per-view basis.

Analysts welcomed the deal but suggested Liverpool could come to regret signing away such rights in perpetuity for what many believe is a relatively low figure of £20m. "When the word 'perpetuity' appears in any transaction for a rights holder it is very dangerous," said one independent media adviser to large sporting bodies. "The £20m may seem a lot of money now but who knows what those rights will be worth 10 years down the line?"

Mr Morrison insisted Liverpool was digging in for the long haul and needed to build broadband businesses and partnering with a media organisation it trusted. Last year Granada paid £22m for a 9.9% stake in Liverpool and the right to become the club's media rights agent. Analysts said football fans are one of the most loyal user groups and Granada could in effect buy 10m customers very cheaply. Merrill Lynch estimates each will be worth about $6,000 (£3,960).

webTitle: New Tory threat after gays defeat

fields.headline: New Tory threat after gays defeat
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: Senior Conservatives yesterday warned that the government will have to abandon more of its legislative programme in the wake of this week's defeat of attempts to repeal the section 28 ban on the "promotion" of homosexuality by local authorities.
fields.body:
Senior Conservatives yesterday warned that the government will have to abandon more of its legislative programme in the wake of this week's defeat of attempts to repeal the section 28 ban on the "promotion" of homosexuality by local authorities.

Downing Street confirmed that Tony Blair's cabinet will not engage in brinkmanship tactics with the Lords and is likely to abandon the repeal rather than risk losing the local government bill of which it was part. Some Labour peers now agree that one bill may have to be sacrificed if the next Queen's speech - the last before the election - is not to be delayed until late November.

After a crossbench coalition of peers voted 270 to 228 on Monday night to keep section 28 Mr Blair's spokesman called the action "a piece of prejudice" and said that nearly half of young gays experience homophobic bullying. Gay groups were also dismayed.

The executive director of Stonewall, Angela Mason, said: "Dropping the repeal of section 28 doesn't resolve the problem. The real issue here is how lesbians and gay men are treated in our society and the refusal of the Lords to pass any gay law reforms. It is disgraceful that an unelected body can ride roughshod over our civil rights."

Lord Strathclyde, William Hague's Lords leader, seized on Mr Blair's retreat to complain that peers face a "mountain of work" on seven bills when they return to Westminster in September - a month earlier than elected MPs. "We make no complaint about that. That is our duty. But equally, we will not be prepared to cut short scrutiny of bills because the government has tried to legislate too much. We will not be deterred from our duty by crude threats to remove more members of the house in a new Lords bill," he said.

The bills at stake include large and complex ones and one high-profile casualty could be the long-delayed freedom of information act. Others are the countryside bill; the Northern Ireland bill which changes the status of the RUC; the mode of trial bill, which restricts the right to trial by jury; the crime bill; the political parties bill; the transport bill; and the fur farming bill.

The FoI bill, widely criticised for being too weak, was tabled last year, but not debated in the Lords until April. No date has been fixed for the committee stage in the Lords where 190 amendments have been tabled. Those will be debated during the October "spillover" period before the Queen's speech opening parliament in November.

The growing legislative confusion was highlighted when peers refused to complete their work on the football (disorder) bill last night. A backbench demand for an extra day was passed despite frontbench Tory support for the government's timetable.

Dissident peers

Labour peers who voted to keep section 28: Lord Ahmed; Lord Cocks of Hartcliffe; Lord Dixon; Lord Donoughue; Lord Evans of Parkside; Lord Islwyn; Lord Lofthouse of Pontefract; Earl Longford; Lord Mason of Barnsley; Lord Mishcon; Lord Orme; Lord Patel of Blackburn; Lord Shore of Stepney; Lord Simon; Lord Stallard; Lord Stoddart of Swindon.
Tory peers who voted against Lady Young's amendment: Lord Garel-Jones; Lord Gilmour of Craigmillar; Lord St John of Fawsley; Lord Andrew Lloyd-Webber; Lord Norton of Louth.

fields.headline: Brief encounters
fields.standfirst: An employment tribunal lawyer writes ...
fields.trailText: An employment tribunal lawyer writes ...
fields.body:
I've been having a steady diet of smut lately - maybe it's a summer thing. Maybe tribunals list these cases for dozy days when evidence of reorganisations and redundancy policies would have them all slumbering.

There is also, of course, the F-factor: the get-a-female-barrister-to-represent-the-employer-in-the-sexual-harassment-case ploy. The idea (I think) is that the tribunal's sensibilities will be less offended if a woman suggests to the applicant that she's a nasty old slapper who liked to have a giggle with the lads etc than if a man put the same questions.

The smut in this week's case, to be fair, did seem pretty evenly distributed between the applicant and her boss. He admitted telling a joke that had a punchline involving him rubbing her breasts. But he said she had previously told an equally risqué joke that ended in her stroking his buttocks through his trousers. He admitted bringing in a video entitled They Came In Outer Space and suggesting she may like to watch it at home so they could discuss it over lunch. But she reciprocated with Pussies In Boots (no, I can't imagine either).

Cross-examination in cases like this is usually a pretty dull "Yes you did"/"No I didn't" affair, so I was a bit surprised when it went like this:

Me: "Then, Ms Applicant, you sent him a Valentine's card, which you will find photocopied on page 54 of the bundle of documents. And we can see there is a, um, reference to his genitals?"

Applicant: "Yes."

Me: "Oh. Then you left a vibrator on his desk some weeks later with the note we see on page 55?"

Applicant: "Yes."

Me: "Oh. Well, what is it about Mr Boss's jokes and remarks exactly that you are saying bothered you?"

Applicant: "I never said they did."

Me: "So why exactly are you bringing this case?"

Applicant: "Because my mate told me it was sex discrimination."

Applicant's solicitor has the air of a man who wishes he'd chucked a sickie. He has clearly failed to ask Applicant some key questions because the fact is, you can indulge in any old smut you like at work as long as nobody minds.

In the way of these things, Mr Boss manages to maintain his air of deep gloom even when the case is booted out. Now it's all come out OK, I think he's wishing he had a male barrister so he would feel less embarrassed about his tragic jokes and extensive collection of pornography. Like I care.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.body:
Well, the genie's out of the bottle (ho ho) for teen pop moppet Christina Aguilera, with a hitherto obscure New York publicist filing suit amid claims she acted as the singer's first manager and has since been swindled out of her rightful millions. In the suit, filed last week at Manhattan Supreme Court, Ruth Inniss (no, me neither) declared that, after first encountering Aguilera (then the host of The Mickey Mouse Show) and her mother Shelly Kearns back in '93, the latter agreed to let her manage her daughter once her contract with Disney was up. Which, of course, didn't happen - although according to Aguilera's current manager Steven Kurtz, that decision had less to do with industry skulduggery than, ah, Inniss making the entire thing up: "I've never met or heard of Ruth Inniss," he told reporters, "and I am not aware of any contributions this woman has ever had concerning Christina's career." Still, such minor details haven't stopped her going after $2m in punitive damages from Kearns and a further $5m from Kurtz.

Meanwhile, it's hello again Robert Downey Jr , the Court Circular veteran who's now managed to get himself sued while still serving time for various addled probation violations. According to a suit filed last Friday in Los Angeles Superior Court byproducers Richard Finney and Terence Michael, both Downey and his father - the equally idiosyncratic indie director Robert Downey Sr - are liable for breach of contract, having failed to come up with a feature they promised to Finney and Michael back in December '96 (in which junior would star, while pops took camera chores). Having been paid $250,000 to commence work, the Downeys then allegedly did little besides make "sporadic submissions of incomplete and unrelated pages", before attempting to fob their employers off with "continuous false assurances". Finney and Michael are now seeking at least $1m in compensation.

fields.headline: Revenge of the video pirates
fields.standfirst: Napster is pretty handy if you don't want to pay for your music. But the real holy grail for bedroom copyists is DVD. And the entertainment industry is running scared. Just how easy are they to rip off?  Dave Green  investigates
fields.trailText: Napster is pretty handy if you don't want to pay for your music. But the real holy grail for bedroom copyists is DVD. And the entertainment industry is running scared. Just how easy are they to rip off? Dave Green investigates
fields.body:
You can lend your friends the oddly watchable X-Men videotape you bought at the market for a fiver. You can "chip" your Playstation so that it plays illicit CD-ROM copies of games as well as the more professionally packaged originals. You can download hundreds of MP3s with Napster and burn them onto your own CDs. There comes a time in every casual entertainment pirate's life when you can sit back and say: "Yes, I am doing my bit to undermine the global commercialisation of culture, as well as getting some sort of pathetic payback for decades of 'two CDs for £22' overcharging."

But then you hear about the current US court case of the big movie studios against the hacker website 2600 over the alleged DVD-copying software, DeCSS, and you think "Maybe I could be doing more." On the surface the allegation seems to be that this one terrifying program, co-written by a 15-year-old Norwegian, transforms any modern PC into a supercharged DVD-pirating factory. Yes, no sooner has a vast consortium of technology companies and movie studios spent billions on coming up with a hot new format than, within months, you can be happily sitting at home, ripping it off on a home computer that cost you £500 from Dixons. Disappointingly, DeCSS doesn't do any such thing.

The program is not, in fact, designed to copy DVDs, nor does it make that task substantially easier. What it does is actually far more interesting.

DeCSS gets its name from CSS, the "Content Scrambling System" designed to make all DVD movies unreadable by anything other than a legitimate, authorised DVD player. This includes DVD drives for PCs, which come with special software to play DVDs on, say, Windows 98. There wasn't such a program for Linux, Windows' extraordinarily hardcore, do-it-yourself rival, so 15-year-old Norwegian Jon Johansen, along with some guys he knew on the internet, wrote their own, based on how they thought the Windows program did it.

So what DeCSS does is descramble the contents of DVD movies, just like any other DVD player, whether it lives inside your computer or under your TV. Of course once you'd DeCSS'd your movie on a PC, you could, in theory, save it to your hard drive (if you had the space), or upload it to the internet (if you had the time), or convert it to a different format, or burn it onto CDs. On the other hand, if you specifically wanted to use DeCSS to do this, you'd have to learn Linux first - which, to the average newcomer, makes Microsoft Windows look like the very pinnacle of convenience and user-friendliness.

And, without underestimating the joys of learning a whole new operating system, why bother? As the wise-beyond-his-years Johansen himself has pointed out, the technology to copy the unscrambled output from officially sanctioned PC DVD drives has been around for a while, in the form of Windows programs with unarguably unambiguous names like "DVD-rip". What's more, if you were serious about pirating DVDs, you wouldn't bother descrambling them first; you'd just take an original along to one of the dodgier pressing plants and ask them to run off a few thousand. As one website puts it (my paraphrasing), "DeCSS is like a translator for a book written in a foreign language - ie the DVD - and every DVD player has the same translator in it. If pirates want to make functional, fully-working copies of DVDs, they don't need the translator. They just need to photocopy the book."

Movie studios, unlike much of their output, aren't completely stupid. DeCSS may well have been targeted because of the vital difference between Linux and many other operating systems: Linux programmers always share their source code, so everyone else can see how their programs work. Embarrassingly, CSS seems unlikely to keep its secrets for long. It uses unusually weak encryption, in order to conform to strict US export regulations that forbid selling more complex technologies - ie anything that US intelligence couldn't crack in the blink of an eye - overseas, lest they fall into the hands of rogue nations (along with their treasured copies of The Matrix and Fight Club). Of course, Hollywood execs have long perpetuated the myth that the most advanced commercial ciphers can easily be cracked by a pizza-munching teenager who sits down, types a few lines, and pronounces: "Hang on - these files are encrypted. This could take a few minutes..." It's ironic that, when it came to protecting their own movies and entrenched commercial interests, they accidentally let life imitate art.

You can "chip" your Playstation so that it plays illicit CD-ROM copies of games as well as the more professionally packaged originals. You can download hundreds of MP3s with Napster and burn them onto your own CDs. There comes a time in every casual entertainment pirate's life when you can sit back and say: "Yes, I am doing my bit to undermine the global commercialisation of culture, as well as getting some sort of pathetic payback for decades of 'two CDs for £22' overcharging." fields.headline: Upstairs, downstairs
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Adam Sweeting
fields.trailText: Secret History/Glasgow Kiss/Rhona
fields.body:
The disembowelling of previously accepted versions of historical events is the stock-in-trade of Secret History (C4), but its film about the Battle of Britain, The Few, was a threadbare effort to dredge up some retroactive controversy. A thimble-full of evidence had been spun into a soufflé of supposition and innuendo, as a handful of elderly ex-fighter pilots were invited to air grievances they'd apparently been harbouring for 60 years.

Certainly it wasn't hard to believe that there was a divide between the officer class in the RAF, many of them moneyed former public schoolboys who'd enjoyed a privileged lifestyle in the services between the wars, and the working-class newcomers who joined up via the Volunteer Reserve as the war loomed. But the assumption that everyone unquestion ingly accepts the myth that the nation was saved from the Hun by squadrons of pipe-smoking Terry-Thomases was simply wrong, as if it had never previously occurred to anybody that flicks like The First Of The Few or Reach For The Sky were idealised propaganda. As long ago as 1969, the Battle Of Britain movie depicted rumblings of class friction behind the scenes.

A couple of unverifiable anecdotes from elderly ex-flyers was scarcely sufficient to support The Few's allegations that officers lived in comfort away from their airfields while the proletariat were left in tents to be bombed by the Luftwaffe, or that officers deliberately withheld crucial information about dogfighting tactics from their social inferiors so they could shoot down more Jerries and increase their own prestige. The show-trial technique was exposed in all its absurdity when a saloon-bar yarn by clubbable old duffer Anthony Bartley became the sole evidence for a sweeping accusation that RAF officers avoided tax and insurance checks on their "expensive" cars by bribing local policemen with drinks. The general level of plausibility was reflected in the archive clips, which kept showing the wrong types of aeroplane at the wrong moment and randomly mixed-up bits of feature film and newsreel.

With the TV schedules plummeting towards their traditional mid-summer nadir, it can only be through some kind of clerical error that Glasgow Kiss (BBC1) hit the screen this week. It's witty. It's warm. Its characters flirt dangerously with cliché, but it's quite touching nonetheless.

The story so far: Cara Rossi, firm-jawed financial analyst, is sent back to her native Glasgow by her untrustworthy London boss to oversee her company's buy-out of the ailing Evening Post newspaper. Working as a football reporter for this scrappy-looking rag is Stuart Morrison, a sensitive single parent still trying to come to grips with the death of his wife two years earlier. Well before the end of episode one, Stuart and Cara had got off with each other, which left you wondering how writer Stephen Greenhorn is going to spin out the remaining instalments.

Where Glasgow Kiss scores is in focusing on dialogue and the interplay of characters, rather than trying to concoct fantastic scenarios never before experienced by any person, living or dead (Border Café, this means you). "Nice bloke meets tough career woman who really only wants to be loved" would hardly amount to a proposal to set the pulse racing, but Greenhorn has squeezed in some telling detail about the forlorn plight of the single romance-seeker and the boozy lives of Glaswegian newspaper folk (the Evening Post looks like Fleet Street 20 years ago), while Sharon Small and Iain Glen tackle the lead roles with sympathy and understatement.

Rhona Cameron's new sitcom, Rhona (BBC2), risks instant turn-off with its jokey fake-American title sequence in which Cameron frolics idiotically among London's best-known landmarks, but the piece itself shows glimmers of promise. It revolves around the central trio of Rhona and her friends Lisa and Geoff, who, like all good sitcom characters, have nothing better to do than sit around contemplating the smouldering wreckage of their love-lives. Rhona can't make her mother understand that she's gay, while Lisa entertains outlandish fantasies about Doug, her therapist. The scene about vomiting in the movies was gratingly over-long, but elsewhere there was some welcome acidity in Cameron's writing.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.body:
Funds criticise Vodafone

An influential group of local authority pension funds has resolved to vote against Vodafone AirTouch's controversial pay policy, following the group's decision to award £20m in one-off bonuses to senior executives.

The Local Authority Pension Fund Forum, which has assets of £35bn, is estimated to own between 1% and 2% of Vodafone AirTouch's shares. Its members include big councils such as West Yorkshire, West Midlands and Greater Manchester.

The forum is furious at rewards being paid to directors for the completion of Vodafone's takeover of German rival Mannesmann. The biggest payment is to chief executive Chris Gent, who stands to get £5m in cash, with £5m of shares to follow in 2002.

A3XX bolsters Airbus fortunes

Airbus is on course to capture half the world's commercial aircraft market over the coming years after yesterday announcing a spate of multi-billion orders, including one for five more of its planned A3XX super-jumbos.

Its biggest order, for 87 planes, comprising the five A3XXs, 62 A320s and 20 A330-200 wide-bodied jets, came from International Lease Finance and is worth $7.5bn (£4.9bn). It brought to $14.5bn the orders it has announced at the Farnborough Air Show, including a dozen A330-200s for British Midland to enter the long-haul market.

Arch-rival Boeing, now restored to profitability, brought its total to $13.3bn, including a $1bn deal with Emirates, which on Monday became the first airline to confirm orders for the Airbus super-jumbo. The Dubai-based airline is taking six Boeing long-range 777-300s.

RTL checks in at £16.5bn

RTL, the television business formed by the merger of assets from media groups Pearson, Bertlesmann and Audiofina, will join the London stock market today with a capitalisation of £16.5bn. RTL will not immediately join the FTSE 100 index because only 11% of the company will be in free float - inclusion on the market needs at least 15% - but that is expected to change when RTL issues new shares to make acquisitions.

BSkyB to turn off satellite

BSkyB is reportedly planning to switch off its analogue satellite signal in August 2001, almost a year and a half earlier than expected. The move, which the firm is expected to announce with its full-year results today, could save the company as much as £60m in transmission costs.

M&S adds two new directors

Marks & Spencer has strengthened its board by recruiting BSkyB's chief executive Tony Ball and Kevin Lomax, the chairman of financial software group Misys, as non-executive directors. A spokesman said the two men had experience in "new economy" industries, which would be useful for the future direction of M&S.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What off-licence employees watch on TV
fields.trailText: What off-licence employees watch on TV
fields.body:
Gerard Fence: "I like a lot of Sunday TV because that's a day off for me and I'm usually knackered. I watched that Badger programme and I actually thought it was really good - really had something going for it. Robson's in it, or Jerome - the girls like him though, don't they? I watch a lot of sport - looking forward to the cricket."

Peter Masson: "I like a lot of comedy and I like EastEnders - although there's never anyone who's drunk in the pub in any convincing way. We get types in here who can barely walk and I just laugh, I do. People ask, how can you stand working in a place where people are coming in drunk all the time, but I find it quite interesting. That's the thing, the TV isn't half as interesting as real life, that's what I think."

Fiona Kay: "The programme I liked was that stuff on Elizabeth, really good. I like history and discovering about different sides to things, what you never got taught at school, and I have a Tudor fascination. Henry VIII - there's a great book about him I want to get for my birthday, can't remember who by. My husband's got a thing about World War Two and he's always in the Imperial War Museum, which is a bit dodgy isn't it? Oh yeah, telly - the television programme I most hate? Emmerdale. Depressing."

Jerry Fellows: "I'm not sure I like anything at the moment. We sometimes put Minder on in the shop, that's now on, you see. Then we might go for a bit of Collector's Lot. It's very quiet in here sometimes, especially if it's bad weather, really. No one in till evening, or after the pub. I like that Alan Davies programme, that Many Splintered Thing. Popular you say? Yeah, it's funny, and it's true. That's why."

Paul Kneller: "I watch nothing but the radio, hahaha! I have that on in the shop, Radio Two or sometimes Four if I'm feeling intellectual. I watch the goldfish and I watch the kettle. Is that enough for you, heheheheh!"

Sin Pattenden spoke to employees of off-licences in Holloway, North London.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: All In The Mind/ Connect
fields.body:
A promised new deal for mental patients is Dr Raj Persaud's opening topic for the new season of All In The Mind (4.30pm, Radio 4). He talks to Professor Louis Appleby, recently appointed as the government's new mental health tsar. The professor is concerned that the current fragmentation of psychiatric services allows too many people to fall between the cracks. He wants to pull all the disparate strands together to offer a reliable round-the-clock service within the next year.

According to one London dealer, of any six paintings sold at auction one, such as the Van Gough copy, pictured, is almost certain to be a fake. As a recent court case demon strated, these forgeries are good enough to fool most "experts", so what safeguards can collectors hope for? In Connect (9.0pm, Radio 4) Quentin Cooper looks at the techniques being deployed.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Deadlier Than The Male/Night On Earth/Eagle's Wing/La Grande Bouffe
fields.body:
Deadlier Than The Male

(Ralph Thomas, 1967)

1pm, Carlton Cinema

Period-piece knock-off spy thriller from the brother of Carry On director Gerald, which social historians will marvel at for its white-male supremacist values and heavy undercurrent of sexual deviancy. It matches Bond on most counts - soundtrack (the Walker Brothers), glamour, storytelling, raunchiness and misogyny. The hero, Richard Johnson is drawn into a typically dastardly plot to overthrow the world which hinges heavily on an international bevy of supermodel assassins

Night On Earth

(Jim Jarmusch, 1991)

11.50pm, FilmFour

A night in the lives of five cab drivers and their passengers: much of human life is there. LA cabbie Wynona Ryder is first away, talking movies with casting agent Gena Rowlands; in New York, Rome, Paris and Helsinki other taxi-tales strange and sad are interwoven. A mellow, moving comedy from the maker of Ghost Dog: The Way of the Samurai.

Eagle's Wing

(Anthony Harvey, 1978)

1am, Carlton Cinema

An odd but excellent British excursion into western territory, with Martin Sheen's naive trapper and Sam Waterston's Kiowa brave in a protracted duel/chase for possession of a beautiful white horse. Think white, think Moby Dick and abstract entities; it's an idiosyncratic, obtuse vision of the west, though rich in character and filmed with a fine eye for landscape. Harvey Keitel is briefly involved.

La Grande Bouffe

(Marco Ferreri, 1973)

2.10am, FilmFour

This tale of outrageous self indulgence has the mad old Marquis De Sade much in mind, and earned Ferreri a certain notoriety for the extreme nature of the themes and content. Supposedly an allegory on the dangers of rampant consumerism, it follows the last days of four libertines who have vowed to eat and screw themselves to death, and attracted a heavyweight cast: Marcello Mastroianni, Philippe Noiret, Ugo Tognazzi and Michel Piccoli.

fields.headline: Insider trading crackdown
fields.standfirst: Market abuse investigation spreads to journalists and internet pundits
fields.trailText: A crackdown on insider dealing was promised yesterday by the financial services authority, the chief City watchdog, which plans to use its new powers to stamp out abuses by financial journalists and internet bulletin board speculators as well as tackling more traditional financial crimes.
fields.body:
A crackdown on insider dealing was promised yesterday by the financial services authority, the chief City watchdog, which plans to use its new powers to stamp out abuses by financial journalists and internet bulletin board speculators as well as tackling more traditional financial crimes.

Initially, journalists may be required to disclose in articles details of shares they own, as a result of pressure by the FSA for changes to the code of practice policed by the Press Complaints Committee.

Publishing its controversial and rewritten draft code on market abuse, the FSA said it intended to ask the the editors' code of practice committee to consider "greater and tighter disclosure of share dealings by journalists, both in terms of internal disclosures and in the articles they write".

The regulator insisted, however, that the move had not been prompted by a recent scandal at the Mirror newspaper, whose two City Slicker columnists were sacked for tipping shares they held.

For the first time the City watchdog, which will have unlimited powers to fine, publicly censure and demand restitution from offenders, set out detailed information on what it would regard as "market abuse". It laid out three categories: misuse of information, giving false or misleading impressions and market distortion.

From next year, the FSA will be able to capture anyone in its net, from the City firms and individuals it already regulates to authors on internet bulletin boards and ordinary "aunt Agatha" investors, it suspects of abusing markets.

Because it will no longer have to take complicated cases through the criminal courts, the FSA expects to handle "additional cases" of such market abuse, although the serious fraud office and Department of Trade and Industry will continue to deal with the most complex cases.

In the case of newspapers, while journalists will fall under the scope of the FSA's new and wider powers to punish so-called market abuse, the regulator believes problems surrounding journalists owning share which they are recommending to readers is best dealt with by the newspaper industry itself. The regulator described the draft code - its second attempt, two years after protests greeted its first draft - as "most of the important and innovative aspects" of the new regime which will come into effect next year when the FSA is officially created.

"It is not without its controversial elements but the key message is that market abuse will not be tolerated in the UK," said Gay Wisbey, director of markets and exchanges at the FSA.

To determine whether market abuse has been committed, the FSA intends to use a "regular user" test, equivalent to the man or woman on the Clapham omnibus indicator used in the courts, to gauge acceptable practice.

The new powers of the FSA to tackle market abuse have led to concerns that it concentrates too much power in the hands of one body. The SFO, which prosecutes complicated financial crimes, is particularly alarmed.

Financial journalists at the Guardian follow a strict policy of disclosure whereby all shareholdings and other financial interests which might give rise to a conflict are noted in a register of interests.

The regulator insisted, however, that the move had not been prompted by a recent scandal at the Mirror newspaper, whose two City Slicker columnists were sacked for tipping shares they held. For the first time the City watchdog, which will have unlimited powers to fine, publicly censure and demand restitution from offenders, set out detailed information on what it would regard as "market abuse". It laid out three categories: misuse of information, giving false or misleading impressions and market distortion. From next year, the FSA will be able to capture anyone in its net, from the City firms and individuals it already regulates to authors on internet bulletin boards and ordinary "aunt Agatha" investors, it suspects of abusing markets. Because it will no longer have to take complicated cases through the criminal courts, the FSA expects to handle "additional cases" of such market abuse, although the serious fraud office and Department of Trade and Industry will continue to deal with the most complex cases. In the case of newspapers, while journalists will fall under the scope of the FSA's new and wider powers to punish so-called market abuse, the regulator believes problems surrounding journalists owning share which they are recommending to readers is best dealt with by the newspaper industry itself. The regulator described the draft code - its second attempt, two years after protests greeted its first draft - as "most of the important and innovative aspects" of the new regime which will come into effect next year when the FSA is officially created. "It is not without its controversial elements but the key message is that market abuse will not be tolerated in the UK," said Gay Wisbey, director of markets and exchanges at the FSA. To determine whether market abuse has been committed, the FSA intends to use a "regular user" test, equivalent to the man or woman on the Clapham omnibus indicator used in the courts, to gauge acceptable practice. The new powers of the FSA to tackle market abuse have led to concerns that it concentrates too much power in the hands of one body. The SFO, which prosecutes complicated financial crimes, is particularly alarmed. Financial journalists at the Guardian follow a strict policy of disclosure whereby all shareholdings and other financial interests which might give rise to a conflict are noted in a register of interests.

fields.headline: Holiday is not an option
fields.standfirst: They say everyone has a novel in them.  Walter Mosley, explains how to get it out
fields.trailText: They say everyone has a novel in them. Walter Mosley, explains how to get it out.
fields.body:
If you want to be a writer, you have to write every day. The consistency, the monotony, the certainty, all vagaries and passions are covered by this daily occurrence. You don't go to a well once but daily. You don't skip a child's breakfast or forget to wake up in the morning. Sleep comes to you each day, and so does the muse. She comes softly and quietly, behind your left ear or in a corner of the next room. Her words are whispers, her ideas shifting renditions of possibilities that have not been resolved, though they have occurred a thousand times in your mind. She, or it, is a collection of memories not exactly your own.

These reminiscences surface in dreams or out of abstract notions brought on by excitement, failures and hopes that you experience continually. These ideas have no physical form. They are smoky concepts liable to disappear at the slightest disturbance. An alarm clock or a ringing telephone will dispel a new character; answering the call will erase a chapter from the world.

Our most precious ability, the knack of creation, is also our most fleeting resource. What might be fades in the world of necessity. How can I create when I have to go to work, cook my dinner, remember what I did wrong to the people who have stopped calling? And even if I do find a moment here and there - a weekend away in the mountains, say - how can I say everything I need to say before the world comes crashing back with all of its sirens and shouts and television shows?

"I know I have a novel in me," I often hear people say. "But how can I get it out?" The answer, always, is every day.

The dream of the writer, of any artist, is a fickle and amorphous thing. One evening you're remembering a homeless man, dressed in clothes that smelled like cheese rinds, whom you once stood next to on a street corner in New York. Your memory becomes a reverie, and in this daydream you ask him where he's from. With a thick accent he tells you that he was born in Hungary, that he was a freedom fighter, but that now, here in the US, his freedom has deteriorated into the poverty of the streets. You write down a few sentences in your journal and sigh. This exhalation is not exhaustion but anticipation at the prospect of a wonderful tale exposing a notion that you still only partly understand.

A day goes by. Another passes. At the end of the next week you find yourself in the same chair, at the same hour when you wrote about the homeless man previously. You open the journal to see what you'd written. You remember everything perfectly, but the life has somehow drained out of it. The words have no art to them; you no longer remember the smell. The idea seems weak, it has dissipated, like smoke.

This is the first important lesson that the writer must learn. Writing a novel is gathering smoke. It's an excursion into the ether of ideas. There's no time to waste. You must work with that idea as well as you can, jotting down notes and dialogue. The first day the dream you gathered will linger, but it won't last long. You have to tend to your flimsy vapours. You have to brush them, reshape them, breathe into them and gather more.

It doesn't matter what time of day you work, but you have to work every day because creation, like life, is always slipping away from you. There's no time limit in which you have to write. One day you might read over what you've done and think about it. You pick up the pencil or turn on the computer, but no new words come. That's fine. Sometimes you can't go further. Correct a misspelling, reread a perplexing paragraph, and then let it go. You have re-entered the dream of the work, and that's enough to keep the story alive for another 24 hours. The next day you might write for hours; there's no way to tell. The goal is not a number of words or hours spent writing. All you need to do is to keep your heart and mind open to the work.

Nothing we create is art at first. It's simply a collection of notions that may never be understood. Returning every day thickens the atmosphere. Images appear. Connections are made. But even these clearer notions will fade if you stay away more than a day. Reality fights against your dreams, it tries to deny creation. The world wants you to be someone known, someone with solid ideas, not blowing smoke. Given a day, reality will begin to scatter your notions; given two days, it will drive them off.

The act of writing is a kind of guerrilla warfare: there is no vacation. In actuality there is very little chance of victory. You are, you fear, like that homeless man, likely to be defeated by your fondest dreams. But then the next day comes, and the words are waiting. You pick up where you left off, in the cool and shifting mists of morning.

webTitle: London stock exchange merger questioned by small but influential brokers

fields.headline: Members question merger
fields.standfirst: Smaller, influential brokers seek clarification
fields.trailText: The London stock exchange faces a new assault on its controversial plans to merge with Frankfurt's Deutsche Börse from a consortium of small but influential member firms and institutions.
fields.body:
The London stock exchange faces a new assault on its controversial plans to merge with Frankfurt's Deutsche Börse from a consortium of small but influential member firms and institutions.

A consortium led by Brian Winterflood, head of Winterflood, the biggest market marker of small companies listed in London, yesterday demanded crisis talks with exhange chairman Don Cruickshank to clarify how the merger will affect trading in smaller company shares, particularly those on the alternative investment market.

The demands by the smaller brokers, which also include Bill Brown, director of AIM equities at fund manager Friends Ivory & Sime fund, Holdsworth Hunt, managing director of Peel Hunt, and Andy Stewart, chairman of Collins Stewart, come as the exchange escalates its charm offensive to win support for the merger.

These key participants remain undecided about the exchange's plans for the merger with its German rival which need to pass a 75% threshold. Mr Winterflood said: "It's a clarification exercise. We need more detail on the merger. The retail market for smaller company shares makes up the majority of daily turnover in London. It's the oil that greases the wheel."

The stock exchange said yesterday that it would reassure Mr Winterflood that it would keep investing and step up investment in AIM once the merger had taken place.

"It's absolutely clear that we treat AIM as a very important part [of the exchange]," Martin Wheatley, head of business development at the exchange said. Quashing speculation that the smaller brokers might try to buy out AIM, Mr Wheatley said: "It's part of the London stock exchange. Brian [Winterflood] is an important part of the market and we want him to feel comfortable."

Mr Winterflood said the consortium was worried about the lack of detail in last week's document, which he described as being for "shareholders not for participants".
