webTitle: Art feature: Matt Damon and Ben Affleck want an unknown to write their new movie.

fields.headline: Good script hunting
fields.standfirst: Matt Damon and Ben Affleck want to make a new movie. And they are hoping to find some unknown to write it.  Geoffrey McNab reports
fields.trailText: Matt Damon and Ben Affleck want to make a new movie. And they are hoping to find some unknown to write it.
fields.body:
"That person from Montana, that cowboy who writes at night when he's off the range," Billy Campbell murmurs in his deep southern drawl. "That woman who wrote in college but hasn't picked it up because she is trying to be a mother to four children in Iowa. That person from South Carolina." He is describing the kind of contestants he hopes will enter Project Greenlight, a new competition to find the US's best unknown film-maker.

No, Campbell insists, this is not a stunt to unearth yet another brat in the Tarantino mould. Cowboys, oldtimers and suburban moms have as much a chance of winning as goatee-bearded film-school wunderkinds. All they need to do is submit their screenplays to a special website (www.projectgreenlight.com) "If you win, we'll pay you to direct it," runs the ad. "We'll produce an HBO series covering it. And Miramax Films will release it."

Campbell, president of Miramax TV, is co-ordinating the entire shebang. "I have no idea how many screenplays we will receive," he reflects. "We estimate anywhere from 75,000 to 200,000." The rules are straightforward. The budget for the winning movie won't exceed $1 million. "So if someone sends Armageddon, that probably won't be chosen. And if your screenplay is called Pearl Harbor, it's pretty unlikely that will get selected either." Only Americans are allowed to enter. (Miramax plans to launch an international version of the competition next year.) You have to be a newcomer. Steven Spielberg is ineligible. So are Matt Damon and Ben Affleck, but buoyed up by their own experiences making Good Will Hunting for Miramax, they've agreed to executive-produce the winning movie anyway.

Rather than hire a small army of readers to winnow down the entrants, Campbell's idea is to have the entrants judge themselves. "Each contestant is electronically sent three scripts at random from other contestants," he explains. "They read them, critique them and fill in forms which are electronically mastered back into our system." The judges are hoping for constructive criticism, not spite-filled demolition jobs. "If you've actually trashed three other people, you are immediately thrown out of the competition. We're not only looking for writing ability, but your ability to analyse others."

Eventually a shortlist of 40 candidates will be drawn up. It's at this point that Harvey Weinstein (the formidable Miramax boss), Matt Damon and Ben Affleck enter the fray, and that the "fast- moving, verité-style" TV series begins shooting in earnest.

Campbell, a Harvard Business school graduate who helped develop such series as ER and Everybody Loves Raymond, promotes the competition with all the fervour of a Mark Twain-era mountebank selling hair tonic. No, it's not simply another of those marketing wheezes which Miramax is famous for. No, Matt and Ben aren't just along for the ride. The project is being organized to fit in with their busy schedules. ("This would not work if their participation was just nominal They've been to every pitch meeting we've had - they're completely hands-on guys.") No, the 13-part series isn't catering to the new fad for voyeuristic TV shows. "This is not Survivor or Big Brother," he insists. "We're not going to create games that pit people against one another." In the next breath, he adds that he has never been around a film or TV set where there haven't been "creative conflict and personality issues - so we won't have to manufacture any of that."

He acknowledges that the winner will have to be strong-willed and thick-skinned to stand up to Weinstein, who is notorious for making even established directors bend to his will. Miramax isn't just going to give an untested film-maker $1m and let him or her get on with it. There's the company brand name to be upheld. "We're spending the money and so of course we're going to have a say in what they're doing, our goal is to choose someone we like, trust and whose creative vision we admire, but also they have to be interested in collaboration."

As Living in Oblivion and The Blair Witch Project testify, US independent directors love to navel gaze - to make movies about making movies. Campbell argues that there is more to this than simple narcissism: getting a film greenlit really is a heroic endeavour. "We're going to give an inside, first-hand, bird's eye view of what it's like, from start to finish, for filmmakers to be given a million dollars to make something they feel so passionate about that they've probably been working on for years. Their trials and tribulations will make great human drama. It will be very real - it will be the way that it really happens, the good and the bad." The TV series, he claims, will appeal to anybody "who loves movies, loves underdogs and loves entrepreneurs". The idea is to follow the successful project all the way through pre-production and casting. The final episode, due to be broadcast in early 2002, will feature the film's premiere.

The British aren't eligible for the first Greenlight competition, but they already have a production prize of their own. Run by Pathé Pictures, open to anyone "with a dream and a word processor", this is now two years old. The first winner was Bernard Wright, an ex-RSC actor who had been scraping a living working in a photographic warehouse in Whitstable. His film, Frankie's Comeback, is in pre-production and will shoot in the spring of next year.

The Brits are generally suspicious of initiatives like the Pathé Prize or the Oscar Moore Foundation Prize. Such competitions may give contestants the illusion of being part of the glamorous, tightly knit world of the film industry. Whether they actually help expose new talent is another question. Are the prizes really needed? It's not as if screenwriters are in short supply. With British cinema awash in lottery cash, everybody seems to have an idea for a movie. "There's a lot of dross out there. Some 95% of scripts you can bin straight away because they really are from lunatics," says Nick Thomas, editor of film magazine Flicks. "I wouldn't have thought that producers and agents would really want to be encouraging more people to churn out the same stuff. Maybe they'll get some gem through it, but this is rather an inefficient way of finding them - anyone who has got an original idea and has got some talent ought to be rising up anyway."

François Ivernel, managing director of Pathé, defends the concept. "It's a big wide door for people who don't have the connection with industry. It's open to whoever has written a script and wants to send it. It's like having a very large net in the sea and catching all the fish. In normal development, the scripts go through a circuit - agents, relationships." Wright, too, is predictably upbeat. "I would just say to anyone who is thinking of sending a script either to the Pathé Prize or to the Miramax one, it does happen. Look at me. I had no track record, nothing. I was just an actor who'd given up acting and was working in a warehouse. I sent it (the screenplay) in and - lo and behold - it's being made."

fields.headline: Claude Sautet
fields.standfirst: Director who brought a discreet charm to his films of the French bourgeoisie
fields.trailText: Director Claude Sautet, who has died aged 76, demonstrated, in his discreetly charming manner, that even members of the French middle-classes are people and have their problems.
fields.body:
The French bourgeoisie, particularly the Parisian species, have seldom been treated with much sympathy on screen, whether by Claude Chabrol, who mocks the complacency of middle-class marriage and sees guilt, jealousy and crime seething under the surface, or by Luis Bunuel in his ironically titled, The Discreet Charm Of The Bourgeoisie. In contrast, director Claude Sautet, who has died aged 76, demonstrated, in his discreetly charming manner, that even members of the French middle-classes are people and have their problems.

The main focus of Sautet's intimate and well-crafted work is the way the characters treat each other within a close relationship. Hence the titles of some of his best films: César And Rosalie (1972), Vincent, François, Paul And The Others (1974), The Bad Son (1980) and Nelly And Monsieur Arnaud (1995). The subject of his first international success, Les Choses De La Vie (The Things Of Life, 1969) is the realisation by a dying architect (Michel Piccoli) that love for his wife, son and friends is more meaningful than the trappings of wealth.

Friendship was as important to Sautet's films as it was to him in life. That was why he tried to work with the same crew, including cinematographer Jean Boffety and composer Philippe Sarde, and actors such as Piccoli, Yves Montand and Romy Schneider - she made five films with Sautet, and her suicide left a deep impression on him.

Born in the Paris suburb of Montrouge, Sautet began his career as a social worker, having joined the Communist party after the liberation (he left in 1952). He was also a music critic for the leftwing magazine, Combat, from 1949 to 1950. Some of his films were constructed like musical compositions - variations on a theme, played by major and minor characters - and music itself (by Maurice Ravel) was the subject and metaphor for the relationships in Un Coeur En Hiver (A Heart In Winter, 1993).

In his mid-20s, Sautet studied at the newly-formed Institut des Hautes Etudes Cinematographiques (IDHEC), where he learnt all aspects of film-making. He then made a short film, Nous N'irons Plus En Bois (1951), worked as a writer on television series, and doctored a number of screenplays, the best being Georges Franju's Eyes Without A Face (1959), a poetic horror movie as distant from his own films as could be.

One of Sautet's first features, Classe Tous Risques (The Big Risk, 1960), was a gripping and unusual thriller starring Jean-Paul Belmondo, about secret agents during the Japanese invasion of China. Unfortunately, his directing career began at the same time as the French new wave, and his style was already considered passé. It did not help that some of his early output was superficial and bland.

However, it was as a not uncritical chronicler of the mores of the French bourgeoisie that Sautet made his name, most of the films being as pleasant, polite and polished as the man himself. They are also very French in that attractive, fashionable people prepare and eat a lot of attractive food, while grappling with life and love. Sometimes, as in The Bad Son, he dealt with ordinary people in ordinary settings.

The only time I met him was in a top restaurant in Lyon. Bertrand Tavernier had invited some of his favourite directors to his home town to celebrate the centenary of cinema. But after the second delicious course, he dragged some of his guests away to watch his latest picture.

Sautet, his priorities correct, stayed to finish the meal. Although an admirer of Billy Wilder and Woody Allen, he told me that he had always refused requests by Hollywood to remake some of his films, because "they are so specific".

fields.headline: Thea Porter
fields.standfirst: When middle eastern fashion came to London
fields.trailText: It is hard to imagine now, when clothes are paraded every season to switch us over to fashion's latest slant or borrowing, what it meant in the 1960s when Thea Porter, in her little Soho shop, brought the old, sensual Middle East to London.
fields.body:
It is hard to imagine now, when clothes are paraded every season to switch us over to fashion's latest slant or borrowing, what it meant in the 1960s when Thea Porter, in her little Soho shop, brought the old, sensual Middle East to London.

Porter, who has died from a lung infection aged 72, was a painter. She was born Dorothea Seale, the daughter of two Presbyterian missionaries in Syria, who later moved to Beirut. She was educated at the Lycée Française in Damascus, Fernhill Manor and London University's Royal Holloway College. Her brother is the journalist Patrick Seale, and their father, Morris Seale, wrote Koran And Bible (1978), among other books.

Thea married Bob Porter, from the British embassy in Beirut, in 1953. They divorced in 1967. She came to London in 1964 with her eight-year-old daughter Venetia, and first tried to make a living by interior decoration. She got a job at Elizabeth Eaton, but had to leave after a client warned Joy King (Eaton's real name) that Thea was recommending satin. This was the Arab taste that London had yet to see.

In 1966, she set up her own shop in Greek Street, Soho, selling huge cushions and French, Italian and Turkish fabrics. She imported some kaftans to cut up into cushions, but kaftans were suddenly in as themselves. She began to make them to her own designs from her furnishing fabrics, using old braid and trimmings. Thea Porter Decorations became Thea Porter Couture.

Rich, beautiful women soon found her. She designed her prints and embroideries herself, and had a signature fabric of lilies, which were also printed on wallpaper for her Bolton Street flat, off Piccadilly. Thea Porter clothes were always very sexy, like her. Her dresses and blouses in chiffon and other expensive soft fabrics speak directly to the senses. Anyone who has them is still wearing them, to admiration.

The beading, sequins and embroidery were often done in India, but the clothes breathed civilised high-living in hot capitals where France was the admired foreign power. They should have been very expensive. She adapted the Levantine feeling into a modern, artistic look; she decorated a bathroom wall with particles of mirror glass, an idea taken up by Andrew Logan, a sculptor friend who became the artist of mirror glass.

Princess Margaret, Baby Jane Holzer, Edna O'Brien, Mick and Bianca Jagger, Pete Townsend, Elizabeth Taylor, Pamela Lady Harlech, Veronique Peck (wife of Gregory), Lauren Bacall and Jutta Laing (wife of RD) wore Thea Porter clothes, and were her friends. She made journalist Christopher Ward a white bridegroom suit. She spotted talent before it had led to fame. She opened a shop in New York in 1968, and another in Paris. She liked to meet Andy Warhol when she was over there.

Friends loved brave, funny, naughty Thea, but the fashion press did not fully appreciate her importance, except for the Los Angeles Times's Mary Lou Luther, and Molly Parkin. In a great fashion period, those clothes brought freedom to young working people (short skirts, soft underwear) with bold seams, cut and collars. They said evenings and pleasure, almost decadence. Her customers got a painter's taste and ancient civilisations. Also, unfortunately, a lack of interest in marketing.

Thea loved and bought art. She knew Patrick Hughes, Hubert "Nibs" Dalwood and Michael Andrews, was a regular at Muriel Belcher's Colony Room, a favourite with Francis Bacon - and even Muriel's waspish successor, Ian Board. When her father met her Soho friends, he commented: "Publicans and sinners, Thea!"

Her dinner parties were magic-carpet, round a mirrored table in a mirrored alcove. The furniture was Turkish, inlaid with mother-of-pearl. The guests' bent heads were repeated forever up on the mirrored ceiling and down on the table, and, by some quirk, one bit of the table showed the street below, where taxis could be seen arriving.

Thea served middle eastern dishes from her kitchen on beautiful plates and, at the end, there was Turkish coffee with cardamom seeds. Several of her friends were Arabs or Byzantine scholars, or from British middle eastern families like the underwater archaeologist Honor Frost. Steeped in the Byzantine, she was un-devious and a pathological truth-teller.

She would be accompanied by a businessman, diplomat or painter; she was never without a man. When Peter Langan opened Langan's in the next street, it was a romance of two people each with an exceptional eye. One of Thea's collections was shown there.

She was small, with red hair until she died. She held her head up, like a pelican flying. She was like a pelican of legend in that she gave of her blood to her friends, always loyal and too generous. She wasn't a good businesswoman, and not all her men friends helped when brought into her business. It went into liquidation in 1981, but she started again a year later.

In 1994, she got a form of Alzheimer's. At first, she could still go out, and a stranger remembers her at a party handing out coloured gemstones from her bag saying: "Keep this as a souvenir of me, it will bring you luck." At a home in Queen's Gate Terrace, she had a large room with her pictures and mother-of-pearl furniture. She was, as usual, popular, and a new nurse, seeing her unable to talk, yet so loving, could not keep back tears. Thea adored her two little granddaughters, and would imagine that the elder, Emily, could fly and was on top of her wardrobe.

She loved all flowers and would go with a friend or two to Kew for a picnic. Having forgotten the glasses once, she suggested they drink the wine out of the avocado skins, which turned out to be possible and all right.

 Dorothea 'Thea' Noelle Naomi Porter, couturier, born December 24 1927; died July 24 2000

webTitle: Ex-Mirror man to be Cook's chief spokesman

fields.headline: Ex-Mirror man to be Cook's chief spokesman
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, is poised to reopen the controversy over the role of spin in Labour's governing style by appointing a former political editor of the Daily Mirror as his chief spokesman.
fields.byline: Ian Black in Brussels and Michael White
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, is poised to reopen the controversy over the role of spin in Labour's governing style by appointing a former political editor of the Daily Mirror as his chief spokesman.

John Williams, who succeeded Alastair Campbell when he left the Mirror to join Tony Blair's team in 1994, is deputy head of the Foreign Office's news department, where he was recruited after Mr Cook's bumpy first year in office.

With the return of his boss Kim Darroch to a diplomatic posting - as the FO's EU director - Mr Williams is set to become the first non-diplomat in the top job, it was unofficially confirmed last night.

FO insiders including, it is said, the permanent secretary, Sir John Kerr, advised against the appointment, arguing that while Mr Williams is adept at dealing with political correspondents, he lacks the experience to cover the range of issues that go with the job.

The appointment follows controversy over leaked memos, the apparent preoccupation of some ministers with spin, and the creeping politicisation of civil servants who help present the government's message to the media.

Led by Mr Campbell, a number of journalists, including three from the Labour-supporting Mirror, have joined the government's information service or the strategic communications unit, which plans long-term media strategy in No 10.

Unlike Mr Campbell and other explicitly political special advisers, Mr Williams was initially recruited via normal open appointment procedures, and this time other in-house candidates were interviewed by the FO's selection board.

The Treasury and Foreign Office were long alone in Whitehall in appointing high-flying officials to run their press offices, to broaden their experience before they returned to their former job.

One of John Major's press secretaries, Gus O'Donnell, went with the then chancellor to No 10, but now runs macroeconomic policy as the Treasury's No 3 official. His successor, Chris Meyer, is now Washington ambassador.

It is assumed by officials that when Mr Cook leaves the FO Mr Williams will leave too. With several information chiefs purged when Labour moved to beef up the Whitehall press operation in 1997, the pattern of press aides being attached to specific ministers appears to be growing, a move attacked by the Tories.

 Change of emphasis

Alastair Campbell (ex-Mirror) Tony Blair's official spokesman

John Williams (ex-Mirror) Currently number two at FO news department, to become Robin Cook's chief spokesman

David Bradshaw (ex-Mirror) Speech writing member of the No 10 strategic communications units

Phil Bassett (ex-Industrial editor, the Times) Member of the SCU

Sheree Dodd (ex-Mirror) Formerly at the NIO, now head of media relations at the DSS

Lance Price (ex-BBC) Director of communications, Labour HQ, Millbank

Phil Murphy (ex-Yorkshire Post and Press Association) Recently moved from Millbank to Downing Street press team

Sian Jarvis (ex-GMTV) Number two in media division at the Department of Health

fields.headline: Lord Butterfield
fields.standfirst: Pioneer whose brilliance and administrative flair advanced the diagnosis and treatment of diabetes
fields.trailText: With the death of Lord Butterfield of Stechford, at the age of 80, the diabetes community has lost a pioneering figure who opened new perspectives, set new standards and stimulated academic groups throughout the world.
fields.body:
With the death of Lord Butterfield of Stechford, at the age of 80, the diabetes community has lost a pioneering figure who opened new perspectives, set new standards and stimulated academic groups throughout the world.

When I joined his newly-formed department of experimental medicine at Guy's hospital in 1959, I found it refreshingly different. Though housed in the converted storage loft of the decrepit Hunts House - where, shamefully, patients were housed until the mid-1990s - it had a warmth and informality, combined with a sense of inquiry and inventiveness that reflected the character and philosophy of its chief, who was known to everybody, from laboratory assistant to consultant colleague, as John.

Some of this rejection of hierarchy he must have brought back from the United States, to which he had been evacuated during the second world war. His roots were in the Midlands; born in Solihull, he was educated at Solihull school and Exeter College, Oxford. He acquired his MD at Johns Hopkins University hospital, Baltimore, a source of pleasure and lasting friendships to him - and, unknowingly, also a cause of subsequent embarrassment.

Many years later, after experiencing some difficulty in getting a US visa, John was asked by the American consul whether he had attended a meeting in a Baltimore bookshop on "the role of trade unionism in the postwar world". He had only the vaguest memory of the event, and absolutely no knowledge that the venue had later been branded a "communist-front organisation". It took several years before he was given his unrestricted entry visa.

Back in Britain, John served with the Royal Army Medical Corps from 1947 to 1950, and was on the scientific staff of the Medical Research Council from 1946 to 1958. Returning to the US, he worked at the Medical College of Virginia, in Richmond, from 1950 to 1952, and earned an OBE in 1953 for research with Sir William Penney on the medical effects of the early British atomic bomb tests in the Monte Bello Islands. It was from John's work there, on the healing of burns, that unexpected observations of the effect of British anti-lewisite, an antidote to a poison gas, on glucose levels in the blood ignited his life-long interest in diabetes.

Returning to Guy's hospital and appointed professor of experimental medicine (or "experimental professor of medicine", as he liked to put it) in 1958, John became intrigued by new automated methods for continuous measurement of blood glucose. He gathered a dedicated team of young scientists and embarked on a decade of studies which exploited the human forearm preparation.

By inserting fine tubes into the artery and the vein, it was possible to measure how much glucose the muscles removed from the blood as it traversed the forearm, how this differed in diabetes, and the effect of insulin and anti-diabetic drugs taken by mouth or injected into the forearm artery. Some of us still bear the scars.

In 1962, John's broad interest in human populations, combined with his scientific flair, gave birth to the Bedford diabetes survey, in which I took great pleasure in being his first lieutenant. The department moved en masse to the Swan hotel, Bedford, where, with the assistance of the enterprising medical officer of health, the late Dr Clive Sharpe, the local Round Table, Boy Scouts, Women's Institute and moribund civil defence organisation, we screened the population for undiagnosed diabetes.

During an unforgettable weekend, urine samples were collected from the front doors of more than 20,000 adult inhabitants and tested for sugar by a production line of doctors, nurses, technicians and students.

We spent the next six weeks doing blood tests on all the positives, and, providentially, on a carefully constructed random sample of the population as a whole. History does not relate whether the health of Bedford took a turn for the better, or worse, but what was learnt from that operation had a decisive influence on the prevailing views of diabetes, and led to internationally-accepted diagnostic standards for the disease, which are still in use today.

Alongside an innovative stream of clinical research, John also maintained a world-class clinical diabetes unit, a dedicated general medical service and an excellent bedside clinical teaching programme. What with contributions to learned societies in Britain, and forays abroad to present the latest research findings, life was enormous fun - and an experience John went to great lengths to ensure that the most junior technician would share.

A major opportunity which he relished was provided by the creation of the Thamesmead new town, on the site of the old Woolwich Arsenal in south London. It was John's vision, while serving on the Woolwich/Erith new-town medical liaison committee from 1965 to 1971, that all the primary care services for this new population should be furnished from the department of community medicine and general practice of Guy's, and that it should become a major centre for multi-disciplinary student teaching and community-based research.

While some of this still operates today, the grand vision was never fully realised for a multitude of reasons, logistic, financial and organisational among them. The breadth of this far-seeing concept, and the enthusiasm it engendered, was a measure of John Butterfield.

Life changed when he was called on to exercise his considerable conciliatory skills as vice chancellor of Nottingham University from 1971 to 1975. Throughout his time there, he was also much involved with planning the extended clinical school of medicine at Cambridge University, where, from 1976 to 1987, he was regius professor of physic.

While maintaining his clinical interests and research contacts, the business of the school, the university and the mastership of Downing College, from 1978 to 1987, claimed more and more of his time. Knighted in 1978, and elevated to a life peerage in 1988, he yet retained his enthusiasms for the advancement of medical knowledge and research, serving on the House of Lords science and technology committee from 1987 to 1988, and on many educational and research bodies in Britain and internationally.

John's contributions to academia, to government health bodies, to advisory councils and research committees were restricted only by the physical limitations of geography and, latterly, health. He was always ready - perhaps too ready - to help.

I exploited this dreadfully, and one of my warmest memories was getting his generous help in arranging to use Downing College for a WHO seminar on the epidemiology and public health aspects of diabetes. We captured John for a couple of hours, and sat drinking beer in the college gardens on a warm summer evening, surrounded by young doctors from more than 30 countries, talking medicine, diabetes, politics and life.

For many of us, who owe him much for the opportunities he gave us, his passing is very personal, the loss of a cordial, ever supportive, colleague and friend. After the tragic death of his first wife Ann, whom he married in 1946, he married Isabel-Ann Foster Kennedy in 1950. She survives him, as does a son from his first marriage and two sons and a daughter from his second.

 William John Hughes Butterfield, Lord Butterfield of Stechford in the County of West Midlands, medical researcher, born March 28 1920; died July 22 2000

The department moved en masse to the Swan hotel, Bedford, where, with the assistance of the enterprising medical officer of health, the late Dr Clive Sharpe, the local Round Table, Boy Scouts, Women's Institute and moribund civil defence organisation, we screened the population for undiagnosed diabetes. During an unforgettable weekend, urine samples were collected from the front doors of more than 20,000 adult inhabitants and tested for sugar by a production line of doctors, nurses, technicians and students. We spent the next six weeks doing blood tests on all the positives, and, providentially, on a carefully constructed random sample of the population as a whole. History does not relate whether the health of Bedford took a turn for the better, or worse, but what was learnt from that operation had a decisive influence on the prevailing views of diabetes, and led to internationally-accepted diagnostic standards for the disease, which are still in use today. Alongside an innovative stream of clinical research, John also maintained a world-class clinical diabetes unit, a dedicated general medical service and an excellent bedside clinical teaching programme. What with contributions to learned societies in Britain, and forays abroad to present the latest research findings, life was enormous fun - and an experience John went to great lengths to ensure that the most junior technician would share. A major opportunity which he relished was provided by the creation of the Thamesmead new town, on the site of the old Woolwich Arsenal in south London. It was John's vision, while serving on the Woolwich/Erith new-town medical liaison committee from 1965 to 1971, that all the primary care services for this new population should be furnished from the department of community medicine and general practice of Guy's, and that it should become a major centre for multi-disciplinary student teaching and community-based research. While some of this still operates today, the grand vision was never fully realised for a multitude of reasons, logistic, financial and organisational among them. The breadth of this far-seeing concept, and the enthusiasm it engendered, was a measure of John Butterfield. Life changed when he was called on to exercise his considerable conciliatory skills as vice chancellor of Nottingham University from 1971 to 1975. Throughout his time there, he was also much involved with planning the extended clinical school of medicine at Cambridge University, where, from 1976 to 1987, he was regius professor of physic. While maintaining his clinical interests and research contacts, the business of the school, the university and the mastership of Downing College, from 1978 to 1987, claimed more and more of his time. Knighted in 1978, and elevated to a life peerage in 1988, he yet retained his enthusiasms for the advancement of medical knowledge and research, serving on the House of Lords science and technology committee from 1987 to 1988, and on many educational and research bodies in Britain and internationally. John's contributions to academia, to government health bodies, to advisory councils and research committees were restricted only by the physical limitations of geography and, latterly, health. He was always ready - perhaps too ready - to help. I exploited this dreadfully, and one of my warmest memories was getting his generous help in arranging to use Downing College for a WHO seminar on the epidemiology and public health aspects of diabetes. We captured John for a couple of hours, and sat drinking beer in the college gardens on a warm summer evening, surrounded by young doctors from more than 30 countries, talking medicine, diabetes, politics and life. For many of us, who owe him much for the opportunities he gave us, his passing is very personal, the loss of a cordial, ever supportive, colleague and friend. After the tragic death of his first wife Ann, whom he married in 1946, he married Isabel-Ann Foster Kennedy in 1950. She survives him, as does a son from his first marriage and two sons and a daughter from his second.  William John Hughes Butterfield, Lord Butterfield of Stechford in the County of West Midlands, medical researcher, born March 28 1920; died July 22 2000

fields.headline: Wal-Mart is our friend
fields.trailText: You are right to say that Wal-Mart has been disastrous for the small American shopkeeper (Leader, July 25). But the retailing giant is a hero among Americans of modest means.
fields.body:
You are right to say that Wal-Mart has been disastrous for the small American shopkeeper (Leader, July 25). But the retailing giant is a hero among Americans of modest means. In 1981, the prices I paid for socks, trousers, underwear, kitchenware and appliances were higher than those charged at Wal-Mart 19 years later. They were higher still if one adjusts for inflation.

But with the relative scarcity of land in Britain, can Wal-Mart be as successful as it has been here in the US? North America still has enormous tracts of open space, which the retailer has been able to buy for almost nothing. We will never see a Wal-Mart in Manhattan, since it cannot pay the rent or property tax and still charge its low prices.

If Wal-Mart is not allowed to locate on green spaces in Britain, it should instead buy up idle industrial sites. Eventually British consumers will see how severely they have been swindled all these years.
Andrew Hirsch
Bainbridge Island, Washington State, US
andrewhirsch@uswest.net

Your leader on supermarkets argues that "the OFT should be asking itself a serious question: why has it taken the arrival of an American corporation to bring about the competition it was supposed to engineer?".

I am not in the grocery business. It is for competitors to compete, and insofar as Wal-Mart is able to enter the market, it is a sign of competitive health. My business is looking after consumers and encouraging competition. To that end I referred the sector to the then Monopolies and Mergers Commission (now the Competition Commission) back in April 1999.
John S Bridgeman
Director general, Office of Fair Trading

fields.headline: No: 1685
fields.standfirst: Pret a Manger
fields.trailText: Pret a Manger
fields.body:
Mmm, I'm feeling bit peckish. How about a mozzarella sandwich with pine nuts and spinach, some vegetable crisps and a yoghurt?

Ah, we must be in Pret a Manger. Tell me a little bit more about this fine gourmet sarnie shop. So glad you asked. In 1986, university chums Julian Metcalfe and Sinclair Beauchamp got fed up with only having two choices for lunch - soggy sandwiches or three-course spreads. So the enterprising duo decided to find a happy medium and fill that gaping hole in the market.

And presumably many stomachs too. More than 25m annually, sating Pret a Manger's bank account with a healthy £90m a year.

And I hear that a certain royal personage adds some of her pennies to that impressive annual turnover? Yes. It appears that our own dear Queen is not averse to a posh sandwich or two at lunchtime, splashing out £1,000 a week from the royal coffers.

Do they do a venison and quail egg super club? No, but she makes do with coronation chicken.

Really? Not really. You will never find yourself standing next to the Queen in a queue. A van is discreetly dispatched daily from the Piccadilly branch with 150 sandwiches for Buck House, and the sandwiches are actually for the staff.

Not good enough for the Queen, perhaps, but surely Pret stuffs some other famous faces. Indeed. You could consult their monthly internal magazine which, apparently, devotes a page an issue to the famous people who have sampled Pret's delights. For those of you who don't have a subscription, Kate Moss, Ewan McGregor and Cilla Black have all chomped on some Pret a Manger vegetarian sushi or slurped a latte.

And how does Pret a Manger feel about its royal devotee? "We're obviously very proud that they've chosen Pret. We value the custom of Buckingham Palace as we value all our customers."

Do say: "Pret a Manger has brought pan-international cuisine to Britain's lunchtimes."

Don't say: "Actually, I fancy a chip buttie."

webTitle: It's anoraks off in the battle for electoral reform

fields.headline: It's anoraks off in the battle for electoral reform
fields.trailText: Hilary Wainwright's scepticism about New Labour's intentions on electoral reform is understandable (Silencing the left, July 24), but it is not correct to present this as a simple left-right issue.
fields.body:
Hilary Wainwright's scepticism about New Labour's intentions on electoral reform is understandable (Silencing the left, July 24), but it is not correct to present this as a simple left-right issue.

While many soft left and Blairite MPs (and Ken Livingstone) support a more proportional electoral system, most Labour MPs of both "old" right and left, along with most trade union bosses, are against. It is an enduring mystery why they support a system that means the inevitable return, sooner or later, of a majority Tory government, elected by a minority - but there it is.

Supporters of electoral reform in the Labour Party constitute a true broad church, and several surveys have shown that a majority of ordinary Labour members support greater proportionality. The true dividing line is between constitutional reformers who want to open up British politics and make it more pluralistic and representative, and constitutional conservatives who prefer to stick to the tired old certainties of Labour-Tory ding-dong.
Andy Roberts
London
andycivicin@gn.apc.org

Hilary Wainwright is right to argue that reform of our electoral system is vital. But to paint the recent developments on electoral reform as a rightwing New Labour conspiracy to stifle debate is extremely misleading.

At Labour's national policy forum in Exeter, the group attempting to ditch the promise of a referendum on electoral reform from the party's manifesto was an old Labour coalition of right-wing trade unionists and members of the leftwing Grassroots Alliance. Historically, much of the left has backed the winner-takes-all politics Wainwright abhors.

Pointing the finger at the centre-left is not the way to ensure a referendum on electoral reform takes place. Progressive politicians who believe in participatory democracy must work together to ensure it is held.
Laura Shepherd-Robinson
London
laurasrobinson@hotmail.com

Hilary Wainwright is right: electoral reform is "too important to leave to anoraks". But convincing MPs to vote to reform the system that elected them has been a historical stumbling block.

That is why Labour's promise in 1997 to set up an independent commission to devise a proportional alternative to put to the people in a referendum was such an important breakthrough.

The commission, chaired by Lord Jenkins, enabled reformers to move out of anorak territory to campaign for its proposal of AV-plus. And the referendum leaves the final decision on reform with the people, not MPs.

Wainwright argues that "there is still time to build up political pressure for a democratic electoral system". I agree. But that pressure should be put behind making the case for the Jenkins proposals, which remain the most likely route to reform.
Nina Temple
Director, Make Votes Count
nina.mvc@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Speaking up for equality
fields.trailText: Lady Young (Blair loses section 28 vote, July 25) claims to be "speaking up for children in opposing the repeal of section 28". Rubbish!
fields.body:
Lady Young (Blair loses section 28 vote, July 25) claims to be "speaking up for children in opposing the repeal of section 28". Rubbish! What about youngsters coming to terms with their own sexuality and realising that they are gay; who is speaking up for them? What about the large number of homophobic teenagers; how can their prejudice be effectively challenged when it is overtly reinforced by leading public figures?

As a teacher, I have no interest in "promoting" homosexuality but I do have a passionate commitment to providing access to equality of opportunity and to encouraging students to appreciate the diversity in a pluralist community. That is why section 28 must go - it is a human rights issue.
Rona Taylor
Kenilworth

So Lady Young and her supporters have persuaded the House of Lords that her fantasies about section 28 are the truth. We can be certain that the religious lobby in parliament will now be planning more tactics to retard progressive legislation.

First on the agenda is the EU directive offering protection from discrimination in employment. For the first time legal protection for gay people is being proposed - but, under pressure from Lady Young and the Christian Institute, the government has announced that it will attempt to exclude sexual orientation from this directive.

When is somebody in parliament going to stand up to this creeping legalisation of intolerance?
George Broadhead
Secretary, Gay and Lesbian Humanist Association

In the real world the struggle for acceptance of gays and lesbians continues on many fronts. Anglican bishops are clearly still divided, but back in 1984 the Unitarian General Assembly declared that the age of consent for homosexuals should be the same as for heterosexuals. For over 20 years we have been reaping the rich benefits of a ministry open to all regardless of sexual orientation. We can't understand what all the fuss is about.
Matthew F Smith
General Assembly of Unitarian and Free Christian Churches
ga@unitarian.org.uk

If anyone disagrees with Tony Blair's government then an opportunity to register that disagreement will be with us within two years. Whereas if I disagree with Lady Young and the other unelected and unaccountable peers, what can I do about it? Absolutely nothing.
Steve Norman
Edinburgh
norm1962@hotmail.com

Section 28 amounts to state-sanctified queer-bashing. Now is the time for Blair to lead from the front, to do what is morally right and socially just, and push through repeal before the general election.
Dr Brian Jones
Bradford
b.t.jones@bradford.ac.uk

I see that, unlike in Scotland, it looks as though it will be a couple of years at least before section 28 ceases to be law in England and Wales. Do you think that this might result in a pause for reflection by those Guardian columnists and correspondents who have been writing about the dark side of devolution revealed by the section 28/2A debate on this side of the border?
Bill Speirs
General secretary, Scottish TUC

One tactic in abolishing clause 28 that Tony Blair may wish to consider is renaming it clause 4. Past experience should tell him that this is a far luckier number when it comes to abolishing unwanted clauses.
Steve Saunders
Edgware, Middlesex

fields.headline: The joys of housework
fields.trailText: Yes, housework is pretty boring (G2, Read it and sweep, July 24), and as a natural slob, I'd love not to have to do it
fields.body:
Yes, housework is pretty boring (G2, Read it and sweep, July 24), and as a natural slob, I'd love not to have to do it. However, I have to disagree that it is without merit and I find it surprising that it hasn't been eulogised before now. The impact of it is certainly not the trivialisation of my thinking and it can be most cathartic.

"Doing the housework" is a time when one is physically occupied and the brain is free to be stimulated in other ways, whether by listening to thought-provoking radio or allowing the mind to wander. Let's face it, most of the time we are occupied in quite stultifyingly boring enterprises that require just enough brain power to clog the mind of original thought. If housework is a modern form of meditation for some women, great. You get mental relaxation and a clean mirror.

The difference between homemaking in previous decades and an urge to Hoover now is that we're choosing to dust rather than being relegated to it. I do, however, wonder what the world is coming to when all we have to think and read about is dissecting the meaning behind hoovering.
Catherine Brown
London
cathbrown13@hotmail.com

Joan Smith's assertion that men do not do their fair share of the housework is a fallacy. Our share is nil. The exception provided by the previous (male) owner of Ms Smith's home proves the point. Most men know that even the most admirable women have problems getting the creases of shirts and trousers right. So many of us keep an ironing board for instructional purposes.
Bob Sellwood
Hove, Sussex
bobbie@catzone.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Roadworks
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel (In praise of building a bypass, July 25) misses the point: upgrading A-roads and building bypasses is creating a new network of motorways and encouraging a further growth of road traffic.
fields.body:
Matthew Engel (In praise of building a bypass, July 25) misses the point: upgrading A-roads and building bypasses is creating a new network of motorways and encouraging a further growth of road traffic. As the traffic grows these improved roads will become inadequate, and noise and inconvenience will spread into the wider countryside.

The new bypasses will attract commercial development, leading to a decline of city centres and any prospect of an integrated transport system will become remote.
John Turley
Wrexham
turleyjt@netscapeonline.co.uk

 I cannot see how widening the A40 is going to solve juggernaut problems. What we have to do is wean ourselves off the need for juggernauts.
Robert Bracegirdle
Leicester
bobbracegirdle@sncv. freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Words of explanation
fields.trailText: A European commission spokesman (EU support hits new low, July 25) says "it would need a long time to explain" why there is so little support for the EU in the UK. It can be explained quite quickly: a largely lying media, public apathy, general ignorance.
fields.body:
A European commission spokesman (EU support hits new low, July 25) says "it would need a long time to explain" why there is so little support for the EU in the UK. It can be explained quite quickly: a largely lying media, public apathy, general ignorance - and the complacency of politicians like Keith Vaz, minister for Europe, whose reported remarks were breathtaking in their blandness. If he and his New Labour colleagues don't start promoting Europe a great deal more effectively, they'll all be looking for jobs alongside Neil Kinnock after the next election.
FM Gillespie
Burwell, Cambridge
fulton@dial.drakken.com

Is it any surprise that the European country with the lowest level of support for the EU is that with the lowest level of educational attainment and the poorest level of linguistic skills?
Patrick Hayes
London
Patrick.Hayes@skillswork.co.uk

For the record, I never approached Stowe school t see if they would like a bronze (Diary, July 25). The sculpturess Shenda Amery, who had been commissionede to do a bronze of myself by Stowe school, approached me. I told her that I was very sorry but I did not have the time to sit. however if Stowe school wanted one they could contact my sister Lily Brockway, who has already made one.
Richard Branson
London

The government has been quite prepared to go to court to silence newspapers over the cases of David Shayler and Tony Geraghty. When, however, the News of the World threatens to let loose havoc, it is curiously powerless to act. Why the difference? Is the government only concerned about the press when the press does what is right?
Justin Horton
Letchworth, Herts

webTitle: Newsreader Kirsty Young to host new quiz show

fields.headline: Newsreader Kirsty Young to host new quiz show
fields.trailText: Kirsty Young's successful appearance on a celebrity edition of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? has landed her a new job. The newscaster was named yesterday as presenter of a new game show from the company that produces the ITV hit.
fields.body:
Kirsty Young's successful appearance on a celebrity edition of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? has landed her a new job. The newscaster was named yesterday as presenter of a new game show from the company that produces the ITV hit.

She will present an interactive general knowledge show called The People Versus, offering contestants unlimited cash prizes.

Ms Young, who announced at the weekend that she is expecting her first child next spring, will record the programmes for showing on ITV later this year. She honed her quiz show credentials in the spring, when she was narrowly defeated by Carol Vorderman in a fundraising celebrity edition of Millionaire.

The new show, produced by Celador, will allow contestants to choose their specialist subjects. Unlike its stablemate, it will give them the chance to win limitless sums, provided they keep answering questions, each worth £5,000, correctly.

The questions will be set not by the producers but by the viewers. If a contestant gives a wrong answer, his or her place will be taken in the next show by the viewer who set the question.

Ms Young, 31, whose trademark is a husky voice, has had a meteoric rise from Radio Scotland, through Channel Five to ITN. webTitle: Comment: Parliament's summer recess lasts until October. But don't grumble

fields.headline: Happy hols, and give us all a break
fields.standfirst:
Parliament's summer recess lasts until October. But don't grumble

Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Parliament's summer recess lasts until October. But don't grumble.
fields.body:
The current parliamentary term ends this Friday. MPs will be allowed to bring in games for the last day, and will be dropped off at the gate with all sorts of cards and presents for Mrs Speaker. Then they'll fly off for a few weeks lying in the sun to get away from all those months of lying in the Sun.

Gordon Brown has been down to WH Smiths to choose his summer reads. There's nothing better than stretching out on the beach with a copy of Whither Global Economics? Tony Blair is constantly setting himself tougher targets, so this summer he'll be fathering triplets and rescuing an entire team of drowning synchronised swimmers.

John Prescott will make do with a week at Blackpool but will be the only person at the fun fair to insist on two Dodgem cars. William Hague and Ffion will spend the summer on their own and far away from the crowds as they undertake another Meet the People Tour of Britain.

And for Conservative shadow ministers such as Gary Streeter and Edward Garnier, it will be a relief just to enjoy a few weeks out of the limelight. But then it's straight back to work as MPs return to Westminster at the end of the summer on... er, October 23.

It has been suggested that when the rest of us take a fortnight off, 14 weeks might be considered a little excessive. Obviously our politicians won't spend all their holidays staying in luxury hotels and drinking too much; there are the party conferences to fit in as well. But it's hard to sympathise with successive governments complaining that they cannot bring in all the measures they would like due to a lack of parliamentary time, when one quarter of the year is used up with the summer holidays alone. The government remind me of those students who used to get up at two o'clock in the afternoon and say: "When am I supposed to fit in writing this essay?"

The length of the summer recess is just one of the ridiculous anachronisms that alienates ordinary voters and increases cynicism and antipathy towards those who govern over us. Like the anti-social hours and the myriad obscure parliamentary conventions, it gives the impression that our politicians are from a different planet to the rest of us, which is unfair on the MPs, John Redwood excepted.

Many of these traditions go back hundreds of years; their origins lost in the mists of time, like Edward Heath's grudges. But that doesn't make them sacrosanct and so when this government was elected it established a "modernisation committee" to try to examine ways of bringing things forward a couple of centuries to somewhere in the mid-1800s.

Sadly parliamentary convention dictated that the modernisation committee was only allowed to meet once a year on Michaelmas Eve, and then only if the member for Old Sarum was wearing a hat. But they have managed to put an end to late-night sitting despite fierce Tory opposition; for some reason MPs like Ann Widdecombe and Michael Howard prefer to come out at night. And experimental morning sittings have now been tried and deemed a great success; the chamber was just as empty before lunch as it usually is the rest to the time.

Another improvement has been Prime Minister's Questions. For no better reason than tradition members could only put the PM on the spot with a supplementary question, so they always had to precede their interrogation with an enquiry about his engagements that day. This convention was done away with to prevent Tony Blair finally losing patience in the way that any ordinary member of the pubic would. "Are you completely deaf or what? You are the sixth bloody person in a row to ask me my engagements for the day; why don't you try listening for a change, you stupid, cloth-eared bastard?"

But the problem is that the modernisation of parliament has only been nibbling at the edges. Instead of coming back in late October, the MPs should never come back at all. In place of a parliament in Westminster, the MPs should meet in cyberspace; we should have a virtual House of Commons to represent our virtual democracy. Like a video conference call, debates could be carried out without MPs ever having to leave their constituencies. It would be the internet equivalent of a late-night radio phone in, though the quality of debates would probably not be quite that liberal and sophisticated.

Of course parliament will never radically change its ways, because the mystique and conventions are all part of a protective shield. The day that we understand everything that is being said will be the day that we realise that the policies don't make any sense either. So nod and smile when politicians say that parliament has to close for three months. The truth is we allow our politicians to have such long holidays for the same reason that we put our senile old relatives into homes. It's not for their benefit, it's just to give the rest of us a break.

fields.headline: Wriggling off the hook
fields.standfirst:
The concluding part of our series on the decline and rebirth of Russian science unearths fresh hope for the research establishment in the shape of a pollution-cleansing worm and a new use for the humble aerosol
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The concluding part of our series on the decline and rebirth of Russian science unearths fresh hope for the research establishment in the shape of a pollution-cleansing worm and a new use for the humble aerosol
fields.body:
In the dank basement of a decrepit academic institute in the village of Bolshevik, a grey provincial sprawl 100 miles from Moscow, Genady Zharikov is cultivating worms. Blue plastic washing-up bowls have been converted into breeding farms for 10 different varieties.

Dr Zharikov has skinny, pale worms that feed on manure and a darker, fatter breed which eats paper shreds torn from Soviet scientific journals. But it is the small, deep-red coloured hybrid that he is most proud of.

The technique he has developed for cleaning industrially poisoned soil using these worms has been hailed as an international breakthrough in environmental science.

His successes, and those of the institute where he works, are an inspiring example of the tentative rebirth of Russian scientific achievement after the dark years of scant funding and shattered morale.

A biochemist by training, Dr Zharikov used to work in the notorious Obolensk Institute of Applied Microbiology - the heart of Russia's germ warfare programme. As international suspicion of the institute's activities grew and Russia's defence industry was severely cut, the institute's work was severely restricted in the early 90s and hundreds of highly qualified weapons scientists faced unemployment.

Some went to work in banks, others to trade goods in the local market, but one enterprising group formed a collective and set up its own institute from the ashes of the defence project.

With no government funding, they looked for private contracts and grants. The International Science and Technology Centre, set up after the Soviet Union collapsed to "prevent experts in weapons of mass destruction from defecting to rogue states and passing on their knowledge", readily provided support.

Dr Zharikov adapted his talents to soil cleansing, focusing on PCB pollution. One of the world's most poisonous industrial compounds, produced globally in large amounts before scientists realised how dangerous they were, PCBs are carcinogenic and cause birth defects and infertility.

Dr Zharikov identified naturally occurring micro-organisms which swiftly degrade the contaminants. The specially bred earthworms will eat the micro-organisms and leave the earth dramatically cleaner.

This ingeniously simple method of speeding up the natural process of soil self-purification has caused excitement in Europe and the institute is already receiving orders for the process from abroad.

Delighted with his achievement in straitened times, Dr Zharikov is optimistic about the future of Russian science.

"It has been a difficult time, but for those who persisted, the worst years are over," he said. For the first time since the early 90s, no scientists took to the streets last year to complain about delayed salary payments and funding cuts.

A pragmatic, forward-looking sect of Russian academics insists that nostalgia for a Soviet scientific golden age is wholly misplaced, arguing that the free flow of government money during that era encouraged wasteful and unnecessary research.

Vladimir Malyukh, a software entrepreneur and former nuclear engineer, explained: "We had too great an emphasis on pure science. We had a huge amount of knowledge, but we didn't know how to apply it.

"Again and again you can see the results of this - we were the first country in space, but we still have no technology now for satellite television.

"Politicians were more interested in show results - to prove to the world what the Soviet Union was capable of - not in results that could be used by the population."

The Soviet Union's spaceships, military aerospace technology and atomic weaponry all matched or surpassed world standards. But the televisions and fridges built for its huge population were riddled with faults. The harsher new environment of a consumer society is beginning, slowly, to remove this imbalance.

Along the corridor, Konstantin Soloviev, 67, a former weapons engineer and aerosols specialist who worked with anthrax, plagues and other highly infectious diseases in the Obolensk institute, is another proponent of Russia's new scientific climate.

Recently he has converted his skills to developing ways of administering flu, whooping cough, measle and other vaccines using aerosols as a swifter, less painful method than injections. His research, presented at international science conferences, has been hailed as ground-breaking.

He stresses the value of the freedom in which scientists in the post-Soviet era are able to work. "We used to work in a completely closed environment - a military style regime - where we were forbidden to reveal the results of our work to anyone except a select group of government officials.

"There was a constant sense that our lives were being monitored and that our work was being watched. Now we can read international journals and discuss developments with colleagues abroad. The greater openness we have now is essential to the development of science."

The optimism of these academic entrepreneurs is in stark contrast to the bleak picture painted by scientists in Russia's older institutes. But even the most despondent of the academic elite refuse to believe that the painful era they have endured has comprehensively destroyed the country's scientific potential. Time has been wasted, talent lost and institutes closed, but the work continues.

An increasingly international climate, with grants provided from abroad and scientists from all countries collaborating on projects, has helped compensate for the shrunken resources in Russia. Moreover, the rhetoric of the new president, Vladimir Putin, focusing on the recreation of Russia as a world power, has succeeded in awakening the hopes of the country's impoverished academics.

The research centre's director, Professor Roman Borovick, is dismissive of colleagues who lament the disappearance of high level state funding.

"The Soviet Union simply had too many scientists. A lot of them were doing pointless work," he said.

"I believe scientists can and should make money."

webTitle: Aids patients used as debt collectors

fields.headline: Aids patients used as debt collectors
fields.trailText: People with Aids are being hired to work as debt collectors in Taiwan, in an attempt to exploit widespread fear of the disease in order to force clients to pay up.
fields.body:
People with Aids are being hired to work as debt collectors in Taiwan, in an attempt to exploit widespread fear of the disease in order to force clients to pay up.

The decision highlights the extent of popular prejudice and ignorance about HIV/Aids throughout much of Asia. Many people in Taiwan still believe that it can be caught from toilet seats or by social contact.

"Hopefully the Aids patients would bring about pressure on the debtors," said Tung Nien-tai, head of the Tsaisheng Credit Service, who acknowledged that HIV/Aids is not passed on easily.

Under the deal, struck on Monday with Chi Chia-wei, head of a halfway house for HIV and Aids patients, collectors would be paid 3,000 Taiwan dollars (£64) a day to visit debtors and urge them to pay up.

Mr Chi, whose group will also receive 50,000 Taiwan dollars as part of the agreement, denied pandering to prejudice.

"These patients need the job, and the loan agency needs clever new methods to get back the money," he said. "It's a proper business, and he did not ask the patients to bite the debtors to make them pay."

But campaigners condemned the agreement as a setback to their struggle to educate the public about the disease, on an island where many people with HIV are refused medical care.

"We can't understand how someone can exploit them and yet try to legitimise the act by pretending to create job opportunities for them," HIV/Aids worker Tang Fu-kuo said.

Foreigners with HIV/Aids are invariably expelled from Taiwan, and former American basketball star Earvin "Magic Johnson" was denied entry in 1995 after being diagnosed HIV positive.

Numerous other instances of discrimination have been documented, including one case of a nurse shaking awake an Aids patient at midnight in order to ask him if he regretted being gay.

Such prejudice mirrors the situation in many other parts of Asia, with people with HIV expelled from schools and health clubs even in relatively progressive Hong Kong.

Taiwan's government has so far resisted calls for legislation to protect the rights of Aids patients. And health officials said nothing could be done about the debt collection plan, unless the employees used needles to intimidate clients into paying.

Nor does Mr Tung show any sign of regret at the controversy he has stirred up.

Mr Chi quoted the loan agent as saying his next step would be to hire unemployed prostitutes to carry out similar work, since debtors might prefer to pay up rather than risk being associated with the women.

webTitle: Splitting heirs is all the rage

fields.headline: Splitting heirs is all the rage
fields.standfirst: Ikea's patriarch provides the latest example of father insisting that he knows best
fields.trailText: In feudal times, which son was to inherit a monarch's realm was not much of a worry, because the laws of hereditary succession meant it would be the eldest. But the move from aristocracy to meritocracy has created a new set of problems for businesses which remain, despite the march of history, personal fiefdoms.
fields.body:
In feudal times, which son was to inherit a monarch's realm was not much of a worry, because the laws of hereditary succession meant it would be the eldest. But the move from aristocracy to meritocracy has created a new set of problems for businesses which remain, despite the march of history, personal fiefdoms.

The furniture group Ikea and its upmarket sidekick Habitat have become the battleground for just such a struggle. Control has been split between three sons of the ultimate owner, Ingvar Kamprad. They must battle it out to prove who should inherit the estimated £20bn family fortune.

According to their exacting father, the Kamprad offspring, Peter, 35, Jonas, 33, and Mathias, 30, have different strengths and weaknesses. "I admire my three sons. They're very clever. But I don't think any of them is capable of running the company, at least not yet,"the 74-year-old patriarch told business magazine Forbes.

Serving Swedish food

Mr Kamprad started life as a carpenter's apprentice in Sweden before building up his successful furniture business. His thriftiness is legendary. He flies economy class, shops endlessly for bargains and typically wears an open-neck denim shirt rather than suit and tie.

He claims this is the way to motivate staff and keep close to his customers. Mr Kamprad has plenty of both. Ikea employs 55,000 people worldwide and has sales of $8.5bn. Britain, where it arrived in 1987, has been one of its particular successes.

It was not always so. Early stores such as the one in Warrington struggled to make an impact. But innovations such as children's play areas and onsite restaurants serving Swedish food finally brought people to the blue and yellow warehouses. Cheap prices helped, too.

Now Ikea has 10 stores and 5,000 staff in Britain with a turnover of £750m. About 50,000 Londoners are likely to pass through its Brent Park premises on the North Circular Road on any weekend.

Ikea plans to open a further 20 stores over the next 10 years in areas such as Glasgow, Southampton and Wales.

Habitat was bought by Mr Kamprad in 1992 from Sir Terence Conran but it now runs 39 stores with 1,700 staff and last year had sales of €180m (£112.5m) from stores such as the one on the Kings Road in London's fashionable Chelsea.

The Kamprad succession story is certainly not unique. The television soap opera Dallas survived for years on the drama of JR and his brother Bobby fighting to take over Ewing Oil from their father and then surviving mother.

In the real world, there has been much speculation and attention about the future leadership of the Murdoch empire.

The Australian-born media magnate's daughter, Elisabeth, has just quit News Corporation's British television subsidiary, BSkyB, where she was head of programming, to work outside the family business. Mr Murdoch's eldest child was passed over for the chief executive's post at BSkyB and many believe this was a symbol that the family business would eventually be handed over to one of her brothers.

In that context, Lachlan, head of News Corporation's US operations, is considered by many to be "first among equals".

But his younger brother, James, has attracted his father's attention because of his career grounding in internet-based media. James Murdoch has just been made head of Star Television, the key to his father's Asian TV ambitions, and is expected to be given a board job soon. Will he emerge the ultimate winner?

Rupert Murdoch, like Mr Kamprad, has said he believes none of his children has yet proved him - or herself a suitable successor: in the meantime he has side-stepped the issue by naming his deputy, Peter Chernin, as heir-apparent.

Another Scandinavian business that fits the Kamprad mould is the Fred Olsen group. At 71, Fred Olsen is Norway's richest man and controller of a global shipping and industrial empire that takes in Timex watches and the Harland & Wolff shipyard in Belfast.

He, too, lives in frugal fashion and has agonised over who should take over. His eldest child, Merete, has been passed over with power devolving to another daughter, Annette. Son Frederick was thought by many to be the eventual successor but he apparently blotted his copy book. Critics say his chances of preferment were damaged by a decision to crew one of Fred Olsen's cruise ships with low cost Filipinos. This led to the family ships being boycotted and a lot of unfavourable publicity for the Olsen name.

In the Grimms' fairy tale The Three Brothers, a man cannot decide which son should be left his only possession, a house. He sends the three out into the world to learn a trade with the one who does best claiming his inheritance.

Whoever wins the battle for Habitat and Ikea, there could still be a happy ending. In the Grimms' fairy tale the winner shares his inheritance with his other two brothers.

Now Ikea has 10 stores and 5,000 staff in Britain with a turnover of £750m. About 50,000 Londoners are likely to pass through its Brent Park premises on the North Circular Road on any weekend. Ikea plans to open a further 20 stores over the next 10 years in areas such as Glasgow, Southampton and Wales. Habitat was bought by Mr Kamprad in 1992 from Sir Terence Conran but it now runs 39 stores with 1,700 staff and last year had sales of €180m (£112.5m) from stores such as the one on the Kings Road in London's fashionable Chelsea. The Kamprad succession story is certainly not unique. The television soap opera Dallas survived for years on the drama of JR and his brother Bobby fighting to take over Ewing Oil from their father and then surviving mother. In the real world, there has been much speculation and attention about the future leadership of the Murdoch empire. The Australian-born media magnate's daughter, Elisabeth, has just quit News Corporation's British television subsidiary, BSkyB, where she was head of programming, to work outside the family business. Mr Murdoch's eldest child was passed over for the chief executive's post at BSkyB and many believe this was a symbol that the family business would eventually be handed over to one of her brothers. In that context, Lachlan, head of News Corporation's US operations, is considered by many to be "first among equals". But his younger brother, James, has attracted his father's attention because of his career grounding in internet-based media. James Murdoch has just been made head of Star Television, the key to his father's Asian TV ambitions, and is expected to be given a board job soon. Will he emerge the ultimate winner? Rupert Murdoch, like Mr Kamprad, has said he believes none of his children has yet proved him - or herself a suitable successor: in the meantime he has side-stepped the issue by naming his deputy, Peter Chernin, as heir-apparent. Another Scandinavian business that fits the Kamprad mould is the Fred Olsen group. At 71, Fred Olsen is Norway's richest man and controller of a global shipping and industrial empire that takes in Timex watches and the Harland & Wolff shipyard in Belfast. He, too, lives in frugal fashion and has agonised over who should take over. His eldest child, Merete, has been passed over with power devolving to another daughter, Annette. Son Frederick was thought by many to be the eventual successor but he apparently blotted his copy book. Critics say his chances of preferment were damaged by a decision to crew one of Fred Olsen's cruise ships with low cost Filipinos. This led to the family ships being boycotted and a lot of unfavourable publicity for the Olsen name. In the Grimms' fairy tale The Three Brothers, a man cannot decide which son should be left his only possession, a house. He sends the three out into the world to learn a trade with the one who does best claiming his inheritance. Whoever wins the battle for Habitat and Ikea, there could still be a happy ending. In the Grimms' fairy tale the winner shares his inheritance with his other two brothers.

webTitle: Business rallies to UN ethics scheme

fields.headline: Business rallies to UN ethics scheme
fields.trailText: A powerful coalition of big businesses, trade unions, and environmental and human rights groups meets in New York today to cement the Global Compact for ethical behaviour in business launched last year by Kofi Annan.
fields.body:
A powerful coalition of big businesses, trade unions, and environmental and human rights groups meets in New York today to cement the Global Compact for ethical behaviour in business launched last year by Kofi Annan.

The Global Compact has the potential to make bigger changes for the poor around the world than traditional aid programmes have ever done.

The UN secretary general has managed to hold together some unlikely allies in the Global Compact. Among the 40 or more big companies that have sent top executives to the meeting are Ericsson of Sweden, Tata of India, and multinationals such as BP, Shell, Nike, Rio Tinto, Volvo, Daimler-Chrysler, Unilever, Dupont, Bayer and British Telecom. Scandinavia, Britain, France and Germany have responded enthusiastically, far better than US business. Japan has not responded at all.

Their partners in New York include Amnesty, Transparency International, the Prince of Wales Forum on GM Foods, the heads of labour confederations, and various human rights organisations.

The first initiative is Ericsson's promise to 140 countries to ensure emergency communications in a disaster such as earthquake or flood.

Another, from Health InterNet Work, is the creation of 10,000 sites for telemedicine.

These and other projects will be posted on the Global Compact website.

"It's an exercise in transparency," says John Ruggie, a UN assistant secretary general and Mr Annan's special adviser on the Global Compact.

Link

www.unglobalcompact.org The Global Compact

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
OJ vows not to pay blood money

OJ Simpson yesterday vowed that he would never pay the $33.5m a civil jury awarded to the families of his wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and Ronald Goldman in 1997 for his responsibility in their deaths.

In a rare interview with NBC's Today programme he said he was innocent and would rather remain unemployed than pay the money. Reuters, Los Angeles

Sierra Leone rebels shut road

A key road to the interior of Sierra Leone from the capital, Freetown, has been closed to traffic because of rebel attacks, days after the UN said its forces had driven the soldiers away.

Hundreds of lorries were caught in traffic jams as they sought alternative routes into the capital yesterday. The incident began when the West Side Boys - soldiers who recently split from a government alliance - ambushed two buses on the road to Masiaka on Monday. Reuters, Freetown

Attack on guide to beating wives

Women's groups are trying to force a ban on a book written by one of Spain's foremost Islamic leaders because it sets out ways in which the faithful can beat their wives without leaving external marks.

They hope to force a ban on Women in Islam by Mohamed Kemal Mostafa, because it contravenes Spanish legislation which protects women from violence. Adela Gooch, Madrid

White farmers go on strike

At least 230 of Zimbabwe's white farmers downed tools and businessmen shut stores yesterday in the area around Karoi, 125 miles north-west of Harare, after Zanu-PF supporters and war veterans beat a white farmer.

Protesters submitted a list of demands to police, including the removal of the chief in Karoi, whom they accuse of fanning tensions. AP, Harare

webTitle: United News sells off Miller Freeman Europe

fields.headline: United News sells off Miller Freeman Europe
fields.standfirst: Reed Elsevier pays £360m
fields.trailText: United News & Media continued to clear the decks yesterday with the £360m sale of exhibitions and trade magazine publisher Miller Freeman Europe to Reed Elsevier.
fields.body:
United News & Media continued to clear the decks yesterday with the £360m sale of exhibitions and trade magazine publisher Miller Freeman Europe to Reed Elsevier.

The sale completes the divestment programme announced last November which had been intended to get United in shape for the now abandoned merger with rival ITV company Carlton Communications.

Its other disposals have included part of the Miller Freeman US business to Dutch publisher VNU last week, a US consumer publishing division and professional images group VCG. United has also sold its prime London headquarters on the South Bank and together the disposals have raised £1.3bn.

Lord Hollick, United's chief executive who at the end of last week put the company's ITV franchises on the auction block, reiterated his pledge to get the best for investors, whatever the outcome for his own ambitions.

"This programme of focusing on our core activities demonstrates United's commitment to putting its shareholders first," he said.

The sale of Miller Freeman's mainland European operations plus the sale of selected assets in the US has shrunk the business by roughly a third. It has hung on to the British exhibition and publishing division, Miller Freeman Asia and the hi-tech based publications in the US.

A United spokesman said the refocusing of the business remained as relevant without the Carlton deal as it had done when the merger was still on course. "The reason for doing this was to focus on markets that we could grow effectively," he said.

The agreement with Reed Elsevier, would make the Anglo-Dutch group the world's largest exhibitions group it said. Miller Freeman Europe organises 100 shows in France, Germany, Italy, Spain and Scandanavia from home decorating to food and drink and owns 50 trade magazines.

Shares in United fell back 35p to 955p as hopes of a counter bid for the media concern which also owns the Express newspaper titles continued to recede.

Negotiations with with rival ITV groups Carlton and Granada Media are understood to have been ongoing yesterday over the potential carving up of United's television assets.

Advisers to Lord Hollick have made it clear that he would prefer a bid for the entire group and it remains unclear what the future for United will be if the television assets alone are sold off.

webTitle: Reuters cashes in with move online

fields.headline: Reuters cashes in with move online
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Reuters, the news and information provider, said yesterday that its latter day conversion to the internet continued to gain momentum as it reported a 9% increase in revenues for the first half to £1.7bn.
fields.body:
Reuters, the news and information provider, said yesterday that its latter day conversion to the internet continued to gain momentum as it reported a 9% increase in revenues for the first half to £1.7bn.

Chief executive Peter Job outlined the company's intent to climb on board the internet in February and since then Reuters has embarked on a series of new ventures. Its strategy is to move the core business onto the web, open new retail markets and broadly accelerate its use of the internet.

The main driver for the growth in turnover was a 50% improvement in revenues at electronic broking division Instinet to £381m.

Group operating profits were 3% better at £285m for the first half before a £41m charge to pay for taking the core business online. That charge will be higher in the second half. The company said the flotation of its new media investment business the Greenhouse Fund and In stinet were still under consideration but added that it would not be rushed while market conditions remained uncertain. Shares in the company were marked up 46p to £13.04.

Paul Richards, media analyst at investment bank West LB Panmure, said the company was "firing on all cylinders.

"A few years ago Reuters was a big, sleepy giant with all the right content which it wasn't making the most of. It's now embracing the internet as a low cost distribution method and is gaining exponential momentum," he said.

Reuters also announced the development of a service with Tibco Software, data group Equant and Yahoo to help businesses build their own websites.

The Greenhouse Fund generated £42m from disposals during the half year and still had £243m of investments in a portfolio of 60 companies. A number of stock market flotations of companies in which the fund held a stake have taken place including Orchestream in Britain and Virage in the United States.
